debateinfo.title: FAMILY ASSISTANCE LEGISLATION AMENDMENT (ADJUSTMENT OF CERTAIN FTB CHILD RATES) BILL 2004

subdebate.1.para: Debate resumed from 18 November 2004, on motion by Ms Ley:

motion.para: That this bill be now read a second time.

talk.start.para: âI rise to speak on the bill on behalf of my colleague the member for Sydney, who is currently on maternity leave, and I do so with great pleasure. It is interesting that the bill that I will be speaking on is the Family Assistance Legislation Amendment (Adjustment of Certain FTB Child Rates) Bill 2004, obviously something of interest to all of those who have families.

speech.para: At the outset I can indicate that Labor do support the passage of this bill, but we do note that this bill has only been necessary to correct the flaws in the indexation provisions of the Family Assistance Act 1999 that arose as a result of changes made under the Family Assistance Legislation Amendment (More Help for FamiliesâIncreased Payments) Bill 2004, which introduced the $600 per child family tax benefit supplement. Labor said from the start that the government had either made a major blunder or sneakily changed the formula for calculating fortnightly family tax benefit A payments so that it could recover or claw back the value of the per child supplement over time. The Minister for Family and Community Services, Senator Patterson, and her former colleague Larry Anthony responded by claiming that the government was fully committed to maintaining the real value of the per child supplement over time. But neither Senator Patterson nor Mr Anthony ever addressed Labor's key charge that the government had deceived families by fiddling with the formula for the fortnightly FTBA payments when it introduced the per child supplement in the 2004 budget.

After two months of insisting that there was no problem, Senator Patterson belatedly conceded in August last year that she and Mr Anthony had botched the original legislation and that it needed to be changed yet again. So here we are. Senator Patterson then of course broke her promise to fix the problem before the federal election. The government finally introduced this bill into the House on 18 November, six months after it created the mess in the budget legislation. Debate on the bill was then delayed until this session, well after Senator Patterson's promise to correct the problem once and for all.

The bill itself, as members of the House might be able to tell, even from that brief history of it, is a technical bill. It seeks to adjust the indexation provisions of the Family Assistance Act 1999 so that the detrimental impact of changes made by the government as part of its 2004 More help for Families legislation is reversed. The bill amends the family tax benefit adjustment provisions in schedule 4 of the Family Assistance Act 1999 that apply in relation to the family tax benefit A under-13 and age 13-15 child rates. Under the new arrangements provided for in the bill if the FTBA under 13 child rate, as indexed by the consumer price index, is less than the amount worked out using the formula of the combined pensioner rate times 16.6 per centâwhere the combined pensioner rate refers to combined pensioner coupleâthen the FTBA under-13 rate is increased to the amount determined under the formula. The position is the same for the family tax benefit A age 13-15 child rate, except that the multiplier is 21.6 per cent. Collectively these tests are more simply known as the safety net benchmark provisions. These provisions had been introduced by previous Labor governments to ensure adequacy of fortnightly payments to Australian families. The arrangements provided for in this bill are the same as those which applied to FTB payments prior to the passage of the budget legislation last year. The bill does not make any changes to the future indexation arrangements for the supplementary FTB payment, which will continue to be adjusted by the CPI.

Since the per child supplement was introduced, Labor has pointed out that the effect of other changes made in that same legislation was that the supplementary payment would be fully recovered or clawed back by the government over time. This was because changes in the budget legislation to the formula for calculating fortnightly FTBA payments compromised the existing safety net benchmark and the value of the per child supplement would be eroded within a five- to seven-year period. This position was supported by the Australian Council of Social Service, which noted in its press release on 21 June 2004:

quote.para: ... the new indexation rules will see Family Tax Benefit rise more slowly than it would have under current rules. The value of the $600 increase will be washed away

speech.para: The safety net benchmarks which were introduced by Labor and carried over in the Family Assistance Act 1999 have not influenced FTB payments recently because those payments have been well above the benchmarks since the FTB system was introduced. However, this will change in the future when the benchmarks catch up with FTB fortnightly payments.

The effect will be that the fortnightly FTBA payments will then start to increase at a lower rate than would have been the case prior to the changes to the formula that were made in last year's budget legislation. Labor argued that, after five to seven years, the value of the foregone increase in FTBA payments would have been greater than the value of the supplementary payment to families. So the government would have clawed back the value of the supplementary payment by reducing the normal fortnightly payments. As I have said, despite denials at the time from Senator Patterson and former junior minister Larry Anthony, the changes made when the supplementary payment was introduced did alter the formulas used to calculate the benchmarks.

Under sections 6 and 7 of schedule 1 of the budget legislation, while 16.6 per cent or 21.6 per cent of the annualised combined partnered pension rate was still calculated, the result of that calculation was reduced by the FTB supplement. These new formulas therefore resulted in lower benchmarks. While the lower benchmarks would still increase in line with movements in male total average weekly earnings, they would take longer to rise to match the CPI indexed FTBA rate. It would only be at that time that the benchmarks started to influence the FTBA rate. So the new benchmarks, which are lower than before because the supplementary payment is deducted, would eventually produce lower rates of FTBA than the original benchmarks. Hence Labor's claim, supported by ACOSS, that the effective value of the $600 supplement would be eroded over time by this detrimental change to the formula for calculating fortnightly FTBA payments. Obviously Australian families were going to miss out.

Eventually, on 4 August 2004, two months after the flaw in her legislation was exposed, Senator Patterson rather ungraciously conceded the need for legislative amendments to ensure the maintenance of the full value of the supplementary payment into the future. It has taken a further six months for the government to bring on the debate about this bill. It has only been through Labor's persistence that the government has belatedly acknowledged the need to make the changes contained in this billâand we are pleased that Australian families will reap the benefits of our persistence. However, as late as 17 November last year Senator Patterson was still criticising Labor for daring to find fault with the budget legislation, rather than owning up to her own failure to ensure that Australian families were not made worse off over the long term by the legislation.

Senator Patterson has continued to try and hide behind what she said was an unintentional change to the safety net benchmark provisions. She cannot bring herself to acknowledge the blunder that she alone has made. If the change really was unintentional, we are at a loss to understand why Senator Patterson took so long to admit that the provisions needed changing. Senator Patterson also criticises Labor for what she describes as `scaremongering' about the problem that she created through her own faulty legislation to introduce the supplementary FTB payment. But if Labor had not raised the problem, we would not be debating this bill today, because Senator Patterson would never have admitted to her mistakes and would never have sought to fix the problemâand Australian families would have been the losers. Senator Patterson should actually stand up in the Senate when this legislation is debated there and acknowledge that if Labor had not identified and exposed this blunder Australian families would have been the losers.

If the government had continued to ignore Labor's concerns then the value of the supplementary payment would have been washed away through the dodgy change to the formula for calculating fortnightly FTBA payments that Senator Patterson included in the budget legislation. Labor's main concern through this whole debate has been to ensure that Australian families who are eligible for the per child supplementary payment are not duped by the government once again. Consistent with the decision by Labor in government to introduce the safety net benchmarks in the first place, Labor now want to ensure that the integrity of the system is maintained, and that it is not undermined by mistakes or backdoor attempts to erode the value of other payments that are made to Australian families. This is why Labor are pleased to finally support the passage of this bill through the House of Representatives today. We hope that it gets quick passage through the Senate and that Australian families will be better off as a result. We note that now is the time for Senator Patterson to admit to her mistakes and move on for the future settling of appropriate payments to Australian families. I thank the House.

talk.start.para: âI rise to support the Family Assistance Legislation Amendment (Adjustment of Certain FTB Child Rates) Bill 2004. The purpose of this bill is to ensure that the real value of fortnightly payments of the family tax benefit part A is maintained in the future. This bill is essential in guaranteeing that the real impact of these payments to families is not lost, by ensuring that fortnightly payments of the family tax benefit part A will be indexed to either the CPI or a percentage of the combined pensioner couple rate. This government is dedicated to ensuring that families are better off under the Howard government and are not disadvantaged following the 2004 budget. With that aim in mind, this bill ensures that fortnightly rates of payment will be adjusted at the same time and for the same amount as would have occurred before the budget.

speech.para: As part of this government's budget initiatives, legislation was passed providing an additional ongoing supplement of $600 per child. My colleagues from across the floor have continually stated that this $600 increase would evaporate over time and would not provide any real benefit to families. I would like to take this opportunity to clarify what is obviously a misconception held by the opposition. At the time the legislation providing for the $600 supplement was passed, provision was included which ensured that the supplement would be indexed each year in accordance with increases in CPI. That legislation, like the bill I speak in support of today, was aimed at providing real and genuine support to families. Together they do so, by ensuring that the funding initiatives put in place by this government are not eroded by increases in the cost of living. Not only are families better off under the Howard government but, on average, Australian families now receive $7,000 in family tax benefit.

The successful passage of this bill provides a guarantee to Australian families that the real value of their family assistance will be maintained. I am heartened to see in the recent policy principles document released by the Labor Party that they are finally willing to recognise the significant benefit the $600 per child payment has provided to Australian families. I trust, therefore, that we will hear no further claims coming from the opposition that this payment and the benefit it provides to families is not a real one.

The cost of the amendments contained in this bill will be $25.9 million from 2006 to 2008. There is no doubt that funding initiatives like this are only possible because of the responsible economic management provided by the Howard government. This government has worked tirelessly to ensure that its strong economic and financial management provides genuine assistance to Australians who need it, while at the same time providing the best possible foundation for future generations of Australians. This bill is aimed directly at achieving both those vitally important goals by providing funding to families while aiming that funding directly at the children who are Australia's future. In conclusion, I am pleased to be able to support this bill and I commend this bill to the House.

talk.start.para: âThe Family Assistance Legislation Amendment (Adjustment of Certain FTB Child Rates) Bill 2004 that the government has before the House will be supported by the opposition. We have heard in this debate some excellent arguments on both sides of the House on this particular matter of health. We on this side of the House have a very long history of involvement in this particular area. Labor was the architect of the great universal public health scheme that gives every Australian, by right, access to quality health care in this country. Sadly, under conservative governments down through the eons the public health system has been run downâand the Howard government is no exception in that respect. Yes, we do see a place for private health insurance in the provision of health care for Australians, but it ought not to be at the expense of the public health system in this country.

speech.para: I will not speak for too long on this particular bill because many of the arguments that I would make in this debate have been covered by other speakers and no doubt will be covered by the member for Gorton when he enters the debate. But, suffice to say, on the issue of health care Labor has form both in government and in opposition. We have seen the chaos created in the past by conservative governments in power. On this occasion we do intend to support this particular measure, but I think the Australian electorate has it right: Labor in government and in opposition has always put the health of Australians front and square in the policies that it has put before them.

talk.start.para: âI thank the member for Corio for foreshadowing some of the comments I wish to make. It is true that we support the Family Assistance Legislation Amendment (Adjustment of Certain FTB Child Rates) Bill 2004, but of course this bill should not have had to happen. I think it is an example of law made on the run. As we know, the government, in its efforts to buy votes at the last election, decided to create some policy or law in an attempt to bribe Australian voters. There are all sorts of questions about the way in which we should dispense the contents of the public purse in order to look after people in need. Indeed, the whole area of family tax benefits is open to question as to the best way to do that. But I do not think it is the case that the government thought through clearly the implications of its initial act announced in the budget last year by the Treasurer.

speech.para: I am aware that the Treasurer was initially against the $600 payment and lost in cabinet. We are very well aware that he saw that it might be perceived as an attempt to buy votes at the next election. I also think we should be aware that the $600 bonus was indeed welcomed by households, because of course any money that provides relief to families in need will be welcomed by the community. There is no doubt that, because the money was announced in a rushed manner and because it was not foreseeable by the recipients of that $600 bonusâor, indeed, more than $600, depending upon how many children there were in each household that was eligible for the paymentâit came as a great surprise. I am very confident that it was welcomed by people in need, as I said.

But I do not think that is going to be the case with future payments, because what the government has effectively done is to foreshadow that you can now expect to receive $600, $1,200 or $1,800 at the end of the financial year. You will be able to calculate that sum and then plan for it. Compared with what has occurred to date, where most recipients received a sum of money which they had not planned for and therefore they welcomed itâthey had not spent it or factored it into their household budget, because it was not something that they knew about until the Treasurer announced it last yearâwe are now going to be in a situation where the families that are eligible for the payment will be factoring in the payment well in advance of receiving it.

The problem of reconciliation, however, is not resolved. That is the one thing we have to really be clear about. The issue of reconciling whether there is a surplus or debt for those recipients eligible for family tax benefits is not resolved by providing lump sums a year down the path. As we know, you have to calculate your own income 12 months in advance. If you are lucky enough to have calculated that sum of income for the household very well, you are not going to be in debt. But, as we know, approximately one-third of recipients of family tax benefits had some form of debt. Indeed, the average debt was in excess of $600.

It is true to say that, if you did not foresee $600 being received at the end of year and then you received it, it would be some relief. If you are going to be in debt in excess of $600, $600 or more is going to help relieve the amount of debt. However, as I say, the difference now, as opposed to last year, is that families now in receipt of such moneys will be calculating that into their budget. It says to me that we do not yet have a fix. We do not have an answer as to how to work out the reconciliation of one's income and eligible family tax benefit. That is the conundrum that most households find themselves in. Now, because they foresee the $600 or more in their household income, it seems to me that they will already be spending thatâor be happy to go further into debt because they will be in receipt of it. But that does not remove the fact that a huge proportion of families were in debt at the end of the financial year because of the system that we operate.

There is also a question of good public policy about providing lump sums. There is no doubt that for many households money amounting to $600 extra would be welcomed or that in some instances it would be the largest amount of money they would see in any given year. I understand why people would want to be in receipt of such sums. But, as decision makers, in dispensing the public purse, we have to consider whether the lump sum payment at the end of the year is the best way to look after children in this country, to provide for them and to assist in the provision of services for them. From looking at the policy and talking to families about the way they tend to budget in the household, the conclusion I have drawn is that it is not the best policy. It might be the best incentive to vote for the government that provides the money, but it is not the best policy for the country for looking after children. There is a whole debate to be had about the way in which the family tax benefit should be paid.

This bill is a cautionary bill. It was introduced into the House because the government was rushing its law. It was rushing its policy; it was forcing through a law; and in Senate estimates it found that it had a flawed act. It had to introduce this bill, which we support, in order to rectify the deficiencies in the preceding bill relating to this matter. We know that this is a bandaid to fix a problem. As I say, I do not think the initial bill fundamentally alters the problem of reconciliation that occurs in the system. I accept that we need to support this bill, but there would have been no need for it if there had been proper and decent consideration of the matters involved rather than rushing to pay out large sums of money before a federal election. If it were not for that, we would not have this bill. I say it is a cautionary bill because we know that very soon the government will have unfettered powers in two chambersâthe greatest level of power any Australian government has had since 1981âand therefore, I would say, a greater inclination to rush through legislation that is flawed.

We support this bill, notwithstanding the comments made by the minister, who said that we were just scaremongering. It was Labor that highlighted the flaws in the system last year. But we say this to the government: do not hurry if you want to make good law; indeed, listen to the critics and provide the capacity for this chamber and the Senate chamber, the chamber of review, to consider bills in this term. If the government fails to do that, we will find ourselves in the same position over and over againâthe position we find ourselves in this morning.

I wish to say a number of things on the broader question of family tax benefits and the way in which the government has responded, but I will not do that this morning. However, I do warn the government to reconsider its approach and to focus on the policy, not the politics. Then we might find ourselves in a better position all round.

talk.start.para: âThe Family Assistance Legislation Amendment (Adjustment of Certain FTB Child Rates) Bill 2004 could just as easily have been titled the `Honey, I stuffed it up (Adjustment of Certain FTB Child Rates) Bill 2004'. The government made an error in the announcements that were first made, and for some considerable time it denied the claims by Labor and the Australian Council of Social Service that over time its legislation would have the effect of clawing back the $600 payment per child. Only when it got over its indignation about any suggestion that Labor might have it right did the government examine this. It then realised that in fact it had made a bad error.

speech.para: As a consequence, we are debating this legislation today because it seeks to rectify that error. To put a monetary figure on the dimensions of the error, this legislation in 2007-08 involves extra expenditure of almost $25 million, which is not an insignificant amount. That is just the beginning of the impact of the error that the government made; that error would compound over time with the erosion of the benefit. So the government has finally admitted its mistake and here we are rectifying that mistake. I join with the member for Gorton who said that now that the government will be controlling the Senate from 1 July it should take note of its capacity to make errors such as this and not seek to rush legislation through. A temptation for ministers will be to try to get their legislation through the House and Senate very quickly and to not agree to Senate inquiries, which often have the beneficial impact of identifying unintended consequences of legislation.

Quite often, Labor approach those Senate inquiries with the objective of improving legislation, whether or not we fundamentally agree with it. The reality is that the government is elected and, if it is going to put legislation through the parliament, let us make sure it is the best possible legislation. Ministers could take note of the lesson that is provided in this legislationâthat is, rushing legislation through due to arrogance is going to end up in humiliation at some point, particularly after 1 July if legislation is rammed through the Senate and the minister has to sponsor the fixing up of errors in it, which no doubt he or she would want to deny until it became a statement of the bleeding obvious.

I point out that the $600 per child payment is one component of the $66 billion spending spree in which this government engaged to secure its re-election. It is astonishing that, at a time when the economy has been growing strongly and consumer spending has been growing at almost unprecedented rates, the government has seen fit to pour petrol on that consumer spending fire through increasing the call on the budget to the extent of that $66 billion. Only around $5 billion of it could be categorised as investment spending; the balance of $61 billion over four years best fits the description of consumption spending. It is precisely the wrong time for a government to be fuelling consumption when consumption is already going at such a cracking pace. That is why the Reserve Bank has finally belled the cat in its Statement on Monetary Policy released the day before yesterday, where it identifies very strong consumer confidence, which is close to record levels; very strong labour market conditions; and a range of other available information suggesting the economy was in strong condition through last year and is likely to have maintained a good pace of growth entering 2005.

There were some suggestions that the housing bubble was deflatingâthat is in fact true. But there are now some indications, as identified by the Reserve Bank, that perhaps that deflation has run its course. Page 3 of the Reserve Bank statement says:

quote.para: More recently, there have been some signs of prices and finance levelling out, or possibly rising.

speech.para: If Australia is confronted with that house price bubble re-inflating, given that it has not deflated by very much, we are in for very tricky and challenging times. But you would not know it, because the government, absolutely committed to its re-election rather than to good economic management, has added $66 billion to demand in Australia. We are in a situation where domestic demand is growing rapidly but exports are performing terribly. Imports are surging, which is associated with that domestic demand. We have the best terms of trade since 1972 but appalling performance in export volumes. In parliament yesterday the Minister for Trade said, `What is the problem? Exports are larger than they were a few years ago.' On the back of record terms of trade anyone could have achieved a growth in export values in nominal terms. But the minister was very keen to blame everything and everyone but himself and the government for the stagnation of export volumes, which mean that Australia has put in its worst export performance since the Second World War.

Why is this relevant to a debate on a $600 family payment? The answer is that the surge in consumer spending in this country and our terrible export performance are creating a large external imbalance. Trade deficits have now been going on for 37 consecutive months with no end in sight. The current account deficit, according to the Statement of Monetary Policy, is approaching 6.75 per cent, which the Reserve Bank itself identifies as a record. The Treasurer, who was asked about the current account deficit yesterday, is behaving like a character from The Life of Brianâalways look on the bright side of life! `What is the problem with a 6.75 per cent current account deficit?' Yesterday he was asked about his statement in 1995 that a six per cent current account deficit is unsustainable. He said that in unequivocal terms, not referring to the composition of the current account deficit or the extent to which it was associated with a budget deficit. He said flatly that a six per cent current account deficit is unsustainable. If a current account deficit of six per cent of GDP is unsustainable, why is a current account deficit of 6.75 per cent suddenly sustainable? The answer is that it is not. It is not sustainable.

In its country report on Australia late last year the IMF pointed to the growing current account deficit and began questioning its sustainability. Economic commentators in this country and, I fear, economists within the government bureaucracy, have overinterpreted the Pitchford thesis to regard it as saying that the current account deficit does not matter. That is in fact not the case. The current account deficit can matter, especially when it is financing rampant consumer spending. We have had 37 successive trade deficits and record current account deficits, which are adding to Australia's foreign debt.

When the present Treasurer and the present Prime Minister rolled out their debt truck in 1995 Australia's foreign debt was $180 billion. They said that was completely unsustainable, that it was selling out Australia's future and that it was $10,000 for every man, woman and child in this country. The net foreign debt is now $406 billion, or $20,000 for every man, woman and child in this country. If it was selling out Australia's sovereignty and Australia's future when it was $10,000 for every man, woman and child in the country, what does that say about a debt of $20,000 for every man, woman and child in the country? Again, back in 1995 when Labor in government pointed out that a very substantial proportion of that foreign debt was in fact private foreign debt, the current Treasurer said, `Look, the only thing that one needs to get one's mind around is the size of the foreign debt of $180 billion.' The Treasurer ought to get his mind around the size of the foreign debt now of $406 billion.

Every day that this government is fuelling consumption spending through its $66 billion spending spree it is adding to the trade deficit, it is adding to the current account deficit and it is adding to net foreign debt. But the government is so blas about this; it does not seem to be concerned. It might not be concerned but the Reserve Bank is concerned. If you read that Statement on Monetary Policy issued two days ago, you will see it has a chilling warning for those households who are receiving the $600 payment that we are debating today. The Reserve Bank appears to be preparing the Australian public for an increase in mortgage interest rates. What the government gives with one hand, the Reserve Bank has to take away with the other because of the government's economic mismanagement. What comfort is it to the Australian families who receive this $600 payment per child if mortgage interest rates go up? Australian borrowers have borrowed to the hilt. Even a one-quarter of one percentage point rise in mortgage interest rates can mean a very substantial addition to repayment obligations.

Before the election the Prime Minister and the Treasurer were trying to create the impression that interest rates would not be a problem if the Liberal-National coalition was re-elected. Yet here we are, just months after the election, and the Reserve Bank bells the cat and basically says that the government's economic mismanagement and its failure to rein in budget spendingâin fact, it is adding fuel to the fireâhas put the Reserve Bank in a situation where it may have no alternative but to increase mortgage interest rates. It is a result of the government's economic mismanagement. The government knew what it was doing; this was not negligence. It was adding almost $66 billion to already rampant consumer spending for one purpose only: not to manage the economy but to organise its re-election and then worry about the interest rate rises later.

On the last day of parliament last year the Treasurer said, `Let's hope we have a happy retailing Christmas.' In the same answer he talked about how maybe you should give love for Christmas and not a Christmas present. Then at the end of that answer he said: `Let's hope we have a happy retailing Christmas'âin other words, let us hope it goes on and on and everyone enjoys this consumption boom. Now the Treasurer and other ministers are in the parliament saying that this consumption boom is creating a few problemsâthat there is a shortage of skills and that is going to create wage pressures, as identified by the Reserve Bank two days ago. The government's response to the wage pressures is: `We'll have more industrial relations reform.' What for? To stop wages rising?

The problem is that there is an excess demand for skilled people. Industrial relations changes, government style, will not mean that those skilled people will command, in a market economy, lower wages. How is further deregulation of the labour market going to ease wage pressures when the problem is that there is already very strong excess demand for skilled employees in this country? The answer is that it will not solve the problem. All it does is give the government another excuse to say, `Everything would have been all right if we had just been able to deregulate the labour market a little bit more.' Instead of trying to create political scapegoats out of the Australian trade union movement and the Australian Labor Party, the government ought to accept its economic responsibilities and implement policies such that mortgage interest rate increases would not be necessary. Through buying its way back into government the coalition has dramatically increased the likelihood of those interest rates rising.

I now want to make an observation about the family payment system. The family payment system has quite a history. Conceptually, it is a good approach because it does seek to redistribute income to those who have less financial and private market capacity. But it has been augmented year after year to the point where it has become a very expensive system indeed. One measure of that expense is that the total collection of personal income tax in 2004-05 is estimated by the budget at $102 billion but total spending on social security and welfare is estimated at $82 billionâthat is, around 80 per cent of all the personal income tax collected in this country is then sent back out in the form of family and other payments.

That suggests a large amount of churningâthat is, the government taxing people, taking the money off them, having it collected by the tax office through often high effective marginal tax rates and then going around and saying: `What jolly good fellows we are. Here's some family payments back.' Here is a radical thought for a coalition government: maybe it would be better not to tax them so much in order to be jolly good fellows and give some of it back in family payments. To the extent that the family payments system provides a genuine redistribution I would support it, but there must be many billions of dollars of revenue collected through the tax system that is returned to the same taxpayers. So the radical thought is: maybe we need to have a look at the whole tax and income support system and see whether we can simplify it. Maybe we could use some of the proceeds that are just being recycled to the same families by the government so that it can get the accolades of saying, `Here's some money in the pocket for you'âmoney that it took out of the other pocket. Maybe it is time for a fundamental look at that.

I understand that the government is looking afresh at these ideas. My belief is that over the last 15 or 20 years the tax system and the family payments system have grown incrementally, not necessarily rationally, and often in order for a government to be re-elected. In 2000 it was increased very substantially as compensation for the GST, because the government recognised that it was not going to be able to compensate people properly for the GST through the tax system alone and that it would need to do so through the family payments system. We have a higgledy-piggledy system that has been built up with some rationality in it but a very large amount of irrationalityâof political opportunismâin it. Maybe this is the time to have a good look at the interaction of the tax and family payments systems.

Labor brought a policy to the last election which sought to reduce effective marginal tax rates for particular income groups and households. That policy had a lot to commend it. It is interesting to note a report by Gillian Beer of NATSEM as to whereâthis was in 2002, so there have been some changesâthe high effective marginal tax rates are. It is revealed that only eight per cent of individuals face effective marginal tax rates above 60 per cent. Of individuals with earnings, only 11 per cent face effective marginal tax rates above 60 per cent. Fifteen per cent of couples with children face high effective marginal tax rates, defined as effective marginal tax rates above 60 per cent, and 23 per cent of sole parents face them. They are the two types of households that face these high effective marginal tax rates. Interestingly, there is a concentration of these high effective marginal tax rates in the middle income ranges. This report and the work of NATSEM is important in forming a proper reform process for our income tax and social security systems. Let us look at it afresh, let us rebuild it, let us make it a rational system and reform the higgledy-piggledy system that has been built up through successive governments seeking re-election and making in many cases very irrational decisions.

talk.start.para: âWe are here today because the government has been caught out. The government was caught out with its sleight of hand where it was trying to hoodwink Australian families with the $600 family tax payment and the yearly payment that was a provision of the legislation last year. It hoodwinked them through the indexation process that was introduced at that time. Let us get this straight right now: there would have been absolutely no change whatsoever to the original legislation had the government not been caught out. This is a government that has been caught out, yet again.

speech.para: We are here now revisiting the legislation with the Family Assistance Legislation Amendment (Adjustment of Certain FTB Child Rates) Bill 2004 to correct an anomaly that arose when the $600 family tax benefit supplement payment was introduced. It was an anomaly that existed because the government thought it could get away with it. It was an anomaly that would have affected Australian families. This is a government that has a long history of introducing legislation which on the surface looks pretty good but which has quite a negative effect on families. I hate to say that this government has really been dragged screaming into the chamber to alter the legislation.

The original bill had provisions that would allow the government to claw back the value of the $600 supplementary payment over a six- to seven-year period and hope that the Australian people would not notice it. We probably need to get this straight, too; let me put it on the record: this $600 payment would not have been necessary had the government revisited the way it calculated the family tax benefit paymentâa payment that results time and time again in families receiving notices from Centrelink that they have incurred a debt. The way it is calculated is a design fault. Families are required to determine their income in advance, and we all know that circumstances change. A person only needs to get a pay rise or work a bit of overtime and the next thing we know a debt has been incurred.

Whilst this legislation will fix the clawback provision of the previous legislation, it will do absolutely nothing to correct the flawed system used to calculate the family tax benefit. I cannot understand why the government cannot admit that it is wrong, go back to the drawing board and fix this issue once and for all. I suppose it requires a bit of character to admit you have made a mistake and to admit that you have duped the Australian peopleâto admit that you have in place a system that causes family after family to incur debts. I will talk a little more about that later.

This legislation, as I have mentioned, corrects an indexation anomaly that arose as a result of the legislation that introduced a $600 family tax benefit supplementary payment following the budget last year. Under the adjustment arrangements provided in the bill, if the family tax benefit for the under-13 child rate, as indexed by the consumer price index, is less than the amount worked out using the formula, CPC rate times 16.6 per cent, the family tax benefit under-13 rate is increased to the amount determined under the formula. The position is the same for the family tax benefit rate for children aged 13 to 16 years, except that the formula is the CPC rate times 21.6 per cent. Collectively, these tests are known as the safety net benchmark.

The arrangements provided for in the bill are the same as those which applied for family tax benefits prior to the passage of the legislation that introduced the family tax payment supplement following the 2004 budget. I cannot understand why the correct calculations were not included in the first piece of legislation. Being the suspicious person that I am when it relates to this government, I would have to say that they hoped that we would not notice but on this side of the House we are a pretty good opposition and we can pick up those things very quickly. We know that this government are always using some sleight of hand, some way to trick the Australian people. On this particular occasion we have made them accountable. We have made them forget the clawback provision they had in the initial legislation, and we have this legislation before us today.

Since the $600 family tax benefit supplement was introduced, Labor has argued time and time again that the government was attempting to claw back this payment by also changing the indexation arrangement for normal family tax benefit payments. We on this side of the House know that is true; we know that the government would have done that. That would have been the result if it had not been for the Labor Partyâif it had not been for the oppositionâbecause that is the way this government works. Because legislation introducing the $600 payment was delayed in the year in which it was introduced, the pre-existing safety net benchmark provisions came into effect. The CPI would be the sole means of adjusting normal family tax benefit payments, and, because the rate of the CPI base increases in the family tax benefit over the next few years, they are likely to be considerably less than they would have been under the safety net benchmarks and the government would have clawed back the entire $600 over six to seven years.

We have seen this in other areas where the government has introduced clawback provisions. Some of it has been seen in audits in the aged care area. Teams have been going back and reassessing the RCSs and patient classifications have been reassessed. The government gives with one hand and takes with the other. We know that; the Australian people know that. If the minister had been really serious about it, this legislation would have been amended in the last parliament.

This government has a philosophy of frowning on people who are in receipt of any sort of welfare payment. It supports families on its termsâand its terms alone. I think that the family tax benefit is one of those pieces of legislation where the government gives lip service to helping families, but, on the other hand, it actually creates a lot of problems for families. The one-off $600 payment made last year was designed to bribe Australian families pre-election, and the annual payment of $600 afterwards is just an attempt to fix a flawed system and a very poor attempt at that. It is interesting to note when the requests for repayment of family debts came outâthey came out after the election. That was no surprise to any of us on this side of the House.

The problem with the family tax benefit is the method of calculation. The problem with the system is that it is a very rigid system, and it is a problem that causes enormous problems for people in Australia. In the electorate of Shortland, it is estimated that, each year, over 4,000 families have debts averaging $900 each, and that is because of the flawed family tax benefit system. Keeping in mind that I said that is the average debt, and that over one-third of the people who are in receipt of family tax benefits in Shortland electorate are incurring those debts, that is a significant number of people.

I have had numerous families come and visit me about debts, and I do not mean one or two people: I mean a significant number of people. They come and visit me with debts of $3,000, $4,000 or, in some cases, even larger amounts. I rang my office this morning and asked them to pull out some details of people who have incurred debts within the electorate in relation to the family tax benefit. I was going to talk about some of those examples here this morning. But, when I received 20 pages of debt details with some 10 names to each page, I thought that would take up too much of the time of the House.

It is a flawed system. If the government was really serious about helping families, it could revisit that system, not with a stopgap measure to change the method of calculation but rather by addressing the core issue and fixing the problem once and for all.

I mentioned earlier in my speech that the government has a very ambivalent approach to providing welfare to people within Australia, be it families, pensioners or particularly people who are unemployed. We are going to see legislation reintroduced in this House relating to the disability support pension and people with disabilities, an area that is very dear to my heart and that I know is causing great angst within my electorate. This whole ambivalence towards welfare payments is of great concern to me. I saw an article in the Sydney Morning Heraldâand I wish I had brought it to the House with meâthat talked about government expenditure. It showed that the largest area of government expenditure was in the area of welfare.

The thing that really concerns me, given the government's philosophy and given the percentage of GDP that is actually spent on welfare payments, is that this government is going to move down the line of privatising Centrelink and privatising our welfare system. That really concerns me. We are seeing moves in the US along that line, and it has been put to me by people who work in the system now that the government has already started this, and it is doing it by stealth. Rather than a wholesale sell-off of Centrelink or associated services, this government will follow a process of outsourcing one function and outsourcing another function, and then effectually you will just have a very small core that has very little responsibility and a very small role.

That is not the Australian way. The Australian way is to look after all Australians. If a person is in need, needs a little extra assistance, the Australian way is to provide it. The Australian way when it comes to supporting families is to put in place a system where Australian families do not incur debts. The Australian way is to look after people. This piece of legislation does go towards effecting a change to legislation that was going to claw back money from Australian families, but unfortunately I do not think it really resolves the core issue. The core issue is to look after Australian families and to make that commitment to Australian families, Australia's future, and to ensure that every child in Australia has the opportunity to have the financial support that they need. That is the idea behind the family tax benefit.

So I support this legislation, but in doing so I have to state very strongly that I am disappointed. I am disappointed that the government had to introduce this legislation. I am disappointed that it took the opposition identifying the problem that existedâor catching the government outâfor the government to take this action. I am very disappointed that the government has not revisited the legislation, changed a flawed system and introduced a family tax benefit system that will not lead to Australian families incurring debts and therefore necessitating a $600 payment to offset that. I should add, as a rider to that, that the $600 does not even meet the average debt incurred by families in the Shortland electorate. I support the legislation, but in doing so I hope that my comments have been noted.

âI thank members on both sides of the House for their contribution to this debate. The Family Assistance Legislation Amendment (Adjustment of Certain FTB Child Rates) Bill 2004 amends the adjustment provisions in the family assistance law as they apply to the family tax benefit child rates for children under 13 and those aged from 13 to 15. Prior to the introduction of the family tax benefit part A supplement on 1 July 2004, the safety net benchmark for these FTB child rates was 16.6 per cent of the combined pensioner couple rate for children under 13 and 21.6 per cent of the combined pensioner couple rate for children aged 13 to 15.

speech.para: The safety net benchmark applied if CPI indexation of these rates resulted in a lesser rate of payment than under the formula. The annual rate of family tax benefit payable for children in these age groups was effectively increased with the introduction earlier this year of a $600 per child family tax benefit part A supplement. The family tax benefit part A supplement is a separate payment that is CPI indexed on 1 July each year and paid as a lump sum at the end of the relevant income year. This additional payment was also reflected in the benchmark formula. This bill further amends the formula to ensure that fortnightly payments of family tax benefit part A in respect of children under 13 and children aged 13 to 15 will be indexed by the greater of either the CPI or a percentage of the combined pensioner couple rate without regard to the supplement. The fortnightly rates will be adjusted at the same time and for the same amount as would have occurred before the introduction of the family tax benefit part A supplement. These changes ensure that the intention of the policy is being delivered and that the real value of fortnightly payments of family tax benefit part A are maintained. The $600 per child family tax benefit part A supplement will continue to be indexed each year in line with increases in the CPI, as is currently provided for in the family assistance law. The real value of the supplement will be maintained through this indexation to the CPI. I commend this bill to the House.
Question agreed to.
Bill read a second time.

talk.start.para: âIt is a great pleasure to be here today to support the AusLink (National Land Transport) Bill 2004 and the AusLink (National Land TransportâConsequential and Transitional Provisions) Bill 2004 because many programs will receive funding as a result of the innovative and futuristic views of the Deputy Prime Minister and Leader of The Nationals, John Anderson. The AusLink package is an exciting step forward and represents a new era of funding of land transport infrastructure in this nation. The Hon. John Anderson had the visionary drive to establish a blueprint for transport infrastructure into our future. I certainly was very supportive of this when I came into this House, recognising that there were significant issues with port and rail authorities and transport and road access to many areas across the Riverina. These areas are great producers, have an enormously beneficial export record for the benefit of this nation and require transport infrastructure and access to be delivered into the future.

speech.para: Without substantial and modern land transport infrastructure, the development of communities that rely so heavily on the ability to transport their produce to markets will be severely impacted upon. This government has recognised this and has worked to ensure that our infrastructure is not only maintained but improved to ensure the viability of our economies well into the future. Many road and rail networks fall under the responsibility of state and territory governments, which are certainly making it very difficult for local government through a series of cost-shifting processes, as the member for Hunter would be well aware, that is almost not able to be contained. The state and territory governments are falling well short of what their commitment should be to ensure the viability of the states and particularly of my electorate of Riverina. Certainly we should be working together to improve our road and rail infrastructure. By doing this, we would be able to achieve a good outcomeâthe best outcomeâfor not only the people of Australia but most importantly for those very good people of the Riverina. A very good working relationship with states and the Commonwealth is what AusLink is all aboutâworking together in a holistic manner to achieve a network of land infrastructure that will continue to assist growth and development throughout this nation.

Having said that the states have been a major problem in the past, I congratulate them for coming forward and being part of a national initiative to ensure that we move forward as a collective team regardless of politics and look out for the interests of the people and the producers and the businesses of Australia. I think it has been a very worthwhile exercise but it took the Leader of The Nationals and the Deputy Prime Minister, John Anderson, to bring these people to the table, to give them some vision so that they recognise that, yes, it is possible for us to work together as a collective for the benefit of the people of Australia. I am sure the member for Hunter would agree with that initiative.

Significant funding announcements have been made by this government for projects that I have lobbied for since being elected as the member for Riverina and they have been successful. Projects such as the funding for the Coolac Bypass have been a priority for my communities for many years now. Together we have lobbied government for funding and have been successful. I am very pleased to state that today, 9 February, I put out a press release headed `Calling of Coolac Bypass tenders welcomed'. I stated:

quote.para: The Nationalsâ

speech.para: I am very proud to be a memberâ

quote.para: Member for Riverina Kay Hull today welcomed the calling of tenders for the construction of the $117 million Coolac Bypass, saying it represented an important milestone in the development of the region.

speech.para: Together the community and I have been lobbying for this, particularly the Mayor of Gundagai Shire Council, Len Tozer, a very good man, and the General Manager, Graham Tickner. The community have assisted me by ensuring that they put their support right behind my efforts to have funding for the Coolac Bypass put into place. The tenders that have been called also end uncertainty for landowners who have been affected by the proposed construction of this 12-kilometre bypass since about 1992 when the proposal came up. Finally, with the help of the Department of Transport and Regional Services, the Hon. John Anderson's office and the community, I have very great pleasure in saying that I have been able to put funding in place. In the press release, I stated:

quote.para: The construction period also represents an opportunity for the businesses and people of Coolac to manage the transition to a day when the highway will no longer pass through town.
The incorporation of two rest areas within the project will emphasise Coolac's traditional role as a highway service town. I will be working to ensure that Coolac is well signposted from the highway.
... local traffic movements had been an important consideration in the bypass design.
The project includes construction of an interchange at Cootamundra Road with a bridge over the highway, which will also provide motorists with access to Coolac village.
Motorists travelling northbound will be able to access Pettit Village and Gobarralong Road by a ramp and underpass at Coleman Street.

speech.para: This is a significant amount of work that has been so long in the making. Finally, after a bit of procrastination we are starting to see benefits and outcomes for this long-awaited bypass. The Australian government has earmarked $1 billion for the Hume Highway upgrade as well. These sorts of projects have been realised and the government has committed to them through the AusLink process. The Deputy Prime Minister and Minister for Transport and Regional Services made a brief visit to my electorate last year and announced this money and he was absolutely applauded throughout the Riverina area. There have been huge death tolls and huge accident rates in Coolac. This matter has been in need of resolution for a long time. I thank the minister for resolving this issue.

The government has also committed an additional $714 million for the Hume Highway in New South Wales and Victoria. The aim is duplicate the highway by 2012. This is long overdue. Another successful outcome was the decision by the government to provide funding of $7 million to improve the West Street exit at Gundagai and to construct an overpass. Gundagai became part of my electorate of Riverina in the 2001 election. It is a fantastic `can do' community and one that I am very proud to represent. We have worked together very strongly in the last three years since the Gundagai community became part of my electorate to ensure that we brought some very good and tangible benefits back to Gundagai. With the continued lobbying and ongoing support from the Gundagai community, we are looking to have this matter resolved and this very dangerous area fixed.

Gundagai was one of the first towns that was bypassed over 20 years ago. The community have been living with a dangerous situation ever since. This project is one of my priorities. Funnily enough, as a politician I do not make promises, but this project is one thing that I wanted to deliver to Gundagai, one thing that I promised I would work myself into the ground in trying to deliver. I think this is the only promise I have ever made: to tangibly deliver a project and outcome and, thankfully, I was successful. This is a great day not only for Gundagai but also for me. But I do not think it will encourage me to make greater promises in the future. It is very difficult as a politician to deliver promises.

As a region renowned for its produce, the Riverina and the MIA areas are dependent on road and rail transport, particularly road transport, to move their products to both domestic and international markets. Many businesses throughout our region are exporters, while many more are encouraged to do so. Without modern and reliable road and rail infrastructure the ability for these producers to further develop markets is very restricted. I have often indicated in this House just how very proud I am of my electorate for the production that it generates: wine from the magnificent wineries, citrus, and rice from the great company of Sunrice. We have a huge amount of exports in our region and they would be hampered if we did not have adequate transport and land infrastructure. A number of highly successful programs are also included as part of the AusLink package, such as a continuation of our Roads to Recovery program and black spot road safety projects.

I remember that when I came into this House as a new member I was very keenâand I still am. I sat down and worked out a way in which we could increase funding to local governments. Coming from local government, having been the deputy mayor of Wagga Wagga City Council prior to my entry into the House, I realised that there was a call on local government to provide a never-ending source of funding for roadworks. When I came into the House I thought that that would be one of the very good things we could do.

John Anderson, to his credit, gave us an opportunity as National Party backbenchers to work together as a collective to try to come up with a proposal that would see money going directly to local government rather than through the states, with them channelling off most of that money into other, unrelated areas. Without doubt, I believe the program that John Anderson introduced has been the most successful program ever introduced into this parliament. Everybody applauds this program because it gives councils the opportunity to directly take this money and put it into their priorities for their local road infrastructure, which can assist them to grow their industries and their businesses. It is a great program which provides much needed assistance to local councils in the Riverina.

I would like to see all roads programs and all funding go directly to local governments. This initiative has proven that councils can manage their own funds reliably and accountably, and you can actually see results delivered on the ground. I think that the more funds we can channel out of the state coffers and directly into local government, the better the benefits that will come not just to country people but to city people. I am sure that city people also lose a lot of the benefits of the funding that is designed to go directly to them, rather than into state coffers for a host of other reasons.

Many of the shire councils that I represent are responsible for thousands of kilometres of roads, yet they often and most likely have a small rate base, so it is very difficult for them to sustain the road network. Carrathool Shire Council, for interest's sake, have an enormous road base for which they have to address maintenance, renewal and new roads, yet they have a very limited rate base.

This Roads to Recovery money and the black spot program are very important. We reintroduced black spot funding. I stand to be corrected, but I think a Labor government in this House wiped out black spot funding and we saw the need to reintroduce it. And it is just so helpful, so I applaud the government again for having the foresight to say, `This is what we need to do for those many people out there.'

As I have indicated before, cost shifting is occurring at a great pace, with the state government passing on more and more responsibility to local councils. Local councils are struggling to maintain thousands of kilometres of roads. They are trying to attract doctors, they are trying to provide medical surgeries and they are trying to prop up the failing health system. In New South Wales under the Carr Labor government we have a failing health system, with the introduction of super regions giving people less and less access to decision makers for health initiatives in their regions.

Local governments have the entire responsibility for an array of community services that are no longer funded by the states. They are kind of representing the states' interests now and delivering most of the states' agenda. Maybe that is a good call; maybe there is a call for the abolition of states. Probably something that should be debated at some stage is just what benefit the states provide, because they are no longer responsible for anything. We hear time and time again in this House about our ailing health system, which the states are responsible for, and about our public education system, which the states are responsible for. Every day the states want the federal government to be responsible for more money, saying, `Give us more, gimme, gimme.' They do not want to be responsible for anything. They want to divest themselves of some education responsibility and hand it over to the federal government in return for something else. It is almost like the states are starting to put their own agenda together to see themselves removed and some other form of government established. We are here to talk about the AusLink legislation, but that was a nice niche to move into because it raises some questions.

talk.start.para: (Mr Hatton)âAs long as you do not stay there too long, that is fine.

âI really am staying well and truly within the bills. With the continuation of the Roads to Recovery program to 2009 and another $1.2 billion, or $300 million a year, many more local projects and roads will be completed, ensuring the safety of the many people that I represent, that you represent, Mr Deputy Speaker Hatton, and that many people in this House represent in their local communities. We have had a significant amount of Roads to Recovery program money in the Riverina electorate. Since 1998, more than $380 million has been delivered to my local governments to enable them to develop and maintain very important local roads.

speech.para: In the most recent round of funding under the national black spot program, in early 2004, more than $953,000 was announced for councils in the Riverina. Works to be completed under this program included installing roundabouts at dangerous intersections, installing median strips, improving signage, carrying out realignments and resurfacing, and widening local roads. I hope that those members who are involved with the New South Wales state government recognise that that is certainly assisting local areas in New South Wales and that the state government should come on down with a little bit of money to try to assist these councils as well, rather than cost-shifting back onto them.

Additionally, AusLink funding has provided $3.6 million to widen the Sturt Highway west of Hayâa fantastic communityâand $4.6 million to construct new bridges on the Sturt Highway west of Narrandera. I launched a tourism brochure, NarranderaâHeart of the Riverina, just last Friday. All the road improvements that have come from the AusLink package will do a great deal to assist tourism and give communities the ability to attract significant visitation with greater ease, as they have a very much better road network that tourists can travel on. The brochure NarranderaâHeart of the Riverina is an absolute credit to the Narrandera Tourist Board, the printers and all the business houses in Narrandera who have got behind this and decided that they want to take significant benefits from the tourism dollar that might be available. That tourism dollar can only assist if we have good road and transport infrastructure, including rail and air. A whole host of areas that are providing benefits back to country people are coming from this AusLink project. I congratulate the Deputy Prime Minister, the Leader of The Nationals, for having the great initiative and innovation to put together this proposal, which can deliver such tangible benefits to the people of the Riverina.

talk.start.para: âI am pleased to speak on the AusLink (National Land Transport) Bill 2004 and the AusLink (National Land TransportâConsequential and Transitional Provisions) Bill 2004. This package of bills provides for an integrated network of road and rail linkages of strategic national importance, including funding provisions for programs under the new national land transport network; black spot projects; and new discretionary funding for strategic regional projects and continuing projects under the Roads to Recovery program.

speech.para: The AusLink (National Land Transport) Bill 2004 gives effect to the government's national land transport policy set out in the white paper which was called AusLink: building our national transport future. The bill establishes a new framework for Australian government funding of land transport infrastructure and the arrangements for which the bill provides will replace over time those contained in the Australian Land Transport Development Act 1988 and the Roads to Recovery Act 2000. The Australian Land Transport Development Act 1988 was originally introduced by the former member for Charltonâand land transport minister in the Hawke governmentâas the Australian Centennial Roads Development Act. Mr Deputy Speaker Hatton, I now have the task of telling my father that the first piece of legislation that he ever introduced as minister has now been replaced, and I know that you would not envy me that task.

talk.start.para: (Mr Hatton)âI would not envy you; it is a challenge.

âThis legislation provides funding for six categories of projects or activities. They include: AusLink national projects, which are projects on the national land transport network; AusLink transport development and innovation projects land transport research entities, which are related to the national land transport network land transport research entities; AusLink strategic regional projects; AusLink black spot projects; and the AusLink Roads to Recovery program.

speech.para: Although this legislation is broadly supported by Labor, we have expressed quite a few concerns about it. Our major concern, which you have heard our shadow minister and other members in this debate speaking about, is that it provides quite considerable discretion for the minister to decide how to allocate funds under AusLink strategic regional projects, and the minister has and will continue to have considerable discretion over the AusLink Roads to Recovery program. Of course, we have concerns about that. I think the shadow minister has referred to it as pork-barrelling in times of elections to shore up support for regional members.

We also have a concern about the lack of consultation which has occurred with the states. Even though the legislation caps maintenance funding at $300 million a year, it places a further onus on the states. The consultation required for a satisfactory arrangement to develop under that process has not occurred. When the green paper was introduced, chapter 5 said that a joint working group on AusLink priorities on the national network was established to assist with developing a possible set of national infrastructure priorities for the initial five-year period of AusLink. However, all the state and territory governments have complained of little or no consultation in the development of national priorities under the first five-year AusLink national land transport plan. As a lot of the onus and funding is being put back to the states, the government would have got a more satisfactory outcome if they had consulted properly with the states and the territories.

Another concern with this legislation is the length of time it has taken for AusLink and the national road network to emerge: the process has taken over two years and still we do not know what the road network structure consists of. As we see from this legislation, that is going to evolve over time, but that is also going to be a matter for ministerial discretion. I can foresee a position in the future where the majority of the roads that are going to be part of the national network are going to flow through Liberal Party and National Party seats throughout the country. As I have mentioned and as the shadow minister and other speakers have mentioned, there is a huge potential for pork-barrelling under AusLink strategic regional projects. I would like to point out one exampleâwhether it is pork-barrelling or a matter of priority, I do not know. I can only explain what the situation has been in my backyard.

My home town is Toronto. I drive to and from Canberra using the national highway system, taking the F3 through to Sydney and travelling on Pennant Hills Road, the Cumberland Highway and then down the Hume Highway to Canberra. As I have driven that route over the last 18 months or so I have noticed a fair bit of work going on down the F3 freeway in the electorates of Dobell and Robertson, which are just south of the electorate of Charlton. I have asked questions and pursued issues in relation to repairs and maintenance that I believe are urgently required on the F3 freeway, which traverses my electorate for some 50 kilometres. Down the road, as I said, road widening seems to be going on, extra lanes are being constructed and repairs are taking place. I have seen many of those big lights that indicate that night work is happening. But once you cross the electorate boundary into Charltonâand then later when you leave the electorateâthere is nothing going on for those 50 kilometres of road, and there are quite a few areas there that require a great deal of maintenance. It will be a tragic day when pork-barrelling in government electorates, if that is what this is, is given greater priority than saving lives and stopping accidents and injuries in non-government held electorates.
On 17 November last year I placed the following questions on notice to the minister. I asked:

(1) Is he aware that engineers of the NSW Roads and Traffic Authority (RTA) conduct inspections of the F3 Freeway between Sydney and Newcastle and does his department receive advice of such inspections and their outcomes.
(2) Does the Government provide funding to maintain and repair the F3 Freeway on the advice of the NSW Roads and Traffic Authority.

(3) Is he aware that recent inspections by RTA officers have found evidence of cracked, dropped or crowned concrete slabs that require urgent replacement North of the Toronto interchange; if not, why not.
(4) Is he aware of `spalls' or `potholes' on the F3 Freeway North of the Toronto interchange that have required constant repair for the last thirteen years; if not, why not.
(5) Will he provide urgent funding to upgrade this section of road before motorists are killed or injured; if not, why not.
Those questions have not been answered yet. I will be taking the issue up with the Speaker after question time, in order to pursue the minister to get a response to those questions.

Still on the issue of electoral exploitation, I received quite a few phone calls during the election campaignâand I do not know whether many of my colleagues did, I have not pursued this with themâquestioning the sudden erection throughout the electorate of signs indicating that local roadworks were being funded by the federal government under the Roads to Recovery program. We have always supported the Roads to Recovery program, and I have supported my local council in relation to the roads that they have allocated the funding to. During the election year these signs just started popping up all over the electorate where Roads to Recovery maintenance had taken place. However, some of the works had been going on for quite some time before the signs popped up, and some of the works had been completed for quite some time before the signs popped up. I ask the question: what kind of instructions were given to local councils around the country to make sure that during that election year those particular works were acknowledged as being funded by the federal government? That notwithstanding, Labor have of course indicated that we will continue to support the Roads to Recovery program.

The member for Riverina talked earlier about the black spot program. That program is another program that was introduced by the former member for Charltonâas the minister for land transport in the Hawke government. That was a great program and did a lot of good under the Hawke government. Of course we were pleased to see the program continue under this government, and we will continue to support it.

We also express our distaste at the obvious blackmailing of the states in relation to road funding. As we all know, the Commonwealth has now threatened to withhold funding unless the states drop their opposition to the Howard government's tough industrial relations laws, which require contractors to abide by draconian codes of practice, which have come out of the witch-hunt the government conducted in the construction industry. South Australia has had to succumb to those threats in order to receive funding of up to $275 million over the next five years for their AusLink projects. As the New South Wales Minister for Industrial Relations John Della Bosca said:

quote.para: ... the commonwealth is playing political games and reducing our per capita funding.

speech.para: We will just have to see how this process plays out. We have seen the indications that once the government gets a majority in the Senate it is going to be no holds barred in the area of industrial relations. This government has always been out to destroy unions and collective bargaining. It has always been out to destroy the protections and conditions that workers have enjoyed over the yearsâprotections and conditions that have been built up and fought for over decades, if not centuries, of struggle by trade unionists.

I would like to refer briefly to a proposal for a major infrastructure development in my electorate of Charlton. Mr Acting Deputy Speaker, whenever infrastructure funding legislation is introducedâor there are other debates in this place where I have the opportunity to do soâyou would know that I often refer to this, because it has been a passion of mine since before I was elected. The Lake Macquarie City Council has identified an urgent need for the development of a transport hub in Glendale, known as the Lake Macquarie Integrated Transport Centre. The project is a major infrastructure development for the Hunter region and will generate jobs growth, improve access to public transport and provide environmental health benefits for Lake Macquarie. In the past 10 years in excess of 1,000 new employment positions have been created in Lake Macquarieâmost within the Cardiff Industrial Park. It is proposed that the estate be expanded and further developed. The industrial area houses major transport and manufacturing firms, which provide employment and major export revenue for Australia. However businesses are hindered by treacherous and inefficient road links to the F3 freeway. Lake Macquarie City Council's proposed integrated transport strategy will alleviate this problem.

As I indicated, I seek leave to table the proposal prepared by the Lake Macquarie City Council Strategy Group entitled The Lake Macquarie Integrated Transport Centre: transport infrastructure for the Hunter's largest industrial park.
Leave granted.

talk.start.para: âThe Hunter region has suffered significantly from the closure of BHP and the downturn in our manufacturing industries. This proposal will greatly assist in the maintenance and extension of employment opportunities in this region. Since before my election in 1998 I have lobbied the Commonwealth to participate in a whole-of-government approach to the centre. This has been repeatedly refused by various coalition government ministers. While shadow minister for economic ownership and community security at the time, Mark Latham, on a visit to the region, announced prior to the last election Labor's better regional cities program and indicated the proposed Lake Macquarie integrated transport centre would be appropriate for funding by a federal Labor government as part of the comprehensive regional infrastructure plan.

speech.para: There has been ongoing consultation and discussion concerning transport infrastructure development in the Hunter region, and that will continue. It is a large region which requires these vital transport links to propel its sustainability into the future. My state colleagues in the region also support the development of this key transport infrastructure. One of my state colleagues, Mr John Mills, the state member for Wallsend, said:

quote.para: An integrated transport centre comprising rail, bus, private vehicle and pedestrian interchange facilities is necessary for Glendale, which sits at the demographic centre of the lower Hunter.
