More people go to work in the commercial and industrial areas of Glendale, Cardiff and Warners Bay than in the whole of the Newcastle Central Business District.

speech.para: The New South Wales government has already committed to funding a railway station and a pedestrian overpass in this particular area. What we are asking is that the Commonwealth also come on board to provide an overpass road, a link road to enable the expansion of the industrial estate where a lot of people work. It is also supported by the member for Lake Macquarie, my colleague Jeff Hunter, MP.

Labor has long advocated an integrated national land transport plan. At the 2004 election we committed to fully funding the national highway network, the establishment of an national infrastructure advisory council to provide industry, expert and consumer advice on national priorities and to extend the criteria for Roads to Recovery projects to include public transport, cycling, walking infrastructure and regional airport runways. We believe that this legislation has the potential for a number of consequences which should be examined by a Senate committee. When this bill reaches the Senate we will seek to refer it to the Senate Rural and Regional Affairs Legislation Committee, to report by May 2005 having examined matters including but not limited to the provisions for ministerial discretion for funding; the initial consultation process with the states and territories and the proposed consultation process for the next five-year period; the potential impact of proposed changes to funding of the national highway; the potential need to establish a national infrastructure advisory council; the potential to extend the criteria for Roads to Recovery projects to include public transport, cycling, walking infrastructure and regional airport runways; and the impact of removing the requirement to tie funding to non-transport related provisions of any bilateral funding agreements struck with the states and territories prior to the 2004 federal electionâthat is, those requiring adherence to the National Code of Practice for the Construction Industry.

This parliament must have a responsibility to ensure that the Commonwealth maintains funding responsibility for the construction and maintenance of infrastructure on what was formally defined as the national highway network, establishes an national infrastructure advisory council and extends the criteria for the Roads to Recovery projects, as I said, to include public transport, cycling, walking infrastructure and regional airport runways. I look forward to seeing some improvements made to this legislation which are vitally important to our country.

talk.start.para: âThe Howard government claims that AusLink will revolutionise the planning and funding of Australia's national roads and railways by taking a long-term strategic approach to the nation's long-term future. It states that this program represents the most significant change since Federation in the way governments tackle the national transport task. AusLink is supposed to transform the way the Australian government plans and funds national transport infrastructure. Australia's major road and rail systems will be planned and developed together to produce a supposedly integrated and high-performing national network that will apparently build this nation's transport future.

speech.para: If this government's sorry record on funding the much needed Calder Highway redevelopment is anything to go by then AusLink is doomed from day one. The Howard government had to be dragged kicking and screaming all the way to have the Calder included in the AusLink program and then it did it only grudgingly. This project has been a constant example of this government's deceit and broken promises since November 1998, and there can be no clearer evidence of this government's treachery on Calder funding than the Treasurer's answer to a question from me on 11 September, 2003, where it could be argued that he deliberately misled the parliament by saying:

quote.para: The duplicationâthe two lanesâof the Calder Highway is being funded under the Roads of National Importance program, a program which never existed under the Labor Party. So if it had not been for this government ... none of that would have occurred ... under the Labor Party there would have been no Commonwealth contribution whatsoever in relation to that. So we have been building and extending the Calder Highway under that programâand, as I indicated, under the RONI programâfifty-fifty. That provides the funding for it.

speech.para: He said:

quote.para: I am sure that the Labor Party would acknowledge the fact that there would have been no funding if it had not been for the coalition.

speech.para: This arrogant Treasurer has deliberately misled this House and I want to show the lie in his claims that Labor had done nothing for the Calder. It was the Hawke Labor government that started the duplication of the Calder Highway. It funded the Big Hill to Ravenswood duplication that was completed in 1986. By 1996 the federal Labor government had provided around $75 millionâestimated to be in excess of $155 million in today's dollarsâfor reconstructing and duplicating the Calder Highway. In other words, the last federal Labor government invested more in today's dollar values than the $100 million the Howard government has so farâand grudginglyâput into the highway.

The federal Labor government provided the funding under a number of programs, including the Australian Bicentennial Road Development program, the Australian Land Transport Development program, the One Nation roads program and the better cities road funding program. As I said before, a sum of $75 million in 1985 dollars equals over $155 million in today's dollars. The federal Labor government provided $2.8 million for the Gap Hill to Gisborne preconstruction, $15.2 million for the Kyneton bypass, $7.1 million for the Diggers Rest to Gap Hill preconstruction, $29.2 million for the Diggers Rest bypass, $13.2 million for the Keilor to Diggers Rest duplication, $2.04 million for the Big Hill to Ravenswood duplication, $2.05 million for the Harcourt to Ravenswood lane construction, and another $3 million for maintenance and lane construction.

What is also of great importance is that Labor set a target to finish the entire Calder Highway duplication from Melbourne to Bendigo by the year 2000. During the 2001 federal election campaign the Howard government said that it would match the state government's funding and that it accepted the state government's completion date of 2006. These promises it systematically dishonoured.

After stalling the project for another four years from 2001, it will be 2005 before any coalition Commonwealth funding will be allocated to the Calder, and the completion date will be 2011 or 2012 at the earliestâthat is, assuming the coalition sticks to its most recent promise, something that history has shown is most unlikely to occur. In fact, the coalition's credibility has been run down and its promises are running on empty.

Because of the coalition government's inaction, dishonesty and blatant disregard for the motorists of central Victoria, the Calder Highway, one of the most important central Victorian infrastructure programs, will take longer to complete than the legendary Snowy Mountains Hydro-Electric Schemeâjust because the Howard-Anderson government originally wanted to walk away from the project. Central Victorian motorists are getting increasingly angry with the coalitionâand is it any wonder?

Rapidly rising fuel prices and taxes are making central Victorian motorists even angrier with the federal government's stalling over the funding of the Calder Highway. In November 2001, when Treasurer Costello falsely promised Bendigo that it would match state funding for the Calder, Bendigo district motorists paid around 84.9c a litre for petrol. They paid 45.82c of this in excise and GST. It cost them around $50.94 to fill a 60-litre tank. They paid $27.49 of this to the Commonwealth in taxes. At that time, they paid around $16.15 in taxes and CityLink tolls for a return trip to Melbourne on the Calder Highway. In May 2004, central Victorian motorists were paying 105.9c a litre at many district outlets. Of this, they paid 47.64c to the federal government in taxes. Today they are paying $63.54 to fill up their tanksâ$12.60 more than when Treasurer Costello made his phoney promise. Of this they are paying $28.58 in taxesâ$1.09 more than in November 2001. They are now paying around $16.98 in taxes and tolls for a return trip on the same treacherously unfinished road to Melbourne. For their taxes, they have got nothing new on the Calder since Mr Costello's pre-election con job of November 2001. The Bendigo electorate pays around $90 million a year in fuel taxes plus GST; since the November 2001 election, it has paid over $200 million in such taxes. This is more than the amount needed to finish the Calder. Where has it gone?

The Howard government has stopped all new funding for the Calder, sabotaged the 2006 completion date promised by the Liberals during the 2001 election campaign and added millions to the cost of the remaining work. The only work now being done on the Calder is by the Bracks state government. Bendigo remains the only major regional centre in Victoria where motorists are taxed on an unfinished road and pay a CityLink entry tax plus GST to get into Melbourne. The Calder is a road potholed with Liberal lies and coalition cop-outs. In 1996 the Liberal Party promised to duplicate the highway. Instead it has only duplicated the taxes on the Calder. In November 2001 Treasurer Costello assured Bendigo that the Calder had a `much higher priority' with the government than the Scoresby Freeway, but a short while later he openly listed Scoresby as the government's top priority. This is the forked tongue of Mr Costello that really infuriates Calder motorists. Mr Costello was quoted as saying:

quote.para: What the Commonwealth does is that it enters into agreements with State Governments for the most important roads in order of priority and ... the order of priority is the Scoresby Freeway and then after we do the Scoresby Freeway we move on to the next one.

speech.para: In reality, from 1997âfour years before it signed up Scoresby as a RONI in 2001âthe government had an agreement with the state to fund the Calder. Since then Mr Costello has ratted on the Calder. The Scoresby is a `RONI come lately' compared to the Calder.

Now the Howard government has dudded the Calder yet again in its AusLink program by not allocating the full $193 million Commonwealth contribution needed to finish the project. The Treasurer is a master of pork-barrelling on the Scoresby and pork pies on the Calder. He took over six years to deliver his 1996 election promise to provide $2 million for Bendigo's arts facilities, and it is more than three years and two federal election campaigns since his promise to match the state funding for the Calder. Is it any wonder that opinion polls are showing that the Treasurer is extremely unpopular with Australian voters.

A former roads minister, Senator Ian Campbell, was Mr Costello's parliamentary secretary for four years. He was the minute taker for the coalition ministers that deserted the Calder at Kyneton. On the day he was appointed roads minister, the transport minister, John Anderson, openly admitted that Calder RONI funding was completed. Then, just before Senator Campbell visited Bendigo, Mr Anderson deliberately distorted the coalition's Calder RONI pledge to duplicate the whole road from Melbourne to Bendigo: it now only covered fixing up the `worst sections'. Labor's Calder guarantee would have enabled the state government to finish the project by the new 2009 deadline, which was caused by the Howard government's dumping of its own 2006 deadline.

Just in case there are any doubts regarding the Howard government's 2001 Calder Highway election promiseâand leaving aside the Treasurer's now infamous 2001 election campaign commitment to match the state government's fundingâI will again quote from a story in the Bendigo Weekly on Friday, 9 November 2001 written by the then federal Liberal candidate for Bendigo, Mr Maurie Sharkey. It states as part of his election platformâand remember that this is the 2001 election we are talking aboutâa `firm commitment to match dollar for dollar with the state government funding to complete the Calder to Bendigo by 2006'âwhich was the state government's time frame then.

Of course, this and other Calder Highway funding commitments from the coalition over the past four years are not worth the paper they are written on. The Howard government abandoned the Calder Highway at Kyneton and recklessly blew out the 2006 completion date it promised at the last election. There has been no new federal government money spent on the Calder Highway for over four years. It has disappeared from the Liberals' road map. The state government is the only government currently funding the two construction sites underway today. Now that the election is over the Howard government is still short changing us on the Calder Highway. The Liberalsâthe Liberal-Nationals that isâwill take up to 10 years to finish it, if they ever do. They have put only enough money for the Calder Highway in the five-year AusLink program to half finish the remaining 43 kilometres of the highway, and a miserable amount of just $12 million for this year. There is no finishing date for the final Faraday to Ravenswood section.

The Calder Highway Improvement Committee has admitted that the Liberals will take seven to eight years to finish the road and it has branded this as `ludicrous'. Nobody in Bendigo trusts the Liberals or The Nationals any more. During the 2001 election campaign Treasurer Costello promised to keep up the duplication of the Calder Highway, but all he duplicated was road taxes. And now he has duplicated some of the worthless throwaway promises that he ditched after the last election. Labor stated time and time again in the months leading up to the last election and to the AusLink announcement that the Howard government would allocate a funding amount for the Calder Highway just to get them through the federal election. That is precisely what they have done by allocating $114 million over five years in the July AusLink statement when the amount required from the Commonwealth to complete the project is $193 million.

The Treasurer made the Calder Highway funding announcement in Geelong, which is nowhere near the Calder Highway. Apparently, the city of Geelong was about as close a city to Bendigo as the Treasurer was game enough to show up in. He also announced with a throwaway line in his media conference an extra $82 million to be available in the next five-year AusLink plan. Nothing in any of the AusLink information available at that time mentioned the additional $82 million. The minister responsible, Mr Anderson, never mentioned it. It was just another Treasurer Costello promise. However, that figure has very recently been added in a two line statement to the Department of Transport and Regional Services AusLink website. Then, as we got closer to the election announcement, the former and current junior roads ministers, Senator Ian Campbell and Mr Jim Lloyd, both stated that they would bring the $82 million forward into this five-year AusLink allocation if required. Apparently, they can just pluck $82 million out of the air to get them through an election campaign. It again begs the question: are these real dollars or are they Khemlani dollars? The fact that there are no forward estimates for the next AusLink five-year plan has conveniently escaped them. If they can pluck $82 million out of the air just to get them through an election why can they not pluck the full $193 million out of the air and finish the project within this five-year plan? That is the state government's time frame, but only if the Howard government honours its promises.

It is little wonder that the government ministers could not stay far enough away from Bendigo during the 2004 election campaign. Just one junior minister crept into the region and managed a short visit to Bendigo during the six-week campaign. The Prime Minister; Deputy Prime Minister; Treasurer; Minister for Health and Ageing; Minister for Education, Science and Training; and all of the other government ministers squibbed it because they know the depth of feeling Bendigo voters have against the coalition and its shoddy treatment of central Victoria. They did not have the courage to face the voters of Bendigo. There was little mention of the Calder Highway during the election campaign and now, in an attempt to slime out of some of its election commitments, the coalition has adopted the same old tactic of shifting the blame onto the states. As always, there will be plenty of supporters and government apologists to peddle the rubbish that the states are responsible for the delays involved in these projects.

Reports in the Bendigo media by journalist Anthony Radford have highlighted the enormous economic benefit that would flow on if the Calder Highway project is completed. More than $400 million would be injected into Bendigo's economy each year if the Calder Highway duplication was completed. Commissioned by Calder Highway lobby group Bendigo Plus, this study, and the ensuing report, also found that the flow-on effect of the economic boost would create some 2,731 jobsâalmost nine per cent of the present work force. The report, written by principal research fellow at La Trobe University's Bendigo Centre for Sustainable Regional Communities, Mr Ian Pinge, identified Bendigo's manufacturing sector as one of the main beneficiaries of a new highway, with output tipped to jump by $212 million.

The subsequent effect of that growth alone was expected to be worth almost $210 million. The report predicts that cultural and recreational services would increase output by some $14.5 million, with a flow-on effect of more than $13 million. Accommodation, cafes and restaurants were also expected to benefit by $7.4 million, with a flow-on effect worth $7.5 million if the duplication was completed. Almost 900 manufacturing jobs would be directly created from the duplication, creating another 1,450 subsequent jobs from the flow-on effect. More than 130 jobs were expected to be created in the cultural and recreation services sector and almost 90 in the accommodation and food sector. The job figures were based on 50 per cent of the present difference between the sectors in Bendigo and Ballarat. Mr Pinge said Ballarat was chosen as a comparison because it had similar population and work force figures. It was also a similar distance from Melbourne and had a four-lane highway. In his report, Mr Pinge was quoted as saying the figures may well be even higher. He said:

quote.para: The final figures must be seen as conservative because only half of the employment differences in sectors including manufacturing have been attributed to road access.

speech.para: He went on:

quote.para: Benefits will be higher when the effects on all areas benefiting from the duplication of the Calder freeway are taken into account.

speech.para: The Calder Highway between Kyneton and Ravenswood would have to be one of the most dangerous sections of road in Australia. Last week, we witnessed yet another fatal accident on a non-duplicated section of the highway. When will this government throw in the towel, stop deliberately avoiding its own election commitments and allocate the required amount of funds to finish the project within five years? The coalition has been defeated in three successive federal elections in the always marginal electorate of Bendigo, with its dishonest treatment of the Calder Highway construction being one of the main contributing factors. It is time the coalition stopped playing dangerous games and honoured its commitments to central Victoria.

talk.start.para: âI am very pleased to follow the member for Bendigo in speaking on theAusLink (National Land Transport) Bill 2004, because alongside the member for Bendigo I feel pretty angry about the treatment of our regional communities by this government under AusLink, and about the way road funding projects in our district have been treated under AusLink during the election. We also feel pretty angry about some of the untruths that were told during the election campaign about what AusLink was going to deliver to our communities, because the reality is very different.

speech.para: Roads are vital to our communities and to our economy. Coming from the regional electorate of Ballarat I know how important it is for regional economies and communities to have a comprehensive national strategy for our roads and highways. The adequacy of roads has a direct impact on the wellbeing and wealth of our regions and our nation. As members in this House are probably aware, the funding of national highways has been of particular concern to me since I became the member for Ballarat.

The Western Highway runs right through the heart of my electorate. It is the principle road link between Melbourne and Adelaide and it is the lifeblood of the state. Each day it carries more than 40,000 vehicles between Melbourne and Ballarat and up to 4,000 between Ballarat and the South Australian border. The highway connects regional centres through western and northern Victoria and plays a key role in linking more remote communities to regional hubs. In terms of freight the Western Highway is the second busiest national highway in Australia, second only to the Hume. With over five million tonnes of interstate freight movement annually, it carries around 4,000 commercial vehicles per day between Ballarat and Melbourne and over 1,000 per day between Ballarat and the South Australian border.

Freight movement along the Western Highway includes steel from Whyalla and Western Port; wool, meat, fruit and vegetables from Adelaide and Western Australia; grape juice and wine to and from South Australia; manufactured goods, particularly car components, from western Victoria to Adelaide and to my electorate in central Victoriaâthe list of goods goes on. When you consider that the government's forecasts estimate that from 2000 to 2020 non-bulk road freight will double and interstate road freight will multiply at an even greater rate, it becomes clear that we need a far reaching, coherent and comprehensive plan for our national transport network.

When the government released its AusLink white paper it promised to develop a strategic approach to our long-term future transport needs across the country. AusLink is the principle means by which the government will fund Australia's national transport infrastructure, and I welcome the additional funding that is contained within it. However, I am disappointed that AusLink and the Howard government have retreated from their responsibilities to fully fund national highways and have prepared the way for a disjointed, stagnating and highly politicised funding process.

Division 1 of the AusLink (National Land Transport) Bill 2004 has the potential to make funding captive to the electoral needs of the Howard government rather than the needs of the wider community. Division 1 provides the minister with considerable discretion. This potentially, given the Howard government's form on Regional Partnerships, enables the Howard government to target electorates on the basis of their marginâwhether they want to win them, whether they want to hold them or whether they owe favours to their National Party matesâwith funding throughout an election cycle. We are living in a time when taxpayers are demanding more value for their taxes and wanting greater transparency from their governments. It is therefore extraordinary that clause 11 of this bill does not even compel the minister to make a cost-benefit analysis on funding programs under AusLink. It is absolutely unbelievable that funding decisions are not going to be made on a cost-benefit basis. If we stopped the ordinary person in the street and asked whether they would give a large sum of money to a builder to do some work on their house, work which they could not quite specify and for which they had not done any economic analysis to see whether it would benefit the property owner or not, they would say, `You must be absolutely joking. That is a ridiculous way of spending money.' Unfortunately, the Howard government is not joking on this issue.

It is a matter of trust. Do you trust the Howard government not to play politics with federal road funding? After what we have seen with Regional Partnerships the answer has to be: absolutely not. My electorate has had firsthand experience of the Howard government putting political considerations above those of developing a consistent and coherent national transport network. The decision to fully fund the Geelong bypass over the Deer Park bypass in the midst of an election year is a perfect example of putting politics over the national interest. The Deer Park bypass of the Western Highway, a national highway, was fully the responsibility of the Commonwealth government and it had the highest cost-benefit ratio of any project in Victoria. Treasurer Costello in the 2001 election campaign acknowledged that it was the highest priority and said they would fund it immediately when funds become available. What had changed by 2004? Suddenly, the seat of Corangamite came into play; they were a bit nervous about it. Suddenly the Geelong bypass became the highest priority for the federal government.

As I have informed this place on a previous occasion, commuters in my electorate have been waiting for years for this government to commit the full $294 million required for the construction of the Deer Park bypass. Labor was prepared to step up to the plate and, despite the government's failure, we promised we would fully fund $294 million to build the Deer Park bypass. It is of great regret to me that, had we won the election, that road would have commenced by now. The start date under Labor was 2005-06âit would have started this year. We now see that this government's commitment is totally inadequate and we have not seen a single sod of dirt turned to get this road built.

The announcement that the Treasurer made in relation to AusLink only delivered $40 million for a $294 million project. On closer inspection, it is not only $40 million for a $294 million project but the project is not to start this year or next year but after the next federal election in 2007-08 and 2008-09, with no further commitments for funding given. The first statement of AusLink says that future funding will be sought from the state government. Then, in an extraordinary back flip in our local newspaper, after the state government said this was a national highway and was fully the responsibility of the Commonwealth to fund, we suddenly hear that they might find some money in future budgets. There is absolutely no statement within the AusLink white paper, no commitment or guarantee given, that any money other than the $40 million to come into play in 2007-08, after the next federal election, will even be given. Forty million dollars is not even enough to start doing the edges and the guttering around where the Deer Park bypass has to go. You cannot even start a $294 million project unless you know you have the money to finish it. Labor promised it during the election campaign. As I said, it is a great regret to me that we did not win, because we would have started building that road this year.

Like all announcements of the government, the devil was in the detailâ$40 million to commence a $294 million project which the government was 100 per cent responsible for building. The Deer Park bypass has been used as a political football by the Howard government, and AusLink does absolutely nothing to guarantee that we will have the funding to complete it, let alone actually get it started. This is a road, again, that had the highest cost-benefit ratio of any of the road projects in Victoria. It is unbelievable to me that the government was able to fully fund Geelong when Geelong was not even on the radar screen two years ago but was not able to fund Deer Park. The gaping funding gap that now exists for the Deer Park bypass is an example of the Howard government's failure to accept its responsibility for Australia's national land transport network. Gone is the Commonwealth's full responsibility for the construction and maintenance of the national highway network. There is $12 billion worth of road and rail projects and not a cost-benefit ratio to be found. To borrow a headline from the Australian Financial Review, this bill well and truly puts politics in the driving seat.

The Howard government has retreated from the 100 per cent funding of our national highways, and the inclusion of a project in the network does not mean that the community will receive its road. Our national highways will now have to rely on local councils and state governments to enter into partnerships, possibly with private companies, to build improvements to roads such as the Western Highway. This opens up the possibility of only being able to get our road finished and funded via a partnership that would essentially mean road tolls. I find it unbelievable that the government stands here and criticises the decision that tolls need to go on the Scoresby to get that road built when this bill opens up the possibility that the only way that communities along national highways will get the funding to get projects built is potentially via tolls. It is completely inconsistent policy on the part of the government.

The Howard government's idea of a partnership is drastically different from the conventional understanding of one. It is unclear how events will unfold. States have clearly been left out of the negotiations in developing the details of the land transport network and will now be asked to pick up the shortfall in funding. AusLink was parachuted onto the desks of state ministers and they were basically told to cop it or go away.

Under AusLink, projects are imposed on state governments with only a part-funding, scattergun approach from the Howard government. The states are left to pick up the tab for the remainder. AusLink has created more uncertainty than ever about how transport infrastructure is built and maintained. Professor Fred Affleck, Director of the Planning and Transport Research Centre at Monash University, gave a pretty balanced assessment of AusLink. He said:

quote.para: There is still a very large role for the States and Territories, local government and the private sector, which is clearly expected to take on an expanded role.

But there are still no agreed mechanisms for coordinating planning and implementation to join up the gaps between these four frames of the big picture of integration. This could be serious. The Commonwealth can't go it alone, or expect others to fill in the blanks it has left in this picture ...

speech.para: AusLink is not the grand national land transport plan that it purports to be. It is not a cooperative approach to transport infrastructure funding; it is buck-passing on a grand scale. State governments were largely ignored during the drafting of AusLink and now they are expected to do their bit. There are no longer clear lines of responsibility between the Commonwealth and state governments. Instead, we now have AusLink corridors with a freight focus imposed by Canberra with a take it or leave it funding arrangement attitude for state and local governments.

What is required for our national infrastructure is exactly what the government is not delivering. The starting point should be the establishment of a national advisory committee with the states and territories, comprising consumers and experts. This process would be inclusive and open and would also ensure that cost-benefit analyses are done on the road projects to be funded. Again, while I welcome the additional $1.053 billion of funding, I am concerned that the Howard government has further politicised an already political process. The lack of cooperation with the state governments may lead to many projects being delayed or, even worse, cancelled altogether. More generally, I feel the Howard government is showing signs of increasing arrogance and contempt. The government is becoming increasingly secretive and more political when developing public policy of this nature.

Sometimes politicians can forget the very real effect their decisions can have on the people out there trying to raise a family or get to work each day. I received an email this morningâit was a pretty timely one and one not solicited by meâfrom a constituent who had just driven down the Western Highway to work. She is one of the commuters who commute from my electorate each day to Melbourne. She was extremely angry about the decision of the Howard government to fund the Geelong bypass at the expense of the Deer Park bypass. The email reads:

quote.para: Dear Catherine, it was with amusement I saw on the news last night that the Geelong Bypass is going to be funded. Yet again âthe havesâ win over âthe have notsâ. As I was driving down the western highway today I felt reasonably resentful, that there may never be a deer park bypass. I have even considered taking the sticker off my car. I don't know why I am even having a reaction of course little Johnny is going to look after his mates first. This is an obvious sign of things to come. The only joy I will get out of the next three years is when people realise what a dictator this man is, to be able to point and say but you voted for him did you not! Good luck Catherine ... Keep those people accountable please. Regards Liz

speech.para: I certainly intend to keep the government accountable and I certainly intend to keep the government accountable about the Deer Park bypass. Not a day will go by when I will not raise this issue either in my local media or in the House. This is a vital piece of infrastructure for these communitiesânot just for Ballarat but for all the communities along the Western Highway from the South Australian border all the way to Melbourne. It is the second busiest freight route in the country and it is ridiculous that a project of this nature could not have been funded by the government.

During the election campaign we had that rather pathetic announcement by the government of $40 million after the next federal electionâin 2007-08âto commence the Deer Park bypass. The AusLink plan, as I said, originally said that the state governments had to find the shortfall of funding. States have budgets too. Suddenly, for a $294 million project that had been the full responsibility of the Commonwealth to fund, because they had responsibility for national highways, the state governments were told, `Well, you're going to have to make up the shortfall if this road is going to get built.' Quite rightly, the Victorian Minister for Transport said that the state government could not assist the Commonwealth to build a road that was 100 per cent a Commonwealth responsibility, and that, whilst it was a major priority for the state government, it had not been on their budget because it was a national highway for which the Commonwealth had responsibility.

After the state government said, `We can't fund this road; it is your responsibility to fund it,' in an absolute backflip we then had the roads minister saying, `Well, we won't seek funding from the state government'âdespite the fact that that is exactly what this bill requiresâ`but it will be subject to future Commonwealth budgets; we'll think about it as we go along.' So, one day the Deer Park bypass was the responsibility of the Commonwealth; the next day it suddenly became Commonwealth-state, then the Commonwealth said, `We'll take over responsibility for it again.' On the day of the announcement of AusLink we had the Treasurer grinning down in Geelong. He would not have dared to come near my seat or that of the member for Bendigo.

I have to say I think the Liberal candidates for both Ballarat and Bendigo made an incredible mistake by going down to Geelong for the announcement to watch the roads and their communities basically get dudded, and by being photographed beside a grinning Treasurer dudding the communities of Ballarat and Bendigo. He would not have dared come near the community of Ballarat at that point, because we were furious, and the reaction from the Ballarat community and from the Western Highway Action Committee, which represents all the councils along the Western Highway, was immediate. We said to the government very clearly: `This is not a promise; you have dudded us with this. This is absolutely not what we were expecting.' Labor came to the party a week later and said: `We're not going to muck around with this. We're not going to drag this out any more. We're going to put our cards on the table. This road is too important to play politics with. We're going to fund it fullyâ100 per cent, $294 millionâto start this financial year.' As I said, unfortunately that has not been a reality.

The reaction of the community was huge; it was absolutely enormous. The front page of the Courier absolutely slammed the government for their decision. During this period of uncertainty by the government we saw a display of complete arrogance by the Liberal Party. The previous member for Ballarat, Michael Ronaldson, who is now a senator elect and will be coming to this place shortly, had the temerity to label the reaction of the local community. You have to remember that this is a project they had been working on for years and years and it suddenly got dudded when they thought they were just going to get over the line on it. The senator elect wrote a letter to the local Courier saying that the local reaction to the announcement was a `dummy spit' and that the community of Ballarat needed to grow up. That is unbelievable from a senator elect who is purporting to represent this area.

Senator elect Ronaldson called those who were objecting to the inadequate decision `rank amateurs'âwhat an affront to the Western Highway Action Committee, who have been fighting for this project for years and who have been very careful to be apolitical in their approach. But they know when they are being sold a dud and it was absolutely incumbent upon themâand they are not all of my political persuasion, I can absolutely guarantee thatâto raise this issue publicly. They raised it publicly, they expressed their anger and Senator elect Michael Ronaldson said to them in the local newspaper, `You're having a dummy-spit and you're rank amateurs.' It was a complete affront to the Western Highway Action Committeeâall of those local mayors down in that area who represent the constituencies along that highwayâand to all the commuters from Ballarat, Bacchus Marsh, Gordon and Ballan.

If the experience of the Deer Park bypass is anything to go by then AusLink will do nothing to assure that the construction of this bypass will happen. In fact, it will make it even less likely that it will happen. I say to all those communities, rural and regional, who live along a national highway: take a good look at what this bill has done in terms of your road funding project for national highways. It has put an enormous burden on you as a local community through your council and an enormous burden on your state governments to fund road projects along national highways, a burden that should rightly be the responsibility of the Commonwealth government, because, after all, you would think that the Commonwealth government should have the responsibility for the national highway network between our major capital cities. The Western Highway is the major highway between Melbourne and Adelaide and is the second busiest freight route, but this bill absolutely duds all the communities along the Western Highway, and it makes the Deer Park bypass even less of a reality.

talk.start.para: âThe AusLink (National Land Transport) Bill 2004 before the parliament today is dedicated to implementing the government's long-awaited AusLink strategy, the land transport strategy that is designed to provide the framework for the government's involvement in road and rail and the future infrastructure needs in these two very important transport sectors. It is, in fact, a rather large blueprint for even more National Party pork-barrelling and it is setting a framework for the government into the future to even further politicise the use of infrastructure spending, particularly road funding, for the purpose of entrenching the government's position in marginal, regional seats.

speech.para: In spite of the fact that we have a long overdue national land transport plan being presented to the parliament, there are major deficiencies with the proposals that the government is putting forward that really do need to be addressed. There are some good aspects to the AusLink strategy; in particular, the step being taken towards much greater mode neutrality between road and rail is an extremely important step for our nation. For too long we have had a tug of war between road and rail, usually at the expense of rail, and, particularly when it comes to a rational freight strategy for our nation, there have been inadequate answers and strategies for these challenges for far too long. So it is good to see that we are taking major steps towards neutrality of funding and neutrality of planning and strategy with respect to road and rail.

There are major weaknesses in our interstate road network, but there are still enormous problems with our interstate rail network. In spite of the many fantasies that have been floated from time to time about great new projects of national vision, such as very fast trains, there is still no question that the primary task in rail transport in this country is to bring our national network up to scratch to deal with some of the major gaps and some of the huge problems, particularly around Sydney, that have yet to be fully addressed.

In an era of growing crisis with respect to infrastructure all around Australia, this AusLink strategy fails the test of economic efficiency. It fails the test of rational allocation of scarce resources. It fails the test of objective criteria designed to ensure that scarce resources go to the areas of greatest need, where the cost-benefit ratios for the nation are at their highest.

The key element of this is that the government is withdrawing from the previous role established by the Hawke government in 1991 in its major reforms to land transport fundingâthat is, from the full funding and maintenance of the national highway system. That was a very important reform, for which credit belongs also to the then New South Wales Liberal government of Nick Greiner for supporting it. It was a very important reform in ensuring that some degree of rationality and economic efficiency emerged in our system of road funding in Australia. The government is taking a very important step towards unravelling that reform and diminishing the federal government's responsibility for the national highway system, in order to shift the focus more towards Roads of National Importance and road funding that is partly funded by the states.

The government is also introducing a discretionary fund for strategic regional projects. As recent events indicate, that is simply code for a slush fund that can be doled out, particularly prior to election campaigns, in order to assist National Party candidates to hold and to win marginal seats. It is entirely obvious what this particular component of the AusLink strategy is about. It is simply to enable further pork-barrelling by the National Party in particularâthe Liberal Party in some areas but mostly the National Partyâin order to maximise their political position. That might seem like a smart political strategy on the part of the government. It may even have some slight impact politicallyâwho knows? But it is bad for the nation. It is bad for the nation's economy. It is bad for our future as a society if scarce dollars are being misused, are being allocated for reasons other than need and for reasons other than economic efficiency and cost-benefit ratio analysis of road funding.

In my remarks, I want to focus on the infamous Roads of National Importance program, which was introduced in 1996 and which, as shadow transport minister, I dubbed the `roads of National Party importance', I think with every justification. In 1996, the Howard government introduced the new structure of road funding, which was predicated on substantial cuts in the projected budget for the national highway system and on the introduction of Roads of National Importance. That program was designed around the federal government going to the states and offering, fifty-fifty, to fund major road upgrades or new roads, based on the states submitting bids and the Commonwealth ultimately making the decision as to where the money would be dedicated.

Gradually, since that period, the proportion of road funding that has been allocated to Roads of National Importance has steadily increased. At the same time, the relative priority given to the national highway system has diminished. In the 1996-97 financial year, the allocation to Roads of National Importance was around $90 million, and by 2001-02 that amount had grown to $253 million. Over that period, there was a significant deterioration in the national highway commitment as well.

The criteria published by the Department of Transport and Regional Services with respect to Roads of National Importance are deliberately vague, very general, and they also unashamedly note that priority will be given to the fulfilment of the government's election commitments in determining whether or not a particular road should be funded. So not only do you start with a set of criteria that are so vague and general that almost any road could potentially qualify but also, quite explicitly, on top of those criteria, you have an acknowledgment that government election commitments will take priority in decisions about which road should be funded. In other words, forget about rational criteria, forget about economic efficiency, forget about the nation's infrastructure needs; the Howard government's approach to road funding is entirely politicised and deliberately intended to foster the prospects of candidates winning seats at the expense of a rational and economically efficient allocation of funding for the nation's infrastructure needs.

It is interesting to look over that period at the list of Roads of National Importance projects to see where the money has gone. An extraordinary preponderance of funding has gone to Queensland and New South Wales. It just so happens, of course, that the National Party is basically a two-state party these days. Guess which states? Queensland and New South Wales. It has two seats left in Victoria. When the incumbents of those seats move on, it is almost inevitable that the Liberal Partyâand possibly Labor, in the case of Gippslandâwill win those seats, and the National Party will be shrunk back to purely a two-state party. Of course, a very substantial proportion of these Roads of National Importance projects are in marginal National Party seats. There is a clear bias that shines through. When you add the criteria to the actuality of what has happened with the funding, you can see very clearly what is going on here. The road funding program of the Commonwealth is being used deliberately for political purposes.

There are some outstanding examples to illustrate how absurd the process of road funding has become. My favourite has always been Main Road 92, which has been allocated a decision as a road of national importance for something like six or seven years, but nothing has happened, for various reasons I will not go into. Perhaps the reason that nothing has happened is that the seat the road is in was once a marginal Liberal seat but has now become relatively secure, and therefore there is no longer any need to spend any money in it. Main Road 92 would have to be one of the less significant roads in Australiaâcertainly not the kind of road that you would expect should qualify for federal funding when you consider some of the major, vital, economic, arterial roads that do not qualify for federal funding and do not get Roads of National Importance funding. That is particularly so when you consider that the plan to upgrade Main Road 92âit is in the seat of Gilmore, which is south of Sydneyâexplicitly acknowledges that in some parts it will remain relatively narrow and winding and not particularly accessible. That is because of the incursion of a national park and because there is a historic bluestone wall there from the time when it was a major wool routeâa very long time ago, going back I think to 1856âand for these reasons it will not be possible to turn it into a seriously major road.

Once again you have a blatant pork-barrel exercise that was designed to improve the electoral prospects of the member for Gilmore, with no real connection to any serious sense of priorities about road funding or any real connection with the major economic interests of the nation. You can apply the same kind of assessment to other roads. The Mount Morgan to Kabra road in the seat of Hinkler, for example, is clearly a less significant road in economic terms than many other major arterial roads throughout the nation, yet it is on the Roads of National Importance list.

The overall picture is that the Howard government is relentlessly playing politics with infrastructure. It is ignoring cost-benefit ratios, which are a useful if not absolute guide to the likely economic value of investing in a particular road project as opposed to any other; it is ignoring economic efficiency; and it is ignoring the nation's needs. As a result, we are seeing the gradual accumulation of infrastructure problems and bottlenecks and the slow deterioration of our export performanceâall of which are eating away at Australia's medium-term economic prospects. This is partly because the Howard government focuses on playing politics with infrastructure spending.

The government is spending quite substantial amounts of money for inadequate returnsâroad funding being the classic example. It is all about ensuring that conservative members get to cut the ribbon and that conservative members are on the front page of the local paper with the upgrade or the new road; it is not about ensuring that the nation's needs are met or that the infrastructure needs of Australia are being addressed.

Meanwhile, when we do confront the question of our inadequate infrastructure performance in this nation, the response of the government is to attack state governments. The response of the Howard government is to say, `It is nothing really to do with us.' The fact is that our exports are deteriorating substantially. Our non-commodity exports of manufactured items and services in particular have deteriorated substantially since about the turn of the century. Over the past four or five years they have dropped substantially as a percentage of our total GDP.

When hit with this criticism, the Howard government answers that it is all the fault of state governments because they are in charge of infrastructure. That is wrong. The state governments in some cases will bear some responsibility, but it is the Howard government that has wasted so much money on so much frippery, on so much rubbish. Going back to the Centenary of Federation fund, the Natural Heritage Trust, Networking the Nation and in this case road funding, the government has wasted so much of taxpayers' money on things that are politically driven and deliver inadequate benefits for the nation and inadequate returns for our economy. Now the chickens are coming home to roost and road funding is one of those areas where it is occurring.

We have very serious infrastructure problems in Australia. We have had decades of neglect of our rail system, and some of those major problems are yet to be resolved. We have problems with the state and federal interface in rail, particularly with respect to New South Wales and Queensland. There has been some progress, but still we have no adequate solution.

Port connections with road and rail are inadequate in many cases. If you look at what has been happening in the road funding area, you will see instances such as the Pacific Highway upgrade, which, from memory, is due to finish in 2016. Clearly a higher priority should be given to that commitment to ensure that we have dual carriageway all the way between Sydney and Brisbane well before 2016. They are the kinds of problems we have, particularly in the transport end of infrastructure in Australia.

While those problems are languishing, while they are not being adequately addressed, the Howard government is frittering away money, time after time, on little pork-barrel projects, regional grants and Networking the Nation. All of these things are designed to make it look as though the government is actually doing something. They are designed to appeal to a few particular local interests and make them think that they are being looked after, while the nation's economy and its underpinning economic structure gradually deteriorate. That will come home to roost sooner than people anticipate.

There has been a complete lack of imagination with respect to dealing with the prospective role of public-private partnerships, which could be playing a much more significant role in dealing with the nation's infrastructure needs. The continuing use of federal-state tensions as an excuse for inaction or for failing to address the real problems in infrastructure is another scandal. It is always about buck-passing and blame shifting and never about tackling the nation's problems; it is just playing politics.

We cannot afford the inefficiencies that flow from these political indulgences anymore. Our economy is still ticking over at a good growth rate, but what we are not doing is setting in place the foundations for continuing strong future growth. As the capacity constraints that are now becoming obvious start to cut in, we will face a period of considerable economic pain in this country as we start to make major adjustments to the investments that should have been occurring over the past five to 10 years. They have not been occurring partly because a lot of the money that could have been dedicated to those kinds of investments has been frittered away in political pork-barrelling.

AusLink started life as a good idea. I acknowledge that substantial elements of this strategy are still worth supporting, especially the concept of integrating the national approach to road and rail. That is a very important first step. Inevitably it has potentially been corrupted by the Howard government's political games and use of pork-barrelling as a political strategy; nonetheless, it is a good first step. It is difficult to take further. We have to acknowledge that it is not easy to take that step further, particularly with the state-federal division and the inherent tension between road and rail; nonetheless, it is a very good start.

It is time that we moved beyond the lack of clear lines of responsibility and accountability and invested in projects that are of economic benefit to the nation. It is also time that we got genuinely serious about rail. I have concentrated mostly in my comments on the question of roads and Roads of National of Importance in particular, but I want to make a couple of observations about the role of rail in Australia.

About seven or eight years ago, early in the Howard government, we had what was then advertised as a giant rail reform program put forward by the Howard government. This involved privatising Australia National, selling different components of it, integrating the track with the Australian Rail Track Corporation and various other things. This was trumpeted as a $2 billion rail reform program. The inevitably gullible media swallowed this slogan whole. In fact, the amount of new spending involved was roughly $50 million, not $2 billion. The $2 billion figure included such absurdities as counting the fact that the Commonwealth had to take on board about $800 million worth of superannuation liabilities from Australia National, which it would have always been implicitly liable for in any event.

For many, many years, the rail sector in this country has been characterised by dilapidated track, speed restrictions in many areas, inability to double-stack containers, substantial delays and overall poor efficiency. Some progress has been made, and there have been some positive consequences of the changes that the Howard government made seven or eight years ago. For example, the time of the overland between Melbourne and Adelaide has diminished significantly. That has had a positive impact on patronage, and that is a good thing. There are still significant problems on the Melbourne to Brisbane legâparticularly dealing with congestion in Sydneyâand, although the ARTC has done a difficult job very well, there are still major areas that need to be addressed. If we are serious about rail reform, transport reform and fixing the infrastructure problems that are starting to bedevil our economy, fixing rail has to be a very high priorityânot flirting with projects of national vision, like steel equivalents of canals, very fast trains and all the other kinds of things that occasionally surface, but just getting the existing network up to scratch, economically efficient and doing a good job. Some progress has been made, but there is a lot more to be done.

The AusLink concept has been good initially, but it needs to be separated from misuse: misuse through petty party politics, misuse through pork-barrelling and misuse by National Party candidates in particular being seen to be delivering the goods to their local areas irrespective of the overall economic needs of the nation. Australia is more dependent on land transport than most countries. It is time we had genuine, rigorous reform and genuine investment in the projects that will improve the overall performance of the network and the overall economic outcomes that we all depend upon from our land transport networkânot more short-term political gains. There is a big challenge for Labor in dealing with these issues, because we will have to clean up the mess. We will be the ones who have to get rigour, economic efficiency and objectivity into the funding of the nation's land transport infrastructure in the wake of the politically driven mess that is being created by the Howard government.

talk.start.para: âI rise to comment upon the AusLink (National Land Transport) Bill 2004 and AusLink (National Land TransportâConsequential and Transitional Provisions) Bill 2004 and to reflect upon the motives that have driven the government to allocate money in the way they have over the last term and beyond. It seems to me, and it has been reflected in comments by my Labor colleaguesâincluding two former shadow ministers for transport and the current shadow minister for transportâthat AusLink as a notion is something worth supporting. However, there has not been the political will by the government to properly fulfil the notion in practice.

speech.para: I am happy to rise after the contributions by the members for Ballarat and Bendigo, because their electorates share with mine concerns with the Deer Park bypass, which is attached to the Western Highway. The member for Ballarat raised the issue of the Western Highway being properly attended to. The Western Highway runs all way through my electorate, and the other important transport spine in Victoria, the Calder, runs from Bendigo through my electorate down to Melbourne. Those two important highways in Victoria have indeed been neglected. Whilst there have been some winners as a result of the AusLink program announced by the Deputy Prime Minister before the election, there are definitely some losers. Unfortunately, the constituents of Gorton, Ballarat and Bendigo are amongst those losers. I rise to express disappointment on behalf of the many thousands of people who will continue to be inconvenienced as a result of the lack of commitment to construct the Deer Park bypass in western Melbourne.

To explain for those who do not know how important it is to that region, as the member for Ballarat has indicated, the Deer Park bypass was a critical piece of infrastructure that would allow for proper travel between not only Ballarat and Melbourne through my electorate but also Melbourne and Adelaideâa very important transport link indeed. As indicated earlier in the debate, it carries the second largest amount of freight after the Hume Highway and has enormous traffic in terms of both freight and commuters. With respect to the concerns that are raised in my electorate in terms of the need for the Deer Park bypass, we have major congestion and safety issues. In Deer Park, Caroline Springs, Burnside and those suburbs, the Western Highway in peak hour effectively converts to a car park. The movement of traffic slows to a crawl for a couple of hours in the morning and the late afternoon as a result of that congestion. If anyone understands the growth corridors of Melbourne in the westâand it is my hope that the government doesâthey will know this ensures that these problems will be compounded, because my electorate and a little beyond my region is the fastest growing area of Victoria. We have suburbs like Caroline Springs that did not exist six years ago, and now 15,000 people live there. There is exponential growth in those areas along the Western Highway, as there has been for some time along the Calder, which really demands some attention in the area of transport.

These areas are not wealthy areas; they are home to decent hard working Australians who deserve to get their fair allocation of transport resources as much as anyone else and more so now because they have been neglected for so long. I am sick and tired of seeing the government worry about the marginals; they might want to start worrying about the marginalised. The constituents of my electorate have felt marginalised in many services. Transport is top of the heap when it comes to the important things that the Commonwealth could do for my electorate.

As indicated earlier, Labor had given a commitment to fund fully the $294 million required to commence the construction of the Deer Park bypass. That would have commenced possibly later this year. Certainly, there was a commitment to commence it in the next 12 months or so and we would have had some idea when that important transport infrastructure would be complete. As it is now, the government has given an undertaking to put up $80 million of that $294 million, but with no time frame for the balanceâthe almost 75 per cent moreârequired to fund the Deer Park bypass. So it is not just a question of Labor committing to the bypass and the government committing to a later date. The commitment we made was that we would build it. Unfortunately, I cannot give any guarantee to my constituents that it will ever be built whilst this government is in office. That disappoints me because there is a dire need and it will be an increasing need as the population grows in the region. I hope the government attends to that quickly.

As was also indicated, I think by the member for Ballarat, it was amazing how quickly the government responded to the need for the Geelong bypass. No-one doubts the concerns that Geelong has and the need for that bypass but independent commentators and third-party authorities on transport in Victoria or indeed nationallyâevery authority that I have come acrossâindicate that the Western Highway was the priority for Victoria. What we saw was the Treasurer and the Prime Minister playing politics over public policy. We saw them putting the interests of the country ahead of the efficiencies and the transport needs to strengthen our economy. We saw them putting those priorities behind the electoral needs of the government. That is something, I think, that people are sick and tired of.

With respect to the Calder, there are some works, which are as important but far less expensive, that the government has failed to commit to. As the member for Bendigo has indicated we still have not seen the completion of the freeway from Melbourne to Bendigo. He is quite right to raise in this place again the concerns of those people in Bendigoâindeed, of anyone between Bendigo and Melbourne and beyond who uses the highway to get to and from their home, place of business and so on. He has raised those concerns. I would like to raise a number of concerns that impact directly upon my electorate.

There are a couple of unsafe intersections that cut across the Calder in Taylors Lakes and in Keilor. Robertsons Road was never meant to intersect with a freeway but it currently intersects with the Calder. As a result, we have had many fatalities and injuries at that intersection that should not have occurred. What was supposed to occur was that two other roads, Sunshine Avenue and Kings Road, were to have proper intersections so that people could safely exit and enter the freeway. As a result of the money not being forthcoming from the Commonwealth, we have not seen any work on those intersections. There is no doubt in my mind that we have seen tragic fatalities as a consequence.

Only last week, I met with a local who lives on Robertsons Road. His house is the closest house to the intersection with the Calder. He has had to come out on numerous occasions to find absolute carnage as a result of completely avoidable accidents if the Commonwealth were doing its job. He has found injured and deceased travellers as a result of that very dangerous intersection that abuts the Calder. It is indeed a RONI. I have to say that the member for Bendigo was correct when he said there are RONIs and RONIs-come-lately. The RONIs-come-latelyâthat is, those that sit in other perhaps marginal electorates that the government is interested inâseem to get attention before the ones with most need. In relation to these intersections on the Calder, I have written to the state government to ask for its assistance in ensuring the construction of safe intersections for Sunshine Avenue and Kings Road. The state government has given a commitment to half fund that work.

Originally I sought, as should be the case, full funding for those intersections, but now I seek funding to match the state government funding for those intersections. They are critical and the failure to construct these proper intersections is causing fatalities and injuries. The sum of money in transport costs is infinitesimal when compared with the tragedy that besets the families of these victims as a result of the failure of governments to respond.

I have had a commitment from the Victorian state government to fix the Kings Road interchange and associated access interchanges and to pay half the cost. What I ask of the federal governmentâand I will be seeking a meeting with the Minister for Local Government, Territories and Roads to talk about this critical issueâis to have the Commonwealth match the state government funding so that we can prevent any further unnecessary fatalities. I am not suggesting that transport accidents will not occur as a result of the improvementsâof course they will. People make errors but they are more likely to make errors that lead to death or injury when roads are unsafe. I can assure you that living where I do very close to those intersectionsâI use them almost every day when I am in my electorateâthey are unsafe and they are causing injury and death. The amount of money required to fix them is not large. It is therefore a travesty to see the constituents of my electorate treated in such a shabby manner and with such obvious disregard for the western suburbs of Melbourne. I beseech the government to respond to my concerns on this matter.

I hope that the government does reconsider the way it allocates its resources in the area of transport. There must be some capacity for governments to allocate money based on need and on the importance of the transport link and to try to remove the politics that goes on in this area. I know there is a great temptationâand other speakers have raised the issue of money coming from nowhere all of a suddenâto fund the transport needs of a marginal seat, but that is just not good enough. The constituents of my electorate deserve as much support as any others, and it should not be based on their margin as a voting body. It must be based on their needs. It must be based on the economic needs of the nation in the macro sense and certainly it should be based on removing danger and increasing the safety of travel at the local level. That seems to be a failing that I have witnessed. I do not pretend to be an expert in transport, but I do know, however, that the western suburbs of Melbourne have been in receipt of very little money from this government.

When third parties like VicRoads and the RACV have mentioned the absolutely dire need for improvements to the Calder Freeway and to the Western Highway, it has fallen on deaf ears. I ask the government to reconsider the way it has applied the funding to date; otherwiseâand I do not like to dramatise these things but there is no doubt in my mindâthere will be deaths that will be attributable to the failure of Commonwealth policy, or indeed any government's policy, where the needs of traffic users have been put second to the electoral interests of the government, which has the power to make decisions to allocate resources. To me there is something quite immoral about the capacity for decision makers to think that their electoral interests are more important than those of people who need improved safety on the roads. I ask the government to reconsider those things. I hope there can be a mechanism, as the member for Melbourne said, by which we can allocate resources on an efficient and economic basis rather than on one that is perceived to be a pork-barrelling basis. We are a vast country with a small population. We cannot afford to waste our limited dollars on an approach that is inefficient and not based on need.

talk.start.para: âI rise to speak on the AusLink (National Land Transport) Bill 2004 and the AusLink (National Land TransportâConsequential and Transitional Provisions) Bill 2004. I want to add my voice to the many we have heard in the parliament on these very important bills, and in particular I want to give my support to the comments of the member for Wills, who has responsibility for the carriage of this bill for the opposition. I concur with his second reading amendment, which asks the House to call upon the government to:

speech.para: (1) maintain funding responsibility for construction and maintenance of infrastructure on what was formerly defined as the National Highway Network;
(2) establish a National Infrastructure Advisory Council; and
(3) extend the criteria for Roads to Recovery projects to include public transport, cycling, walking infrastructure and regional airport runwaysâ.

It is important to note Labor's view of these bills. We agree with the fundamental principle that the Commonwealth government needs to play a role in Australia's future land transport needs. It needs to do that using a coordinated approach and with a long-term commitment to those issues. We also need to have an approach that is based on commonsense and good planning. However, what we have seen is AusLink, proposed by the Howard government, which is nothing of the sort. AusLink is woefully inadequate. The government should be turning its full attention to the national land transport plan, and there is a lot of evidence that points to that need. If we look at the economic figures and data, at what the Treasurer has been saying in the last few weeks, at comments by the Reserve Bank of Australia and at reports by the OECD and so forth, we see that they point to a need for Australia to invest in the future through infrastructure. There is this great need because of the lack of spending on infrastructure over recent decades.

AusLink is not a nation building piece of legislation. In fact it is not in this nation's best interest to carry out all or some of the parts contained in it. It is in essence a pork-barrelling exercise in the finest traditions of this government and in particular of the National Party. You will not get any arguments from the National Party members about that actually being the case because they will often tell you how proud they are of their initiatives in this area. Above all it is a national disgrace, and the people of Australia deserve better from the national government. It should represent all people in all electorates, regardless of state boundaries or local government boundaries. If it is truly to be a nationally significant programâand it is often referred to by the Deputy Prime Minister as being somewhat equivalent to the Snowy Mountains Schemeâthen it truly should be national. It should be based on principles of fairness and equity, on principles of delivering for this country's future.

If you were to take a map and colour code that map to show where funding will actually be going, if you were to take a green pen, a red pen and a blue pen and started highlighting where money will be going, you would find very little red and you would find a little bit of blue but you would find a hell of a lot of green in all the National Party areas. Instead of getting some national leadership from the government on some agreed priorities we see a piece of legislation that seeks to achieve what the government believe are political objectives, which is an agreement between the Liberal and National parties. The allocation of funds, rather than being based on sound principles of a nation's need, is based on the old-fashioned principles of pork-barrelling.

The Australian Labor Party, on the other hand, has a long tradition of delivering great outcomes in respect of the nation's infrastructure needs. The Australian Labor Party also has a long tradition of ensuring growth and productivity for the Australian economy. You would not have to look too far in recent weeks to hear the talk about strong economic growthâ14 consecutive years of economic growth. That economic growth has not been built in the last nine years, when this government has been in, but was actually delivered and built upon for the future by the Hawke and Keating governments during the 1980s and the 1990s. I feel we have not spoken enough about this, and the Labor Party is not given credit for it. Those tough economic reforms and decisions made under those two governments, the Hawke and Keating governments, have paved the way for future governments, in particular the Howard government, to be able to enjoy the fruits of that economic reform, to enjoy the economic good times that it now has. Nobody with a commonsense approach could possibly say that 14 consecutive years of economic growth were somehow delivered miraculously in the last few years by this government. They were not. The foundations and the grounding were built during the eighties and the nineties.

What concerns me more than the historic perspective is the failure of this government to do something constructive and positive with those 14 consecutive years of economic growth. It has failed to invest in our future. It has failed to invest in infrastructure. It has failed to invest fully to capitalise on those reforms undertaken by past Labor governments, to take those steps that we needed to take to ensure our prosperity. AusLink certainly comes up short and it highlights the failure of the federal government to deliver some national leadership and some genuine policy.

Adding some more weight to what I have been saying about the economic growth that we have enjoyed and the concerns that are being felt now was the release late last week of the OECD economic survey of Australia, confirming that the government has been complacent about our economic future. The OECD's report card on Australia shows that economic reform under the Howard government has stalledâthere has not actually been any. The government has gone to sleep at the wheel. The report highlights the failure of the government to invest in our nation's road and rail infrastructure, hence the need for this AusLink program to put some money back. As the Deputy Prime Minister will tell you, it is a bit over $11 billion. It is $11 billion not enough and it is $11 billion too late. We need more investment and we need that investment to happen quickly. Also just a few days ago the Reserve Bank of Australia highlighted the skill shortages and infrastructure bottlenecks that are hindering the future economic growth of our nation. These problems are again a direct result of the federal government's complacency and failure to plan for the future, to do something with those good economic times that the government is so proud of.

Unlike the government, Labor refuse to take our future economic prosperity for granted, and that is why we are proposing a number of amendments to this legislation which I highlighted at the outset of my speech. Many of you in this place will have heard me talk about the Ipswich Motorway, because it is a piece of road vital to Queensland's economic future and particularly important to the south-east of Queensland. It happens to go through the middle of my electorate as well. I will say something about that. Just because a road goes through somebody's electorate, it does not necessarily mean that it belongs to that electorate. It just happens to be geographically positioned there. It belongs to all of the people of south-east Queensland. It is important for the economies of Brisbane, Ipswich and Toowoomba, to further up north and west, towards Warwick and so on. That road is the vital link, the only link. It is the lifeline between a whole range of not only cities but major regional centres as well. So my concern and my desire to see this road fully upgraded is not just about my own backyard, though I certainly want to see some improvements there as well. It is about ensuring that the south-east of Queensland, the highest growth region in Australia, is catered for and looked after by the federal government. We all know about the serious neglect.

I want to put on the record quickly some issues which highlight the overall problem with road funding as well as some details about the Ipswich Motorway and the potential for a so-called northern bypass, which is a half bypass that would skirt around the Ipswich Motorway. Since it came to power in 1996, the government has completely turned its back and walked away from a whole range of federally funded national roads and highways. It has walked away from the people in those areas, not just in my electorate but in all manner of electorates.

And with each year that has passed the task has become more difficult.
