talk.start.para: âI have received a letter from the honourable member for Wills proposing that a definite matter of public importance be submitted to the House for discussion, namely:

quote.para: The Howard Government's maladministration of the Regional Partnerships Program

interjection.para: I call upon those members who approve of the proposed discussion to rise in their places.

para.inline: More than the number of members required by the standing orders having risen in their placesâ

talk.start.para: âI want to say at the outset that the Leader of the House indicated in his response in relation to our censure motion that the opposition were estopped from criticising Regional Partnerships grants because we did not oppose them during the election campaign period. Let me say in response that essentially we were had and the Australian people were had. We were given the impression that there was an orderly, independent process of assessment of these applications and that these grants were being made pursuant to that due process. Subsequently, the truth has come out that applications were approved without an application even being lodged. Applications were approved without the support or recommendation of the local area consultative committee. Applications were approved for projects which were in competition with other, private sector projectsâthe doctrine of competitive neutrality was being flouted. Applications were approved in circumstances where there was such a flagrant conflict of interest that a representative of the applicants was working as a staffer in the minister's officer. So, all over the place, we have come across unsatisfactory, inappropriate, improper aspects of administration of this program, and we intend to criticise them. It would be irresponsible of us to do anything less than that.

speech.para: The other thing that the minister said by way of response to some of our concerns about Regional Partnerships was the claim that a similar number of applications from Labor electorates were successful compared to the number coming from Liberal and National Party electorates. Let me assure the House that the only reason there is any substance to that is that there is a very low number of applications coming forward from Labor electorates compared with those coming from Liberal and National Party electorates. The reason for that is that Regional Partnerships has essentially been operated as a secret society. I invite members on my side of the House to indicate to me just what advice they received from the government about the existence of this scheme. It was a scheme whereby the government appointed the chairs of the area consultative committeesâthey appointed their fellow committee membersâand then set about assessing applications. Many of those applications have been essentially inside jobs. This is a program for those in the know. We have seen it degenerate into a $150 million pork barrel administered by the Leader of the National Party himself.

We are indebted to the Independent member for New England for first blowing the whistle in relation to this arrangement. He had the temerity to think that there might be some Regional Partnerships money for projects in his electorateâfor example, the Tamworth Equine and Livestock Centreâand the message came back from the government: `No, we're not going to fund that project while the Independent member for New England is associated with it.' Their idea was that the purpose of this program was to benefit the National Party. So, if the Independent member for New England was associated with it, it certainly was not achieving its purpose at all. So they had to get rid of him. When we asked Minister Anderson about this, he said that the reason that they had demanded that the name of the Independent member for New England be removed from the application was that they did not want the program to be political.

talk.start.para: âYes, astonishingâa great sense of irony! When we started examining this program we found, as I have indicated to the House, applications being approved prior to applications being lodged, applications falling over and applications being approved despite the advice of the department. The Senate Finance and Public Administration References Committee discovered in its hearings last week that principally Minister Kelly had departed from departmental recommendations not to approve a project and had decided to approve projects on 11 occasions. On a further three occasions she had given the projects 100 per cent of the funding sought, when the department had recommended less. On a further three occasions, where the department had recommended that a project be approved, she had not approved the project. The Auditor-General has made plain in his investigation of previous programs that he believes that where this happens there needs to be a paper trail, that the reasons for the departure from the departmental recommendation need to be given and that those reasons need to be made public.

speech.para: It is extraordinary that this government refuses to make public the reasons for those decisions and departures. Indeed, this government refuses to make public the recommendations from the area consultative committees. That makes a joke of the whole process of independent assessment. It makes a farce of the whole idea of public accountabilityâwhere the government goes before the Senate committee and says, `No, we are not prepared to tell you what the area consultative committee has recommended,' and, when it suits the government, it will say, `Oh, this project was recommended by the area consultative committee.' But it is not prepared to make available to the House and to the people of Australia the totality of recommendations coming forward from area consultative committees about these projects.

The other comment I would like to make about this idea that 78 per cent of projects have been approved is that it is almost an `everyone's a winner' situation. Some honourable members will remember the Centenary of Federation projects. All of us, as local members, had the capacity to go out and seek applications. I do not know what the general arrangement was, but in my electorate we ended up funding six or seven applications but knocking back 40 or 50, so it was not an `everyone's a winner' situation. There were many more applications than could be successful grants. But Regional Partnerships has been a program for those in the know and as a result there has been a relative scarcity of applications. It has not been advertised in the newspapers, on radio or on TV. Opposition members have not been informed of the nature of it; it has been kept in-house.

Since my speech in parliament before Christmas on this issue we have learned details of a further project where good money was thrown after bad. Some $660,000 of taxpayers' money was given to the Beaudesert Shire Railway Support Group through the Regional Partnerships program in a circumstance where Beaudesert Rail had gone into receivership back in May 2003. That did not stop this government committing a further $660,000 to get Beaudesert Rail out of receivership. But we know that this project is not happening, even though Beaudesert Rail came out of receivership late last year with creditors receiving just 19 cents in the dollar. I understand that this project ceased operating in August this year and is subject to continuing legal action by creditors. Taxpayers are entitled to much more prudent stewardship of their money than this.

Today we have seen a situation which just about takes the cake in terms of Regional Partnerships worst practice. Back in July and August 2004 the government announced two Regional Partnerships program grants totalling $1.5 million to facilitate dredging of Tumbi Creek, located at The Entrance in the marginal electorate of Dobell. Those grants, announced by the local member for Dobell and by the Prime Minister, were to fund the dredging of the mouth of Tumbi Creek and the relocation of spoil to the municipal tip. We matched the government's funding commitment during the 2004 election campaign. We were told this project had been approved under Regional Partnerships. We assumed that it had been properly assessed, so why wouldn't we support it? Like all other Australians, we have been misled in relation to this matter.

The member for Dobell announced the first Regional Partnerships grant of $748,000 on 8 June. That announcement preceded Wyong Shire Council's consideration of a dredging options report and a decision to lodge an application under the Regional Partnerships program. The Daily Telegraph Central Coast extra edition on 9 June last year carried this report:

quote.para: Federal member for Dobell, Ken Ticehurst, yesterday committed the money to pay for 15,000 cubic metres of spoil to be dredged and dumped at Buttonderry Tip near Wyee under the Regional Partnerships program. Wyong Shire Council will meet tonight to decide how best to deal with the Tumbi Creek problem and whether or not to apply for the funding.

speech.para: What a bizarre process. How can the member for Dobell be saying that Minister Kelly has approved this project when Minister Kelly has not even seen an application? She has approved the grant; now all we need is the application. That reminds me of the Queen of Hearts in Alice in Wonderland, who sentenced first and the trial came later. In Minister Kelly's case, it is grant first and lodge the application later. According to advice from the Department of Transport and Regional Services to the Senate Finance and Public Administration References Committee regional funding inquiry, the first Tumbi Creek funding application was lodged on 24 June last year and approved on the same dayâ16 days after the member for Dobell announced the first Regional Partnerships funding allocation. This ought to be compared with other area consultative committees, who have been waiting months and months for a decision from this department.

We also discovered that there was a second application. The Department of Transport and Regional Services told the Senate inquiry that Regional Partnerships applications were lodged on 24 June and on 11 July. The Prime Minister announced the second Regional Partnerships funding allocation on 26 August, three days before the federal election date was named, and yet the Department of Transport and Regional Services says that just one approval was made, on 24 Juneâthe same day the first application was received. Either no formal approval was granted with respect to the second funding application, or the full funding was approved prior to submission of the second application and the public campaign for state government funding was just a charade. It is important to understand that no part of this process fell within the election period and no action related to this process could be considered as an election commitment free from the rigour of standard administrative processes.

We have also discovered that the local area advisory consultative committee considers the project proposal a low priority and that the New South Wales government has expressed concern about the proposed expenditure of $2 million on remedial action unrelated to the Tuggerah Lakes estuary management plan. As I indicated to the House earlier, not only did we have that bizarre and farcical situation of grants being approved without applications even being made, let alone assessed, but we subsequently had a situation where rainfall last year washed out the Tumbi Creek mouth. We had a situation where Mr Graeme Hallett, a special adviser in the office of Jim Lloyd, Minister for Local Government, Territories and Roads, wrote to Giulio Cerasani, Mr Cobb's DLO, about the conditions for this grant, making clear his expectation that there would be no doubt about the way forward to deliver the commitment on Tumbi Creek. I understand that Mr Hallett had been working as one of the campaign team in the office of the member for Dobell, so he was in a position to know a great deal about the member for Dobell's views on these matters. He fired off an email to the department saying, `We don't want any doubt about the way forward to deliver the commitment on Tumbi Creek.' He said:

quote.para: The commitment by the Howard government to the electors of Dobell, in partnership with the Wyong council, is non-negotiable. It is the position of Mr Ticehurst that the money be delivered as agreed for the works in the schedule of agreement under Regional Partnerships.

speech.para: His message to the department was very clear. His expectation was that that money would be paid over, regardless of whether or not it was needed any longer for dredging works. When his email to the department did not seem to be hitting the mark, he fired off another email to the member for Dobell and the Wyong shire non-Labor councillors, issuing the following warning:

quote.para: Any changes mean less federal money, so Wyong officials should keep their counsel on this if we want the total allocated by the PM for Tumbi Creek.

speech.para: The import of that email is absolutely clear. The intention is to defraud taxpayers. The intention is to make sure that the grant goes ahead, whether it is needed or not. That is scandalous. We have the minister's office seeking to mislead his own department. We have the minister's office telling Wyong Shire Council, `You keep quiet about this; otherwise we will lose some of this money.' This is a disgraceful situation. It is time the Prime Minister faced up to his responsibilities under his ministerial code of conduct. It is time he faced up to his responsibility to make sure that Regional Partnerships becomes something better than a National Party slush fund. (Time expired)

talker.name: Cobb, John, MP
Mr JOHN COBB
talker.role: Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister for Transport and Regional Services

talk.start.para: âI certainly welcome the opportunity to speak on this matter of public importance, especially when it is to make clear what an incredibly good program Regional Partnerships has been. While the input from the members opposite has been all about what it does for National Party peopleâthey intimate that this is in regional and remote Australiaâin actual fact today they have done nothing but talk about almost metropolitan projects. And that is what Regional Partnerships is about. It does not just look after regional Australia. Obviously it stresses the needs of regional Australia, but it also looks after outer metropolitan areas.

speech.para: This program was put in place some 18 months ago. It was done not because one day the government decided to see just what it might be able to do for regional Australia but because some five or six years ago the Deputy Prime Minister called a Regional Australia Summit. Quite obviously the members of the opposition do not like the fact that Regional Partnerships is an incredibly successful program. It is probably the most popular program in Australia today, perhaps second to or running in conjunction with Roads to Recovery, which is also something this government brought in. This area having been ignored by Labor for 13 years, Roads to Recovery, like Regional Partnerships, is out there expressly to help people who desperately need it.

Some five years ago the Deputy Prime Minister, who was then the minister for regional services, called a summit of some 200 or 300 people from right around Australia. As a matter of fact, I was there in the guise of an agropolitician, representing farmers from around Australia. I was one of those delegates. That conference, that gathering here in Canberra of people from right around regional Australia, looked at what was happening at a time when the efficiency driven rationalisation of farming in country Australia and unemployment were at their height and we needed to know what could be done about them. For three days those delegates were helped by people from government and from the universities of regional Australia to sort out their ideas. And they had ideas.

The government looked at the things that conference came up with that it, in partnership with the communities of regional Australia, could do to make things work, to get things goingâto get the guts of regional Australia turned around and to help it go forward once again. There was a very strong call that there needed to be a mechanism that would enable our communities to build their own way aheadâa vehicle to help them help themselves and enable us to go forward and help them. It would be a leg-up, a new start, to address local needs.

What happened? The government listened to what 200 or 300 people from right around Australia said. We did not listen to bureaucrats; we did not listen to politicians; we listened to what the people out there said should happen. One of the many responses to the Regional Australia Summit was to develop a range of policies and programs, using examples of what people from Western Australia, northern Queensland, western New South Wales and places like Bendigo and Ballarat had been able to do for themselves. The particular areas that were addressed were health, education, jobs, capacity building and restructuring, where particular infrastructure had failed services or where particular industries were no longer viable in an area.

One of the key initiatives, one of the first responses, was the government's Regional Solutions Program, which enabled communities to apply for funds to work in community situations. Lo and behold, it was highly successful. It was the forerunner to Regional Partnerships. When the Regional Solutions Program reached the end of its life it became obvious that, in a partnership situation, we could help regional Australia rebuild itselfâthat we could make an enormous difference. Eighteen months ago Regional Partnerships was born. It brought together the government's key regional development programs, including the Regional Solutions Program, the Regional Assistance ProgramâRAPâthe Rural Transaction Centres program and the government's specially targeted structural adjustment initiatives. The aim of it was to strengthen economic growth and help with services and regional planningâto give people an opportunity to help themselves. Major structural change was enabled by it. One of the major things to come out of Regional Partnerships is that it helps creates new jobs. People help themselves create new jobs.

I do not think it will come as a surprise, even to those opposite, to learn that this government is a huge supporter of regional development. We believe in it. We believe in supporting the regions. Agriculture, even without mining, is still responsible for creating nearly one-quarter of Australia's exports. Through Regional Partnerships and as a result of that original summit we continue to respond to what regional Australia wantsâto the needs of country people in towns, in the bush and all around the country. The rationalisation that has occurred in the last 10 to 20 years has been absolutely enormous, with environmental change and major economic and social change. All we have done is respond to that, and we have responded very well.

I guess it is hard for those opposite, because they never tried to do anything about it. They never made any attempt to find out what the problems were in the first place and they certainly did not attempt to address them. What makes Regional Partnerships so successful? It is not just us on our own or the communities on their own. It is the local communities, the local government, the local councils, the Commonwealth and your friends the state government who are supporting Regional Partnerships. Every $1 that we put into a Regional Partnerships program is on average attracting $3 more. Some of that, I grant you, is state money. Your political colleagues, if I may call them that, around the country obviously see what a beneficial tool Regional Partnerships is, how necessary it is and what a heck of a good job it is doing. We are not only helping to create jobs, we are stimulating local economies. More than anything, what we are doing is working. I think that is what is upsetting you: it works, we invented it, we made sure that we listened to the communities and we pushed it forward. Even your own political colleagues are working with us to help make it work.

While those on the other side do not like it, the main reason that I think we are standing here today talking about this is that they would like very much to divert the government, the parliament and certainly Australia from their own problems. What better thing to do than try to attack one of the most successful programs any government has ever devised? So they start a Senate inquiry, which is quite obviously nothing more than a witch-hunt. It has tried to discredit the integrity of this program, which I have demonstrated is one of the more successful programs that has ever been created.

I heard the member for Wills not long ago talking about the fact that 78 per cent of these projects go through. So he is assuming that not enough are being applied for. What he totally misunderstandsâhe understands nothing about the whole programâis that the ACCs try to help people in their attempts to make applications. The department helps people in their attempts to make applications. Those that are wildly unlikely to get up never see the light of day, because it is pointed out that they are not appropriate. Seventy-eight per cent is a very creditable figure when you realise that a lot of people are being steered the right way from the start: 1,111 projects, roughly $202 million worth, have been submitted; 674, $150 million worth, have been assessed; 522, $125 million worth, have been approved; 152 have not been approved; and 169 have been withdrawn. Why have they been withdrawn? Why are they not part of the projects submitted? Because people were steered the right way in the beginning so that they did not waste their own time or the time of the department and the ACCs.

I seem to recall the member for Wills being astounded that the previous Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister for Transport and Regional Services who oversaw Regional Partnerships changed the departmental recommendation on 11 occasions. That is incredible. That is 11 out of 674 projectsâsomething under two per cent. We are a government; we are not a part of a department. If departments got everything right all the time then we would not have governments. We are elected to do a job. The minister or the parliamentary secretary is elected to make an assessment. I think two per cent or 11 out of 674 is such a low figure that, given most projects and most ministerial intervention, it almost does not exist. The statement by the member for Wills would be one of the most ridiculous statements made in this House for a long time by anybodyâshadow minister or otherwise.

I draw the attention of the House to the fact that the oppositionâbe it the new Leader of the Opposition, the member for Wills or anyone elseâare simply trying to divert the attention of Australians from their own troubles by attacking one of the most successful programs around at the moment. It is also very sad that they choose to attack a project which is bringing so much help to so many people.

When local governments, communities, charitable organisations and corporate citizens are throwing money into projects around Australia at a rate of $3 for every dollar the Commonwealth puts in, I do not think that sounds like a program that is being rorted. That sounds like a program that is needed and that is doing one heck of a job around Australia. It is an active program; it is working; it is popular; and it is a proven process.

Mr Deputy Speaker, let me tell you as someone who administers that process that it is exhaustive. The way that projects are given due diligenceâgiven that we are very aware that we are dealing with tax dollars from people who obviously are not going to benefit from Regional Partnershipsâis an exhaustive process.

I also think it is particularly sad that in this chamber we hear members of the opposition drag up the names of departmental officials who work their guts out and who do a hell of a job. The opposition could not care less whether that is embarrassing to a person who has done nothing but their job and who has done it well. It is very sad to drag up their name in the public arena; it is a shame. In fact, I think it is disgraceful.

We are talking about a program which delivers jobs and which helps restructuring, health and services. The member for Wills seems to have left us for the moment. He does not like to listen to anybody, except himself. I would like to challenge him on a few projects. The Flat Bottle project is in his own electorate, strangely enough. I would like to hear him tell those people that he does not support the $150,000 of Regional Partnerships funding for the Social Firm Management Group for the Flat Bottle Co. project. I would like to hear him go to the member for Grey's electorate in South Australia and say to PY Media that he does not support the PY Network project in one of the most disadvantaged areas in Australia. I would like him go to the town of Cobar in my electorate and tell the people there that they do not need a medical centre. (Time expired).

talk.start.para: âWe have seen the purported defence of the indefensible. There is no doubt that the Regional Partnerships program was massively rorted. It is a disgrace of public administration. Look at the simple things that have been established. There is the conflict of interest in the office of the former Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister for Transport and Regional Services. Mr Crooke was employed in her office whilst also making representations on behalf of a beneficiary in the A2 Milk scandal. Look at the instances where the minister overrode the department, with no rationale being established. It is entirely contrary to the way in which the AuditorGeneral said these matters should be administered. Look at the absurd malapportionment and the inexplicable distribution of the funds across Australia.

speech.para: We have reached a point where, for the first time, Australian parliamentarians who travel to Papua New Guinea will not be able to adopt any superior airs when they look at the schemes that have been adopted in Papua New Guinea for discretionary fundsâwhere each member of parliament is given discretionary funds to allocate as they willâbecause in this country the government is allocating funds as it will, with entire indifference to its opposition. Where the government spent money in Labor seats, it did so to secure victory in marginal seatsâBass is the best example. The government did not distribute funds fairly across the board to seats; it did it with an eye specifically to its own electoral advantage.

What about the extraordinary way in which the latest scandal has been revealed about Tumbi Creek? The member for Dobell announced that program about a fortnight before an application was made. I call that the Nostradamus defenceâthe capacity to look into the future and anticipate an application being made and the minister approving it. I suspect that the member for Dobell is actually the secret author of `Mystic Medusa',the horoscope that appears every weekend in the Weekend Australian. He wrote his own horoscope in the last issue on 5-6 February. The member's birthday makes him an Aquarian. This is his horoscope:

quote.para: The usual old merde disguised as a New Deal. ... You could polish this up into a gem of a sitcom: Psyche near Uranus in your $$$ sector makes television projects/appearances extra profitable all month. ... Meanwhile, it's all about the reinvention of wonderful You, numero uno again with an astro-cluster in Aquarius and your annual New Moon on February 9.

speech.para: Mystic Medusa, you have got it right: in the old merde again!

Take aside the absurdity of an announcement of a project before it has been sought, then look at what actually happens once the grant has been announced. The grant was to clear the blockage at the mouth of a creekâ$1.5 million to dredge that sand out and take it to a tip. But what happens between the seeking of the grant and its request is massive rainfall, so the mouth of the creek is unblocked. There is no requirement to do the dredgingâa problem because, plainly, the council anticipated that they would have to seek a reallocation of the funds. But what happens? The minister's office intervenes to tell them, `Don't do that because, were you to do that, we would have to reduce your funding or you might not get it at all.' So there is a conspiracy engaged in wherein the council is asked to provide false information about the state of the creek.

What is this akin to? Even assuming there was some propriety in the grant, is it not like the situation where a person discovers a theft of their property, makes an insurance claim and then, perhaps a fortnight later, discovers that he actually misplaced that which he had claimedâbut there is a conspiracy between him and his friends not to disclose that to the insurance company? Is that not fraud? Of course it is. And it is fraud not only with respect to our common understanding. Plainly, were these facts to be established as we understand themâin a debate such as this we can only hypothesise rather than make direct allegationsâthere are a number of offences under the Criminal Code which appear to be apposite. Section 134.2, on obtaining financial advantage through deception, sets out the fault elements of that crime. The physical element is that the `Defendant induces a person to believe a thing is true'âthat is, that the creek is still blocked. The fault element requires `Intention', and plainly there was intention. For the physical element that the representation is `False', the fault element requires `Intention or Recklessness'. The physical element is that `A third party obtains a financial advantage from a Commonwealth entity'. The fault element ultimately requires `Dishonesty'.

Assume for a moment that there was doubt about the applicability of that section; there could hardly be any doubt about the applicability of section 135.1, `General Dishonesty'. General dishonesty simply requires in the physical element of conduct that the `Defendant does something' with the `Intention (of dishonestly obtaining a gain from another person who is a C'wealth entity)'. When we speak of `conduct' and `doing things', remember that the Criminal Code defines conduct and engaging in conduct as either performing or omitting to perform an act. So remaining silent when you know that the department believes the creek is still blocked, or putting forward representations to the effect that it remains blocked when you know it is not, clearly comes under that heading.
Then you have provisions under section 135.2, `Obtaining a financial advantage'. Those provisions state:

quote.para: The following elements are for the offence of obtaining a financial advantage for another:
1. Physical Element (`conduct') Defendant induces the C'wealth entity to do something
Fault Element Intention
2. Physical Element (`result of conduct') A third party received a financial advantage from the C'wealth
Fault Element Knowledge or Belief (that the third party is ineligible to receive that financial advantage)

speech.para: Of course, there are other offences, such as conspiracy to defraud when conducted not by a single person but, as it appears in this instance, by a number of parties engaging together to have the Commonwealth make payments to which they are no longer entitled. Section 135.4(1), conspiracy to obtain a gain, and section 135.4(7), conspiracy to influence a Commonwealth official, would apply.

Then there are provisions in relation to false or misleading statements and applications. There are a number of different offences in relation to that. But, if you make a statement with the intention to do so, if that statement is false and misleading, if that statement omits a matter or thing and you have knowledge of that, and if you have made that statement in relation to an application for a claim for benefit or you are reckless with regard to that, then you commit that crime. Under section 137.1 `False or misleading information', there are a number of provisions about simply giving `information to another'. The intention must be to provide that information, where the information is `false or misleading' and omits a `matter or thing', you have knowledge of that and the other person is a Commonwealth entity.

There are serious matters that not only this House but no doubt law enforcement will be looking at to examine whether or not the matters described in this House today are made out. But the Prime Minister, like Diogenes, walking around the stews of the National Party seeking the honest man, seems blind to the obvious. Not a single sparrow will fall. Not a single minor minister will be drawn into a breach of the ministerial code. But, like Monty Python, there they are: the parrotsâ

talk.start.para: âThe dead parrots!
ânot dead; just resting, pining for the fjords. But, yes, the House knows that they are dead parrots, and they are sitting there waiting to fall.

âMonty Python, Diogenes, Mystic Medusaâa wealth of allusions there. Harold Wilson famously said that a week is a long time in politics. Well, if a week is a long time, what a difference four months make. Four months ago all members of this House would have been actively engaged on election day. In 45 minutes time, the first results would have come through from Tasmania. It was the day that the Australian people cast their judgment on who they wanted to lead Australia over the next three years.

speech.para: I remember the message at that time was that Labor was ready to lead. What I found during the Christmas break and over January was that one of the questions that constituents would pose was: `What if Labor had won?' It is worth thinking about: what if the Labor Party had won? Usually that question elicits chuckles and a little bit of mirth. Other constituents have said that one of the great joys in life for them is waking up, listening to the ABC news, lying in bed in the morning and just chuckling at the latest episode in the saga and soap opera that is the Australian Labor Party.

One of the key questions that was asked and answered during the federal election campaign was: `Who do you trust to manage an $800 billion economy?' Our message very consistently was: it takes focus; it takes discipline; it takes a good record to run a complex, large Australian economy. People cast their judgments. Politics is a competitive business and the job of the opposition is to mount the argument that they could administer the country and the economy better than the government. As I said, people actually stop and say, `What if the Labor Party had won?' As we have seen the last four months unfolding, it is worth thinking about how Labor would have responded to the tsunami, for example. How would Labor have dealt with some of the challenges that are facing the Australian government now?

During the election campaign I found, like all members, that there were a couple of conversations that really stuck in my mind. One came fairly early in the campaign when a gentleman rang me and said that his father had always told him that he would be quite happy to have a Labor government but they were no good on foreign policy and they were no good on finance. I thought that sounded like our campaign and I said: `When did your father say this? That's incredible.' He said, `My father died in 1952.' What it shows you is that there are some perennials in Australian politics that do not change. Labor, in the view of the population, is always suspect on those issues. The issues in 2004 were the economy and national security.

This is a MPI on the subject of administration. It is worth going back and looking at Labor's track record on administration. I found it an amazing conjunction of events when we had the devastation of the tsunami on 26 December 2004 and then on 1 January 2005 the National Archives released the cabinet records from 1974. Of course, one of the things in 1974 was Cyclone Tracy on Christmas Eve. John Menadue reported that Gough Whitlam was reluctant to return from an overseas trip. His quote went something like: `If I have to put up with theâexpletive deletedâcaucus, I will have my trips.' It was a reminder of how 30 years ago a previous member for Werriwa dealt with a natural disaster. It was a reminder of how a Labor government approached a natural disaster in Australia. People are welcome to draw their own conclusions there.

More recently, we can go to the Hawke-Keating years. Another one of the key questionsâand Labor is trying to morph it into something elseâwas, as we asserted, that interest rates are always higher under a Labor government. That was what we said, and Mr Beazley, the Leader of the Opposition, is trying to say that we were talking about the movement of interest rates. All we said was that interest rates are always higher under a Labor government. That is because the trade union movement has too much influence in the Labor Party and because Labor governments spend more than they collect. Those are the principal reasons. Interest rates reached 17 per cent under the Labor Party and averaged 12 per cent. That was over the Hawke-Keating years.

Of course, the famous example of maladministration that everyone knows about was the whiteboard affairâthe sports rorts affairâin which the administration was so slack that there were no records, and a channel of money was funnelled into Labor Party electorates. That was now 11 years ago. Centenary House is another example of a Labor rort where taxpayers' money has been channelled back into the Australian Labor Party to fund their election campaigns.

There have been some allegations about regional programs. The member for Wills made some allegations that the majority of funds flow to coalition electorates. There is a very good reason for that: the majority of rural electorates are held by the coalition. Out of 45 rural seats, 38 are held by the Liberal Party or by the National Party. If you add in provincial seats, almost three-quarters of them are held by the Liberal Party or by the National Party. I think an assertion was made that there was a very low number of applications coming from Labor Party seats. A very good question is why? We used to hear a bit from the Labor members for McMillan, Braddon and Paterson. They used to be trotted out as representatives of rural and regional Australia. Why were these Labor members not generating applications in their electorates? Labor used to hold seats in regional Australia. During the Hawke-Keating years from 1983 to 1996 I think they held as many rural and regional seats as the Liberal Party and the National Party did. People showed what they thought about that. People showed what they thought about their work level, their representation and their ability to deliver for their electorates when they tossed them out in 1996.

This shows that coalition members are much more in touch with the needs of their communities and they are much more active in supporting community-driven projects. Eight hundred applications came from coalition electorates compared with 205 from Labor electorates. What were the Labor members doing? I know that many members on this side who represent rural and regional areas go to a lot of effort to try to get their community groups to put in applications. We have heard a little bit about a creek in Dobell. We did not hear much in this MPI about the turtle interpretation centre which the Labor Party committed $1Â½ million towards. It had already secured funding from the state and local government authorities. No approach had been made to the Australian government, yet the Labor Party announced $1Â½ million to the turtle interpretation centre. Of course, they matched the funding for the creek in Dobell. They announced $150 million for a rail line in Richmond, $1 million for a national centre of democracy in Ballarat, $10 million for a national museum in Cairns, $1 million for something in Bundaberg, $3 million for Thuringowa and $6 million for the Rockhampton showgrounds. What applications were put in? What costings were done? In conclusion, it is the job of the opposition to hold the government to account, but the Labor Party's track record is very poor. (Time expired)

talk.start.para: âI move:

motion.para: That, in accordance with the provisions of the Public Works Committee Act 1969, the following proposed work be referred to the Parliamentary Standing Committee on Public Works for consideration and report: Proposed refurbishment of Australia House in London, United Kingdom.

speech.para: The Department of Foreign Affairs and Trade proposes the refurbishment of Australia House in London. Australia House accommodates the Australian High Commission in London, as well as a number of federal and state government tenant agencies, including Department of Defence staff.

The building is not only Australia's oldest overseas mission but is also the oldest originally occupied chancery of any foreign mission in London. Officially opened in 1918, Australia House has served Australians at home and in the United Kingdom without interruption since that time. It is located in London's West End, so is readily accessible to the many thousands of Australians who visit each year and to those who wish to visit or migrate to Australia. Australia House is therefore a prestigious and centrally located asset well worth preserving.

While the building has been well maintained over its lifetime, changes in internal functions of accommodated staff and environmental effects over almost 90 years have rendered it inevitable that a substantial refurbishment is required. To this end, an initial refurbishment project was undertaken in the late 1990s. The works now proposed are those priority areas remaining, comprising external works to the three building core light wells and internal works to the fourth-level accommodation of the Australian Defence staff.

The light wells are the most difficult areas of Australia House to access and the areas most in need of refurbishment to overcome water ingress and general facia deterioration. A substantial temporary structure will need to be erected to provide access. The level-four works are intended to occur concurrently in order to get the maximum use out of this structure. This not only achieves a reasonable construction synergy, but it also avoids logistic and security concerns that would otherwise be associated with having to access level four internally through Australia House. The scope of the proposed works will include the following:
erection of a temporary scaffold and hoist structure outside Australia House, and inside the light wells, for movement of personnel, equipment and material;
construction of temporary accommodation on the top building floors for Defence staff while their fourth level is refurbished;
refurbishment of the fourth level of the building, including base building services and fit-out, after Defence staff have temporarily relocated;

refurbishment of the light wells, comprising replacement of single glaze windows and frames with double glaze units of similar appearance, repair and replacement of damaged brickwork, face tiles and cast iron pipe work, and high pressure cleaning generally; and
removal of scaffold and hoists after completion of refurbishment works.

The estimated cost of the new proposal is $11.98 million. Subject to parliamentary approval, these works are planned to commence in May 2006 and to be completed by mid-2007. I commend the motion to the House.
Question agreed to.

talker.name: Stone, Dr Sharman, MP
Dr STONE
talker.role: Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister for Finance and Administration

talk.start.para: âI move:

motion.para: That, in accordance with the provisions of the Public Works Committee Act 1969, the following proposed work be referred to the Parliamentary Standing Committee on Public Works for consideration and report: Ordnance breakdown facility, proof and experimental establishment site, Port Wakefield, South Australia.

speech.para: The Department of Defence proposes to provide an ordnance breakdown facility that will be located at the Proof and Experimental Establishment site at Port Wakefield, South Australia. This proposal was referred to the Public Works Committee on 24 June 2004 but the reference lapsed when the previous committee ceased to exist with the prorogation of parliament on 31 August 2004.

The proposed facility will enhance the capability of the Defence Science and Technology Organisation to provide technical intelligence on a range of weapons that potentially threaten Australian Defence Force personnel. The proposed ordnance breakdown facility consists of the following elements:
a disassembly building that provides separate rooms for breakdown of explosive ordnance, radiographic examination and equipment storage along with an enclosed external unloading/loading bay;
a cutting building that provides separate rooms for operation of remotely controlled cutting equipment, radiographic examination and equipment storage along with an enclosed external loading bay;
explosive ordnance storehouses for the storage of explosive ordnance and broken down components; and
supporting infrastructure and services.

The budget estimate for the proposed works is $8.4 million. Subject to parliamentary approval, construction will start mid-year and be completed by the middle of next year. I commend the motion to the House.
Question agreed to.

talk.start.para: âI move:

motion.para: That, in accordance with the provisions of the Public Works Committee Act 1969, the following proposed work be referred to the Parliamentary Standing Committee on Public Works for consideration and report: Development of on-base housing for Defence at Puckapunyal, Victoria.

speech.para: The Defence Housing Authority proposes the construction of 80 on-base residences at the Puckapunyal army base in Victoria. The role of the Defence Housing Authority is to provide suitable housing to meet the operational needs of the Australian Defence Force and the requirements of the Department of Defence.

The Defence Housing Authority satisfies Defence accommodation requirements through a mixture of: construction off-base, with a view to retaining the properties or selling them with a lease attached; construction on-base, to accord with Defence operational or policy requirements and/or if such construction is the most cost-effective for all concerned; direct purchase, with a view to retaining the properties or selling them with a lease attached; and direct lease from the private rental market. Of these options, only on-base construction is feasible at Puckapunyal. The housing market in the nearest town, Seymour, would be too readily distorted by Defence requirements and provides few amenities beyond those available on-base.

The project involves the construction of 80 three-bedroom houses on previously occupied residential sites that are presently vacant. Infrastructure works are not required. The proposed project will have a positive effect on the local economy during the construction period, not only through persons working directly on the site but also through the off-site supply of material, plant and equipment. The construction of these new dwellings on-base at Puckapunyal is not expected to affect either the sale or rental markets for residential accommodation in the neighbouring townships. The estimated cost of the proposal is $19.6 million. Subject to parliamentary and Defence Housing Authority board approval, the construction program is expected to commence in July this year, with the delivery of completed dwellings expected to occur progressively from February 2006 through to November 2006. I commend the motion to the House.
Question agreed to.

debateinfo.title: AUSLINK (NATIONAL LAND TRANSPORTâCONSEQUENTIAL AND TRANSITIONAL PROVISIONS) BILL 2004

subdebate.1.para: Debate resumed.

talk.start.para: (Hon. I.R. Causley)âThe original question was that these bills be now read a second time. To this the honourable member for Wills has moved as an amendment that all words after `That' be omitted with a view to substituting other words. The question now is that the words proposed to be omitted stand part of the question.

âI am very angry, and so is the Geelong community, that there is any suggestion from the Howard government that funding for the Geelong bypass be tied in any shape or form to other Victorian AusLink projects such as the Scoresby bypass. This is a critical piece of regional and national infrastructure. I simply say to the Howard government: quit playing politics with it and get on with the job. I have one other piece of advice for the minister and the government: good public policy outcomes and strong partnerships with other levels of government are never achieved in a lasting sense when one key party is motivated by vindictive ideological obsessions.

speech.para: It has been a strongly held belief of mine that Australia's transport infrastructure is a major determinant of its economic growth. That is why I have despaired at the wasted years of the Howard government in this very important area of public policy. In my shadow ministerial portfolio responsibilities I have often taken a particular interest in the struggle by rural communities for road funding. One such involvement in recent years was with the community of Ungarra on the Eyre Peninsula in South Australia to secure funding to complete a local road for that community. I note that the Eyre Peninsula was recently devastated by bushfires, with significant loss of life, and I wish the people of Ungarra well in their recovery from the bushfires. They are proud, resilient and decent country people, and I am sure they will come through this disaster with a stronger community.

In my own community in the Geelong region I am very proud of the achievements of past and present Labor governments, both federal and state, in ensuring that the region's transport infrastructure positions the Geelong area for future economic growth. It was a federal Labor government that contributed funding to the dual carriageway on the Bellarine Highway which now services Leopold, Drysdale, Clifton Springs and other coastal towns on the Bellarine Peninsula. It was a federal Labor government that contributed substantially to the dual carriageway between Geelong and the Great Ocean Road at Torquay, which has underpinned massive tourism and residential growth along the Great Ocean Road. It was the Bracks government and the federal opposition, led by Kim Beazley at the time, that made the public financial commitment to the third lane on the Princes Highway between Geelong and Melbourne, forcing the federal coalition to match our funding commitment. It was the Bracks Labor government that was the first to commit funding to the Geelong bypass. I commend the contributions of my state Labor parliamentary colleagues and their efforts in securing that commitment, which was the catalyst for the eventual commitment made by the Howard government. Transport issues have dominated the Geelong political scene over the 11 years I have been the member for Corio, and I have been pleased to play my part, on behalf of my constituents, in the lobbying efforts to secure funding from all levels of government for these important projects.

We on this side of the House will be supporting the broad intent of this legislation. Why wouldn't we? After all, we went to the 2001 election with a detailed proposal for a national land transport plan. There are several key proposals that have formed the core of Labor's policy in opposition since 1996, and we intend to insist on them again during this termânamely, the setting of national transport infrastructure priorities for road and rail, the pursuit of an integrated planning approach to the land transport task, the construction of genuine partnerships with other levels of government to achieve national outcomes, the pursuit of a long-term funding framework that exists beyond the half lives of governments at various levels and the integration of the transport task with other social and environmental objectives.

The past behaviour of the Howard government in this policy area gives the opposition grave concern about the administration of AusLink and transport policy. We are not convinced that the government is really committed to a national land transport plan and funding according to agreed priorities. We have little confidence that the government will not rort substantial slabs of the land transport budget for its own political ends, as has occurred in other regional programsâas, dare I say it, revealed by the Leader of the Opposition today in question time. Even a cursory reading of the minister's second reading speech indicates that there is significant potential for the government to rort the land transport budget again.

There is disturbing evidence of the government's intention to once again dodge its fiscal responsibility in the transport area and cost shift to Labor states in a systematic way. It is also disturbing to note that, in order to peddle its own ideological obsessions and prejudices, the government intends abusing the important partnership required with state Labor governments to undertake these projects. The Victorian government did not come to the table with over $190 million worth of funding for the Geelong ring-road project and make the federal contribution contingent on certain provisions if funding was to proceed, so why is the federal government seeking to do that with state Labor governments?

The government's use of its purchasing power to achieve its ideological objectives in the construction industry through its so-called code of practice is a case in point. This code of practice has no legislative sanction and can be changed at whim by the government. There is no independent review of the code's application within government and its potential impact on legally certified agreements struck under the Workplace Relations Act, and there is no independent review of the impact on employers who wish to tender for projects but have struck such legal agreements that may be non-compliant with the code. Yet the government has been prepared to put in jeopardy key infrastructure projects for the Geelong regionâand othersâfor the sake of pursuing its own ideological obsessions and political prejudices.

With regard to Australian agriculture and fisheries, the efficiency of the road transport task is critical to the long-term prosperity of many of our key rural industries, such as meat, grains, sugar, dairy and horticulture, and to rural communities which depend on them for their ongoing viability. The nation's export performance and competitiveness in agriculture depends heavily on the achievement of greater efficiencies in the transport task. We do expect that in regional areas the government will fund key land transport infrastructure projects that will deliver over the long term the sorts of economic efficiencies that underpin our great rural and fishing industries and lead at the end of the day to greater prosperity for all Australians.

talker.name: Beazley, Kim, MP
Mr BEAZLEY
talker.role: Leader of the Opposition

talk.start.para: âThe AusLink (National Land Transport) Bill 2004 and the AusLink (National Land TransportâConsequential and Transitional Provisions) Bill 2004 underscore Labor's concerns about this government's approach to management of the nation's infrastructure and to management of Australia's economy more generally. This is a government where political considerations take priority over considerations relating to Australia's national interest. It is a government where short-term fixes take precedence over long-term economic and social needs. It is a complacent government that wants to take credit for our current prosperityâwhich is the fruit of a long period of reformsâbut has neither the vision nor the backbone to take the decisions that will build Australia's future prosperity.

speech.para: It is interesting that more and more often in the community now people are accepting the view that our long period of prosperity is in large measure a product of the decisionsâcontroversial and difficult in their dayâthat were taken by the Hawke and Keating governments. This government has benefited enormously from that prosperity and now it has squandered it. In all the indices of those measures that we put in place when we were in office you can see that Australia is going backwards where we once went forwards. The figures associated with exports show under this government a rate of growth that is half what it was when we were in office. Research and development funding in the business sector collapsed for the first few years of operation of this government. It is only just beginning to trend upwards now, while all our competitors have been on a non-stop trajectory upwards. There has been a collapse in skillsâand in traditional areas that has been worst of all.

As it is with infrastructure, so it is with training. This government loves the political atmosphere. It is tremendously good with words and political positioning but appalling with the delivery of outcomes. In the skills area, for example, we had the modern apprenticeship training system, which simply concealed the collapse of traditional trades. And now, if you go to the mining companies in my home town, they will not have a conversation with you about indiscipline in their work forces; they will say to you very directly, `We will not invest and we cannot invest because we cannot get a work force.' They cannot get it here and they cannot bring it in from overseas. It is not availableâthe welders are not there; the electricians are not there. An electrician in a Western Australian mining town now will earn between $150,000 and $200,000 a year. The mining companies have no capacity to do the work that they need to do, because they do not have the resources that need to be there to do it.

The other area is national infrastructure, and this comes back to this bill. The OECD report that was out last week simply repeats what I have had to say in my opening remarks on this bill. That OECD report was very critical of this government. It was critical of this government in two key areas: skills, which I have already mentioned, and infrastructure. It is not as though money is not spent; it is just how it is spent. Again, it is not part of a national plan targeted to real areas of need; it is part of a national scheme of pork-barrelling targeted at political concerns of the Commonwealth.

You cannot do this over a lengthy period of time without the nation paying a penalty. Day by day, we are hearing more about the crisis in infrastructure facing this nation. We hear about problems that are emerging in the crucial infrastructure networks that help make Australia efficient and competitive in the global economyâproblems such as roads, ports, water, communications, energy and other crucial aspects of the nation's infrastructure. We are facing serious economic constraints; the long-term effects of years of short-term, politically driven policy making are beginning to hit home.

That is why I want to comment on this bill. Rather than coming to terms with the nation's infrastructure problems and the lack of strategic planning that has caused them, this government now plans to make matters worse. As the member for Wills said in his comments to this House yesterday, this is the latest instalment in a sorry tale of the progressive collapsing of the nation's infrastructure spending into a series of National Party slush funds. We have seen it before. In the environment we have seen it with the Natural Heritage Trust. In communications we have seen it with Networking the Nation. In roads we have seen it with Roads of National Importance. We have seen it with the Regional Partnerships program. And now we see a complacent government planning to entrench its self-interested political decision making in this bill.

Contemplate the programs I have been talking aboutâevery one of them surrounded by verbiage of fine words and the right sentiments with the mobilisation of community sentiment behind them. Every one of themâto the tune of tens of millions of dollarsâis targeted to support a short-term political outcome, not a long-term benefit for the nation. You cannot do that without damaging your country in the end. It is smart politics while it lastsâGod knows the government is very rarely internally inspected through the accountability processes around this townâbut sooner or later the chickens come home to roost, and they are cackling away in the yard now as we look at the bare bones of the infrastructure strategies of this government.

Distance has always been a critical element of the story of this nation's development. We have never enjoyed the advantage that many of our trading partners haveâof large populations living in close proximity to other well-populated countries providing ready access to markets for their goods and services. We have always lived with great distances between our heavily populated areas and, of course, with great distances between our country and our friends and neighbours. This means that infrastructure planning has always been a crucially important element in our national development. Good planning and prudent investment can overcome challenges of distance. Without clear-sighted, long-term planning for the needs of growing populations and industries, we experience the bottlenecks and strains on our infrastructure that we now face.

What we need now is a process of objective, long-sighted planning of our nation's infrastructure needs. We need a government that is willing to work cooperatively with the states and act in the national interest. We do not need another slush fund to allow the nation's limited resources to be diverted into white elephant projects in marginal National Party electorates. But that is exactly what this bill proposes with the AusLink Strategic Regional Projects fund. People should learn to be fearful when they hear those sorts of words associated with any government proposition. This $150 million fund gives the minister wide discretion as to how to allocate those funds, on top of the AusLink Roads to Recovery program, which similarly gives the minister virtual free rein on spending decisions.

Make no mistake about it: this is a story in which there are more losers than winners. When crucial infrastructure funds are being diverted for pork-barrelling for National Party politicians, the people who bear the costs of those decisions are the families spread throughout the vast suburban areas of our major cities. These are the people who live in the exploding suburbs where a failure of long-term planning means that the infrastructure networks and services that they rely on from day to day are too often stretched to breaking point. They have to cope with the daily grind of battling through congested roads where the Commonwealth fails to live up to its national responsibilities.

People in areas like Campbelltown and Liverpool, which I visited last week, have to put up with overstretched infrastructure every day of their livesâtheir roads, transport links, hospitals and schools. They are the people who are losing out because this government is more concerned with National Party politicians than with ordinary families. They have to live with the inconvenience and disruption to family life that occurs when you cannot find a bulk-billing GP after hours, when the hospital emergency room is miles away and always overcrowded or when a failure to coordinate transport effectively means that they waste hours every week in travelling between home, work and schools. They are the people who are forgotten when this government is forking out millions of dollars on projects that would not get a look-in if there was a fair, objective process for funding our infrastructure needs. The people in areas like Campbelltown and Liverpool would at least get a fair hearing if we had a fair, objective process for deciding how to allocate our spending on crucial infrastructure. But they do not get a look-in because they are not located in a National Party electorate.

The government's neglect of those families is so great that with this by-election coming up in the seat of Werriwa it cannot even decide whether it will bother to field a candidate. `We do not need Werriwa,' said some unnamed Liberal Party official. Those opposite do not need an electorate where there may be a challenge to what they nefariously intend to do with the resources that are allocated by the Commonwealth. In Werriwa, people face a choked up M5 motorway each day. That road was part of the former national highway networkâthe national responsibility that this government is now walking away from. Under this bill the government no longer accepts full responsibility for maintaining those roads. Instead, the government proposes to cap its maintenance commitment to our national highway network at $300 million a year. This government is walking away from its obligations to families in Campbelltown and Liverpool while it sets up a $150 million slush fund for the National Party.

Our federal system requires national leadership and a national strategy that can ensure that our infrastructure supports our economic growth rather than constraining it. Infrastructure is a linchpin of economic prosperity. That is why Labor advocates a national infrastructure advisory council that can examine and advise on the nation's infrastructure priorities, free of interference from politicians, so that the nation can enjoy the best economic and social outcomes from its infrastructure investments. That is why Labor believes we need a cooperative approach to working with the states and territories to solve infrastructure bottlenecks rather than playing them off against each other, or using roads funding to impose divisive industrial relations ideology on states and territories by refusing to fund road projects unless they follow Canberra's edicts.

There are elements of this legislation that we support. We support its long overdue attempt to link road and rail planning and to develop integrated corridor strategies for our land transport infrastructure. But we regret the government walking away from its national responsibilities by disowning its full responsibility for what was once formally called the national highway network. At a time when a decade of failed infrastructure policy is now holding our nation back, we can ill afford further indulgence of this government's preoccupation with politics over good policy. We will live for years with the consequences of failing to plan for the needs of our growing industries and our growing families. In infrastructure, bad policy making cannot be reversed overnight. That is why we urge this government to put the nation's interests ahead of its own political interests and to waste no more time in putting in place a transparent, objective and fair framework for meeting Australia's infrastructure needs for now and our future.

talk.start.para: âI want to continue with the theme established by the Leader of the Opposition. If the AusLink (National Land Transport) Bill 2004 were a genuine attempt to improve and better integrate Australia's critical infrastructure it would have the overwhelming support of the opposition, and we would not have a second reading amendment before the House. As the Leader of the Opposition pointed out, the OECD report and the Reserve Bank statement, both of last week, have identified bottlenecks in our productive capacity as the biggest hurdle to our ongoing sustainable economic growth, as the biggest reason for our poor export performance and growing current account deficit and as applying the greatest pressure of all on interest rates in this country at the moment.

speech.para: Sadly, it is not the case that this bill represents a real and genuine attempt to integrate land transport infrastructure in this country, and that is very disappointing indeed. This bill is really about two things. First, it is to enhance the government's pork-barrelling potential. Second, it is to enhance the government's ability to shift many of its financial obligations and responsibilities onto the states and, in so doing, to provide themselves with an opportunity on every occasion to shift blame to the states, as they are so known to do. The government has long been frustrated by the constraints of the current road funding arrangements which, in addition to its contribution to the local road components of grants to local councils, leave it almost entirely responsible for the national highway network.

There is plenty of evidence around the place to back the allegation that this government has been slowly but surely siphoning funding for projects in marginal seats away from the national highway project. It has been taking money away from its key traditional responsibility and spending it on projects under the banner, in particular, of Roads of National Importance. This is not to say that the opposition does not see merit in some of the projects which have been funded under programs such as Roads of National Importance, but we still allege that there are many projects that, as the Leader of the Opposition pointed out, would never get a guernsey if they were exposed to proper scrutiny and competition from more worthy projects.

Let me share with the House just one example of the sort of skewed results that you get when you put politics in front of the economic and social needs of the Australian economy. I want to talk briefly about a project in my own electorate, commonly known as the Kurri Corridor, but more recently referred to as the link between the F3 freeway and the New England Highway just north of Branxton. When the Howard government won office in 1996, the F3 to Branxton project was on track and construction funding was expected by the end of that decade. Here we are halfway through the next decade and not one sod has been turned. Even worse, the AusLink proposal to broaden the Commonwealth's responsibilities for road funding at the expense of the national highway project will likely push funding for the F3 link out by another decade.

Let me share with the House the importance of this road project. It is a project that I have been fighting for since Easter 1988, long before coming to this place, when I was a councillor on Cessnock City Council. In Easter 1988 the then final section of the F3 freeway was opened to a little place called Freemans Waterhole. That became the dead end. From there all of that freeway traffic spilt onto the roads of the local government authority, causing both an economic and a social nightmare. So we as a community started lobbying for what is commonly called the Kurri Corridor. We were successful in getting the community's preferred route option for that project. We were very confident that the case had been made in economic terms to have construction funding allocated to that project by the end of the decade or by the year 2000. Alas, the Howard government was elected. In that first budget of 1996 in particular, it embarked on some massive funding cuts, which was of course very bad news for that project. And the bad news has been ongoing ever since, in particular as a result of the government's ongoing determination to siphon money away from the national highway project, which the Kurri Corridor would form part of, and onto other projects where it believes it can get a greater political benefit.

The Kurri Corridor would be of great benefit to the Hunter in economic terms, in social terms, in road transport terms and in safety terms. It would rid many towns in my electorateâincluding the major towns of Cessnock and Maitland and smaller towns like Greta and Lochinvar, which are long-term sufferersâof the heavy vehicle traffic and the noise it creates as a result of the government's failure not to fund this project. I note that numerous economic studies have been undertaken that confirm the fact that, in economic terms, the Kurri Corridor would be of great economic benefit to the Hunter region. It would bring our coal exports closer to the port and it would bring the whole region closer to Sydney. The benefits would also extend way beyond my electorate, indeed into the electorate of the Deputy Prime Minister and member for Gwydir, the architect of this flawed AusLink proposal; and into electorates to the west of mine, such Calare which produces much of the product other than coal that goes through the port of Newcastle.

So important is the F3 link to our local communities that in recent years a local community group known as `Link or Sink' has sprung up. It has been very active in lobbying both the Commonwealth and the state governments in an attempt to bring funding forward for this important project. Unfortunately, despite the fact that they have had a number of discussions with Minister Anderson and his underlings, they have been given no real hope that the government is about to change its attitude on this subject. The reality is that, under this funding proposal, an important road link such as the Kurri Corridor, which goes substantially if not wholly through the electorate of Hunter, which the government considers a safe seat, is not likely to enjoy priority over some of these other projects the government has in mind, which of course run through either opposition held marginal seats or government held seats. That highlights a major flaw in this bill, and conjures for us again the prospect of the National Party being ongoing in its attempt to allocate money not on the basis of economic or social benefit but on the basis of political benefit. If the government believes there is a better funding model for road funding, one that better delivers outcomes, then the opposition would be prepared to support it. If broadening the Commonwealth's responsibilities delivers better results, we would be more than happy to support the proposition. But such a plan is not contained within the bill before the House today.

Let me turn to some other bottlenecks that the Deputy Prime Minister has been making a habit of waxing lyrical about in this place in recent times: the bottlenecks involved in some of our important port facilities. AusLink is apparently about dealing, amongst other things, with local land transport links to ports. There is not much point getting the land transport links to the ports right if there is undercapacity at the ports themselves. These ports, like the port of Newcastle, are so critical to Australia's economic wellbeing and have been subject to some consideration in the Reserve Bank and OECD reports and by a range of economic commentators around this country.

The port of Newcastle is the lifeblood of the Hunter in economic terms. It is the nation's largest coal port, but one that is currently choked. It is choked to the point that it is not unusual to see 50 ships sitting off the coast of Newcastleâa problem that is costing the coal companies operating in the Hunter Valley up to $100 million annually in demurrage charges. To get the capacity of the port of Newcastle to a point capable of coping with the current demand for export coal out of the Hunter regionâfrom the current 90-odd million tonnes to 120 million tonnesâwould require expenditure of some $300 million, or just three year's worth of demurrage. Where is the economic sense in all of that?

I will not say that the port of Newcastle is unique, because similar problems exist off the Bowen Basin in Queensland, but it is a monopoly. The Leader of the Opposition just made the point that the Hawke-Keating reforms of the 1980s and 1990s, in particular the competition reforms of the 1990s, are what gave this economy the economic boost that has been sustained in all that time and which is now in its 14th year. It was competition reform that gave the Australian economy a boost over major economies like the US throughout the 1990s, and it is competition reform that has allowed the economy to better deal with capacity constraints and to better avoid upward pressure on interest rates. Unfortunately, there is not much competition in the port of Newcastle, and that is much to the detriment of the Hunter region's economy.

The monopoly port facility is run by Port Waratah Coal Services. Who owns Port Waratah Coal Services? Mainly, in majority terms, it is owned by the coalminers Rio Tinto and Xstrata. Despite the dramatic growth in demand for export coal in recent years, much of which was easily predicted given the growth in China in particular, no real expansion in capacity has taken place at that port. Instead, Port Waratah Coal Services has successfully secured authorisation from the ACCC to put a quota system in place which restricts competition by allocating a share of port capacity to each of the producers who seek to use it. This of course is a practice which (1) disadvantages the smaller producers, who are of course on all current predictions the producers seeking to grow fastest and (2) has the effect of allowing the big companies which control PWCS to stall capacity investment. It is obvious.

The quota system is an advantage to the big players for three reasons. One, the big players, subject to ACCC authorisation, effectively set the rules. Two, the big players can meet their contracts from other global projects. In a sense, they can sequence their projects and source coal to meet their contracts from other global projects. It is a luxury not enjoyed by the small players like Excel Mining, Centennial Coal, Donaldson Coal et cetera. Three, demurrage charges are a much greater burden on the smaller players than they are on the big players like Xstrata and Rio Tinto.

While this quota system has been responsible for reducing the queue of ships sitting off Newcastle in recent months, the quota system allows the monopolist PWCS, owned by the big players Rio Tinto and Xstrata, to defer investment to take advantage of the situation at the expense of smaller producers, the economy of the Hunter region and the national economy. The quota application provided the government, through its agency the ACCC, with an opportunity to secure commitments to that investment before issuing the authorisation. Smaller coal companies do not have a problem with the quota system per se, but they see it as an opportunity, a tool, used by the big players to defer investment, and they do not appreciate the fact that the government has failed to use the authorisation as an opportunity to at the same time get a commitment on investment. As I said, the Reserve Bank has identified these bottlenecks as being crucial to the ongoing economic capacity of our economy as a whole.
