During question time, the Deputy Prime Minister in particularâand I think the Treasurer on one or two occasionsâhas been very quick to try to shift the blame for the problems in our port capacity onto the state governments. With respect to the Newcastle port, this is grossly unfair. The New South Wales government has done all in its power to improve the situation. The Deputy Prime Minister likes to remind us that ARTC has now taken control of the rail infrastructure that takes the coal to the port of Newcastle. I too think that that is a good thing and I look forward to this government, as the majority shareholder in ARTC, continuing to apply sufficient pressure on that organisation to invest what is necessary to get the rail infrastructure up to an appropriate capacity.

But there is no point in getting rail capacity up if the port capacity does not increase as well. The chain is only as strong as its weakest link. It is no good the Deputy Prime Minister coming in here crowing about what has been done in terms of the ownership of the rail infrastructure while refusing to concede any responsibility whatsoever for what is happening at the port of Newcastle. My message to the Deputy Prime Minister is this: `It's competition, stupid.' It is competition and it is only the Commonwealth government that can sort out the competition issues we are experiencing at the port of Newcastle.

We should not be surprised that the government is hesitant to do so. We have seen this government's attitude towards competition policy. We have seen its failure to take on another round of competition reform. We have seen its failure to embrace with any urgency the recommendations of the Dawson review, although it did not mind embracing pretty quickly those recommendations that suited the big end of town such as the softer merger laws. It has been reluctant to pick up the Senate committee's recommendations on a range of issues, but in particular on the strengthening of section 46.

I read a very interesting speech by Saul Eslake of the ANZ Bank recentlyâa speech he delivered to the Australian Competition and Consumer Commissionâin which he made the point, which I made earlier, that it is competition policy in this country that has given us our big lift in economic growth and capacity; it is competition policy that has given us a greater buffer against higher interest rates when we are reaching capacity in the economy; and it is competition policy that we must continue to pursue. It is now up to the Commonwealth government to have a good, hard look at what is happening in the port of Newcastle and act for a change to assist us in our problems there and to recover the $1.4 billion in sales we are losing annually as a result of its inaction.

talk.start.para: âI rise today to support the AusLink (National Land Transport) Bill 2004 and the cognate bill, but there are a number of concerns I would like to raise in relation to infrastructure generally. Before getting into my speech, I would just like to comment on one of the things that the member for Hunter raised. I would agree with him in relation to the port of Newcastle. As a state member in the north-west and New England area, and as the federal member for New England, I have had quite a lot to do with the Newcastle Port Authority, the Newcastle Business Chamber and other groups in Newcastle that are interested in the development of the port and the relationship that the port has with the various areas around it. The member for Parkes is here, too; he would be well aware of the relationship between Dubbo and the central west area and Newcastle and also the Tamworth-Gunnedah area in relation to Newcastle.

speech.para: One of the things that really needs to be addressed is the infrastructure needs of the Newcastle port and the importance it has to the northern and western parts of inland New South Wales. One of the pieces of infrastructure that is not mentioned in the AusLink documents is the Murrurundi tunnel. I am sure the member for Hunter would agreed that that is a very important piece of infrastructure that needs to be addressed at both a state and a federal level if we are going to develop the port of Newcastle and the coal industry north of the Liverpool Range in the electorates of Gwydir and New England.

Having said that, obviously I think all of us in this chamber recognise that the AusLink white paper and subsequent legislation do an important thing. They attempt to integrate the road and rail networks nationally, and I think that is significant in itself. We will all argue that there is not enough money in there, and I would argue that the Minister for Transport and Regional Services has probably exploded the funding arrangements in terms of how many Snowy Mountain schemes are actually in this particular document compared with what is historical fact, but there is no doubt that there is more money and there is an attempt to integrate road and rail and, in some cases, to link in with the ports. I would say that there is not enough in relation to Newcastle, of course, but I congratulate the minister on having a national approach to this particular problem. It is a problem in that we are continually building roads and rail has been ignored, and I think we are seeing the added impact of some of the road building schemes without looking at integration totally.

I am a supporter of the inland rail link that has been talked about for some years, and I think that this document, particularly the agreement through the Australian Rail Track Corporationâthe $872 million that was signed off between the state of New South Wales and the Commonwealth governmentâis an important move forward in relation to that particular agenda. But we really do need the government to put more in and react in a much more positive sense than it has in recent years to that particular project, because, if we are talking about infrastructure in inland Australia, we will have to have a rail system that can actually work right across the inland of Australia and take goods into Darwin and back to Sydney and Melbourne.

There are a few comments that I would like to make. Obviously I do not think anybody in this parliament would suggest that the funding arrangements in AusLink are sufficient. I do not think any member of the government would argue that the infrastructure needs of Australia are going to be covered sufficiently in AusLink, otherwise there would not be members of the governmentâand one of those members of the government, the member for Parkes, is at the table at the momentâarguing that there is a need to sell a very important piece of infrastructure, Telstra, to fund other infrastructure. I have very great concerns that an agenda is building up in parts of regional Australiaâand Dubbo is one of those areas where that agenda is growingâwhere moves are afoot to actually push for the sale of Telstra so that road and rail can be sufficiently funded in regional Australia. That says to me straightaway that, even though this legislation recognises the need to integrate and the obvious benefits downstream of integration, there is not sufficient money.

I caution Mr Roger Fletcher, one of the major sheepmeat processors in Australia, about being used as a puppet in developing an argument to sell Telstra to fund other infrastructure. It is an insult to country people to say that they cannot have the infrastructure they require and that the only way they will get it is to sell some other infrastructure. I think all of us would know that in this century telecommunications is going to be the most important piece of infrastructure in regional Australia. It is the very piece of infrastructure that negates distance as being a disadvantage of living in a country area. It removes smallness as being a disadvantage in terms of size. If you get equity of access and equity of costâand I believe you have to have government involvement to achieve that, because the private market will not provide thatâonly then will country people out-compete their city cousins in terms of their location. I think a nasty agenda is being developedâand I would caution the member for Parkes on his involvement in itâto promote the sale of a significant piece of infrastructure to fund another piece and to say to people that that is the only way they are going to get sufficient funds to provide the infrastructure that they require. We all know that there are other ways of achieving those outcomes.

One of the other issues that I would raise is the Roads to Recovery program, and I compliment the minister and the government on it. I think there is no doubt that that has been a successful program. I was very pleasedâjust prior to or during the election campaign, I cannot remember quite whenâto see that the government moved back to a similar system, where the full $300 million was going to be treated on an equitable basis across all local government areas. The original proposal was that $200 million would be treated under a similar formula to that of the previous Roads to Recovery programâa successful program in my viewâand $100 million would be opened up to the discretion of government.

We have had a debate today and there is a debate going on in the Senate about these sorts of discretionary lumps of money. There is no doubt that there is a politicisation of the process or, at best, that it allows possible tampering, even though that may not be going on to the extent that some people might like to think it is. Those sorts of schemes allow people to develop their own thought processes about transparency, whereas the original Roads to Recovery program was a very fair program. It went out to all local government areas. The locals made the decisions on the ground. There was no way that the bureaucracy or the state governmentâand I applaud the federal government for bypassing the states in that senseâor the minister could have an impact on the direction of that funding. I think Roads to Recovery is a successful program and should be looked at as a bit of a model for other programs in the future.

I remember being involved as a state member, again, in the campaign to get more money for local roads. I will just highlight for a moment the importance of unity. I note with great interest that the Australian Local Government Association is currently embarking on a program to achieve one per cent of income tax to go back to local governmentâa much more transparent scheme, again, that would allow some growth as the economy grows, as the income tax receipts grow, so that more of that money could flow to local governmentârather than the very archaic system we have now. I congratulate the President of the Australian Local Government Association, Councillor Bell, for his initiative. I urge all members to support that initiative, because if it is supported through a whole range of organisations I have no doubt that it will be successful.

I will just take people back to the genesis of the Roads to Recovery program. A meeting was held from 5 to 8 March 2000 in Moree, in the current minister's seat of Gwydir. He was the minister then, too, I think. The meeting was under the auspices of the Deputy Prime Minister; he had encouraged the meeting to occur. It was about creating solutions: a National Rural Roads Congress. It was put on under the auspices of the Australian Local Government Association.

One of the things that disturbed me at the time in the advertisements for and promotion of the programâand the Deputy Prime Minister was involved in its promotionâwas as follows. This congress was coming together to look at how road infrastructure was going to be funded in the next 20 to 50 years, at how this money was to be provided. That was a very worthy question. But one of the things that concerned me greatly, and I was critical at the time, was that in the documents that were circulated a statement was made: `It is clearly not going to be funded from current sources of funds.' That was suggesting to local government, from the federal level, that local government would receive no more money from the fuel tax receipts than they were getting, so the congress should look at other ways of achieving funding arrangements: private-public partnerships and those sorts of arrangements. The signal was sent from government at that stage: `Don't expect any more from fuel taxation receipts.'

I think at that stage something like $800 million of Commonwealth funds was being spent on roads. Obviously that was not enough. That is a bit over 2c a litre at the bowser, and I think we are all aware that we are paying 38c and then there is GST on top of that. It was a little bit over 2c a litre, and the government was saying at the time through the Deputy Prime Minister: `Don't expect any more.'

The Australian Local Government Association did not accept that. To their credit, they argued that more receipts should be made available, particularly for local roads, as there was a real maintenance problem developing in terms of infrastructure. To their credit, they were able to come out with what is now the very successful program called Roads to Recovery.

I raise that today because I think the Australian Local Government Association, having been successful in getting the Roads to Recovery program up, are now on the cusp of getting another successful program up if they really lobby hard and apply the political pressure that is required. I encourage them to do that to the best of their intent, because the one per cent income tax receipts that are being talked about are a very worthy goal.

When you start to look at the $11.8 billion included in this AusLink funding program, there are a number of things that suddenly jump out at you. The government is arguing that, because Roads to Recovery was not planned to go beyond this year, it is not in the forward estimates, and therefore it is new money if it goes on into the future. So the government is arguing that that is part of the growth in infrastructure funding. I would dispute that. I would suggest that that is clouding the issue somewhat.

Another thing that is clouding the issue is in relation to the Fuel Sales Grants Scheme. Most people would remember that the Fuel Sales Grants Scheme was put in place to alleviate the disparity between country and city fuel prices that would have occurred when the 10 per cent GST was imposed. The government, assisted by the National Farmers Federation and othersâand the member for Parkes was involved at that time as a farmer representativeâquite rightly argued at the time that country people should not be disadvantaged in any way by the imposition of the goods and services tax. The Fuel Sales Grants Scheme was put in place to neutralise the impact, by way of location, of a government tax.

The government has decided to remove that money. Although it is $270 million a year, it is accounted for in this document as $810 million over three years. That means that country motorists will in a sense be paying for that portion of the $11.8 billion. Country motorists will pay from one cent to 3c a litre more for fuel at the bowser because of the removal of this scheme. Even worse than that, out of the $810 million that country motorists used to receive, there is no guarantee at all that that money will go to country projects. There is no focus in the documents that suggests that country people will be advantaged by that $810 million.

In the few moments left to me, I will briefly run through some other infrastructure needs that I believe have an impact on the New England and north-west area and should be looked at in terms of future estimates of infrastructure requirements and costings. I spoke earlier of the Murrurundi rail tunnel and the Newcastle port. Bolivia Hill, south of Tenterfield on the New England Highway, has to be one of the major traffic hazards that is left on the national highway. I do congratulate the government for the work that it has been doing on the New England Highway. A lot of good work is being done there, but I do not see Bolivia Hill factored into the AusLink arrangements and I think it should be. There is also the inland rail initiative that I spoke of before. There is currently some examination within the electorate of a transport hub to be based at Glen Innes. If that is seen to be feasible, it may well require the extension of the rail line to be reopened above Armidale through to Queensland, which would be a major initiative for the electorate of New England but it would impact on other areas.

I would like to spend a moment on the strategic regional projects in the AusLink papers. There has been some adjustment of the total sums of money but, effectively, it is $30 million a year for five years and is there for various councils that may come together and decide they have a worthy regional project that needs greater funding than would flow through the normal Roads to Recovery or other government grant processes. I think it is a good idea, and I encourage the government. I think the Tenterfield Council is coming to this House next week to talk to the minister about the road from Legume to Woodenbong in my electorate. It is on the northern extremity. The Woodenbong point is 128 kilometres from Brisbane, but it has an enormous impact on a number of electorates in southern Queensland, the Darling Downs, the top end of New England and, very importantly, the Lismore and Casino areas on the coast of New South Wales. It is one of those classic cases where funding of this strategic project would advantage a number of councils, two states, and a number of members of parliament from different backgrounds. I would urge the minister to look very closely at that project because it is a very worthy one.

I spoke briefly a moment ago about the Australian Rail Track Corporation, the $872 million negotiation that took place between the state and the Commonwealth governments last year and the final sign-off. The AusLink documentation seems to suggest that the Commonwealth government is putting $872 million into that arrangement. In fact, it reads that way, but it is not strictly true. The federal government is only putting $150 million in; the New South Wales government, $50 million; and Pacific National, $50 million. The federal government is arranging for debt funding of $620 million. Although I recognise the importance of the agreement, I think the minister should be careful in articulating that there has been $872 million injected at a federal level. That is not the case at all. I am also aware that the ARTC is to manage the remaining linesâthe non-Hunter, non-metropolitan linesâin New South Wales. I would like the minister to articulate in his reply what that will mean for some of the smaller lines that will not become part of the national network. (Time expired)

talk.start.para: âIn this debate on the AusLink (National Land Transport) Bill 2004 and related legislation there is really no debate at all about the crucial need for investment in land transport infrastructure in this country. Australia's vast size and its dependence on bulk commodity exports means that a safe and efficient land transport network is a central part of maintaining our productivity and our standard of living. In areas like the one that I represent, the condition of our road and rail infrastructure has a direct bearing on everyday life. The road and rail links between the coal and beef producers and their processors and markets are make-or-break for these industries. That is why it is so important for this government to understand the needs and the potential of these industries in regional Australia and to support their growth through strategic investment in relevant infrastructure.

speech.para: Just as important is the way that the state of roads impacts on the daily lives of people in my electorate and their access to services and opportunities. Whether it is for medical treatment, education or, in the case of many coalminers, the trip back and forth from their homes on the coast to their jobs at the mines, the state of roads is an issue of equity, safety and quality of life. As I said, there is no debate at all about the importance of infrastructure in this country. Rather, the debate on this bill is about how to achieve a strategically planned and integrated land transport network that delivers the best possible returns on the government's infrastructure spending.

Labor do not believe that AusLink as it is proposed in these bills achieves those aims. That is why we intend to refer the bills to a Senate committee for further investigation and why we have moved the second reading amendment, which calls on the government to maintain funding responsibility for the construction and maintenance of the national highway, to establish a national infrastructure advisory council and to extend the criteria for Roads to Recovery to include public transport, cycling, walking infrastructure and regional airport runways.

Australia's infrastructure needs have come into sharp focus in recent times, but it is for all the wrong reasons. The government, of course, wants to tell us about the bright new future for infrastructure planning and investment under AusLink, but it still has an awful lot of explaining to do about exactly what it has been doingâor rather not doingâfor the last nine years. What has it been doing while capacity constraints have developed at our ports, holding back vital export industries like the booming black coal industry in Central Queensland? What has it been doing while bottlenecks have grown worse on our major rail freight routes? And what has it been doing while funding for the national highway has failed to keep pace with the need for upgrading and maintenance?

While we are debating these AusLink bills the Australian economy is starting to feel the results of this government's failure to invest wisely and strategically in the important transport infrastructure that our industries need to remain competitive and to make the most of opportunities that are presented by a buoyant world economy. It is not just the opposition that is making these points. Earlier this week the Reserve Bank warned about the risk of increased inflation and rising interest rates as a result of infrastructure constraints and skills shortages. Infrastructure constraints and skills shortages do not materialise overnight, so it is obvious that this government has been asleep at the wheel for the last nine years. It is a government that is happy to cash in on the hard and meaningful reform work that the last Labor government put in placeâa government that is happy to take all the creditâbut which is too complacent and self-satisfied to face up to the challenges that needed to be addressed in order to maintain the improvements in productivity and competitiveness that Labor achieved in the Australian economy.

While the government wants to sell its AusLink package as a sign of its commitment to strategic and integrated planning and funding of infrastructure, we in the Labor Party see plenty to be sceptical about based on the government's dismal performance over the past nine years, as evidenced by the pressure points in our economy that were obvious to everyone, it now seems, except the Howard government. The concerns that the Labor Party have about AusLink in its current form are reflected in our second reading amendment. For example, we are concerned that, for all its talk about integrated planning and funding partnerships with the state governments, is AusLink really just an exercise in cost-shifting and stepping back from the Commonwealth government's responsibility in the area of land transport? That certainly seems to be the case when it comes to funding for the national highway.

AusLink requires the federal government to determine a national land transport network consisting of nationally significant road and rail links, but it does not identify the national highway, nor does it specify federal government responsibility for construction and maintenance of the national highway network. So where is the certainty for the people of Central Queenslandâwho rely on the Bruce Highway as a lifeline to Brisbane for so many business and personal needsâthat funding will be there for its maintenance and upgrading as population pressures increase traffic on that road? Instead of the Commonwealth accepting its responsibility for that vital piece of national infrastructure, it has now capped its contribution to maintenance of the national highway at $300 million per annum for the five-year life of the current AusLink agreement. The maintenance shortfall, which can only get bigger, especially in a fast-growing state like Queensland, is left for the state government to pick up.

Labor's election commitment to fully fund the national highway would provide much more certainty to the people of my electorate that the Bruce Highway would receive the attention it deserves as the major transport link along the Queensland coast. We are also concerned that this package builds in the same flaws and opportunities for pork-barrelling that we have seen demonstrated in the Regional Partnerships program. Funding for projects in key elements of the AusLink packageâthe AusLink strategic regional projects funding and a proportion of the Roads to Recovery fundingâare left to the minister's discretion. Where have we heard that one before? Just a couple of hours ago in question time and in the censure motion debate. Prior to the last election $93 million of strategic regional projects money was already committed, and you can bet that the minister will be busy exercising his discretion in favour of his National Party mates in key seats in the lead-up to the next election.

Labor take the infrastructure needs of this country much more seriously. We actually believe that when it comes to investing millions, if not billions, of dollars in infrastructure it is the national interest, rather than narrow self-serving political interests, that should prevail. That is why Labor have taken the proposal for a national infrastructure advisory council to the last two elections. When it comes to building a strategic and integrated transport network in Australia we want decisions to be based on the best possible independent advice, free from political interests. Our plan for an advisory council would see infrastructure investments guided by objective advice from industry, consumer and expert representatives based on transparent social, economic and environmental criteria.

Given the way that the funding for the Regional Partnerships program was distributed, the people of my electorate of Capricornia are well entitled to ask whether the Howard government can be trusted to distribute the funding for AusLink equitably across all of Australia. Across the local government areas of Central Queensland there are 146 roads which have been identified as roads of regional significance by the Central Queensland Regional Road Group. The people of Central Queensland would like to be assured that these roads, which local councils have determined hold the key to future development in Central Queensland, will be given the necessary priority to ensure that they are upgraded to a standard which will support the opportunities we are creating in the mining, agriculture, defence and tourism industries.

In the Livingstone shire alone, 39 roads have been identified as vital to tourist development on the Capricorn Coast, as well as the much needed improvement of the access roads to the Shoalwater Bay defence training area. I particularly wish to dwell for a moment on these access roads to Shoalwater Bay. I am sure that all in this House are aware of the importance of this facility to our defence forces and our allies who use the Shoalwater Bay training area. We on this side of the House believe that the access roads to Shoalwater Bay are not only roads of regional significance but, in fact, roads of national significance, due to the critical role that Shoalwater Bay plays in our national defence capability. This is why prior to the last election we committed an Australian Labor government to spending the $15 million necessary to ensure adequate access to the military training area.

The Shoalwater Bay training area is widely recognised as one of the best military training facilities in the world. This facility is the only area in Australia where the Army, Air Force and Navy are able to engage in joint military exercises. This area is used extensively by Australian forces and those of our allies the United States and Singapore. Training exercises and joint manoeuvres are held at Shoalwater Bay regularly.

The Shoalwater Bay training area is serviced by four road routes. These are the Stanage Bay Road, better known as the grey route; Raspberry Creek Road, better known as the green route; Rossmoya and Canal Creek roads, better known as the brown route; and Farnborough and Byfield roads, better known as the blue route. It is worth noting that the blue route is a Queensland Department of Main Roads road and is sealed up to Byfield. So one could argue that the Queensland government has done its bit for national security and it is now up to the Howard Government to do its bit by attending to the other three entrance roads to this vital training facility.

Whilst it is true that the Department of Defence does provide some `make good' funding to the Livingstone Shire Council to assist with road repairs to Shoalwater Bay, undertaking the proposed upgrading works will result in long-term savings of approximately one-third of the annual maintenance cost of the existing gravel roads. This is particularly important with the prospect now of an expansion of military exercises in Shoalwater Bay following last year's signing by the government of a joint training agreement with the United States.

It is expected that by 2007 the Central Queensland region will be hosting as many as 10,000 US soldiers. It is not good enough for the Howard government to commit our country to such an undertaking without due consideration to the added demands it will place on the infrastructure in Central Queensland. Patch-up money for maintenance of these rural roads will simply not keep up with the demands placed on these roads, and it should not be the ratepayers of Livingstone shire who foot the bill.

As well as the Queensland government, the whole of the Central Queensland region has invested heavily in infrastructure to support and profit from Defence Force use of the Shoalwater Bay training area. Further infrastructure and development is required to keep Shoalwater Bay training area as a preferred training venue, with the resulting benefits to our regional economy. It is estimated that Defence Force exercises at Shoalwater Bay training area inject $10 million into the regional economy every year. This figure is significantly more every second year, when joint exercises with the US defence forces are conducted. In addition, there are significant multiplier effects to the wider economy of Central Queensland, including an estimated $7 million expended through military tourism in the region every year.

The people of Central Queensland ask the government to pick up the commitment made by the Australian Labor Party and fund these roads of national defence importance. We ask the government to seal the remaining gravel sections of the Rossmoya Road, Canal Creek Road, the Raspberry Creek Road and Stanage Bay Road to the entrance of the Shoalwater Bay training area. Members of this House may recall, as do the people of Central Queensland, that it was only after the commitment I and the Australian Labor Party made prior to the 1998 federal election to upgrade the runway at Rockhampton Airport that the Howard government finally provided the money to enable the use of Rockhampton Airport by jumbo jets. That was necessary for the continued development and use of the defence training facilities at Shoalwater Bay, and so too is the sealing of the access roads to the Shoalwater Bay training area.

It is not just in the area of supporting the defence industry and defence activity in Central Queensland that we need assistance from the federal government. As anyone reading the paper over the last couple of weeks would know, the coal industry is also crying out for immediate investment in infrastructure to support that industry. This is necessary for the prosperity of not only Central Queensland, which is the biggest coalmining area in Australia, but also the whole of our national economy.

That brings me to another important transport project in my electorate, the so-called missing link that would open up access between the whole of the northern Bowen Basin coalmining region and the Abbot Point coal-loading facility at Bowen in North Queensland. Construction of 70 kilometres of railway line would link the Newlands-Abbot Point line with the Goonyella-Moranbah line, providing an integrated transport link between the Bowen Basin coal industry and the port of Abbot Point. With an estimated construction cost of $72.2 million, it was determined by a Queensland Rail feasibility study in 1993 that sufficient benefit could be generated to justify investment in the rail link. There is no question, 12 years on from that feasibility study, that the time has come for the federal government to look very closely at this project, which would solve many of the problems facing the coal industry right now.

As I said, we have seen stories in the paper day after day this week on the capacity constraints that are becoming very obvious at the coal-loading facilities in Newcastle and, closer to my home in Central Queensland, at the coal-loading facilities of Hay Point and Dalrymple Bay. Coal production is booming in the Bowen Basin and there is huge demand for Australian black coal. The advantages of building this rail link between the Newlands-Abbot Point line and the Goonyella-Moranbah line are that it would open up the Bowen Basin to Abbot Point and that it would create an alternative coal export facility to those at Dalrymple Bay and Hay Point, which are constrained not only by their capacity constraints but also by weather. Abbot Point is much more reliable throughout the year and is not as affected by the weather as Dalrymple Bay and Hay Point are. There is capacity in the current design of Abbot Point to double the size of the Abbot Point coal-loading facility, and I am told by the Bowen Collinsville Enterprise organisation that that could be done at a much lower cost than an equivalent expansion at either Hay Point or Dalrymple Bay.

The constraints on export capacity are really holding back activity in the coal industry at the moment. It is crazy for the government to overlook this relatively minor infrastructure projectâjust 70 kilometres of rail line that could greatly expand the coal exporting capacity of Central Queensland. The Bowen Collinsville Enterprise organisation has, in conjunction with the Bowen Shire Council, done an awful lot of homework on this project, as has Queensland Rail. I think it is very much the time, when we hear about the constraints on our coal exporting capacity every day, to look closely at this project under the strategic regional projects element of AusLink, to see what can be done to support this project so as to open up not just the coal industry but also possibilities for other bulk commodities that could be shipped out through Abbott Point. The project would be of enormous benefit to the town of Bowen, which has done it tough in the last few years, and also to its neighbouring town of Collinsville, which is an important coalmining centre some 80 kilometres south-west of Bowen.

In conclusion I want to urge the government to take seriously the approach that the Labor Party has taken to this bill. We are not blocking the bill in any sense. We have moved the second reading amendment in very good faith, putting forward ideas that we have come up with for important infrastructure development in this country, proposing a way forward to make sure that infrastructure investment is done in a way that is not partisan in any way and is coherent and strategicâensuring that it is not done to favour one interest over another. Our proposals for a national infrastructure advisory council are all about taking the politics out of infrastructure spending and I think that is very worthy and something that the government should look at very closely. Our other proviso on supporting this bill is to subject the measures to a Senate inquiry. That is also done in a very constructive spirit, because we realise at the moment that we have had too little focus on infrastructure spending in this country and that is now really creating bottlenecks that can jeopardise our economic prosperity into the future. We are supporting the bill, but I call on the government not only to look closely at the projects that I have highlighted in my electorate but also to consider carefully the recommendations that come out of the Senate inquiry, because the inquiry will be carried out in the national interest.

talk.start.para: âThe AusLink (National Land Transport) Bill 2004 and the AusLink (National Land TransportâConsequential and Transitional Provisions) Bill 2004 have the capacity to impact on the future prosperity of Australia. This can be seen from the contributions made by speakers on both sides of the House. From an economic point of view no issues are more important than those covered in this legislation. This package of bills provides for an integrated network of road and rail transport linkages of national importance and includes funding provisions for programs under a new national land transport network, black spot projects, a new discretionary fund for strategic regional projects and continuing projects under the Roads to Recovery program. In making my contribution to the parliament, I will talk about a number of those.

speech.para: It is imperative that Australia has the best, most effective and efficient transport system available. To achieve this it must embrace all forms of transport and of infrastructure supporting our transport systems: rail, road, sea, public transport, airport runways, cycleways and walkways. Some of those are not covered in this legislation. One of the glaring omissions from this legislation is any mention whatsoever of shipping and port infrastructure, because that infrastructure is vital for our nation. I find this most disturbing. After all, Australia is an island nation and shipping and our ports are vital to our future. I support the linkage of road and rail, but I believe it would enhance our transport system if the issues surrounding shippingâsuch as our portsâwere also covered by this legislation.

I commence my contribution to this debate by highlighting the importance of our national transport system or network. Unfortunately, I believe the government has been negligent and has ignored the best optionsâthe best practiceâon the grounds of opting once again for a political approach and grubby politics. I do not believe that when it comes to something as vital as this we should be indulging ourselves in grubby politics. I come to this place having looked at roads from three different levels of government. I have been fortunate enough to be a representative at local government level, state level and now federal level. At each of those levels the issues surrounding roads and road infrastructure are amongst the most important issues.

Back in 2001-02, I conducted a survey of my electorate. I presented the constituents of Shortland with a list of items and asked them to rank them from the most important to the least important. Of all the items that people were presented with roads came out on top as an issue. The road infrastructure within their area was highlighted by 96 per cent of people as being of great importance. This legislation covers a number of areas, and I will spend some time going through them.

The purpose of this AusLink legislation is to limit the operation of the Australian Land Transport Development Act 1988 and to remove the ALTD special account. This requires that a national land transport network consisting of nationally significant roads and rail links be determined. This is fundamentally different from existing arrangements as it does not identify the national highway network, which has been an underlying principle in all previous legislation. I find that of great concern. It does not specify federal government responsibility for the construction and maintenance of our national highway network either. I know that many speakers on this side of the House have already highlighted that fact, and we have highlighted it because we see this as the Commonwealth moving away from one of its core responsibilities. The Commonwealth has always had responsibility for our national highways.

In this legislation, I see the government inching away from its responsibilities. One of the things that always concerns me, no matter what area I am looking at, is the tension between the Commonwealth, state and local government. Each level of government often tries to shift its areas of responsibility to the other. I do not think that is the best solution for the Australian people. I think the best solution is for the federal government to show leadership, and for all levels of government to work together, rather than having a situation where one level of government is seeking to abrogate its responsibilities. I fear that, by not identifying the national highway network and by moving away from its responsibilities for the construction and maintenance of the national highway, the Commonwealth is abrogating its responsibilities. The bill sets out eligibility criteria for different categories of assistance and the matters which may be considered in deciding whether a project or activities are to be approved or funded. It provides conditions for funding. Under the existing arrangements, state and federal governments identify the priorities for federal funding and provide project management. This will change under this legislation.

One of the things that really concerns me is the discretionary power that the minister will have under this legislation. I know I speak for my colleagues on this side of the House when I say that we believe in accountability and openness. I do not think you can achieve those things where there is a high level of discretionary power. The minister decides how to allocate funds for projects under AusLink strategic regional projects. I fear that can lead to pork-barrelling and the establishment of another National Party slush fundâanother fund to re-elect the Howard government.

The Australian people deserve better than that. The Australian people deserve a government that makes its decisions openly and does not rely on discretionary power. Earlier today we were talking about the Regional Partnerships program. The thing that worries me about that program is that the area consultative committee can make a recommendation and then that recommendation can be overridden by the minister. I do not believe that is good government. I do not believe that is best practice in government. I find it particularly disturbing that one of the projects that has been discussed is Tumbi Creek, which is in the Wyong Shire Council area, which is also included in the Shortland electorate.

talk.start.para: (Mr Baldwin)âOrder! The member will bring herself back to the bill.

âThank you, Mr Deputy Speaker. But don't be too sensitive about it, because I am actually talking about discretionary powersâhow discretionary powers work currently and how they will work under this legislation. I feel that, where there are examples of discretionary powers not working properly, it behoves me, as a member of this House, to highlight that fact in the parliament.

speech.para: The process that was adopted in the development of this legislation was as follows. There was a green paper on 7 January 2002 and, once that green paper was tabled, it was open for comment until 7 February 2003. There were 550 written submissions, from government, industry and the community. The white paper was released in June 2004. The green paper that had a joint working group on AusLink priorities on the national network was established to assist in the development of a possible set of national infrastructure priorities for the initial five years. However, the thing that concerns me is that state and territory governments have complained that there was little or no consultation in developing the national priorities for the first five years of the AusLink national land transport plan. This is of great concern because, as I highlighted earlier, the best results are achieved by governments at all levels working together.
I would like to briefly turn to the white paper. In doing so, I wish to highlight that all the right words are used. The executive summary says:

quote.para: The Australian Government is embarking on a far-reaching transformation of the way Australia plans, funds and delivers land transport infrastructure.

speech.para: Planning is good. The words used in this executive summary are good, but what about the details that underline this? The executive summary continues:

quote.para: Under AusLink, the Australian Government takes a strategic approach to Australia's future ...

speech.para: A strategic approach is the approach that needs to be taken. The document goes on to say that it does this `by ensuring that the nation's land transport network meets future challenges'. But I really do not think that this legislation does that, and that is the sad part of it. It is a missed opportunity. The government had the opportunity to do that, to ensure the development of the type of modern infrastructure that would take Australia into the next century, that would ensure sustainable economic growth, and I believe it has failed. It has failed to a large extent by slipping into the mire of partisan politics yet again, just as it did with the Regional Partnerships program.

I would now like to highlight some of the issues that I see as important and some of the areas where I think the government has failed. I have highlighted the discretionary power of the minister. I do not like that. As I pointed out, that has been well established. You have seen the flaws in that today here in the House, particularly with reference to Tumbi Creek. The Commonwealth is also abrogating its responsibilityâthe cost sharing with the states for the maintenance of the highway. I feel that that is extremely flawed and a very bad step by the government. I think the government really needs to revisit that.

The Labor Party, as the member for Capricornia pointed out so admirably in her contribution to the parliament, has gone to the last two elections with a proposal for a national infrastructure council. That would get around some of the problems that I have with this legislation. It would be an open and accountable way to look at developing the priorities that are in the nation's interests. It would be a way to ensure that those statements that I read out from the white paperâabout our need to plan and deliver the funds in the appropriate wayâactually get put into practice so that we do get a land transport network that meets the future needs of Australia. We need this to happen without political interference.

We do not need any more National Party slush funds, we do not need any more re-elect Howard slush funds; we need good quality infrastructure. We need investment in the development of this infrastructure and we need that to be determined on a needs basis and in a way that will ensure that Australia has the best infrastructureâinfrastructure that meets the needs of our nation. We need a cooperative approach that includes all levels of government, the community and business. I do not think that that can happen under this legislation. I did refer to the flaws in that process in relation to the first five-year AusLink national land transport plan and the fact that the states and territories were not happy with the consultation in relation to that and their ability to have input into that. We need quality infrastructure. We need this to work for the future of Australia. We need it for economic growth and sustainable regional communities. Unless we have the right sort of infrastructure and the right sort of transport system, that will never happen.

As I have already highlighted a number of times, we do not want any more National Party slush funds. We do not want any more pork-barrelling. We do not want a new Regional Partnerships program. We do not want any more partisan decisions: the kinds of decisions that have happened with the National Trust program or with the Roads of National Importanceâor with Networking the Nation, in the communication area. We want that to stop. We want decisions made on merit. We want our infrastructure to be invested in and developed in the interests of the nation, not in the interests of partisan politics. That approach is not in Australia's interests. Parochial politics do not lead to a sustainable economic future. It is time the government moved away from that approach and developed an approach that is for all Australians and in Australia's interests.

Governments have choices. This government can choose to govern for all Australians and in the best interests of our nation or it can choose to adopt a small-minded partisan political approach: I fear that this legislation has the potential to allow the government to again make the second choice. We need quality infrastructure. We need infrastructure for the futureâto ensure a strong future. We do not want to end up as a second-rate nation. Australia needs a strong national transport and infrastructure system, with a national highway properly funded by a government preoccupied with theâ

talk.start.para: âWhere are you getting this from?
âOrder! The member deserves to be heard in silence.

âThank you very much, Mr Deputy Speaker; I appreciate your intervention and protection from the minister. We need a government that will lead us towards a prosperous future with the infrastructure that this nation needs for economic growth and for a sound future. Australia needs a transport system that is developed in an independent manner by an independent body, a body like the national infrastructureâ (Time expired)

âI am constantly amazed at the piety of opposition when whiteboards and blackboards are put aside until they can be dragged out when the government benches are resumed. At least there is, I thinkâI hopeâthe germ of a constructive suggestion in the contribution of the previous speaker, the member for Shortland. I hope that the comments I make might suggest some sort of way whereby we may get a processâand I think we have already got it with the Grants Commission allocating Roads to Recovery moneyâwhere money is allocated on a fair and reasonable basis depending on need, length of road, population and the actual need of the local government area in question.

speech.para: The AusLink (National Land Transport) Bill 2004 puts into place the mechanism for the government's new integrated approach to the planning and financing of a national land transport network. That is a very good thing. The plan outlined in the bill is the culmination, we are told, of three years of consultation and development and allocates some $11.8 billion in federal funding over five years for both road and rail and for an integrated land transport network. The government has identified a doubling in non-bulk freight, a doubling in interstate road freight and a 40 per cent increase in passenger travel to 2020.

I am happy to see the additional $872 million to be invested in the Australian Rail Track Corporation for the eastern seaboard north-south rail links over the next five years. I remember evidence given to the `Time running out' inquiry that I was a member of a couple of years back. That was an inquiry of the Standing Committee on Primary Industries and Regional Services. If I remember correctly, Mr Deputy Speaker Baldwin, you may have been a part of that. Time after time, there was evidence of the parlous state of our rail network. I seem to remember a story about our main Brisbane-Sydney line where the guard had to reach out and manually trigger the signals at certain points along that link. This was in 1999-2000. The network has been Third World standard in many respects, and anything that can be done to bring that link alone up to world-class standard must be welcome. We must strike a balance between rail and road in this country and allow rail to catch up. It is way, way behind. I believe that this national land transport bill goes a long way towards improving that critical state of our rail network.

I want to concentrate my remarks on the aspects of the plan supporting local and regional infrastructure. In January last year, the minister announced the continuation of the Roads to Recovery program, which was due to expire at the end of financial year 2005. The 2004-05 budget provided for the allocation of another $1.2 billion to the program over four years. That consisted of $200 million per year to be allocated under the Roads to Recovery formula to fund local roads and $100 million allocated on a competitive basis for projects of economic and social significance.

The AusLink white paper released in June last year split this funding into two streams, providing $400 million for Strategic Regional Projects and $800 million for the AusLink Roads to Recovery program. During the election campaign, the coalition announced that it would top up funding available to councils under the Roads to Recovery formula to its original $1.2 billion over four years. Councils quite rightly saw the white paper's two-stream formula as cutting their guaranteed allocations by a third. This has been corrected. In the same policy document, `Building our national transport future', the coalition undertook to provide Strategic Regional Projects funding of $120 million over the same period. I am not quite sure whether this money replaces the $400 million allocated to the strategic regional projects in the white paper or whether it is in addition to it. I hope that the minister or his advisers might be able to clarify this situation.

Roads to Recovery has been an extremely important program for councils in my electorate, providing councils with much-needed extra road funding since its introduction four years ago. What is more, unlike other programs which have had a good airing in recent days, it has been allocated by an independent process, through the Grants Commission, according to a clear formula. It has enabled the replacement of old and dangerous bridges, the upgrading of intersections and the widening of narrow country roads. The number of signs around my electorate, and no doubt others, is testament to the worth of the projects to which that money has been put.

But there are figures that show that we are only beginning to catch up with the slow decline in infrastructure spending in this country over the last 20 years, particularly in roads since 1990. The figures in the Bills Digest quite clearly display the fact that in real termsâand I know the GST has become available to the states in that periodâCommonwealth funding has slipped from $1,597.3 million in 1993-94 dollars in the 1990-91 year to $1,358.2 million in 2002-03.

It can be rightly said that, while very welcome and necessary, the Roads to Recovery program has but helped catch up, to a degree, with the clear falling away in funding over that decade and longer. It is welcome, and this national AusLink program will go further towards redressing that fall off in national infrastructure spending over the last two decades. The AusLink strategic regional project is designed to support local transport projects of regional, economic and social significance, as described in the white paper. In brief, the idea is to target local transport links that are significant to major transport corridors that are part of the national network that form an important part of the economic development strategies within a region, provide access to export related transport networks and enhance access for regional communities to services and employment.

I would hope this includes a serious examination of transport links from western New South Wales to the ports of Newcastle and Wollongong so that we do not put all our planning energy into the Sydney corridor, of which I will say a little bit more in a moment. There is a lot of evidence coming from and supported by gentlemen such as Professor John Chudleigh, who has had a lot of input into the government's regional strategies over the years. He and others are very concerned that we are thinking in terms of east-west development, particularly in New South Wales, and we are not looking enough at our north-south links, particularly in the tableland area just west of the Great Divide. There are links, such as that through Canberra, Goulburn, Bathurst and north to Mudgee, that have been improved significantly in recent years with Roads to Recovery and black spot funding. It is a bit like the Telstra networkâit is a super highway in parts, a reasonable highway in parts and virtually a dirt track in others. It needs to be linked up into one major link so that we can deflect a lot of transport pressure from the Blue Mountains corridor to the ports of Newcastle and Wollongong. I note an earlier contributionâI think it was from the member for Hunterâwhich said that we must also be looking at integrating our transport and infrastructure strategies to include our port infrastructure.

That brings me to the national infrastructure report that was done by a parliamentary committee and delivered in February 2000. There were a couple of key recommendations. I believe the most important one in fact was recommendation 6:

quote.para: ... that the Commonwealth Government establish a National Infrastructure Advisory Council with expertise from the public and the private sectors, to facilitate the efficient and equitable provision of national infrastructure by both public and private sector stakeholders.

speech.para: Many recommendations in that report referred to the need for the national infrastructure council to be set up as an advisory council to report, through the Council of Australian Governments, to ministers responsible for regional development on strategic infrastructureâwhere it is taking place and what the needs areâand looking forward 10, 20 and 30 years rather than succumbing to the temptation to look only at the electoral cycle. The AusLink program is the beginning of that sort of structure, but it lacks the vision that this report recommended following the input of Fred Argy and others, along with councils all over Australia, infrastructure experts and tax experts looking at the potential for superannuation funds to become involved in national infrastructure and so on. There is an element of that structure in the rail portion of this AusLink program, and I know the minister said that he did not want to have another advisory group involved in the process. But I and the committee, made up of members of this House from right across the political spectrum, saw enough evidence to suggest strongly that it should be a prime consideration in any transport policy in this country.

As others have said, there is far too much discretionary spending in this particular bill. There are real concerns in my mind about some of the approval of projects processes built into the bill. I notice under division 1, approval of projects, it is commented by those researching this bill that the minister's determination is not required to be tabled in each house of parliament and is not subject to disallowance. That may or may not attract the interest of the minister, but I would like him, if he would, to explain exactly why that process is in place. There is a comment at the end of the Bills Digest that details of projects approved under the national plan are not required to be tabled or published, with the exception of the Roads to Recovery program. Given that there is a large discretionary fund for competitive tendering, it does suggest that there could be a temptationânot necessarily with this minister or government but in years aheadâfor any minister in a tight election process to use a discretion that is not in the best interests of regional or national infrastructure priorities and wise spending of scarce public moneys.

I would like to comment on a couple of the contributions that councils in my area made to the AusLink green paper. The Central West Regional Organisation of Councils, CENTROC, said amongst other things in its submission:

quote.para: It has long been recognised that transport will play an increasing part in the area's development.

speech.para: CENTROC stretches from Condobolin to Wellington, Forbes, Cowra and all the councils in between to the Blue Mountains. The submission continued:

quote.para: Intermodal points are now established at Blayney and Parkes and others are planned. Road conditions, as mentioned elsewhere in this submission, impeded the realisation of the area's potential. All of the local government areas in CENTROC have an umbilical cord to Sydney via the Great Western Highway and this road is the dominant form of transport and clearly needs the most focus.

speech.para: While the Dubbo-Sydney link is on the AusLink program, there seems to me to be a strong need to look at those links to the ports of Newcastle and Wollongong and to also see a greater commitment to the Mid Western Highway and those other links between Bathurst, Cowra, Parkes and the Blue Mountains.

In recent days a draft of the Blue Mountains highway proposal has been released. This is being conducted by consultants for a tri-government Blue Mountains access group, which is headed by the Hon. Ian Armstrong and includes members of all political parties, state and federal; Independents; and party representatives west of the Blue Mountains. It has detailed a four-lane divided highway which would commence south of Windsor and approximate the Bells Line of Road up to the Newnes Plateau then follow the plateau north of Lithgow and intersect with the Great Western Highway at the Mudgee turn-off.

Members may remember some suggestions that were pilloried by the state Labor government where tunnels under the mountains were suggested. There have been any number of suggestions of how this can be done and how the sand derived from those tunnels from the sandstone curtain could be used for Sydney's building boom in the years ahead. I think the money involved in such a project would absolutely preclude its completion on a cost-benefit ratio at this point. However, we now haveâit will not be released in detail for another six weeks or soâan engineering and economic report that suggests that an above topography route, which is 94 kilometres in length, is feasible. It will run into some quite significant opposition through the fact that six kilometres of it will touch on the declared wilderness area of the Blue Mountains National Park. That is going to be a major hurdle, no doubt.

I put it to the House that unless there is a `decoagulation', if you likeâit is the only word I can think ofâof that link across the Blue Mountains, we are going to get gridlock within 10, 15 or 20 years. The central west of New South Wales, and all of those arteries leading into that route across the mountains, carry goods that contribute enormously to the production and the wealth of this country. We must find a route across those mountains that is better than the existing Great Western Highway.

The government assisted by declaring the Great Western Highway a road of national importance in the late nineties and I think they contributed something in the order of $100 million to help develop that improved access. But the more that route is being improved, the more it is resembling a glorified Pennant Hills road. I have travelled it several times recently. While there is an enormous amount of work being done, it strikes me that with its variation of speed limitsâ50, 60, 70, 80 and 90 kilometres per hourâit is never going to represent the sort of national highway link that will be required in the years ahead. That begs the question: why don't we look more at the Bells Line of Road option to see if we cannot reach some sort of compromise? The suggested route, as I understand it, goes behind the heritage villages of the Bilpin area. I think it is very much worth investigating. If it gets approvalâand there is enormous support for itâthen it should become part of the AusLink program and attract significant federal support, as should the upgrading of the rail linkages not only into Sydney but into those ports of Newcastle and Wollongong, as I have suggested.

talker.name: Lloyd, Jim, MP
Mr LLOYD
talker.role: Minister for Local Government, Territories and Roads

talk.start.para: âI take this opportunity to thank all honourable members for their contribution to this debate. Today is a very significant day in this parliament, where we will see the passing of the AusLink (National Land Transport) Bill 2004 and the AusLink (National Land TransportâConsequential and Transitional Provisions) Bill 2004 through this House.

speech.para: These bills represent major reform legislation. They herald the most important change to national land transport policy in the past 30 years. The AusLink program has a generational commitment to transport infrastructure improvement. It will help deliver on the government's vision for a land transport system that can both meet the challenges of the transport task and make its contribution to a stronger economy. Since coming to office, the Australian government has already taken major steps towards positioning Australia to sustain long-term economic growth. It has significantly reduced public debt by some $70 billion and fundamentally restructured the tax system. High performing land transport infrastructure is a further prerequisite to ongoing improvements in our national productivity and competitiveness as our population ages over the next 20 to 30 years.

The AusLink initiative introduces a new, modern and innovative approach to land transport infrastructure planning, decision making and funding. It backs these reforms with a massive increase in funding which our sound economic stewardship has enabled us to provide. The overwhelming bulk of the AusLink investmentâover $8 billion over the next five yearsâwill be directed to the new land transport network. The new AusLink national network brings together for the very first time previously separated planned and funded road and rail networks into a single, integrated network which will be an essential foundation for a fully effective national transport system.

The government is providing the platform for the revitalisation of the national rail network. Without an effective interstate rail freight system, Australia's transport system cannot work. For the first time, the Australian government's transport infrastructure funding will be guided and underpinned by an announced five-year national plan. The five-year plan focuses on the highest priority projects that provide economic and social benefits from a national perspective. Importantly, we are also providing a five-year funding commitment which gives certainty to state and local governments, and to transport and construction industries. This is unprecedented and provides for certainty of investment.

AusLink provides the framework for a planned national system whereby all levels of government will be working to deliver the best transport investment. The Australian government has set out a clear strategic direction which governs the priorities it has established for the next five years. In brief, these priorities are: establishing long-term and integrated planning; improving the eastern seaboard's north-south corridors; improving interstate and interregional corridors; addressing urban congestion on key freight links; utilising technology where it can enhance and improve efficiency, safety and security on the national network; improving safety and security overall; protecting the Australian government's past investment in major links; and supporting regional and local economic growth. At the project level, the program provides for substantial investment in Australia's most important land transport links, including the F3 and Pacific Highway, the Hume Highway, the Sydney to Brisbane and Sydney to Melbourne interstate railways, and the Bruce and Calder highways.

The program enables many critical projects to be undertakenâthe Geelong bypass, the Peel deviation in Western Australia, the Port River expressway in South Australia and the Bridgewater Bridge in Tasmania are just a few examples. It is absurd to suggest that investment in such projects will not yield major economic benefits at both the national and local level. This will be the first time that a national government will be putting in place arrangements that look beyond the current five-year program through a development of long-term corridor strategies developed against a 20-year time horizon. Corridor strategies will provide the basis for identifying shared government priorities and provide non-government stakeholders with the opportunity to contribute to the longer term planning and funding of national land transport infrastructure in Australia.

Corridor strategies will be supported by a range of rigorous studies to determine corridor needs, deficiencies and future priorities. They will focus on identifying the best solution to the transport needs of each corridor, irrespective of the transport mode. Industry and stakeholder consultation will be a critical source of information. Work on developing corridor strategies in conjunction with the state and territory governments will commence in earnest this year. Initially we will focus on a small number of pilot studies and expand into larger groups as we gain experience.

There will be a nationally consistent project assessment methodology to inform the development of corridor strategies and the assessment of future project priorities. This methodology has been developed in conjunction with the states, territories and local government and has now also been agreed to by Australian Transport Council ministers. This is a key reform. The government has set up the framework for evidence based national investment. AusLink is about ensuring the nation invests in its best projects.

The opposition has made a number of proposals in its second reading amendment. The first relates to the discontinuation of the national highway system. The opposition amendment is critical of the discontinuation of the 30-year-old national highway system funding arrangement. The bill provides for the government to move beyond the single mode-focused national highway system to a broader and integrated network of nationally important road and rail links. A number of opposition members made comments during the debate which were also supportive of moving on from the old national highway system to a concept of a single, integrated network.

Under the announced AusLink program, all states and the Northern Territory will receive large increases in funding for construction projects on the national network. It is therefore quite ridiculous to suggest that the Australian government is somehow avoiding its funding responsibilities. The AusLink shared funding arrangements recognise that many projects on the national network as well as having substantial national benefits will also have benefits that are more local in nature. In these cases, funding contributions at both the national and state level are appropriate. The AusLink shared funding arrangements also recognise that the national network now includes links that previously had been totally or partly the responsibility of the states to fundâlinks that the Australian government previously had no responsibility for. At the same time, the Australian government is continuing to fully fund many projects on the former national highway system, particular those in rural and remote areas. The opposition's position is now an outdated approach to transport funding and, accordingly, the government does not support it.

The second part of the opposition amendment proposes the establishment of an independent national infrastructure advisory council. Whilst the government's AusLink white paper lays considerable stress on the importance of long-term planning for national land transport infrastructure, it cannot support the opposition's approach. Labor's proposal, which is lacking in any firm detail, is to set up another bureaucratic talkfest that will not provide effective advice on national priorities. Our view is that such advice is unnecessary at this stage, given that the national land transport network is premised on infrastructure investment priorities identified by the state governments. An example is the Pacific and Hume highways. Indeed, our priorities were reached following quite detailed consultation and advice from departments at the state government level. These governments will continue to work closely with us to establish corridor needs and priorities on the national network.

The AusLink white paper does moot in the future the establishment of a National Transport Advisory Council. The Australian Transport Council, comprising Australian, state and territory government representation, has already agreed to further consider the establishment of the National Transport Advisory Council in the future. If the council decides to establish such a body, it will provide strategic analysis and advice on long-term planning for the national transport system involving all stakeholders, including the private sector.

The Leader of the Opposition is completely wrong in his claims that AusLink is promoting tension between the Australian government and the states and territories. AusLink is intended to promote a cooperative approach between all levels of government in Australia for long-term transport infrastructure planning and implementation. The process that is already underway to establish agreed priorities on the national network is clear evidence of that. As a government, we will not abrogate our responsibilities to take decisions in the nation's best interests. We are setting priorities and making the investment. We work cooperatively with the states, territories and local governments, but we will not agree to Labor's amendment.

The third part of that second reading amendment is the broadening of the Roads to Recovery funding purpose. The AusLink bill also demonstrates the Australian government's continuing commitment to local communities through extending the very successful Roads to Recovery program beyond its initial time frame of 2005, a program that I recall the Leader of the Opposition called a `boondoggle' when it was first introduced, but it has been one of the government's greatest programs and well received, particularly with local councils throughout Australia.

I was also pleased to hear that many opposition members are convinced of the worth of this program, which has been, as I said earlier, of enormous benefit to local councils throughout Australia. Local councils know that it is a good thing, and opposition members also know that it is a good thing. In 2004-05 some $253 million is being provided for local roads in the final year of the current four-year Roads to Recovery program. By the end of this current program, some 12,000 local road projects will have been funded. In the four years from 2005-06, and 2008-09, a further $1.2 billion will be provided to local councillors on the basis of a similar funding formula arrangement that has applied under the current Roads to Recovery program.

That sends a very strong signal that this government is determined to continue to help achieve a vibrant economy and social outcomes for local communities. Councils will continue to have wide discretion in determining the projects to which their formula based applications are applied. The key condition is simply that it be spent on the construction and maintenance of roads. The government's firm view is that the planning and funding of public transport services is a state and, in some cases, local responsibility. That said, it is open to local councils to apply funding to road construction projects which might assist, for example, the efficient and safe operation of road based public transport. Honourable members might also like to note that the definition of a road in this bill already includes a path for the use of persons riding bicycles. We do not propose to extend the criteria beyond those for which we have currently provided.

Early passage of this legislation will enable local governments across Australia to be given certainty about the future of funding and the conditions applying to this important stream of funding to improve and maintain local roads. I urge the opposition to enable this legislation to pass not only through this House but through the Senate as quickly as possible so that this important program can again be funded for local councils.

In addition to the $1.453 billion, which will be distributed to councils on a formula basis, $150 million will be provided over the five years from 2004-05 to 2008-09 for local road projects of strategic regional importance. This will include funding for local roads in unincorporated areas. I emphasise that this is additional money. This is new money which is important to local councils. This funding for local roads under the Roads to Recovery money is in addition to the $2.55 billion over the next five years that will be provided to local councils as untied local road grants.

The government is concerned to see not only effective planning in investment decision making but also efficient project delivery arrangements. The application of the national construction code and implementation guidelines is a key part of the government's drive to improve the efficiency of the construction industry and eliminate uncompetitive practices. It is therefore an important element of the AusLink five-year funding agreements currently being negotiated with the states. I am delighted that the Victorian government has agreed to apply unchanged the national construction code to AusLink projects in Victoria.

Consistent with the government's longstanding undertaking to consult with the states and territories on any proposed changes to the code, the government will consult with the Victorian government on possible future changes to the code and implementation guidelines. A formal agreement is yet to be finalised where, for the purposes of the code, AusLink funding to Victoria would be considered as one project. Agreement to the code paves the way to settle the bilateral AusLink five-year funding agreement with Victoria. This development follows agreements being reached between the Australian and South Australian governments on joint implementation guidelines that will apply to major AusLink projects in South Australia.
