business.start.para: The DEPUTY SPEAKER (Hon. I.R. Causley) took the chair at 9.40 a.m.

talk.start.para: âThis morning I would like to pay tribute to two of my constituents, both of whom are very creative. The first is Jean Kent. Jean wrote to me in November last year to let me know that she had been awarded a grant of $20,000 by the Literature Board of the Australia Council for the Arts to work on her fifth collection of poetry. She has a book in the making which has a working title of `Mangoes and Madeleines'. She says this `will explore and celebrate places where a variety of contemporary Australians feel at home'. She has lived and worked in Lake Macquarie and the Hunter Valley since 1983 and says `you can be sure that these places will have starring roles!' Jean writes:

quote.para: This grant will be invaluable for my writing of the poems. Making any sort of living from literary writing is very difficult and funding from the Australia Council provides both an acknowledgement that this is valued work and time to concentrate on that work, without the distractions and stresses of other employment. I am very grateful for the support of literature through this program.

speech.para: Jean grew up in Queensland. She began publishing poetry in 1971 and, as she said, she has lived in Lake Macquarie since 1983 and is currently a lecturer in creative writing at the University of Newcastle. The subject of this new collection of poems, as I said, will range from Lake Macquarie and the Hunter Valley to Paris and Lithuania in order to explore and celebrate places where a variety of contemporary Australians feel at home. I pay tribute to Jean Kent.

The other creative young person in my electorate that I would like to speak about is Nikki Wilson-Smith. Nikki arrived in Canberra on the weekend along with another 36 young Australians for the Heywire Youth Issues Forum. This forum enables 16- to 22-year-olds to discuss issues relevant to them with Australia's political and cultural leaders. In about 20 minutes time, I am going to have a chance to meet with Nikki Wilson-Smith. Nikki produced a radio story for our local ABC radio in Newcastle as part of the Heywire program, focusing on the issue of Sudanese refugees who have settled in Newcastle and who have recently been the subject of a disgusting racist campaign. However, she speaks of befriending Sudanese refugees and how she experienced racism herself. When in Vietnam buying guitar strings, she was kicked out of a shop because she was white. Experiencing that racial hatred has inspired this 21-year-old to embrace multiculturalism and to embrace other cultures in our community. I congratulate her for it and look forward to speaking with her. (Time expired)

talk.start.para: âOn Saturday night I had the great honour and pleasure of representing the Hon. John Howard, Prime Minister of Australia, at the launch of the Master Butchers Cooperative centenary book: Master Butchers CooperativeâOur first 100 years 1905-2005. Present on this auspicious occasion were my state parliamentary colleague the Hon. Caroline Schaefer MLC, shadow minister for primary industry; board members of the Master Butchers Cooperative Ltd; Ron Turner, finance and admin manager; Lachlan Bowtell, director of marketing of the Meat and Livestock Association; authors Trevor Ford, Jeff Daniels and Rada Turner; and other guests, including the master butchers and their wives. I want to pay tribute today to one of the three authors, Rada Turner, who lives in Pooraka in my electorate of Makin. It was a great pleasure on the night to pay tribute to her work, along with that of the other two authors.

speech.para: I want to congratulate the board of directors for commissioning this book to chronicle the events in the history of the meat industry in South Australia from its beginnings in 1905. The authors have done an extraordinary job. The book was a year in production. Not only have the authors contributed to the Master Butchers Cooperative historical record, but they have made an immensely important contribution to South Australian history and the history of our great nation. From the very beginning of the book the authors take us through a delightful journey of facts, anecdotes, mateship and yarns that trace the struggles, hardships, diligence and devotion of the many and varied members of the MBL, who worked to continue the foundation of one of the most successful cooperatives to operate anywhere in the world. Of course, there are too many to be named individually, and I must leave that to others.

The journey also takes us through the battle for hides and skins, drought, World War I, the roaring twenties, the Depression years, World War II, our relationship with the Empire, the advent of the butchers picnic and the annual ball, Hyde's Patent Bar and women in the meat industry. At this point I would like to acknowledge the special tribute paid by the authors in chapter 4 to women in the meat industry. As the authors stated, there were two groups of women around which the meat industry revolved: those who were married to or were children of members and those who were not. Wives were often accorded great respect, such as in the article written by spyglass in the Master Butcher on 5 June 1939. He wrote:

quote.para: There are hundreds of present day butchers who owe all to their wives: who amongst us has not seen them wielding the chopper, wrapping up parcels, answering the telephone, chatting with customers and being forced to listen week in and week out to the same old anecdotes of what happened to some of their customers at their last operation.

talk.start.para: âI rise this morning to talk about the provision of a fairly basic serviceâan essential service, you would thinkâin a suburb called Narre Warren South, which some members may know has about 14,000 residents. It is an area full of young home owners and young families, and one that is filled with enormous community spirit. On weekends these people and families visit Strathaird Reserve and the Amberly Park Shopping Centreâa fairly innovative shopping centre that was opened in about October 2003 and has been incredibly well supported by the community. The shopping centre has a supermarket, a newsagent, a bank and financial services office and other shops. In April, it will even have a fully bulk-billing medical office, which will have about nine professional suites. It is a growing shopping centre which is actually a community hub.

speech.para: It may surprise those present to know, having provided this fulsome description of the shopping centre, that one thing it does not have is an Australia Post box. That is a rather absurd situation. This shopping centre has been open for 16 months and has roughly 25,000 people going through it per week using the facilities and the businesses. Aki Giorgio is a young small business owner who personifies Narre Warren South. He lives there, he is a battler and he has established a newsagency in Amberly Park Shopping Centre. About 200 people a day use Aki's newsagency and many of them say the same thing: `We pay our taxes. We work hard in the community. We are going to have a fully bulk-billing medical centre, but we're not going to have an Australia Post box!'

We have made numerous representations to Australia Post with respect to this issue, and they say there is postbox in the Casey Central Shopping Centre, which is roughly 2.6 kilometres away from the Amberly Park Shopping Centre. I would like to advise Australia Post to consult a Melwaysâa very useful exercise. They would see that Narre Warren South has two very distinct geographical areas: one is situated around Berwick Springs and the other is based around the Amberly Park Shopping Centre, which does not have an Australia Post facility.

It is no wonder that people get very upset about governments and feel powerless. Aki Giorgio has been lobbying for 16 months to get something as basic as one red Australia Post box. He has written letters, we have tabled petitions and he has not got it. Australia Post say in their mission statement that they want to deliver high-quality services to the people of the region. It is about time that they delivered on their mission statement. It is about time that they delivered the services that Narre Warren residents deserve and need.

talker.name: Hunt, Gregory, MP
Mr HUNT
talker.role: Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister for the Environment and Heritage

talk.start.para: âIn the aftermath of the Boxing Day tragedyâthe earthquake, the tsunami and the devastation to peoples throughout South-East Asia and, in particular, around the Indian OceanâI would like to acknowledge and pay tribute to the many people within the electorate of Flinders who acted independently and jointly with great generosity. There are a number of groups that I would like to acknowledge in particular for their generosity.

speech.para: Firstly, the Western Port Oberon Association, inspired by the work of Wendy Kelly, a woman of Sri Lankan descent, gathered together enormous amounts of food, clothing and other items as well as some funding to assist victims of the tsunami in Sri Lanka. They gave many hours of their time. Led by Wendy, they put in an enormous effort and have dispatched a huge quantity of desperately needed materials to the people of Sri Lanka. So I very specifically want to say to Wendy Kelly and to the Western Port Oberon Association, led by Max Bryant: thank you for the generosity and the time you have given. It is a wonderful demonstration of common humanity, compassion and the generosity which is always within the community.

The second group I want to acknowledge is the Rotary Club of Phillip Island. The Rotary Club on Phillip Island put together what you might call a coin table, where people were encouraged to put down a gold coin. Through that process, where the table was in the main shopping centre of Cowes on Phillip Island, they filled the table four times. Each table had approximately $8,000 worth of coins on it, so through that one simple process of coin donations they raised $32,000 over a couple of weeks. It was an extraordinarily simple but effective process. Similarly, both Rotary and Lions in Westernport and Hastings raised a significant amount of funds and also materiel for tsunami victims throughout the Indian Ocean region. They are tremendous groups with tremendous volunteers who made a wonderfully important contribution.

Finally, the Clean Ocean Foundation, rather than raising funds for itself, used a public rally about the Gunnamatta outfall to raise funds for people in coastal villages who had hosted and taken care of surfersâbecause there is a common linkâand they did a tremendous job in so doing. I want to thank not just these groups but also all the groups and individuals throughout the electorate of Flinders who have given generously and without hesitation. It is a wonderful example of community spirit. (Time expired)

talk.start.para: âI also rise today to make some comments regarding the situation facing the international community and particular countries following the tsunami disaster. I will make some specific comments about the situation in Sri Lanka; however, I will begin in general terms. No-one could remain untouched by the tremendous devastation from the tsunami in a number of countries, particularly Indonesia but also Sri Lanka, India and Thailand, and in many other countries to a much smaller extentâthough, nonetheless, for those communities there is still a sense of real devastation from what has occurred. People cannot fail to be touched by the work of the international community and of ordinary people throughout the world, particularly here in Australia. Australians have opened up their hearts and their pockets to provide support.

speech.para: I think it is also very proper to acknowledge that the efforts of the Australian government on behalf of the Australian community have been more than significant and are certainly to be commended as a real commitment to providing the necessary assistance to communities. It sets a benchmark for the future for dealing with international disasters, and I urge the government to maintain that sort of commitment to these sorts of problems. Hopefully, we will not face something of this nature again, but history tells us that we will.

Having made those points and commended the activities that the government has undertaken, particularly in relation to Indonesia, I would like to say a little about the situation in Sri Lanka. Many members, including the previous speaker, the member for Flinders, have expatriates of the Sri Lankan community living in their electorates. I certainly have a large expatriate Sri Lankan community in my electorate. It is a very diverse community. We often use that word `diverse' in this chamber, but in the context of the Sri Lankan community it most certainly is diverse. It has been defined to an extent by the civil war that has been going on in Sri Lanka for many years. Significant communities of Sinhalese, Tamils, Burghers and Muslims are all part of what makes up modern Sri Lanka.

In the context of what has occurred there in recent times, we are seeing a very desperate situation. It is a country with a population that is just under the population of Australia's, yet we are talking about over 31,000 people who have died. We are talking about nearly 80,000 families who have been displaced, and over half a million people have been involved in that. We are talking about over 320 camps that have been set up to deal with the issues being faced there. Certainly, there are problems that need to be dealt with by the Sri Lankan government and there are concerns that have to be dealt with by the community. I support all efforts that can be done to assist in Sri Lanka. (Time expired)

talk.start.para: âToday I rise to speak about an issue which is close to my heartâthe tireless and ongoing work of emergency service personnel in a crisis. The day of Tuesday, 11 January will be a day forever etched in the minds of the residents of South Australia's Eyre Peninsula. It was on that day that South Australia suffered the worst and most devastating bushfire seen in the state since Ash Wednesday. Numerous lives were lost and thousands of hectares of land destroyed as the fire took very little time to ruin lives and livelihoods. One South Australian family battled to cope with the loss not only of their two children but of their grandmother as well.

speech.para: The tragedy and devastation of this crisis is undeniable and its impact far-reaching. But I stand before you today not to dwell on that sadness and tragedy but to present to you the amazing story of hope and inspiration that emerged from the disaster. That is the story of the South Australian volunteers who risked their lives and gave their time to rush to the aid of their fellow South Australians.

This tragic day saw 15 other difficult fires burning across South Australia and across thousands of hectares of South Australian country. Fire service volunteers from every corner of the state were involved in firefighting and behind the scenes service. Individuals joined to work as one teamâfarmers, private farm units, personnel from all emergency agencies, the metropolitan fire service, government departments and members of the communityâto battle the crisis. These extraordinary people came together and worked tirelessly for one common goalâto serve and save their community.

Very rarely from a tragedy such as this can any positives be drawn, especially when human life is lost in a struggle against the elements. But from this tragedy comes an inspirational story. It is a story of mateship, hope and selflessness. It is a story of unity, commitment and determination. It is the story of the South Australian volunteer. South Australian volunteers placed their lives on the line on 11 January 2005, and they did so not to protect their own livelihoods or loved ones but to protect the lives and property of friends, neighbours and in some cases strangers for the one simple reason that these people needed their help. That help has continued beyond the battle to put out the fire and it will continue long after the clean-up is finished.

Aid organisations and a whole new band of volunteers have gone into the area to help those left to rebuild their lives. South Australians have again dug deep and donated anything they can spare to help in the rebuilding process. I stand before you today as a very proud South Australian, reflecting and acknowledging the people around us in times of tragedy. (Time expired)

talk.start.para: (Hon. I.R. Causley)âOrder! In accordance with standing order 193 the time for members' statements has concluded.

subdebate.1.para: Debate resumed from 8 December 2004, on motion by Mrs Markus:

motion.para: That the address be agreed to.

talk.start.para: âInnovation and renewal are always a challenge and they are particularly so for a government holding office for significant periods. Past policies and programs constrain new departures and the inertia inherent in defending existing commitments is always a brake on progress. Nonetheless, an important test of a government's vitality is its ability to keep innovating.

speech.para: The Governor-General's speech and the policy substance of the election campaign demonstrate that the coalition is meeting this challenge across a wide band of areas. The foundation of this ability has been the strength of the Australian economy that has resulted from the coalition's stewardship. The Australian economy has been made into one of the world's strongest. The results of the economic reforms over the period of the Howard government are manifest: increased productivity and economic growth at a long-term average of 3.5 per cent per annum; the increase in the wealth and incomes of the Australian people; the fall in unemployment from 11 per cent to 5.1 per cent, the lowest level of unemployment since 1976; and inflation and interest rates have been kept low. This economic performance, produced by effective management, has given the government the capacity to innovate in positive and constructive ways in many areas.

When I was young I was struck by an academic paper with the title `Necessity is the mother of invention, or the devil makes work for idle hands: two theories of innovation'. In more prosaic terms the question posed was whether innovation was dictated by scarcity or liberated by plenty. As is usually the case with academic propositions, neither is entirely true. There is, to steal a phrase, a `third way'. Innovation is driven by both need and by opportunity. Under the Howard government effective economic management has meant that innovation to meet real needs has taken place amongst favourable settings. Scarcity ultimately cannot be banished; choices do have to be made between different needs. Overwhelmingly however, the coalition has been able to meet needs by creating a positive sum game. I want to exemplify this proposition by looking at two of the areas covered in the Governor-General's speechâMedicare and school education.

I take Medicare first. As I have said before, there is not much point in pretending that the coalition has always been wholeheartedly committed to Medicare or its precursor, Medibank. That is simply not the case. Many of us recollect, and some of us participated in, the constant change to Medibank under the Fraser government. During our opposition years promises were constantly made to fundamentally change the basic components of Medicare. This changed in the aftermath of Fightback when John Howard as Leader of the Opposition gave an unequivocal commitment that the coalition would fully retain the Medicare system. That commitment has been honoured and exceeded. Governments are never free of blemishes but I think it is a great tribute to the coalition that we eventually recognised one of the major Whitlam reforms and embraced it. The reality is that one of the Howard government's great success stories has been strengthening Medicare. It is the coalition government that has ensured the viability of Medicare.

The government has ensured that all Australians have improved access to affordable medical services. The centrepiece of the government's new Strengthening Medicare package is the safety net. This protects individuals and families often coping with chronic illness or injury who confront significant out-of-pocket medical costs. In my electorate of Kooyong alone some 6,500 people benefited from the safety net in the first three months of its operation.

The government has also moved to underpin and expand the rate of bulk-billing in Australia. It did so prior to the election and during the campaign when it announced the introduction of the 100 per cent Medicare measure. From 1 January 2005 the Medicare benefits schedule now pays 100 per cent rebate on scheduled fees for unreferred GP visits. The high level of reimbursement applies to all unreferred GP visits not just bulk-billed consultations, as Labor proposed. The national bulk-billing rate has risen by 5.3 percentage points, or eight per cent in relative terms, since the Strengthening Medicare package was announced. The national bulk-billing rate for Australians aged 65 or older is even higher. In that age category 82.1 per cent of all medical consultations are now bulk-billed.

The question of philosophy lies at the heart of any debate about health policy, and I am afraid that I have to say that Labor has a very blinkered view about health and, in particular, the role of the private sector in delivering what is a quality health care system by any international standard. Fortunately, the government has come to understand that a public and private sector mix and balance is essential to the delivery of quality health and education services in this country. Lifetime Health Cover and a 30 per cent private health insurance rebate have relieved pressure on public hospitals and improved access for people who do not have private health insurance. It has enhanced the likelihood of early and appropriate hospitalisation whenever and wherever it is required. The interests of all Australians are best served when we have viable, efficient and successful private, as well as public, hospitals.

There must be a commitment to support those Australians who make the sacrifice to take out and maintain private health insurance, and optimise their treatment options. The government's 30 per cent private health insurance rebate does support these Australians and, during the course of the election campaign, the government announced a plan to increase that rebate to 35 per cent for Australians aged 65 and 40 per cent for Australians aged 70 years or older. I look forward to that change coming into operation in April following the passage of the enabling legislation, which is scheduled for debate today.

Finally, I am pleased that this government has directed attention, planning and resources to some of the unsung areas of need in our communityâto the problems of mental health and dementia. The government will invest $110 million in mental health and ensure that Australians with mental health problems receive effective care. This government can be rightly proud of its achievements across a broad spectrum of policies and programs and health is a perfect illustration of that position.

I would like to take a few minutes now to mention the very significant steps that the government has taken and will continue to take in the area of education. The Howard government is committed to providing record sums of money to the nation's schools. Over the coming four-year period, 2005 to 2008, the government has allocated $33 billion for schools education. This includes $10.8 billion supplementary funding for state schools, $12.8 billion general recurrent funding for Catholic schools and $7.8 billion for independent schools. Funding for all non-government schools in Australia will in future be based on the socioeconomic status funding model which means that every non-government school will receive funding based on the same transparent and objective funding formula, based on independent data, consistent for all schools.

It is one of the government objectives in adopting this funding model that private investment in education in Australia should not be discouraged and therefore the model does not take into account a school's private income from fees or other resources, or its assets. Rather, the level of government support to each of the children in any given non-government school is determined by reference to the socioeconomic status of the families in the areas from which the students at that school are drawn. This is in stark contrast to the plans that the Labor Party had in store for non-government schoolsâwhich I do not think have been revisedâshould it have been elected on 9 October. The Labor Party planned to slash the funding of 67 schools in Victoria and New South Wales by $520 million over the next four years. Thirty-two of those schools are in Victoria and seven were in my electorate of Kooyong. Another five Kooyong schools would have had their funding capped at the present level. This would have affected over 13,500 students, almost half the number of students who attend school in my electorate and would have resulted in a loss of $40 million of funding over the next four years for the schools which were targeted.

I am proud to be a product of the government school system and I am fully supportive of that system. I was very proud when the Prime Minister announced, as part of the current funding commitment to school education in Australia, a further $1 billion to support infrastructure needs, libraries, computers et cetera at government and under resourced non-government schools. I believe this is innovation at its best, which is permitted by a strong and growing economy.

As I have said, innovation and change are important. I want to raise one area where I believe innovation and change are necessary and possible, and that is in the area of refugees and asylum seekers. Our policies towards asylum seekers were premised on concern about vast numbers of undeserving and potentially dangerous people landing on our shores. Today, unauthorised boat arrivals have all but ceased and the great majority of people they carried have turned out to be genuine refugees. There were no terrorists hiding amongst the asylum seekers. Globally the number of refugees has nearly halved during the last decade. Of particular significance to Australia is the fact that refugees have stopped flowing from Afghanistan and Iraq, two of the main source countries of asylum seekers coming here without visas.

If a crisis situation justifies severe measures and the crisis passes, on what basis can the severe measures be perpetuated? In brief, I believe that we need to release asylum seekers in detention, of whom there are only a couple of hundred, who have passed health and security checks and place them in the community until their applications have been processed. I believe that thousands of genuine refugees who have temporary protection visas should be given permanent residence in a one-off amnesty. But today I want to focus, albeit briefly, on the policy of indefinite detention. The average prison sentence for people convicted of rape and other sexual crimes in Victoria and New South Wales is just over four years and it is between two and three years for offenders guilty of robbery, abduction or kidnapping. In Australia's immigration detention centres there are people who have been locked up for more than four years, the longest being for more than six years. These people are detained indefinitely, potentially for life, because they have been found to be ineligible for an Australian visa and we cannot find another country to accept them.

In the US the nation's courts have recently drawn upon the bill of rights in the constitution to question the government assertion of complete authority to indefinitely detain immigrants who cannot be deported. The Australian Constitution has fewer provisions for the protection of human rights. In 2004, by a 4-3 majority, the High Court decided that the government had the legal power to indefinitely detain people it wished to deport even if it is in practice impossible to deport them. In the relevant case, Al-Kateb v Godwin, Mr Justice McHugh, one of the majority, said:

quote.para: As long as the detention is for the purpose of deportation or preventing aliens from entering Australia or the Australian community, the justice or wisdom of the course taken by the Parliament is not examinable in this or any other domestic court. It is not for courts, exercising federal jurisdiction, to determine whether the course taken by Parliament is unjust or contrary to basic human rights.

speech.para: The result of this policy is illustrated by Mohammed, or Peter, Qasim, who has spent more than six years in immigration detention and may be imprisoned for life. Mr Qasim and the department of immigration disagree about some of the circumstances of his situation. But what is beyond doubt is that Mr Qasim is not detained because he has been charged or convicted of any crime, nor is he suspected of terrorism nor is he in any respect alleged to constitute a danger to the Australian community. Mr Qasim has been detained for a period longer than the average sentence of imprisonment for robbers and rapists because he is ineligible for an Australian visa and we cannot find another country to take him. To put it simply, I believe that the policy of indefinite detention of people who have committed no crimeâand I think this is a position actually supported by both sides of the parliamentâand who pose no threat to the Australian community should not be sustained.

I would like to conclude by acknowledging the work of my many loyal supporters in Kooyong who have contributed time and effort year after year to my re-election campaign. I owe much to the chairman of my electorate council, Bill Clancy, and to his vice-chairman, Paul Davey, who filled in at the last minute so effectively during the conduct of my campaign. I say a heartfelt thank you to them, the team of volunteersâwho organised fundraising events, who walked with me in all weather through the streets of the electorate and who dropped pamphlets in letterboxesâand all those Liberal Party members and friends who manned the polling booths on election day and during the pre-poll periods and visited so many hospitals and nursing homes and risked everything by displaying my posters on their front gardens, astonishingly attractive though they were. My staff deserve particular mention, and I am always grateful to them.

I am pleased to be back in this place and I recommit myself to serving the people of Kooyong and this parliament. I would like to welcome the new MPs from Victoria: Russell Broadbent, who had the only victory in a Labor seat in Victoriaâand it is really good to see Russell back againâAndrew Robb and Jason Wood. I would also like to say farewell to Bob Charles and David Kemp, who served the government and the parliament well. I would like to congratulate Senator Judith Troeth, who had a stunning and deserved victory in the doubtful third Senate position in Victoria.

talk.start.para: âThe address-in-reply affords us the opportunity to reflect on the election of the 41st Parliament of Australia. Like my Labor colleagues, I am disappointed not to be in government and not to have the opportunity to deliver for my electorate of Newcastle policies that would have united us under shared opportunity, policies that would have encouraged individual and community achievement to prosper our collective economic fortunes, and policies that would have promoted our safety and security and restored our international reputation as a nation that uses its capacity to aid global harmony and prosperity. But that is not to be.

speech.para: In his election victory speech, the Prime Minister committed to govern for all Australians. The people of Newcastle intend to hold him to account for that pledge and we look forward to benefiting fairly from the Prime Minister's commitment over the next three years. Novocastrians too made a choice in that election. They registered their strong support for Labor's agenda, and for that I sincerely thank them. In fact, I am wonderfully proud that the people of Newcastle exercised their vote to deliver me the greatest pro-Labor swing in the country. I am the first to acknowledge that I represent the best electorate in Australia, where people vote not just for the good of themselves but also for the good of their community. In Newcastle we have a saying that there is only half a degree of separation between us. We know each other well because we band together in our neighbourhoods, our community and sporting clubs, our volunteer organisations and through those marvellous networks and associations built up over time, living lives that value the place we live in and the people who live there. It is a place where people still smile and talk to strangers, where generosity abounds and where pride and encouragement are extended to everyone who has a go.

Labor's election agenda was so strongly supported by Novocastrians because it offered shared economic progress and success. In Newcastle, that agenda would have seen $20 million in funding for our Energy Australia Stadium, the home of the Knights and Newcastle United Jets football teams, but also the home of parochial pride and celebration. Unfortunately the Prime Minister offered no contribution to this project which would have allowed our city to better compete for international sporting and entertainment events and gain the economic and employment benefits of increased tourism. I encourage the Prime Minister to have a fresh look at this issue, with a view to facilitating growth in regional economiesâforming genuine regional partnerships in all regional economies and not just in seats the coalition holds or wishes to hold at elections.

Newcastle voters also favoured Labor's commitment to restore regional status to our universityâsomething we sorely miss. It is important to understand that in regions universities are very special places. Unlike the sandstone universities, regional universities depend on good regional partnerships for their success, and regions depend on universities for their success as well. In this partnership, research and entrepreneurship are facilitated, student needs are understood and responded to locally, sponsorship is assisted and the purpose of the university is embedded within the community. The Department of Education, Science and Training recently sponsored a regional engagement forum at our university, which suggests that they see it as a regional university. It is logical, then, that the outcomes and strategies from that forum could best be enacted if regional status and attached funding were available in 2005, particularly when our outstanding research record is viewed against regional business linkages. Minister Nelson, we would welcome your sensible intervention to reinstate regional status to the University of Newcastle.

Labor's election commitment to provide 40 additional medical places at the University of Newcastle to respond to the GP shortage in our region was also understood and appreciated by the voters of Newcastle. As our university specialises in training GPs, it could accommodate those places instantly. As doctors who train in regional universities generally end up practising in the regions, this would benefit electorates, both Labor and coalition, throughout the Hunter, New England, Central Coast and North Coast regions. Given the attrition rate of GPs in regional Australia, I again urge Minister Nelson and Minister Abbott to confer and bring additional places on line at the University of Newcastle with some urgency. Additional places in central Sydney do not make much sense, given that the majority of medical work force shortages are in regional Australia.

Providing after-hours GP services was also a Labor priority, with a commitment given by our shadow minister for health to maintain funding at current levels to our highly successful GP access after-hours service. This service originated in the Hunter and its trial and expansion was supported by the coalition. That was welcomed by all of us. In fact, this excellent model has become the benchmark for similar services around the country. However, Minister Abbott was dragged screaming and kicking to support ongoing funding by the hard work of the people of the Hunter and Newcastle who made it clear, through media, letters and petitions of support, that they expected any government, Labor or Liberal, to fund what works and works well to manage the emergency health care of communities. So we look forward to adequate and continuing funding to the Hunter GP access after-hours service.

This week already we have heard much about the national skills shortage crisis. The Reserve Bank of Australia have identified it as a major factor in restraining our export performance, particularly in non-commodity exports such as manufacturing. In Newcastle we have been trying to tell the government about the skills shortage for quite a long time. In fact, the millennium skills report prepared some years ago by our region pointed to this looming shortage, but unfortunately this was not responded to by the Howard government. In the election Labor well understood the need to overcome the skills shortage in Newcastle and the Hunter. Labor's commitment to providing special skill-up and youth link-up initiatives in our region appealed to our community, ever concerned for the future of our young people, who continue to face some of the highest unemployment rates in the country. Special support is needed to increase school retention rates and to use the talents of our youth to the best advantage for this nation's productivity. In Newcastle we would welcome a hand up for our young people from this government.

Unfortunately, it seems that all the government has offered is a new technical college for regions with skill shortages. As a former principal I have some major problems with this initiative on several grounds, but particularly because it ignores existing initiatives by TAFEs and schools to advance vocational education in collaboration with local industry, according to local needs. It is already happening in prosperous regions, in regions that are willing to find their own solutions. For example, in my region a highly successful call centre training program was initiated in response to growing industry demand. Similarly, hospitality partnerships have also been successful in overcoming skill deficiencies. In the traditional trades areas, where there is a major gap, our local group training companies have had some outstanding successes through their partnerships with industry and TAFEs. If government had listened to them, and responded to their advice earlier, then we would not have had the skills crisis that currently hampers growth and compounds our current account deficit. But the political reality is that the Howard government has neglected the great manufacturing regions like Newcastle and the Hunter. We would wonder whether there is a selective disregard for Labor held areas. Only now that we have the largest current account deficit in the nation's history is the government taking notice.

As for the new technical colleges, I applaud the local solution being put forward by HunterNetâthe manufacturing industry cluster groupâthe Hunter Institute of TAFE and the Australian Industry Group in my electorate to work in partnership with local schools to deliver this program. It is a model they are putting forward to the government in response to their request to get these colleges going. Only local approaches with efficient use of existing local resources will be able to adequately respond to resolving the skills shortages. But, at best, this solution, with only 300 students catered for, will be only a token measure given the scale of the problem.

Affordable child care and predictable financial support when raising children were seen as vital to the economic prosperity of Newcastle families. They are right. Data released recently shows that fertility decline in the regions is five times greater than the average across the state of New South Wales. That should be worrying to all members of parliament. Does that mean the end of rural communities? I repeat: the rate of fertility decline in the regions is five times greater than the state average. Voters supported policies that increased resources to child-care centres and recognised the need for child-care workers to be trained and rewarded. They rejected the taxation concession approach put forward by the government that meant the more you paid for child care the more you could claim on your tax return. Again, that is another selective policy that favours those on highest incomes. I thank Sharan Burrow from the ACTU for supporting this social area of need, and certainly for supporting my campaign in Newcastle.

When it comes to taxation and incomes, Newcastle voters did not forget that in Peter Costello's last budget he chose to overlook 90 per cent of themâthose people who actually earn less than $52,000 per year. I do not think that those of us on comfortable salaries look around enough and see how much ordinary Australians earn. Perhaps low-wage earners have not forgotten just how hard the government resisted increases to the minimum wage over the past three years.

Had Labor been elected, 64 out of 65 schools in my electorate, be they public or private, would have received more funding, and more students seeking places at TAFE and university would have gained entry because of Labor's increase in funded places. We would also have seen the 25 per cent HECS hike removed, and perhaps our university would have not faced reduced enrolments this yearâwhat has turned out to be a national trend, predicted by Labor. If you are going to keep burdening young people they will turn away. That is exactly what has happened. They have turned away from the economic burden of being a tertiary student under a government that increases the user pays approach to gaining higher education in what we like to call `the clever country'.

Newcastle's support for Labor's health policies, supporting Medicare Gold and retaining bulk-billing, remained as strong as ever. We have a proud public health tradition in Newcastle and the Hunter, and we understand the economic health and social dividends that result from investing more into the public health system. Sadly, only in the last few weeks, another GP has closed his doors in my electorate. I say `sadly' because this GP faces a health crisis of his own. He is only a young man and it is going to be a very difficult time for him. He had to abandon his practice; he could not find a locum. He could not find any GP to take it over. Why was that? Because he bulk-bills. It is a bulk-billing practice with a mostly aged population. That is just tragic. What does it say about the success of Minister Abbott's rescue efforts for Medicare? Just more failure and more distress to an overworked profession and to their patients. It remains the biggest shame in this nation that we cannot provide GP services to all Australians.

I have now fought two election campaigns in which I have been the candidate. Having been a member of the Labor Party for well over 25 years, I can say that it is certainly different when you are the candidate. In the first campaign, in 2001, I benefited a great deal from Newcastle's traditional support for Labor and from the good efforts of my predecessor, Allan Morris. But this campaign was one where, even though national issues and campaign tactics had a major influence, there was an element of appraisal of my own performance. That can be very challenging. But I was a very fortunate candidate to have had the support of so many Labor members and friends, not to mention a wonderful family and staff. They are too numerous to name individually, but I wish to formally thank my entire campaign team and all volunteers who supported our belief and determination to provide a better government.

I also thank my caucus executive colleagues and our national campaign directorate for their support of my campaign. They were very obliging in visiting Newcastle, listening to the people and developing policy that really responded to Newcastle's needs. They genuinely understood those needs and did their best to incorporate that into policy and election activities. I again pledge my devoted service to the people of Newcastle and give my assurance that, while ever I hold the seat, the government will be well aware of our needs and reminded of our contribution to this great country. I also assure the people of Newcastle that under my representation Labor will never be able to take them for granted nor will they ever be able to take for granted the loyal support that Newcastle has shown to Labor for 104 years.

Election campaigns also bring sadness and regret. The results can show a randomness that sees talented people of compassion and dedication leave this place. For Labor, we lost some wonderful caucus colleagues, and I particularly pay tribute to my friend Sharryn Jackson, the former member for Hasluck, who constantly inspired meâI do miss herâwith her love for her electorate and her constant championing of their concerns. She is sorely missed.

Since the election there have been other losses too, in particular for Labor the loss of our former leader Mark Latham due to ill health. I express on the public record my gratitude and respect for his efforts to provide a real alternative for the Australian people. Mark was a man of big ideas and bold visions, but he was also a man with the common touch who valued the contributions of all Australians. His pride in this country and his passionate belief in Labor's principles were evident for everyone to see. He saw a wonderful link between Labor's policies and the strength and goodness of the Australian peopleâa link I know he wished to nourish and sustain with policies that he believed would lead to greater prosperity, security and national achievement within a social framework that valued the spirit of fairness and generosity to others. He also is missed. I extend my gratitude and best wishes to Mark, particularly for the challenges he faces with his health. I thank him very much for his dedication to Labor.

The leadership baton for Labor now rests with Kim Beazley. I am not quite sure if Kim will return as patron to the Knights and be seen running up Red Hill in his Knights jersey but I know that, like the Knights, our local football heroes, he is hungry for victory in our political version of the grand final. I am proud and privileged to once more be part of this parliament and I am proud and privileged to be part of the Labor opposition leader's quest for government of this great nation. We are a great nation with a great spirit.

I pay tribute to the overwhelming generosity displayed by Australians to our neighbours in the tragic aftermath of the tsunami. It showed that we have a commitment to helping others. We have a collective strength in that way. Australians have matured to the point where we now see our neighbours in a more global sense. We know that part of the responsibility of living in the lucky country is giving aid and comfort to our regional neighbours. The majority of financial aid that leaves these shores in normal times comes from the pockets of ordinary Australians. We truly are generous and caring.

I want to draw attention to comments by a young doctor. I tried to find his name, but I have not been successful. He was awarded an Australia Day national honour for his assistance as part of medical teams who treated the victims of the Bali bombings. In his interview he said something very special. He said that he had been humbled by the experience of treating Australians. He said that, to a man and woman at that time, everyone he treated told him to help another person first, as that person's need was greater than their own. In my role as a parliamentarian I have learnt that the greatest inspiration comes from the extraordinary feats of ordinary Australians.

Sadly, in my electorate we recently saw the worst of the human spirit, when a small group of racists sought to vilify our new Sudanese residence. Newcastle has almost 500 Sudanese refugees who have been sponsored by the Newcastle community. In response to this attack by a fewâI think dangerousâpeople, Newcastle rose up and supported our Sudanese community and celebrated our multicultural diversity. It will live with me for a long time that 600 people came together in a massive celebration. Having just heard the member for Kooyong talk about Qasim, who has been in a detention centre here for over six years, I can only say that it was very sad to hear a Sudanese man of approximately 40 years of age say that he was born in a refugee camp, that he had lived his entire life in a refugee camp and that his children were born in a refugee camp. It is wonderful that we can offer these people some hope. The celebration was a very moving experience, and I pay tribute to the people of Newcastle. It is a privilege to represent them.

In conclusion, I want to raise a sensitive matter. I have a great deal of respect and appreciation for the professional way in which the staff in Parliament Houseâpolitical, electorate and parliamentaryâsupport the government of this country. However, in the past three years I have been alarmed at times by the treatment of interjectors in the public gallery. Although this is an infrequent occurrence, on too many occasions the response to interjectors has in my view been excessively physical. On those particular occasions no warning appeared to have been given. No attempts seem to have been made to explain the consequences or actions that would have to be taken to remove the person from the gallery. Unfortunately, at times the force applied seemed excessive relative to the actions of those causing the problem and to the restraining power needed to escort the offenders from the gallery.

As a member of parliament I am always grateful for the vigilance of our security personnel and acknowledge that they are placed in the front line of potential risk and, consequently, do respond with the thoughts of possible worst-case scenarios uppermost in their minds. But this remains the people's house and, as we watch those walls being built around our perimeters, we have a responsibility to ensure that Australia's democracy is visible and accessible to the people we represent. It is therefore essential that our security staff members are each given the best training possible to respond to critical incidents appropriately. I urge attention to this matter by those charged with this responsibility. We are fortunate in this House to have an open, inclusive government. It must continue.

talker.name: Hardgrave, Gary, MP
Mr HARDGRAVE
talker.role: Minister for Vocational and Technical Education and Minister Assisting the Prime Minister

talk.start.para: âI am greatly honoured to be able to stand here as the member for Moreton and to reaffirm the commitment I have made on each occasion, at the commencement of the now four parliaments to which I have been elected, to maintain my focus, my attention, on matters within my electorate as my first call of duty. My Moreton-centric rallying cry of 1996 I have attempted to maintain to the best of my human possibilities and personal energies. It has been 34 years since my family moved into what is the federal electorate of Moreton in the Sunnybank area. The footprints of my family's efforts have perhaps not been anything out of the ordinary but, rather, part of the local community, working through P&Cs and my parents Doug and Hazel, the Lions Club of Brisbane Macgregor and other organisations. This set in train an approach which I will continue to attempt to fulfil in these next three years.

speech.para: Having been a student of Runcorn State School and Macgregor High School and, in more recent years, Griffith University, where I completed part-time studies, knowing that each of those institutions is within the electorate that I represent is an enormous point of anchoring for me to keep reality in check. I am always conscious that people are never afraid to walk up to me in local shopping centres and at community events and remind me that I attended school with them, their daughter, their son or, in more recent years, their parents. As a local lad I am very greatly honoured to be in this place to do my best to represent the views and concerns of the good people of this part of Australia.

I want to briefly report upon the 2004 election campaign and work my way through a number of issues that are of importance to the local electorate. The No. 1 issue in my electorate was very clearly a lack of faith in the alternative that was presented. Economic management was a point of reckoning for people. Interest rates became an example to people, particularly in those fast-developing suburbs of Calamvale, Parkinson and Drewvale and through Eight Mile Plains, Runcorn, Stretton and Sunnybank Hills. In those suburbs, where people have invested in themselves and their families, people were veryâand rightlyâconcerned about the lack of clarity, the lack of ability and the lack of experience that was being offered by the alternative. They spoke very loudly and very strongly in that regard. People were saying to me that clearly the Australian Labor Party are not the party that they had once voted for and that they do not represent real people any more. There is an enormous amount of work that those opposite have got to do. They have to look within themselves to realise that they are the custodians of what is now a failed party that has a lot of work to do to try to restore some sense of faith in average Australians. I am sure that they will do that and I guess, from the point of view of a solid political debate, one would hope they get on with that task.

I had people say to me that they had concerns about some aspects of the tough decisions the government made. At Calamvale College one man said, `I wasn't happy over the war in Iraq, but I do not trust and do not believe the Australian Labor Party can properly represent me or, indeed, would be a safe bet for this country, so I am voting for you.' I thank that gentleman, because I think it is important that people do express those sorts of views in that sort of way. It is a positive gesture from that man, whose name I do not know, but I was very pleased to receive his support last October.

But the key issues, apart from the Australian Labor Party and people's genuine concerns, were the infrastructure and transport issues in my electorate. The Australian Labor Party promised a quick pot of money to try to deal with some of these issues. There was no plan that underpinned it, though. Labor essentially wanted and still wantâI noticed the member for Wills, the Labor Party spokesman on these things, in the House yesterdayâto put more trucks through my local area. They actually want to direct more interstate trucks down the Brisbane Urban Corridor, which is Kessels Road in my electorate. The alternative that the Howard government has planned is the AusLink proposal. It is a way around this important issue, and now even the Queensland government are acknowledging that AusLink has something to offer.

The Queensland transport minister, Paul Lucas, understands my passion. He campaigned against me in the last election. He and I have traded a few blows over the past 12 months, but I have to say to you that I have had meetings with Paul Lucas and I am very satisfied that, since the election, he knows that people want an end to the sense of jurisdictional battles on these issues. I applaud his commitment, along with that of Minister Jim Lloyd and, before him, Minister Ian Campbell, in dealing with these issues in a proper, planned and coordinated way. I do not apologise to Paul Lucas for standing up strongly to him on behalf of my constituents. I can assure him and the House that I have given stick where needed to my ministerial colleagues for exactly the same reasonâand I certainly will not stop doing that.

So what have we done? The Australian government are now financing a removal of the toll on the Southern Brisbane Bypass at night. They are doing that because 40 per cent of the trucks that go through my electorate would use the alternative if the toll was not there, and we want to get some real data. The Queensland government are now cooperating and taking the million or so dollars that we are putting on the table for this. That toll trial will start at the end of this month of February. This is fantastic news.

There is more that I want. I want to see the Persse Road toll plaza taken out completely. This toll plaza impedes the good progress and the good use of local road assets. We see too many cars on Gowan Road through Stretton and Calamvale as people from south of my electorate motor around that toll plaza and go up Warrigal Road at Eight Mile Plains and Runcorn. I want to see an end to that and I have spoken to Paul Lucas about this. We are in the business of working together. The Queensland government are making a contribution as well. I acknowledge that a numberplate recognition technology being installed now along the Kessels Road corridor will mean that trucks that are using this road instead of using the toll road in the toll-free trial period will be asked why they are there. Their numberplate will be photographed and the driver will be followed upâI see no problems with that.

I have to say to those who have listened to my comments in this place and publicly over the last eight years on this subject that my consistent approach has now been vindicated both by the Australian government's AusLink plan and by the cooperative actions of the Queensland government. I welcome that.

There is also a federal and state feasibility study to look at the engineering solutions for the Kessels-Mains roads bottleneck, and I welcome that. But again we saw yesterday that the Australian Labor Party have learnt absolutely nothing from the federal election campaign, because the Labor Party are still saying, `No, let's just dig the ditch; let's put the overpass in.' That is a signal for more trucks through my electorate. I will not stand idly by and allow the Labor Party to put more trucks through my area. We need a proper plan. There is no need to build that overpass until we know that the big trucks are off the local roads. The overpass can come but not before the trucks are gone.

Then there is the overpass that is needed on Beaudesert Road at Acacia Ridge to replace the level crossing on the Sydney-Brisbane rail line. Beaudesert Road is a state road, the rail line is in fact owned by the Queensland government, and yet Queensland state members and the federal Labor Party are saying the federal government should build this overpass. I say we would if the state government would cooperate with the Australian government's AusLink proposal and lease that rail line from Brisbane to the border. We are trying to bring the Brisbane freight equation into the 21st century and provide a rail line that actually works on 21st-century standards. The New South Wales government has signed up on the Sydney-Brisbane rail plan, but the 130 kilometres from the Queensland border to Brisbane is going to wallow in early 20th-century technology at best unless we get the progress that we are calling for. I am hoping that, in the spirit of cooperation that now seems to be there from the Queensland government, Minister Lucas and Minister Anderson will get a satisfactory result. That last 130 kilometres needs to be in that form of agreement because then, under AusLink, we will plan and build infrastructure improvements, including that overpass at Acacia Ridge.

As the local federal member and as a long-term resident I have always supported the use of that rail corridorâwhich is only used for that interstate rail operationâas an extension of the Brisbane city rail service. It is outrageous to think that, in 2005, suburbs like Algester, Calamvale and Parkinson and, indeed, places as far south as the electorate of my colleague from Forde are not served by a rail system. It is one of the reasons why local roads in my electorate are being choked with cars, because people are in cars rather than on trains. Those are big-ticket items. They have been part of my efforts over the last eight years or so since being elected as the federal member in this place and they will continue to be part of my activity until we get the results that local people expect of me.

My electorate is now the most culturally diverse electorate in the entire state of Queensland. My previous portfolio of Citizenship and Multicultural Affairs meant that I learnt a lot from my local community which I could then use, not by way of judgment, but as a point of comparison with the conduct of communities in other places. My community has lots of people from lots of places. It means that while we are a fairly small pond by comparison with places in Western Sydney we, nevertheless, are a very happy pond.

We will, as is always the case, have infectious Chinese New Year events. We have already been to a couple. They will happen all through this week, and probably this month, throughout my electorate. Many of the local Islamic community have come from places like South Africa and Zimbabwe. They are professional people who have brought enormous skills; 96 per cent of the Muslims who have come from South Africa and Zimbabwe to Queensland have come as business migrants. They have brought investment opportunities and skills.

In the last few weeks they have been involved in the business of raising enormous amounts of money for the tsunami appeal. I was pleased to attend a function which, with other efforts raising funds from local mosques, pulled together some $200,000. Last weekend we saw children on a walkathon. It was kids for kids, raising funds under the organisational auspices of Crescents of Brisbane, getting kids to understand that they can make a difference. These are great examples of a local community digging deep and doing good things. It is also a good testimony of a community, particularly the Islamic community, that has had a difficult time in recent years. It has affected me as a person. It has affected my conduct as a member of parliament. I am very, very proud to know these people.

We also have many people who are new to Australia and have come from the Horn of Africaâfrom Eritrea, Ethiopia, Somalia. An enormous number of people have come from Sudan. We know that they are there because the Courier Mail discovered that in the last seven days. I have talked proudly about these people wherever I have gone around the country and will continue to do so. They are people who understand what it is like to have nothing. When they come to a country like Australiaâwhere freedom is a given and where liberty, the right to do everything that is permitted by law, is something they have never known before they have come to this placeâit really reminds us about exactly who we are and where we come from. I am very proud to be part of the Liberal Party of Australia, which, from the founder on, has always said that no racial or religious caveat applies to its sense of respect for the rights of an individual. I am pleased to maintain that approach.

One of the ways in which we have been able to bring citizens of long standing and citizens of new standing together has been through the infection of locally based community citizenship ceremonies. On Australia Day this year I was pleased to preside on behalf of Peter McGauran, the Minister for Citizenship and Multicultural Affairs, at the first ever university based citizenship ceremony, at Griffith University. I praise the Griffith University Lions Club for their efforts in convening it. The Brisbane Macgregor Lions Club, whose community service knows no bounds, sponsored the event at Macgregor state primary school hall. On that day there were also the Moreton community awardsâ

talk.start.para: (Mr Hatton)âDoes the honourable member seek to intervene?
âI do.
âI would like to continue my speech on behalf of my electorate.
âThe intervention is declined.

âI would like the member for Melbourne Ports to take it up at another time. I am very pleased that on that day we were also able to confer awards on very good local citizens who have made a difference in my local communityâeverybody from Brian Ryan, of Sunnybank, who has given over 100 blood donations to the Red Cross over many decades, to Ivan King, who stood by his wife, Iris, who now has an OAM for her 45 years of helping guiding at Wellers Hill. Ivan drove Iris to every event. He was rightly awarded. John Allen, of Ekibin Lions Club, who lives at Yeronga, has had 16 years involvement there fundraising in every possible way. He was a torchbearer for the Sydney Olympics. John Allen has always made it possible for young people to see the uniform he walked in and the torch he carried.

speech.para: John Corless, of Yeronga, is perhaps an unsung hero of the Australian Football League in Queensland, in that he has been dedicated to this sport and its development through local schools such as Yeronga state school. He has been President of Yeronga AFL since 1991. Melvena Hallam, of Algester, has for eight years worked without fail for three days a week at the Veterans Support and Advocacy Service. Wally Sefjack, of Macgregor, is a US-born citizen who has love and passion for a sense of good citizenry in Australia. His involvement through the Sunnybank RSL rightly afforded him this sort of note in dispatch. It was a very emotional moment. There were many members from the local QE2 hospital auxiliaryâpeople who have made such a difference in that organisation, which has raised over $1.4 million over the past 20 years.

Perhaps the most emotional award went to Mrs Barbara Saranin, who accepted the award on behalf of her late husband, Alex. Alex Saranin was Russian born and came to Australia via Shanghai. His storyâthe things he and his family went through, both in Russia and in China, in their escape to this country in the post-Communist revolution eraâand his application and effort in our local community were very inspiring. He wrote a book which he has handed on to others to readâa book which I would certainly endorse to all others. His local Nathan Neighbourhood Watch group, who do so much good community work, humbled and honoured him when they named their good neighbour award after him.

Speaking of Neighbourhood Watch, we continue to have a very strong, effective and capable community response where people are adding to the thin blue line of policing, working in partnership with the local police service to make a difference. I am very proud to offer support to each of them. In places like Algester and Calamvale, which are new to my electorate, I have been happy to engage in their activities. At Stretton they run a wonderful barbecue and picnic event each year that brings the community together. It is great to see, as well as those activities in longer established areas such as Chelmer, Graceville, Sherwood, Tennyson, Yeronga and Moorooka.

I was very pleased to see a constituent of mine Jenny Bobeszko, who was the chairperson of the Brisbane South regional support group, was noted at the state Neighbourhood Watch rally held on election day last year as the regional community member of the year award recipient. I think it is right that we acknowledge her leadership and her involvement.

In the years ahead one of the new portfolio challenges is the important area of ensuring that young people feel empowered by the choices they make through their schooling lives and are able to progress in a positive and constructive way from their schooldays to their work days through further opportunities in apprenticeships in the trade skills. My local electorate actually offers me an enormous amount of instruction on this as well.

In my electorate there are long-established partnerships between business and high schools, which will continue to have an impact on the conduct in my new portfolio responsibilities. The Southside Cluster Industry Placement Scheme, the SCIPS program, chaired by Cameron Innes and so well administered by Carmel Dalton, involves schools in and around my electorate, including Clairvaux MacKillop College, Yeronga State High School, Our Lady's College at Annerley, Runcorn State High School and Holland Park High School. They also provide a pay-as-you-use service to Macgregor State High School.

They have over 700 students involved in 1,200 placementsâsome students are sent out more than once. It is a good scheme. It shows you that the local community in my electorate took up the challenges issued by the federal government in about 1997 and indeed by the short-lived state coalition government of that era to engage in these sorts of programs. It is not well understood that of the school based new apprentices around the country over half of them are in Queensland, which is an indictment of states like New South Wales and Victoria especially. Over half of them are in Queensland, but unfortunately not enough of them are in the traditional trades.

I pay tribute to former minister Dr Kemp, who set in train these sorts of structures, and to former ministers in that short-lived coalition governmentâthe now Liberal leader, Bob Quinn, and now Liberal senator for Queensland, Santo Santoro. They were ministers for education and training at a time when these new structures came into place. The maturity of those in Queensland, particularly in my electorate, set me some very good examples to look for in other places.

I thank the Liberal Party division of Moreton for their faith in me as their candidate, now on four occasions. I promise to continue to work hard for all involved. I thank the state party president, Michael Caltabiano, and the state director, Geoff Greene, all of my staff who worked hard and my FEC chair, Angela Owen-Taylor, and I am thankful for the opportunity to address the House this morning.

During the minister's remarks I rose, as is our right in this chamber, to ask the minister a question when he raised the national issue of citizenship. Could you or the Deputy Speaker, at your convenience after consulting the records of this committee, advise me when and if at all a minister has refused to take an intervention?

âThe rules regarding interventions are very clear. You would know and appreciate that, whether a person is a minister or not, it is up to the member speaking whether they choose to take an intervention. My first experience of an interventionâI think it was the member for Flinders interjectingâwas that I could choose to keep the flow by letting the interjection go through or choose to answer it. At the introduction of this rule there was an expectation that people would take the interjection and so on, but there is no demand that that should be done.

âMr Deputy Speaker, I rise on the point of order, and thank you for that observation. My ambition this morning was to speak on behalf of my electorate. I happen to also be a member of the executive. I am never afraid to take questions from the opposition on executive related matters, but today I want to be here particularly as the member for Moreton.

âI welcome this opportunity to speak to the House in the address-in-reply debate following the federal election and the formal opening of the 41st Parliament. It is indeed my privilege to receive the reindorsement from my community to serve again in this great parliament. I want to record my thanks to the people of the electorate of Canberra for placing their trust in me as their federal representative.

speech.para: The result we received in this electorate, with an increase in the primary vote, could not have been achieved without the hard work and assistance of many people. There is my staffâKathryn, Chris, Daniel, Rose, Shaun and Helenâwho face the daily challenges with me and who display great loyalty not only to me but to our supporters and, most importantly, to our community. There are all those wonderful people in the local Australian Labor Party who had to face two elections within seven days, yet were willing and able to get out and work so hard to ensure our local success. There are also all the volunteers who phoned or called in to offer their help. My sincere thanks to each one of you. In my role as a shadow minister it is difficult, given the level of resources available to us in opposition. However, I thank Victoria, who worked long and hard with me last term in our two areas of responsibilityânamely, ageing and seniors, and disabilities.

I am extremely proud to represent the community of Canberraâan electorate with an electoral enrolment of 109,476 voters at the time of the election. Our community is no different to any other in Australia. We share similar aspirations and hopes. We have similar concerns and stresses. We are very resilient, ready to support each other through those unexpected challenges. The devastating fires of January 2003 certainly displayed that characteristic. Some commentators observed that this showed that Canberra really did have a heart. We reckon they never really knew us and that that heart was always evident.

It seems appropriate that the seat of Canberraâin the Australian Capital Territory, which was created specifically to hold the government of this countryâcan claim connections to so many other towns, cities and nations. At the last census 17,664 people who were born in Europe lived in the seat of Canberra. There were 7,252 people from Asia, 933 from subSaharan Africa, and 871 from North Africa and the Middle East. Just over 24 per cent of my constituentsâa bit over 37,000 peopleâwere born overseas and now call the seat of Canberra home. Whether we were born in Woden, Wangaratta or Western Samoa, we are all Canberrans and very proud of our city. We happen to live in the nation's capital, of which we are all extremely proud. It is a beautiful city with a special role, and we all take our part in that role very seriously.

I am also pleased to have the opportunity to reflect on a couple of issues that I see as important in identifying who we are as a nation. It has been said that we can judge ourselves by how we treat others. I also see this test as a window into our collective conscience. I want to refer to the state of the health of our Indigenous Australians and, in so doing, turn to the report entitled Health is life. This report of the inquiry into Indigenous health by the House of Representatives Standing Committee on Family and Community Affairs was presented to this House in May 2000. The committee received the reference from the government to conduct that inquiry. The report was a product of over two years work, involving a number of members of this House, and it is fair to say that we all desperately hoped that this report would really make a difference. It is 4Â½ years later, and I find it extremely distressing every time I read another front page headline or hear another news report telling us how serious the situation of Indigenous health is. The statistics are trotted out, we all agree the figures are appallingâand so on it goes. I quote from the foreword of the report:

quote.para: The continuing poor state of Indigenous health, and the many efforts of successive governments to address the issue, has seemingly left a nation at a loss to know what to do for the best on this issue.

speech.para: It went on:

quote.para: We know that there are no easy answers to the issues of Indigenous health and all participants in the Inquiry acknowledged the long road ahead, but we believe that our Report offers some signposts to the future.

speech.para: What we desperately need is leadership on this issue. We acknowledge that it would be unlikely to see significant improvement until the fragmentation of services, the cost-shifting and the lack of agreement on responsibility for Indigenous health are fully addressed. The committee agreed:

quote.para: ... that for this to happen there must be a clear agreement between the states and the Commonwealth, not only about what their respective responsibilities are but also on how these responsibilities will be acted upon and the level of resources to be committed by all parties.

speech.para: It seems the realities of today remain the same: in general terms, Indigenous Australians are more likely to be unemployed or on lower incomes, less educated, imprisoned or in some form of care, homeless or living in overcrowded or substandard conditions, as well as being unwell or dying earlier than the non-Indigenous population. The life expectancy of Indigenous Australians is about 18 years shorter than for other Australians. Their age adjusted mortality is about three times the non-Indigenous rate and much higher with respect to some conditions.

An article in the Australian on 19 November 2004 entitled `Crowded houses are home to the plight of poverty' quoted the Minister for Immigration and Multicultural and Indigenous Affairs, Amanda Vanstone:

quote.para: ... communities had to take responsibility for maintenance and repairs. There was to be âno more build and abandonâ.

speech.para: The article went on:

quote.para: âThe current state of housing is an indication the current approach is in need of change,â Senator Vanstone said. âMore money, or more of the same, won't work.â

speech.para: The same article indicated that $2.295 billion would be required to address the Indigenous housing shortfall.
The committee's report discussed in some detail the question of maintenance and training. In relation to this issue the report talked about:

quote.para: ... an innovative national training program about maintenance skills that is not at the trade level, but which is formal and accredited and could be extended with subsequent training to trade qualifications. Existing trade programs should continue to be supported and expanded where possible.

Focussing on ongoing maintenance and health hardware work in the communities on a long-term basis provides the potential for long-term meaningful employment which will also have considerable health benefits.

speech.para: It is now 4Â½ years since that report was produced, and where do we find ourselves today? Well, late last year we had a debate opening up in the media and elsewhere about mutual obligationâagreements calling on the community to guarantee certain behaviours such as washing children's faces, putting out the garbage, ensuring children shower every day and get to school on time, and so on. And, in return, the federal government would supply, in one case, $172,260 to provide and install petrol bowsers in a particular town. Mutually agreed approaches are not in themselves unacceptable, but we must ask: how far is this method of provision of basic service going to go?
