We are all aware of the courageous action of Michael Long and the `long walk' initiative late last year. I had the opportunity of joining the walk for a brief time here in Canberra and, with many others from our community, offering my support. Following Michael Long's walk to Canberra the Prime Minister met with him and others. Some commentators at the time welcomed the Prime Minister putting the issues on the agenda: `What a good thing to have this discussion! We are now offered an opportunity we cannot ignore'âand so on, basically cheering the so-called intervention of the PM at the time. Of course that is a good thing. The point is that these issues should never be off the agenda. It should not take a walk by Michael Long or anyone else to have the Prime Minister of this country acknowledge the issues facing our Indigenous communities around the country.

The issues are diverse; they are not simple. And we all share some responsibility for the continuing poor state of health, education, employment and opportunity affecting our Indigenous communities. Some of us in this House had the opportunity through that committee inquiry to visit many city, rural and very remote Indigenous communities. We saw some wonderful examples where sheer determination and self-belief were winning out. We also saw some shocking examples of poor planning and infrastructure development, lack of care and accountability that verged, I have to admit, on the incomprehensible. How will these mutual obligation arrangements fix, for example, the construction of a community rubbish tip up hill from the houses, causing leaching into the soil? Or the construction of a new health centre including a badly needed dental care service but no funding for the dentist? Or the high rate of otitis mediaâcommonly known as glue earâin young children but a visit by or access to qualified audiology services being virtually impossible? Or the construction of new housing but no potable water connected to the houses? Or the supply of affordableâI repeat, affordableâfresh food in a community despite the very high cost of transportation which is also severely affected during wet season rains with road closures and flooding? Or the sense in medical evacuation from northern WA to Perth rather than across the border to Darwin because of questions as to who pays for what? Or the supply of a bus for a youth program, the funding of which precludes the elderly in the same town being allowed to use the same bus?

The examples are many and I could go on at length. I cannot see how these types of fundamental issues can be improved by a mutual obligation agreement, and I am not suggesting that they should or can be. What I am suggesting is that the federal government in a leadership role address the fundamental issues of governance, cost shifting and jurisdictional divide, and begin to move those blockages to some of the solutions along with their colleagues in the states and territories. I now turn to recommendation 1 of that report, which states:

quote.para: The Commonwealth accept it has the major responsibility for the provision of primary health care to Indigenous Australians:

The Commonwealth must assume responsibility for developing, in collaboration with the States and Territories, an efficient, coordinated and effective mechanism for the delivery of services and programs which impact on the health and well-being of the Indigenous population.

speech.para: Yes, the Indigenous people and their communities have roles and responsibilities but it is a two-way street. Let us encourage and support our Indigenous people and work with them. Mutually agreeable arrangements should be supported. However, government must be clear in what it is doing. Its responsibilities, I have to say, are clear to me. I urge the government to outline to this parliament what has been done in practical ways to address the health issues facing our Indigenous population.

The other issue I want to speak about is policy affecting our people with a disability. The new administrative arrangements of this government, I believe, show the transfer of disability support pension payments away from social security, and they are now the concern of the Minister for Workforce Participation. I note this change of governance with some concern. Let us look very carefully at this government's record and question their intent with the administrative arrangement. The government is using the results of a recent pilot study into DSP employment assistance to support their intent to coerce DSP recipients off pensions and into work. The Minister for Workforce Participation issued the results of the pilot study outlined in an article in the Canberra Times on 25 November. It was claimed that of 671 participants with disabilities who receive intensive assistance from Job Network providers one-third found employment or enrolled in education courses within six months. The minister said that the results showed that people with disabilities were `willing to work' and he went on to say:

quote.para: For those people that we think aren't there legitimately, then we need to try to adopt some coercion ... That's unfortunate in that minority of cases ...

speech.para: This government talks about coercionâa government that has done little to support any constructive move from welfare to work for people with disabilities. It is a government that in some cases has actually failed in the funding of programs designed to support these people.

Before the minister goes off and draws up his plan for coercion, he should look a little bit more closely at this pilot study. For example, 62 per cent of the participants had previously indicated a willingness to work by being registered with Centrelink as looking for work. The DSP recipients in the pilot were those who did not have any ongoing support requirements. The DSP participants volunteered. The pilot was not designed to canvass a cross-section of DSP participants and cannot expect results representative of the general DSP population. They are just a few points on a quick look at the study. It should be no surprise to the government that many people on DSP would dearly love to be back at work and not be reliant on welfare support. You do not need a study to know this; you just need to speak with them. They will tell you very clearly the problems they encounter in trying to get back to work full time, part time or casually. The reality is clear. Unfortunately people with a disability are less likely to be in the work force than those with no disability.

Consider these statistics. In the last financial year just under 10 per cent of people on the disability support pension had employment related earnings, that is around 63,000 people out of a population of 673,000. Australia has the seventh lowest employment rate in the OECD for people with a disability. According to the 2003 OECD employment outlook, Australian people with a disability had just over a 40 per cent chance of finding employment. In comparison, people with no disability had a 70 to 80 per cent chance of finding work. Nearly two-thirds of the OECD countries measured had better employment rates than Australia for people with a disability than for people with no disability. So it is not hard to imagine why people with a disability are less likely to be in the work force. I have heard many stories of people facing discrimination which may even lead to them giving up looking for a job. Others may not have access to the support they need to find employment. Some of the other challenges faced by people with a disability who want to work include low self-esteem, social isolation, dependence on welfare, poor education and transport issues.

This government has undertaken massive reforms in the disability employment sector, but no reforms are worthy unless they serve the people directly affectedâthat is, the people with a disability. That should be the sole motive. This pilot sounds more like another reform to suit a government agenda. While it talks about the importance of people with a disability entering the work force and the need for employers to be more innovative in this area, the Howard government over the years has employed fewer people with a disability. For example, the proportion of people with a disability employed by the Commonwealth government has decreased from 5.7 per cent in 1993 to 3.6 per cent in 2002. As I have said, any reforms can only be considered legitimate if people with a disability and their families and carers are the central focus of the reforms under consideration. Anything other than that represents a government on its own philosophical path.

It must be noted that this government tied the release of funding for 17,200 additional disability employment places to cutting the fortnightly pensions of 200,000 disability pensioners by more than $50âan initiative not agreed to by this parliament. I repeat: 17,200 additional disability support places from this government depended on people agreeing that 200,000 disability pensioners have their incomes cut. Because that did not happen, those 17,200 additional places did not come. I do not know what other people think about a government that does that, but I know what I think: it is pretty poor.

People with disabilities who are seeking to return to work must have access to appropriate services, support and adequately trained advisers within the job placement services and, most importantly, they must be given encouragement and time to allow that transition. I strongly support the proposal made by the Acting Disability Discrimination Commissioner, Dr Sev Ozdowski, for a public inquiry on the issues affecting equal employment opportunity for people with a disability in Australia. This is vital, given the government's track record in this area. The whole question of people with a disability in this country being employable, being happy to be employed and being able to be employed will not be enhanced by a government acting in a coercive manner. It will be enhanced if the government works with the community in a positive, forward-looking way, providing encouragement and support where necessary.

It is an honour for me have the opportunity to speak in the address-in-reply debate. I look forward to working with and for the people of the electorate of Canberra and working in this parliament in the hope that we can make a difference to the lives and fortunes of all in our community.

talk.start.para: âIt is a great pleasure to be here today to speak in the address-in-reply debate. In my fifth term in parliament, I still have the feeling of wonder that we are able to reinvent the process of democracy every three yearsâthe apparent simplicity of it all, yet the sheer incredibility of it when one looks at how utterly few and endangered are the true democratic societies of our world. There are times when I wish that every person in the electorate of Pearce and beyond had the opportunity to visit this place and see the parliament in action. It is unfortunate that many see only glimpses on their television screen and the odd report in the daily paper. There is so much more to this parliament, and so much more that I think the Australian public could appreciate if they could share this experience with us.

speech.para: I am proud of the bipartisan work that is undertaken by the many committees of the parliament and the outstanding contributions of the men and women elected to office. These are men and women who represent broadly the electorates throughout Australia, 150 of them, notwithstanding their political differences. Whatever differences within our political alliances, we all regard the preservation of democracy as our first concern whenever it is threatened by the malevolent forces of fundamentalist extremism. As elected members we are well supported by the staff of Parliament House, an aspect that the public rarely gets to see. Hopefully there will be a growing awareness of the public operation of parliament through the great work of the House of Representatives Liaison and Projects Office, which has published some valuable material in recent timesâincluding computer programs and CD-ROMsâto better inform schoolchildren and members of the public about the operation and work of this parliament. I thank and congratulate those within the parliamentary staff areas for this outstanding work. Thank you.

We have a system of government that serves us well. Many of us have watched the elections in Iraq and the courage of the Iraqi people going to the polls under such difficult circumstances. In fact my colleague here Joanna Gash went to Jordan and has been part of the process to ensure the success of the Iraqi elections. The election images beamed around the world should serve to strengthen our resolveâevery one of us, whether we are members of parliament or members of the general publicâto support our democratic processes and to participate fully to ensure the continuance of a strong democratic system of government. A democracy relies on not only members in this place representing their electorates but also the interaction of the Australian public with their members of parliament. Sometimes I hear from people that they do not see their member of parliament, but I always say to people, `This engagement is a two-way process.' There is an obligation on both parties, not just on members of parliament but also on members of the public, to come forward and discuss their concerns and to seek changes where those changes are appropriate. We must continue to strengthen our resolve in that regard, to have maximum participation by the Australian people in what goes on in this place.

This is also the first opportunity I have had since the federal election to place on record my appreciation to the many people who assisted me with the Pearce campaign, particularly Mr Lane Taylor, who took on the role of campaign chair as well as treasurerâa role that he has undertaken since my first campaign in 1992. That is participation and that is something to be proud of, and I am very grateful for that. He was ably supported by an excellent committee and by my staff. One is fortunate indeed to have the benefit of working with people who, with the same generosity of spirit and cheerful conviction that they have displayed in previous elections, are again committed so fully to participating in the democratic processes of our country. The electors of Pearce have once again elected me to represent them in the federal parliament, and I greatly appreciate the opportunity they have afforded me to ensure that their voices are heard in this place. I pledge myself to return to renew my energetic commitment to vigorous representation.

The Pearce electorate is a vast tract. It is the third-largest electorate in Western Australia and it includes outer suburban, rural and coastal communities with very diverse needs. The issues that are common to all include health, education, transport and telecommunications to name a few. I am grateful to our ministers in the respective portfolios for the consideration they have given to the electors of Pearce in the ongoing quest to improve these services. That said, I am very much aware that there is much more to be done. But the electorate has been well served by the legacy of over eight years of the Howard government. I will not go through all of these; I think they are fairly well understood. But economic growth has been made possible by these policies and certainly by financial deregulation and microeconomic reform, including important changes to the taxation system.

This has resulted in the benefit of economic growth and prosperity being shared amongst all Australians. That share has been very evenly distributed throughout the electorate according to the National Centre for Social and Economic Modelling. They say that household income in the poorer suburbs and regions grew by 23.2 per cent, while the growth in income in the top-earning suburbs was negligibly higher at 24.2 per cent. The largest increase in household income was found in middle Australia, with a 28.9 per cent increase. So that puts paid to those who would criticise the Howard government for economic reform that delivers only to the rich. This has been a very significant contribution by the Howard government not only to ensure national prosperity but also to ensure that all members of the public benefit from that prosperity. Long may that continue.

These benefits are only possible with continuous economic reform. If we are to sustain the distribution of wealth throughout the community, we must continue down the path of reform in the future. There is no doubt about that. Some of these reforms include further reform to the taxation system. One of the things that deeply concerns me about the tax system today is that so few people understand it, even professionals. It is becoming more and more difficult. It has grown like topsy over the years and it is very hard for people to keep up with the rulings. The public have a right to expect that this parliament will deal with a reform of the tax system that allows average people to understand what their tax obligations are, and I do not think that is the case at the moment.

I do not think you will find too much disagreement anywhere that we pay too much tax, but that is always a balancing argument because our expectations are great. As long as we have great expectations of government to provide a variety of services then we will have to pay a reasonable amount of tax. I sometimes reflect on how many countries have the number of museums, theatres, libraries and other facilities that we have in Australia today. The infrastructure, which is really quite amazing for a large country, all has to be paid for. I guess the argument about the amount of taxation will be one that will be well and truly debated as the years go on.

The other area for reform is industrial relations. Having participated in the debate about the unfair dismissal laws and the attempts by the Howard government to change these laws on many occasions, I hope that commonsense will eventually prevail and that small business will be unburdened of what has been a very poor piece of legislation. It shows all the worst aspects of legislation: it was so heavily weighted against small business people, who are the primary employers of Australians in their small businesses. The last thing we want to do is discourage them from employing more people. There is always a balance to be had, but I believe that the legislation as it was before our attempts to amend it was highly prejudicial to the mums and dads in the community who run small businesses.

I also support the suggestion by the Prime Minister that we examine a single national industrial relations system and the simplification of the awards structure. Again, if we do not to take some of the worst aspects of industrial relations from our employer groups, then it is a great disincentive for businesses to grow and develop. It is a very costly system to the nation. So it has to be fair but it must also be streamlined so that you do not have the situation that exists today.

Certainly when doorknocking small businesses in my electorate over the past few weeks, I found deep concern in Western Australia about the push to bring back 24-hour trading. It is not that most business people are in essence opposed to 24-hour trading. The reason that those in Western Australia are concerned about it is the need for them to pay penalty rates to employees for working on Sunday or outside what are considered to be normal hours. This is a great difficulty for most small businesses. There is simply not the fat to be able to pay these kinds of penalty rates. The tragedy of it is that there are many people in our community today who want to work on Sundays and who want to take up part-time outside hours work. The industrial relations laws in Western Australia are a great impediment to small business supporting the competition policy requirement for 24-hour trading. Until the Western Australian state Labor government come to grips with that, they are going to continue to have resistance to a great degree from the Western Australian small business community. The fact is that by the time a small business pays penalty rates for a Sunday or outside hours there is no profit left from its opening. The current system is cumbersome and is certainly discouraging for many business owners.

The other area of continuing reform that interests me is education and training. I think the Minister for Education, Science and Training, Dr Nelson, has provided outstanding leadership in education and training. He has done a great deal to provide solutions for many of the problems, particularly those to do with vocational training and apprenticeships, which have increased a lot. With full employment, we are seeing at the moment shortages in trade areas. Some measures have been put in place to address those, but I think we need to continue with that push because there is no doubt that future economic success is inextricably linked to having a ready and appropriately qualified work force. It is unacceptable to have the huge trade shortages that we have today with the potential to hobble many industries. Training is not just the responsibility of government though, and I want to stress this. Over the years we have seen many industries withdraw from training, relying on hiring companies to provide experienced labour for them. In an environment of rapid development and economic prosperity, this has led to a critical shortage of tradespeople across a wide area. I welcome particularly the announcements by Minister Nelson of the establishment of new training facilities. I know that work is progressing well on the implementation of this particular election commitment.

There are other areas of the social policy realm that I would like to see addressed. One of those is mental health. Sadly, we have seen the case of Cornelia Rau. What the case of Cornelia Rau has done though is highlight for both government and the Australian community that the issue of mental health is a very important and very pressing one within our community. Since the shift in policy to discourage institutionalising the mentally ill in our community, we have seen a steady number of homeless people at risk in a variety of ways as the system has failed to adequately support them. I know that the Commonwealth has been aware of the growing need for support in this area and that, through the National Mental Health Strategy, has responded with a steady increase in the amount of funding at a federal level for mental health services. The Commonwealth has contributed an increase of 128 per cent since 1993. Sadly, the states increased spending by a mere 40 per cent over the same period. Once again in mental health we are seeing a failure of consistency in approach to mental health services across the country. With a greater mobility of people, this demands a consistent approach to the delivery of services.

One of the other areas that has been of concern to me is that of unlawful arrivals in Australia. No-one can deny the terrible dilemma that faces modern governments today with an increasing number of refugees and displaced people looking for a better life outside their own countries, some of them whose lives depend on their escape from their own countries. A government has an obligation to its citizens though to have an orderly migration program and to play a role in taking legitimate refugees. As unpleasant as mandatory detention is, I cannot think of many options available to initially process people who arrive without appropriate entry visas. The responsibility of government is heightened by the events of 9/11 and the international environment in which we find ourselves in the 21st century.

I continue to be concerned about the lengthy time people are being held in detention before a determination is made. I remain particularly concerned about the effect of long detention periods on children, and I believe we should urgently establish an independent review process on how to shorten the period of mandatory detention and improve practices for dealing with unlawful arrivals. There are people who have been in detention centres since they were children. They have now become adults and remain in those centres. There are some who, as adults, have been in detention for in excess of six years. This is one of the policy areas that I personally am committed to seeing addressed in this term of parliament.

Aboriginal reconciliation and Aboriginal health remain issues for me. Listening to a radio program over the holiday, I was shocked and saddened by a report on Aboriginal returned servicemen. Apparently, they went unrecognised after returning from the war and most often died without recognition. They did not receive the same benefits as other returned servicemen. I did not know that and I was shocked to learn of it. In fact, a farmer and his wife from Western Australia spoke on the program and what they said was very touching. The program, though, offered a glimmer of hope with the restoration of the graves of Aboriginal ex-servicemen and the appropriate recognition on the headstone of service to their country.

It made me stop and think that this is just one of many injustices done to Aboriginal people, who were, after all, the first people of the land. It is a matter of enduring shame that so many Aboriginal people still live in circumstances long unacceptable to most of us. Practical reconciliation is an important part of dealing with the continuing poor state of Aboriginal health, housing and education; but it is not enough. Listening to the relatives of the Aboriginal servicemen in the radio program, I was touched by their humility and gratefulness in the face of the awful neglect of men who should have been treated with dignity and respect and who have lain in unmarked graves until very recently.

We have inherited a bountiful, beautiful country without the awful violence that has marked the colonisation and settlement of other nations. This is in part I am certain due to the peaceful, sharing nature of Aboriginal people. Over the years we have jumped from being overpatronising to having little interest or support for the broader issues facing Aboriginal communities caught in the dilemma of preserving the remnants of an amazing culture with the need to engage with a contemporary world. However difficult that task may be and however uncomfortable we may feel, we owe our Aboriginal people more than practical reconciliation. There is a need for us to recognise the injustices and the ill-conceived policies, no matter how well meaning they were. Once we can accept and acknowledge this without compromise, then and only then can we walk hand in hand with our Aboriginal brothers and sisters to a better future. It requires humility. We must be able to acknowledge the injustices without equivocation. Further, we need to highlight the successes, for there are many within the Aboriginal communities, and to be optimistic and hopeful for a brighter future. (Time expired)

talk.start.para: âThere are a number of issues I would like to speak about today in the address-in-reply of the Governor-General's speech. The first has to be to thank the electors of Isaacs for, once again, asking me to represent them here in Australia's parliament. To be elected to represent one's neighbours and fellow residents across, in my case, a number of suburbs is a great honour. I intend to continue to do all I can to represent the people of Isaacs as well as I can by being available to them as much as possible. For instance, I will be continuing my practice of conducting mobile offices in shopping centres outside office hours throughout the year and I will be continuing my program of doorknocking throughout the parliamentary term.

speech.para: I think that one of the risks of being elected to parliament is to get too involved in all the wonderful opportunities that present themselves outside the electorate and suddenly not have any time for the most important opportunity of allâthat is, to hear what is going on in your own backyard. I intend to do all I can to make sure that I continue to remember the most important people: those whom I represent when I am in Canberra.

I am disappointed in the election result. I am pleased that I have been returned to parliament, but I wish that I had the company of a few more of my colleagues and that we were all sitting on the other side of the House. But the Australian people have spoken. We live in a democracy and we abide by the decision of the people despite personal feelings. The election just gone did not focus, as many experts predicted, on the war in Iraq, on refugees or even on national security. Despite the changed conditions in our world, grassroots issues and local worries took centre stage. Health and education were the issues most often raised with me during the election campaign period. The next group of issues most often raised with me were to do with the war in Iraq, our relationship with the US and the honesty of the current government.

But it is clear from the election results that the economy, or more accurately its effect on individual households, was the major issue in Isaacs. A decent life with a secure incomeâhopefully from a satisfying jobâgood affordable health care, access to excellent education, and respect for the physical environment and our neighbours, both local and global, should be features of our society. Many of Australia's policies in these areas have been the envy of many other countries, but I am afraid that much of this is about to disappear. In order to ensure that we continue in an effective society we, in this parliament, have an obligation to ensure that everyone is able to enjoy a decent life. We are all Australians and nobody has more of a claim than anybody else to a good way of life or a chance to enjoy life. In a fair and decent society, we will always make decisions that protect the weakâeven to the disadvantage of the strong. A fair and decent society will ensure proper care of all its members whatever their strengths, weaknesses and capacities. It does not reward those who already have plenty at the expense of those who have less. A fair and decent society accepts and enjoys differences, and encourages and even demands tolerance.
The Speaker, in his first speech as the newly elected Speaker, reminded us that the eyes of the nation are on us as we go about our business here in parliament. The Speaker said:

quote.para: We all have a responsibility to repay the trust of our citizens by discharging our duties in a way worthy of respect.

speech.para: I have said before in this place that our behaviour, particularly in question time, is not always conducive to respect. It is clear to all of us here that question time is not typical of a parliamentary day, but that is not the perception of most Australians and of the people who speak to me. For most people, parliament is the bit of question time that they see on the nightly news when we are often engaged in behaviour in keeping with the rowdier elements of a football crowd when the umpire has made the wrong decision.

Parliament is one of our places of business and we are at work. We have been given the job of representing our constituency in federal parliament, making decisions that shape our nation and affect everyone's daily lives. The people of Australia deserve to feel assured that we are executing our jobs professionally and properly. I do not think the parliament that the public seesâthat is, a bit of question timeâoffers anyone that reassurance. To my mind, it is most important that Australians have confidence in their MPs. It is important for a number of reasons: one of them being the ongoing health of our democracy. If people become disillusioned about our system of government, they will withdraw from it.

We are already seeing a significant number of voters who express absolute disinterest in voting. Recently there have been a few calls from government MPs and senators for the introduction of non-compulsory voting. Those calling for this change cite an increasing number of voters who say they are disinterested as a reason for that change. I guess their argument runs along the lines of: if a voter does not care or cannot be bothered why make them vote? But I argue that this is exactly what we should not do. We must address the don't care attitude, not accept it as unmovable. The don't care attitude is certainly not acceptable if we are at all interested in looking after our democracy. The suggestion that we move to non-compulsory voting is a step backwards, a step away from a strong democracy. Voting should be considered a responsibility not just a right. One thing that can be done immediately to redress this attitude of `why bother' is to polish up our image, particularly the way we behave in parliament. If we are seen to behave in a professional way then this is a good first step.

Mr Deputy Speaker Quick, it comes as no news to you that Labor has long been aware of the need to reform the health system. Presently something like $500 million per year is wasted because of the delineation between federal and state health systems. In particular, there are many frail and aged people in acute beds in public hospitals waiting for a bed in an aged care facility. This situation is distressing for older people and their families, frustrating for those trying to find beds for acute patients and a waste of our resources. I urge the government to adopt a policy similar to the one called Medicare Gold announced by Labor during the election campaign. The principle of Medicare Gold was excellent. It allows one level of government to fund the health and accommodation requirements of our aged and frail people, saving half a billion dollars a year and giving the aged the security of knowing that they will have access to appropriate and affordable health care when they need it.

The Howard government does not have a clear view of the real needs of Australians in the health field. Policy fixes and bandaids like MedicarePlus and the so-called Medicare safety net do little to instil confidence in those who need access to doctors and health professionals. The safety net will see the evolution of a two-tiered health system in Australiaâthe end to access to excellent and affordable health care regardless of who you are and the depths of your pocket. Medicare, and before it Medibank, has been the cornerstone of Australia's health system for a quarter of a century. A system that was once the envy of the world is being eroded by the short-sighted policies of the Howard government. The Prime Minister has never been a fan of Medicare. He has always wanted to demolish it and will now do so.

Labor want to strengthen Medicare and restore bulk-billing for all Australians. Labor are committed to restoring a national role for the provision of dental health to remove the unacceptable situation of many people who are waiting for a long time for essential dental care. We are committed to public funding for all listed vaccinesâa policy which stands in stark contrast to the government's policy. The government's policy is one of only providing funding for recommended vaccines when shamed into it by the strength of public opinion, as evidenced last year in the pneumococcal vaccine debate.

One of what I call the `sleeping issues' is unemployment in the older work force, so-called mature age unemployment. A number of older menâand it is usually menâhave recently told me about problems they experienced in finding a job. Often the person has been employed for most of his life and is now suddenly out of work because of redundancy or downsizing. These people often face a different set of problems to other unemployed people, but these problems are, nevertheless, just as important and need to be addressed. A typical case is a man in his late 40s or 50s, out of work often for the first time, often well qualified or skilled in his old job and often in a household where his partner works and has a reasonable income. The older unemployed person usually experiences the same feelings as other unemployed people do: loss of confidence, immense frustration at being unable to find work and a feeling of the world passing by and of suddenly being invisible. Add to this the frustration of not being eligible for assistance at Job Network because of a partner's income, and you end up with someone very frustrated and often angryâand with good cause.

I was delighted that the Labor Party's policies included specific plans to provide assistance to those mature age unemployed people. Labor's policy had a number of measures to assist older people who were out of work. One of those proposals was the establishment of mature age career centres. These centres would provide assistance and support targeted to mature age Australians out of work and would help them get back into work. The challenge for the government now is to take the necessary steps to look after these people and to ensure that their skills and experiences are not lost to the work force.

All we have had so far from the Howard government is a promise of a mature age worker tax offset. Workers over 55 who earn up to $48,000 a year will receive a $500-a-year tax break. I am not knocking the tax break for older workers, but it is hardly a policy to assist those out of work. This policy does nothing to address the generalisations and misconceptions about older workers, nor does it provide incentives for employers to retrain or hire older workers. The Governor-General has said that there are links between skills and achievements and a robust economy, yet the Howard government has few policies that address the difficulty older people have in finding employment. The truth is that, more than ever, the experience and knowledge of mature age workers is needed. With an ageing population, the need to recognise the skills and stability of mature workers is a necessity if we are all to use our resources to build a strong economy and support our ageing population.

As I said earlier, the economy was an important issue in the election campaign. People responded to the clever interest rate scare campaign. The fact that many people are so close to the edge financially is a direct result of the policies of this government over recent years. The government likes to claim credit for a good economy, yet many people no longer have the security of a reliable permanent job. Many people are living with what I have heard referred to as `a portfolio of jobs'. That is polite talk for someone trying to hold down a number of part-time or casual jobs, instead of having the comfort and security of one full-time permanent job.

In this strong economy I note that as a nation Australia is spending far more than it earns. Our current account deficit has hit record levels. We cannot continue along this path. The situation is unsustainable, yet we hear nothing from the government of plans to address this issueâsensible plans, that is.

What is unacceptable is for the Howard government to claim that they can control interest rates and that they are the only party that is economically responsible. History shows that, as Treasurer, John Howard presided over four consecutive budget deficits in the late seventies and early eighties. We hear about high interest rates under the Hawke government, but we do not hear about the fact that, when the coalition was tossed out in 1983, interest rates were around 16 per cent. They moved up and down over the next few years, peaking at 17 per cent, as we are so often reminded, before steadily falling to around seven per cent when Labor lost office in 1996. Since then interest rates have moved a bit and are now around 5Â½ per cent.

It is interesting too to look at Australia's interest rate history compared with rates in other countries. Australia's interest rates have always moved consistently with movements in other countries, the lesson being that interest rates are not under the direct control of government. Firstly, the Reserve Bank sets the interest rate and it is independent of the government. Secondly, Australia is part of a wider economy and our rates will move broadly with the fortunes or otherwise of like nations.

There is a shortage of skilled workers in Australia. Many people, including the Business Council of Australia, have been telling us this for some time. The response we now have from the government is to establish a few federally run technical colleges. There is no logic to this. We have a TAFE system in place which is crying out for more places so that it can meet the demand of students. We have industry crying out for more skilled workers. But the government takes the longwinded approach of developing another system on top of an existing oneâa system which will take many years to produce graduates. This is a crazy solution to the problem. It is wasting the resources of our young people who today, right now, cannot get into TAFE. The challenge for the government is to abandon this crazy idea and fund places in the system that already exists and get on with training our young people, providing the skills that we need.

Another challenge the government must face in this term is the growing crisis in aged care. I have already talked a bit about the need to streamline the provision of aged care services, but there are other aspects to this issue. There is a shortage of places, exacerbated by the long lead times of bringing beds into operation once the bed licences have been issued. We have to get much better at providing an adequate number of beds, we have to get better at bringing them on line more quickly and we have to get better at providing the right mix of low- and high-level care beds.

Aged care operators in Isaacs tell me that, more and more, those entering the system for the first time are frailer and sicker than those entering the system for the first time a decade ago. This is probably a reflection of people's determination to stay at home as long as possible, coupled with better services provided to those at home. What it means for the aged care sector, though, is the need for a different mix of beds, more high-level beds, more services for those at home and more respite services to help the carers of those staying at home but needing day-to-day care.

The aged care sector also faces problems with staffing. Nurses in the aged care sector earn less than those in the acute sector, with the result that it is increasingly hard to attract and then keep staff in the aged care sector. Attention must also be paid to the question of adequate capital funding of aged care facilities. This does not mean bonds, but it does mean providing adequate funding so that aged care facilities can maintain decent physical facilities.

I have mentioned some of the challenges facing Australia. I have not talked about others such as the need for reform in the funding arrangements for schools, the need to provide for the thousands of people caring for frail relatives or disabled people, the need to improve at government level our attitude to our physical environment and to our Indigenous community, and our responsibilities in the global community. I will be doing all I can from this side of the House to keep the pressure on the government to attend properly to the challenges that this country and my electorate are facing.

talk.start.para: âIt is with considerable pleasure, even at this late time and in this chamber, that I get my opportunity, in the address-in-reply debate, to respond to the Governor-General's speech. In looking to the document, I see a series of subheadings which are all-important to the interests of Australians. The first heading is `Maintaining a strong economy' and many of the other headings relate back to that commitment. I was somewhat disappointed, nevertheless, to find that throughout that series of commitments nothing was said about taxation reform. Taxation reform does not necessarily mean tax cuts. There is a great old statement about taxation. The perfect tax requires simplicity, equity and certaintyâor it might be the other way around: simplicity, certainty and equity. I do not think the Australian tax system at state, local or Commonwealth level meets any of those criteria. It is a challenge to this parliamentânot this governmentâto address those principles and see what we can do about a stack of paperwork and all the tragedies that are brought to our attention as people spend half their business life or their personal life trying to reduce the burden arising, in the case of personal taxation, from bracket creep in particular.

speech.para: I thought it would be a good opportunity to put on the record just a few facts that I obtained in trying to address these principles myself. The advice I received is very interesting. I asked this question of the Libraryâwho gave me this information from the statistics; it is not their view: how many taxpayers have a gross income below $6,000, below $10,000 and below $15,000? The latest statisticsâwhich, I might add, are from 2001-02âare that there are 10,343,677 taxpayers and, of these, 1.7335 million, or 16.8 per cent, had total incomes of less than $10,000 and 2.7 million, in round figures, or 26.1 per cent, had total incomes of less than $15,000. There are no published figures on my other question.

Then I asked: how much government revenue would be received if all income earners above $10,000 were taxed from the first dollar at 17c or 10c, but all under $10,000 paid nothing? In other words, you paid on all your income if you earned more than $10,000. It was estimated that for 2004-05 if those individuals with taxable income of less than $10,001 paid no tax and all other taxable individuals paid 10 per cent, the additional revenue would be $3.1 billion. If we made it 17 per cent, the additional revenue would be $9.1 billion.

I also asked how much revenue we receive in the various categories of taxationâthat is, the 17 per cent rate, the 30 per cent rate, the 42 per cent rate and the 47 per cent rate. It is interesting to note that, presently, the 17 per cent rate delivers 22 per cent of the total tax collected; the 30 per cent rate, 44 per cent of the total tax collected; the 42 per cent rate, seven per cent of the total tax collected; and the 47 per cent rate, 26 per cent of the total tax collected. That is a huge burden because, even on the proposed future brackets, too many Australians are moving into the two higher brackets, 42 and 47 per cent, and they do not equate with the company tax rate, which is 30 per cent. So what do people do? They waste the time of their accountants, who should be telling them how to run their businessâand this is even at the corporate levelâtrying to find ways to escape that problem. We have all heard of the family trust and the associated company arrangements that have to be put in place. Having been in that field for years as a business man, and then moving to this parliament, where I wished to extricate myself from a lot of those arrangements, I discovered just how difficult that was and what a mess it had created in our financial dealings as a family.

Why do we do it? As Terry McCrann quite properly told us in an article the other day, we are all rich people seeking to distribute or claim as many $6,000 tax-free thresholds as we can. If we had to pay tax from the first dollar that would not be an option, and therefore the interest in a lot of those complex arrangements would disappear overnight. Of course this issue could be addressed, as I have pointed out, simply by saying nobody pays tax if they earn less than $10,000. That is a fairly generous arrangement for the 17 per cent who are in that category. At the same time, those people who earn greater amounts would start paying with the first dollar, and if that were 17 per cent we would find that the $9.1 billion of revenue would be fairly close to the $13 billion of revenue the government would lose if it discontinued the 42 per cent and 47 per cent tax rates. That is not perfect, but I guess it addresses the simplicity argument. Someone might say I am simple to even put it up, but too many people are making money out of the complexity, and I think that is a great pity. It just brings to our attention better ways perhaps of achieving those three criteria.

Let us look at where the money is spent and how it is raised through other avenues. State revenue, according to the advice I have received, is about $75 billion. Do not think this is going to happen tomorrow, because much more powerful people in my party make these decisions, but I asked a question as to what would happen if GST were applied to all transactions without exemption and the rate was five per cent, 10 per cent and 12 per cent. I am told that at five per cent the revenue would be $21.2 billion; at 10 per cent, $42.4 billion; and at 12 per cent, $50.9 billionâand maybe I should have asked what the revenue would be at 15 per cent.

GST revenue in the year 2003-04 was $33 billion, with our highly complex arrangements. So we have states expending $75 billion with all their nasty taxesâand I want to refer to them, but they are not their fault. On extrapolating those figures, the total state revenue of $75 billion could probably be met with a 15 per cent GST rate. They could get rid of payroll tax, stamp duty and all those things, other than in my mind a fee relative to the actual service provided. That is how stamp duty started: it was a fee to record your property transactionâand that was quite appropriate, but it converted to a revenue measure over time.

In looking at this you would immediately say: `What about the poor people? They'd have to pay 15 per cent on a lettuce; isn't that terrible?' But the average Australian moves house every seven years. Even for a modest residence today the stamp duty would be $10,000 or $12,000. Divide that by seven and that is over $1,500 a year in personal tax, but nobody thinks about it in that context. Of course, if they buy a new car every three years, they would need to pay another $1,000 or whatever in state stamp duty. So wouldn't they possibly be better off paying 15 per cent on a lettuceâthat is a question, not a statementâinstead of those other taxes and payroll tax?

If you think there is no payroll tax on a tin of beans, think again. There is no such thing as a free lunch. To make a profit, a business that is paying payroll tax must pass it on to the consumer. Of course we know the detriments that that tax has in terms of its complexity and the employment decisions of employers et cetera. If they are an exporter then that is a burden they carry when they are competing in the real world with other countries that have different forms of taxation. So would it be better to have a GST that does not tax exports as the sole means of state revenue?

These are the sorts of figures that I think can be talked about. They do not involve any substantial reduction in the overall tax burden, but certainly there would be some shifting. Nevertheless, I do not see why Wilson Tuckey or Kerry Packer need $6,000 of their income tax free. I think that, even on our rather poor salaries, we would be better off paying 17c on $6,000 than 47c on $20,000 or $30,000 or whatever it is. There would be benefits.

There are shearers working in my electorate who refuse to shear more than 150 sheep a day. Some of them can shear 200 sheep, but they say, `I'm not going to sheer the last 50 sheep for the taxman.' So what happens? The shearing period gets extended and everybodyâthe contractor, the farmer and eventually the consumerâhas to pay the shed hands for a couple of extra days to get the job finished. That is not necessarily good for anyone. So there are a lot of disincentives in those high tax rates.

I argue very strongly that the top personal tax rate should always be harmonised with the company tax rate, whatever it is. All the schemes that cause people pain, and the fights that follow with the Taxation Commissioner, would suddenly cease. Nevertheless, in terms of the administration of the tax act, I have never been able to understand why we as a parliament have not promoted a simple law which says that, if a taxpayer makes a full disclosure to the ATO which is later disputed by the Taxation Commissionerâand that is fair enoughâany penalties or interest should only apply, say, 60 days after the Taxation Commissioner notifies the taxpayer that he disagrees with their personal calculation of how much tax they owe. I cannot see how people can go for three or four years making certain claims and then get a letter in the mail from the Taxation Commissioner which says: `Three or four years ago you did something with which I now disagree. I am therefore hitting you with heavy penalties and interest charges over that period.' That often puts people in a position where they go broke. I cannot understand how there is any certainty, simplicity or, more particularly, equity in that arrangement.

I believe that our parliament should say it is a fundamental rule that, until the Taxation Commissioner tells you he disagrees, you cannot be hit with penalties or interest for that period. It should be up to the Taxation Commissioner. As they once did, he can look at your tax return and write to you the following day. The rule is that you should make full disclosure and not tell untruths. So if you say, `I earned all this money and I entered scheme X and I believe that entitled me to reduce my tax by Y,' I see no reason whatsoever why, in those circumstances, you should be penalised until the Taxation Commissioner disagrees.

I put those few figures on the record for people to consider. We probably should sit down as a parliament and come up with alternatives of that nature. But my target is the removal of tax avoidance. I think the $6,000 tax-free threshold is much more beneficial to high-income earners than low-income earners. I really do. I think we need to have a better approach to that, notwithstanding that low-income earners are not expected to pay tax at the same rate as people in higher income categories. Having said that, I hope the parliament will see in the next three years a major approach to this from both sides.

I have sat through 13 years of opposition in this place. And I made the point yesterday that the Prime Minister has given credit to Bob Hawke, in particular, for the reforms that passed through this parliament during the Hawke governmentâwhen Keating was Treasurerâand the Keating government. Most of them got through the caucus because Keating or Hawke were able to go to the caucus and say, `You'll get no trouble from the coalition opposition on this issue.' I sat there in the shadow cabinet for years judging new policy announcements. When Keating came up with his GST we did not knock it. The trade unions knocked it, but we did not. They pulled the rug out from under him. As I recollect, it was all decided in a motel room. But the reality is that we said it was a positive measure.

A great challenge to the Labor Party and its new leader is to look at things and analyse them for the benefit of Australia, not for whether they are going to win or lose the next election. I think Aussies have gone well past the gravy train, notwithstanding we all still ride it. Australians are a lot more analytical and they want to see members of parliament get together on good issues, not running scare campaigns just because they sound good, not surfing to re-election on a tax that the community has now accepted and that might be the better source of 100 per cent of state revenues if we got rid of all those other taxes. Who stops to think that their house costs them $1,500 a year in stamp duty? That is about 30 bucks a week. Nobody thinks of it but that is what it is statistically. Of course it has even been a threat to the building industry at times because people have stood back and said, `I can't afford to buy a new house because I can't afford to sell the old one,' and that is a problem because we want people to buy new houses. It is good for the economy.

Because there is no such thing as a free lunch, I constantly remind people that with some deregulation of the labour market there has been a very substantial increase in the buying power of the average wage earner. Money? As we all know, at times during the Weimar Republic you needed a wheelbarrow to take enough money to buy a loaf of bread. Dollars? Not worth anything, more particularly if the tax man is the biggest beneficiary. But the fact of life is that, under the Howard government, workers' buying power has gone up by about 13 per cent. That statistically compares to two per cent over 13 years of the Hawke government and the Accord. Why? Because the Accord kept providing more cash but it did not provide the offsets in productivity that meant that Mrs Worker could buy things at a competitive price. The Chinese have fixed that up, and it is now a fact that children's clothing is cheaper than when I was clothing my children 40 years ago. Certainly in real terms it is much cheaper. That is as good as a pay increase.

We have to look at it in this way. It is no good going out there and saying, `Now is the time to grab a heap of dollars,' if it puts up our taxes, puts up costs to employers and eventually puts up the prices in supermarkets. But I do not think the world is ever going to let us get away with that again. Free markets are a given and they are happening here in Australia. Of course, most of the time the beneficiary is the consumer, and that is a good thing. So we have to win and maintain our living standard in two areas. We want good governmentâand I think the infrastructure argument is very important.

I have spent a lot of time on tax now and I will not get to the other things I wanted to say, but we are going to have to make hydrogen in this country and fuel all our vehicles with it. We can make it all from renewable energy. My farmers can make enough of it from the sun to use on their farms. We can use the tides of the Kimberleys, and I invite the Labor opposition to give my mob a touch up and say you will do it. Colin Barnett has grabbed the political initiative in WA by saying that he will bring water down from the north and he does not care what it costs. People are interested in those things. We have enough energy in the tides of the Kimberleys, otherwise unusable, to liquefy hydrogen, put it in a ship like we do with natural gasâthere is no rocket science involvedâand ship it to Sydney. General Motors told us in the Australian on the 19th of last month that they will be selling hydrogen cars in 2010.

We have got three buses running around Perth doing a wonderful job, and all that comes out of their exhaust pipes is steam. They are the only three in the Southern Hemisphere. It is a wonderful example of what we can do; we should be planning for that together. It is no good saying you are going to have hydrogen cars and then burn coal to electrolyse the water to make it. Let the coal industry generate the 50 per cent of energy needed for electricityâthat is convenient and cheap. Let us put all our wheels under hydrogen, and 50 per cent of our energy consumption will be clean and can be generated by renewable resources. As I said, I should have allowed more time for this issue. They are all interesting issues. If we get those things right as a parliament, the community will be eternally grateful.

talk.start.para: âWelcome back to the Speaker's panel, Mr Deputy Speaker Quick. It is really good to see you presiding over the affairs of the Main Committee this morning. In my contribution to the address-in-reply debate I want to discuss an issue that has been neglected by the Prime Minister as well as the Governor-General in his remarks at the opening of this parliament. It is the issue of increasing poverty in Australia and the increasing inequality that we are seeing between the haves and the have-nots. It is true that the Prime Minister has nominated reform of the industrial relations system and welfare reform as the big ticket items for his fourth term of office. Yet I am surprised by the continuing silence of the Prime Minister, and the Governor-General in his address, about what I see as one of the nation's biggest problemsâthat is, poverty and growing inequality.

speech.para: The Prime Minister would be well advised to take a leaf out of Nelson Mandela's book. In addressing a recent mass rally in London, which was focusing on the very critical issue of global poverty, Nelson Mandela had this to say:

quote.para: Like slavery and apartheid, poverty is not natural. It is man-made and it can be overcome and eradicated by the actions of human beings.
And Overcoming poverty is not a gesture of charity ... It is the protection of a fundamental human right, the right to dignity and a decent life.

speech.para: If our Prime Minister was really serious about improving the wellbeing of people in our community, he would elevate these two issues to the forefront of public policy debate and action in this country. In so doing he could really make a difference to the lot of many in our community who are witnessing the steady erosion of the notion of a fair go. We often hear Australia spoken of as a land of great opportunity with Australians enjoying a high standard of living and wellbeing. This is becoming increasingly true only for the majority in our country as a disturbingly high and growing number of people in our midst are living in poverty and denied the opportunities that come with economic and social wellbeing.

While financial hardship is the most obvious dimension of poverty, and usually the criteria that is used to define what we understand as the poverty line in this nation, people who live in relative poverty also lack the resources required for them to participate as full members of our society. The 2004 comprehensive Senate inquiry into poverty and financial hardship examined a number of ways of measuring poverty and concluded that there is:

quote.para: ... a consensus that the numbers of Australians living in poverty generally ranges from 2 to 3.5 million ...

speech.para: So the strong economic gains that we hear so much about from the Prime Minister and from the government, particularly in contributions in the House and in the Governor-General's opening address, have not been fairly shared by all our citizens.

While our economic indicators have continued to reach upwards, so has the level of inequality, poverty, homelessness, long-term unemployment, suicide and child abuse. Clearly something is going drastically wrong. The current levels of poverty in a country as rich as ours is quite unacceptable. There is, as people have described it, a blindness of affluence that affects our public debate, for it is largely the people reaping the benefits of economic growth who are also analysing and writing about national issues and setting the agenda. Those who are falling by the wayside regrettably have little voice to articulate the issues of concern to them and their communities. The Howard government continues to turn a blind eye to these problems. It has no strategy to tackle poverty and inequality in our society. In fact the government is abrogating its responsibility to tackle this great indignity.

While people can argue about what level is appropriate for setting the poverty lineâsome people argue it should be based on average wages or median wagesâthey all agree, and there can be no denying, that poverty is growing and that there are numerous deprivations that come with being poor. The Senate report to which I referred documents the close association between poverty and inequality of opportunity and reveals that the disadvantage in our nation is increasingly concentrated and geographic in its manifestations. I refer to a number of key indicators of poverty and inequality. These include the statistic that I referred to earlierâthat between two million and 3Â½ million Australians today are living in poverty and that number has increased under the Howard government's stewardship. Today, around 700,000 children are growing up in households in Australia in which neither parent works. The number of working poor is on the increase, with nearly one million working families not earning enough to lift them above the poverty line. While one-tenth of Australian households now own 45 per cent of our wealth, half the number of households in Australia own only seven per cent. Surely this reveals the extent of inequality in our midst.

As we all know, poverty is associated with poorer health outcomes, behavioural difficulties, low educational attainment, juvenile offending, social isolation and lack of support. Very disturbingly, intergenerational poverty is becoming a growing reality for a significant number of Australian families, some of whom live in my electorate. Voluntary and church organisations throughout the length and breadth of Australia continue to report a large growth in the number of people accessing their services and coming to them for emergency relief and assistance. The harsh reality of the situation in Australia was reinforced in a recently released UN human development index in 2004. It showed what we all knowâthat Australia was performing very well in terms of economic targets. It showed Australia's economic growth helped rank us third in the highly developed world for our human development but, at the same time, Australia was among the worst performers when it came to poverty. Australia was placed fourth on the human poverty index, with the United States, not surprisingly, the worst performer.

Added to this national dimension of poverty and inequality is a new phenomenon that is developing, one that is referred to as `postcode poverty'. In a recent study by the Ignatius Centre released last year, titled Community Adversity and Resilience, the centre measured the concentration of disadvantage according to postcode areas in New South Wales and Victoria. I took a particular interest in the findings of this report, for among the 40 highest ranking New South Wales postcode areas on a general disadvantage factor were three postcodes in my electorate of Throsbyâthe postcodes covering the suburbs around Warrawong, Berkeley and Port Kembla. Let me say a little about these areas.

In the suburbs that I have mentioned the median individual income, according to the most recent census data, is between $233 and $263 per week. The median family income is in the range of $435 to $550. In one area alone, the unemployment rate is recorded as being 20.2 per cent. In my electorate of Throsby, 22 per cent of children aged under 15 now live in families where no person is employed. These are real people, not just statistics. We need to deal with the problems that automatically ariseâthe fact that 7,000 children in my electorate are today growing up in homes where no-one has a connection with paid employment.

Naturally I was very interested in examining the conclusions of the study and what suggestions the Ignatius Centre, in its report, made for future policy and action. I want to point to a few of them. The study found that in Australia we are now witnessing growing areas of entrenched social disadvantage and intergenerational poverty that is related to where one lives, hence the term `postcode poverty'. It showed quite clearly that social exclusion breeds social alienation and the social problems that come with it. But, interestingly enough, the study also found that communities that can score highly on the measure of social cohesion seem to cope considerably better in the face of unemployment, low family income, low occupational skills and limited education. The study found that the causes and potential remedies of social disadvantage are located at many levels. The research paper goes on to argue:

quote.para: Without diminishing in any way the importance of macroeconomic factors to the economic and social health of a neighbourhood, the findings are a reminder that a community's internal relations can also play a significant part in shaping its wellbeing.

speech.para: Following from this the authors argue:

quote.para: ... strengthening the connectedness or social cohesion of disadvantaged areas is an integral part of renewing the life opportunities of people.

speech.para: So I think we can say with some degree of certainty that some communities facing and burdened by disadvantage appear more resilient than others in overcoming adversity and making the most of opportunities that come along.

These research findings would have very important implications for government policy and strategies for dealing with poverty if there were the political will to take them up. In particular, this study shows, firstly, that we need locality-specific measures to supplement general policy initiatives in dealing with disadvantage and poverty. Secondly, the study shows that there needs to be a redefinition of the relationship between communities and government agencies. In other words, this involves a different way of agencies working with communities. What seems very central is the need to build a sense of partnership with the community and to build a sense of commitment and community ownership.

When disadvantage has become entrenched in a community over many yearsâor even over decadesâas it has in parts of my electorate, governments need to understand that matters cannot be put right within a yearly or three-yearly funding cycle. I had reason to write recently to the Minister for Family and Community Services on behalf of a number of local projects that were facing the end of their funding rounds. One in particular, the Bundaleer project run by Barnardos, is doing some magnificent work on a public housing estate in my electorate. Yet no sooner had the first funding round been put into place, with a community development officer and really good positive outcomes being achieved, than they found that the guidelines for the next round of funding had changedâand the all too frequent cycle of applying and waiting for approval from government befell that project. I want to reinforce again the point that if you want to see good outcomes then you have to understand that you will not overcome intergenerational poverty with a funding grant of a year or, at best, three years. We need governments to work in a more holistic way with the communities, building their own self-confidence and community capacity.
There is a clear message in the findings of this important research that the Howard government should be acknowledging and heeding. The authors said:

quote.para: If for the first time in Australia's history, one's destiny might be shaped by one's location, or even one's postcodeâ

speech.para: whether that be an urban, regional or remote communityâ

quote.para: it might be time to rethink some of the rules of the game.

speech.para: I do not think the argument could be put more succinctly.

The recent Senate inquiry into poverty both heard and documented an enormous range of stories about the impact of poverty on our community. Through many submissions a number of important messages came through. Firstly, poverty is not just about disadvantage and financial hardship; it is also about exclusion and lack of opportunity and choice. Secondly and very importantly, tackling poverty requires leadership by the national government and a strategy involving all levels of government working in partnership with a range of business and community organisations. I would argue that it is not too late for the Howard government to address this problem, but it does require political will and acknowledgement of growing inequality and poverty at a time of relative economic prosperity. In the chamber we often hear both the Treasurer and the Prime Minister talking up the economic outcomes. There is no doubt that, relative to other advanced economies, Australia is faring very well, although a number of worrying signs are beginning to emerge. But we never hear the same government talk about this underlying problem, because this government is also afflicted by the `blindness of affluence'. It does not really see and does not really appreciate what it is like to be living in one of these very disadvantaged communities.

We need a national strategy initiated by the government, complete with performance targets for poverty alleviation. That call has been made widely by a number of church and welfare organisations as well. This is precisely what occurred in Ireland with their adoption of a national antipoverty strategy. The Irish government aims to combat poverty in the medium to long term and develop an explicit definition of poverty and an understanding of the causes of poverty and social exclusion. In Britain, the SureStart early intervention program is now operating in 500 disadvantaged neighbourhoods, providing a more holistic approach and response to these issues.

I urge the government to act on a national antipoverty plan if it is really serious about producing positive outcomes for our community in this term of office. In my view, such a plan would result in far more beneficial outcomes for a wider group of people than the ideologically driven industrial relations and welfare reforms that the Howard government is intent on pursuing. I believe that, in this ideologically driven quest to change the industrial relations system, the people that I have been talking about today, who are very much the victims of poverty and inequality, will be further disadvantaged by the deregulation of the existing protections that we find in our industrial relations system. We can only add to the growing numbers of working poor and those living in poverty by having an agenda that tries to dismantle the protections that have been in place for a long time to look after the needs and interests of those with little bargaining power in the work force.

Similarly, I am very concerned, on behalf of the great numbers of people on the disability support pension in my electorate, that the reforms in this area are going to force the many people finding it hard to make ends meet into even more precarious situations in the future. So while we can all take heart from some of the very good economic outcomes that we have seen over the last couple of decades, many of them put into place by the reforms undertaken by earlier Labor governments, I think it is time that the Howard government acknowledged that, despite our economic gains, there are increasing numbers of Australians living in poverty. It is a major national issue. Inequality in our society is growing, and the time has come for the government to take some national action on this issue, because it does require political will, not what we are seeing: turning of a blind eye to the poverty that exists in our communities.

talker.name: Entsch, Warren, MP
Mr ENTSCH
talker.role: Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister for Industry, Tourism and Resources

talk.start.para: âIt is a great pleasure for me to participate today in this address-in-reply debate. I am certainly proud to stand here as the federal member for Leichhardt for the fourth time and, along with my colleague the member for Deakin, as part of the fourth Howard government. The Australian public has again given this government a clear mandate: continue with our policies and keep this country very strong economically and of course safe from terrorism. I believe the Howard government won its fourth term so convincingly because of its outstanding record in keeping our nation's economy thriving, and I was glad to see the member for Throsby actually acknowledging the strength of the economy at the moment.

speech.para: Despite economic troubles around the world, Australia has managed to continue to prosper, maintaining low unemployment and record low interest rates and continuing to reduce government debt. Our country remains the best-performing nation in the OECD. Our budget surplus of $8 billion in 2003-04â$3.5 billion higher than estimated at the time of the 2004-05 budgetâagain reflects the strength of the economy. The $96 billion debt that we inherited in 1996 has now been slashed to below $26 billion. That is a huge saving that we are generating in funds that it is not necessary to pay as the interest on that debt. Our unemployment rate as of only yesterday is 5.1 per cent nationallyâthe lowest in over 30 yearsâwhich is an outstanding performance. In Cairns, in my region, the unemployment rate has dropped to 4.7 per cent. Again, this is an outstanding statistic.

This last election brought many successes to my electorate, including ongoing funding for stage 3 of the development of the Cairns esplanade. There is $10 million to continue the boardwalk towards the international airport, $11.4 million for the Daintree rainforest and wet tropics, $5 million for the Daintree Coast Conservation Initiative, $1 million for further protection of the endangered cassowary and $5.4 million from the Natural Heritage Trust to help manage the wet tropics. There was also $40 million set aside to establish a marine and tropical research centre at James Cook University, to support very important research relating to the Great Barrier Reef and the tropical rainforest. At this stage, I would like to say a special thanks to Russell Reichelt from the CRC Reef Research Centre, John McIntyre from TTNQ and Daniel Gschwind, the Chief Executive of the Queensland Tourism Industry Council, who worked very closely with me in securing this funding. This came about after the CRC for Reef Research and the CRC for Rainforest Futures were unsuccessful in their bids for ongoing funding.

There were many who were critical of government for not allowing that funding to continue, even though both bids clearly did not meet the criteria under the CRC guidelines. These three people realised that immediately and were prepared to come in and work very closely with me and, as a direct result of their endeavours, we now have a new $100 million program that is directly focused on public good CRC endeavours that have an environment focus. They are taken out of the normal CRC process. The first $40 million goes to its establishment. So to those three gentlemen I say, `Excellent work'.

We are starting to see the first of our young doctors being trained at James Cook University, through a medical facility that this government established some years ago. We are now taking the next step, with another $12 million committed to a new veterinary science facility at James Cook University to be established in Townsville and with links to the Cairns campus. It will focus on tropical agriculture. What is even more important and more significant for regional areas is that it is looking at establishing a satellite facility at Malanda, in the tablelands, for large animals and tropical agriculture. This new facility will provide a unique focus on tropical animal husbandry and diseases in tropical agriculture.

There is also $6 million over four years to provide 50 new veterinary science places in 2006, rising to 137 in 2009.
