This is going to provide some outstanding opportunities not only for young people interested in studying veterinary science in our region but also for students from the South-East Asian region who want to study. They will be able to contribute to our community and study in Far North Queensland. It is a great benefit for our region to get more and more foreign students accessing our facilities, paying full fees and bringing the additional resources for accommodation and other living costs that they distribute around our community while they are there.

There was also $6 million towards the Great Green Way project, a tourist initiative linking Townsville to Cairns. The tourism industry in Far North Queensland already employs some 12,000 people. Tourism initiatives are vitally important, with 16.4 per cent of the total Far North Queensland work force being employed in tourism. With the Great Green Way initiative, we will see these figures start to grow. The tourism industry provides some 40 per cent of our income in Far North Queensland. You can see how important that industry is to us.

On the education side, there have also been some great initiatives welcomed in my electorate, with the government boosting training in areas of skill shortages through packages designed to encourage more young people to take up trades. While Minister Nelson was in my region, he announced that the $800 tool kit for new apprentices and the living away from home allowance will be extended to third-year apprentices. These are absolutely vital for young people in my area, given that a lot of them come down from the Torres Strait, Cape York and remote areas. To get extra financial support while living away from home provides an additional incentive for apprentices to finish their training.

One of the 24 Australian technical colleges to be established will be in Townsville, which will be great and certainly something we can access. I am certainly looking forward to seeing these colleges as they are rolled out. Once these 24 colleges have been established, I will certainly be putting in a bid for a 25th, hopefully in Cairns. The government commitment to direct funds for infrastructure through the P&Cs is a great way to fund schools, to stop cost shifting in state governments, allowing for the refurbishment of classrooms, the installation of airconditioning, the upgrade of tuckshop facilities et cetera, and will give the parents of children attending these schools a much greater say, assisting them in raising funds for particular initiatives. It would have been of particular benefit to the school community in Cairns North, one of the oldest schools in Cairns, that had been run down appallingly. However, the Beattie Labor government decided to shut the school down on 10 December, to sell it off to developers for housing or some other real estate venture, rather than allow it to continue as an educational facilityâa bitter disappointment for many of the parents of children who attended that school.

When you come from a regional area you cannot make any comment in this place without raising the issue of roads. I think that the government's $12.5 billion land transport initiative through AusLink is outstanding. Leichhardt is certainly going to be a significant benefactor of that initiative. Initially none of the money allocated to Queensland was to be set aside for flood-proofing a particularly difficult area south of Cairns on the Bruce Highway at Tully. Unfortunately, the state government saw this as a low priority and suggested that it was part of an eight-year plan. We disagreed and, with some outstanding support from the Minister for Local Government, Territories and Roads, Mr Lloyd, we were able to quarantine $80-odd million from Queensland for the upgrading of that area.

When that road is flooded and the road transporters stop, it has an impact on all communities north of Tully, not only from a tourism perspective but also from a supply perspective. It is an almost annual event. We thought the $80 million might have fixed the problem, because the state government suggested that was what it would cost, but after we allocated the money we found they had done no planning whatsoever. We then had to supply another $1Â½ million to the state government and ask that they initiate a plan immediately so we could get the thing started. Rather than the three years that they were suggesting, we encouraged them to get the plan done in 12 months.

Again, I thought that would have been the end of the issue but, unfortunately, when dealing with Mr Beattie and his Labor government you have to get used to surprises. After all this had taken place we found out that he had decided not to go ahead with this because he does not want to sign up to our national building code. He has decided that the community of Tully and communities further north are secondary, in his consideration, to making sure that he does not offend the unions on issues such as right of access to the road construction site, union membership et cetera.

The situation has reached something of a stalemate now, but I am hoping that Mr Beattie will take some leadership from South Australia and, as of yesterday, from Victoria. The Victorian government have signed up to the national code. I now hope that Queensland will be the third government to sign up so that construction of this road can commence. It is vital infrastructure. The Queensland government cannot afford to start playing around and engaging in this sort of nonsense. I call on Mr Beattie to sign up and get the money flowing without any further delay.

Some $30 million has been spent on our Southern Access Road. The recent three-laning of the area between the Sheehy and Foster roads was completed just before Christmas. However, I am disturbed that the federal department of transport advises me that there have been no further submissions for ongoing work in that area. It is a stop and start situation where people are continually being inconvenienced rather than having continuity of flow in getting the job finished. I am already pursuing the Queensland Department of Main Roads and saying: `Get out there and have a look at it. Have a bit of vision. Think towards tomorrow. Don't wait until the problem is upon us and then blame the federal government for not fixing it. Get it up front so that we can get the resources to get the job finished.'

I was also very pleased to receive confirmation of funding for the Peninsula Development Road. Maintaining that as a road of national importance is vital for the Cape York community. While some $5 million has already been allocated to that road as the federal government's contribution, I would encourage the state government to consider continuing the upgrading of that highway and committing more resources to it. The Australian government, through the Roads of National Importance program, will contribute 50 per cent to all ongoing projects, so I ask them to continue to plan for the future, thinking of the needs of the Cape York residents.

The allocation of $500,000 to Russett Park residents for flood-proofing was welcomed by the community. The Mareeba Shire Council have stepped up to the plate and have put their $500,000 on the table. The only one that is not prepared to contribute is, again, the Beattie Labor government. The community are absolutely outraged, as are the council. I can assure you that, after all the work that we have put in, I am very angry that the state government is still reluctant to contribute. We have not lost a life this year. We nearly lost one last year and the year before that. I think we have lost two lives so farâthe lives of people trying to cross that road in a flood. It is vital that the state Labor government steps up and meets its commitments. I have to say that funding for the Black Spot and Roads to Recovery programs has been outstanding in my electorate. I look forward to both those programs continuing because they are of immense benefit.

The government is certainly going to pursue its longstanding policy on the full sale of Telstra. I totally support that policy. We came to government in 1996, and 90 per cent of people in my electorate now have access to mobile phone coverage, internet and a whole range of services that they could only have dreamt of. We have recently extended mobile phone coverage to places as remote as Badu Island, Sabai Island and Murray Island in the middle of the Torres Strait. Sabai is within three kilometres of mainland Papua New Guinea and they can now talk on a mobile phoneâsomething that could never have been dreamt of a few years ago. There has been a huge benefit, as there has been with the extension of television and radio right through these areas which a couple of years ago could only dream of having those services available to them.

There were a lot of initiatives in the last budget in relation to families, carers and women. There have also been huge initiatives in relation to health. There was the increase in the rebate for GP consultations from 85 to 100 per cent and a number of other initiatives. In mental health, some $50 million will be provided over four years to provide assistance to GPs in the detection of depression. There is some $30 million for better outcomes for mental health care initiatives and some $30 million for beyondblue, a national, independent not-for-profit organisation which addresses the issue of depression. I think the events of the last week or so highlight the desperate need for further mental health initiatives. This funding will certainly start to address some of these issues, but I think a lot more has to be done in this area. I hope the outcome of the inquiry into this recent event will be a catalyst for both the states and the Australian government to start to look at greater investment in what I believe is an area of absolutely desperate need: mental health and, in particular, schizophrenia. I hope that some positives start to come out of this inquiry. It has certainly highlighted the shortfall.

In July we will, of course, see the abolition of ATSIC. Given that I have in my electorate the third largest Indigenous population in Australia, I can tell you that the overwhelming majority of Indigenous people on the ground and in remote communities are watching the clock and waiting for the day. They just cannot wait for it to come. It cannot come quickly enough.

I would like to finish by having a look at some of the initiatives that were proposed by the Labor Party at the last election. The Labor Party are wondering why they lostâand lost so soundly. You only have to have a look at their policies in Cape York. They are now talking about locking up the cape. They are talking about restricting economic opportunities. They signalled that they would be cutting legal assistance for Cape York farmers, fishers and miners engaged in native title disputes and throw the whole native title system into doubt. Their environmental policies were clearly designed to win votes.

The ideologists in the latte set in Sydney and Melbourne have no consideration for the residents of Cape York. They talked about buying back land for conservation and creating new World Heritage areas, but nowhere did they commit to security of tenure for the existing residents. When will Labor learn that the residents of Cape York, the Daintree and, for that matter, other areas are an absolutely integral part of managing and protecting the environment? If you lock up these areas there will be no-one left to manage the weeds, control the feral animals and manage and protect the sensitive environment there. The Labor Party's policies in Far North Queensland were led by Senator Jan McLucas and her socialist left faction, which once held significant power in that area. However, the Labor Party's results in this election were the lowest everâand you can see why. (Time expired)

talk.start.para: âI thank the member for Deakin for having the courage to admit that he, like me and so many other members of the House, is a latte lover. Leaving the latte lovers alone and getting down to business, I would like to begin my speech in the address-in-reply debate by placing on record my gratitude to the former Speaker of the House of Representatives, the Hon. Neil Andrew, who was a wonderful Speaker. I had an opportunity to get to know him better when I was part of a delegation to Chile a couple of years ago, which he led. I wish Neil and his wife, Carolyn, a happy retirement. It is a hard-earned retirement and I know they are looking forward to it. As a new member, I found him as Speaker very helpful, inviting and encouraging.

speech.para: I would like to take this opportunity to thank the voters of the federal electorate of Calwell, who have given me the privilege and the honour to represent them in this place for a second term. It is difficult to believe that three years have passed and that I now no longer have the cover of being a new member. As I enter my second term, I presume it is expected that I have mastered the art of a lot of things, but I would like to reflect on my previous term. There are two particularly rewarding experiences that I had. The most significant one for me was the private member's motion on breast prostheses that I moved in my first year here. It highlighted the difficulties that lots of women had once they were diagnosed with breast cancer and the difficulty in acquiring adequate prostheses after a mastectomy.

That private member's motion, of course, led to my party, the Labor Party, adopting a policy for a nationally funded program for the provision of breast prostheses for women who have had mastectomies. I would like to say again that such a program would address what is still an unacceptable situation which exists with state hospital budgets that do not provide adequate and sufficient breast prostheses for women with breast cancer. That problem continues to exist and will continue to exist until such time as this government or a future government acts to establish a national, dedicated, fully funded program specifically for the provision of breast prostheses.

My other significant experience was the work that I did as the Australian delegate to the Inter-Parliamentary Union. This work and experience gave me an incredible insight into the work of parliamentarians from around the world. I can only say that the experiences and the knowledge I gained were invaluable on a personal level and certainly on a professional level.

During the 2004 election and in the months since, we have heard much talk about family values and the importance of family life. As a woman who is both a member of parliament and a mother, I want to say that I am encouraged when I hear this discussion because that means that perhaps the political culture and traditions of this place may start to better accommodate family life. I have found that change has occurred and is occurring. It is happening slowly, but I can say that, if we as parliamentarians seek in the course of our jobs to improve the lives of Australian families, I think we need to lead by example.

It is very important to our overall democratic process that, as individuals and members of parliament, we are seen to be practising the values that we want to promote to the broader community. So I look forward to the debates around family life and values, and in particular I look forward to the examination of government policies on the basis of how they impact not just on families but on community relations as a whole, because, although the traditional family is the bedrock of our society, we have to accept the fact that there exist many different family structures, all worthy of our acknowledgement, all worthy of legitimacy and certainly all worthy of our support.

No one political party has a monopoly on family values, and I certainly will not be tolerating any situation where self-appointed representatives or advocates of `family' are allowed to operate from a narrow basis and seek to impose or mandate their views on the general community. This would be a danger to our democratic society and to the cohesion of our diverse and multicultural society.

I would like to thank the people who have made my re-election possible. Firstly, I want to thank my own family, whose understanding of my working hours and long stays in Canberra is always appreciated by me, although sometimes resented by them. I am sure that we all agree that being a member of parliament and travelling to Canberra is indeed very difficult on family life and, in particular, on young children. Obviously, as MPs we make a lot of sacrifices. I do not think the general public appreciate just how many sacrifices we do make, but I could not do this job without the support of my husband and, I guess, to a certain extent his sacrifices. In addition to his role as an academic he has taken on many new roles and I think that he has come through with flying colours. So as a former teacher I give him a big gold star. He has done extremely well and I could not do this job without his support and encouragement.

I would also like to thank my electorate staff who are very important to me and to all of usâJoanne, Ismail, Brendan, Ros, Helen, Gulay and Bronwyn. I know there are a lot of them but believe me we are operating within the frameworks here. I would also like to thank those who have moved onâElliot and Jason. I thank them all for their tireless efforts during the time that they served in our office and during the election campaign. Of course, I want to thank all of the people who make up the Calwell FEA and the Calwell campaign committee. It is not possible to stand here without the support of these people. I am extremely pleased and honoured to have them working with me and I want to continue to work with them in the interests of the people of Calwell.

talk.start.para: âParticularly, the people of Greenvale!

âIndeed, particularly the people of Greenvale. Calwell is a very diverse electorate. It is a culturally diverse and multifaith electorate with mixed demographics. I know many individuals and groups well because many formed part of my old electorate but there are lots of new groups that I look forward to getting to know and to forming relationships with. Following the last federal redistribution some 61 per cent of voters in the new seat of Calwell voted in the new seat for the first time. So the challenge for me is that I have a significantly changed electorate and, as a result, the electorate that I spoke about in my inaugural speech in 2001 has now become very different.

speech.para: In the south there still remain the familiar, and I must say the much loved, urban communities of Broadmeadows, Tullamarine and Westmeadows. Many of the families in these suburbs earn their living working in either the transport industries at Tullamarine or in the manufacturing facilities of companies like Ford, Nestle or Yakka. In the east of my electorate are the communities of Greenvale, Craigieburn and Roxburgh Park. These communities have many young families and they have been typified as the mortgage belt of my electorate. The families in these communities struggle with high levels of household debt. This is a worrying phenomenon, as Australia has the highest rate of personal and domestic debt in the world. With their large mortgages those people are very vulnerable to interest rate rises. I guess to a certain extent this vulnerability led to the success of the government's interest rate scare campaign during the last federal election. These families will, however, continue to endure the anxieties and pressures that inevitably come with high mortgages. And, with the Prime Minister's refusal during question time yesterday to guarantee that interest rates will not rise, I suspect that many of these families will continue to live in a state of anxiety and difficulty as they try to negotiate family budgets.

Craigieburn is a new addition to my electorate. I have spent a lot of time in Craigieburn getting to know the people and the community. In particular, I would like to note the great work of Rita McMillin of Selwyn House. She works tirelessly to run this fantastic local community centre. Craigieburn is an old community which is now surrounded by a fast growing outer urban sprawl. With more growth predictedâI think we are expecting 15,000 new people to move into Craigieburn within the next 10 yearsâthe challenge for all of us will be to ensure that the infrastructure keeps up with community growth. In particular in Craigieburn I would like to thank the local church organisations such as the Brotherhood of St Lawrence and the Anglican Church, who form the backbone of community services, and I look forward to continue working with the church groups in assisting them with the wonderful work that they do with the community. In addition, the recently formed Craigieburn Progress Association is another great organisation and another step in community building. I want to thank Spencer and Brenda Davis for their initiative and the amount of work and commitment they have put into establishing the Craigieburn Progress Association.

Finally, in the west of my electorate lies the communities of Bulla and Sunbury. Bulla is a very small community of only 380 people, but Sunbury is a substantial new addition to the federal seat of Calwell. Sunbury has grown from being a small regional town centre to having a population of about 35,000 and growing. Sunbury is a beautiful community, a beautiful town, and its inhabitants insist that it is well known as the birthplace for the `Ashes'. It is also becoming very well known for its wineries and the production of some of the very best Australian wines. The more established wineries of Goonawarra and Craiglee and an abundance of smaller boutique wineries make this area an attractive place for those who wish to invest in one of Australia's fastest growing and most successful export industries. In fact, yesterday I had a meeting with a delegation from the European Union and they made the point that one in every second bottle of wine they open at the EUâI presume at dinners and so forthâis an Australian wine. So the success of our wine is phenomenal and we should be proud of that. I am certainly proud to have Sunbury in my electorate contributing to this phenomenal success.

I have met a lot of wonderful people in Sunbury. There are many great people who live and work there and who are active in the community. I acknowledge the fantastic work in particular of Ray Scrace and the Sunbury Men's Drop-In Centre who operate a woodworking shop for older male residents at the local community health centre. This facility gives many of the older residents a daily sense of purpose. The drop-in centre helps them tackle the ever-increasing problem of loneliness and depression which many older men face, whether it is because they have lost partners or are coping with chronic or debilitating illnesses. This is a great problem in the community of Sunbury.
Debate interrupted.

para.inline: Sitting suspended from 1.00 p.m. to 4.01 p.m.

talk.start.para: âBefore the suspension of the sitting I was speaking about issues of concern to my electorate of Calwell and, in particular, to the town of Sunbury. I was congratulating Ray Scrace and his men's drop-in centre for the work that they doâthe centre accommodates men who are looking for a place to drop in and perhaps do some woodwork or have a bit of a chatâand making the point that mental health is a serious issue, not just for the broader Australian community but for my electorate and for Sunbury. I am very pleased about the government's election promise committing $110 million to mental health awarenessâI certainly look forward to that, as I know we all do. This issue requires attention at the highest level. Mental health afflicts the young and the old, men and women alike. It is an issue I took a keen interest in in the previous parliament and I will continue to take an interest in it in this parliament. While I am addressing this issue I would like to congratulate the Schizophrenia Friendship Group, which today launched a kit for our electorate offices and our staff. It is a wonderful kit that gives our staff an opportunity to understand constituents who may present with mental health symptoms.

speech.para: While on the subject of Sunbury, I take the opportunity to thank Ted Jarrett from the Goonawarra Golf Club. Ted is an icon of the Sunbury community who works hard to support his club. His efforts are tireless. He is a man who, though at retirement age, is still dreaming big dreams for his community and, in particular, for the development and prosperity of his beloved golf club. I am honoured to accept the club's offer to be their patron. Even though I know almost nothing about golf, I look forward to the challenges that being patron will present to me.

As we enter this new term of parliament my electorate faces many of the challenges that are typical for communities in outer metropolitan areas across the nation. I will work hard, in partnership with my community and my constituents, to ensure that their concerns are brought to the attention of the parliament. The government now has the opportunity to address many of the key concerns and issues facing our nation, but its greatest challenge will be to do this by governing in the interests of all Australians. We in the opposition intend to keep a close watch on events in this place and we will do whatever is necessary on behalf of our electorates and in the national interest to ensure that the government is in fact governing for the interests of all Australians. I represent some 85,000 people, a majority of whom did not vote for the government. Nevertheless, their lives will be affected by policies that this government implements in the next three years, and I am certain that that effect will not always be beneficial or positive.

In my inaugural speech I spoke about my commitment to our multicultural community and to reconciliation with our Indigenous communities. Unfortunately, both issues have suffered serious setbacks in recent years. I would like to make the point that we have a responsibility to promote harmony and racial tolerance in a substantial way. In the life of this parliament I aim to lend my voice and support to the advancement of Indigenous issues. My electorate has large ethnic communities and a significant Indigenous population, with Calwell being on the land whose traditional owners are the Wurundjeri people of the Coolum nation. I am proud to say that the many and varied cultural groups in Calwell work well to demonstrate how strong community partnerships can advance their cause. In the case of the Indigenous community there is excellent work being done by Koori activists working with Dianella Community Health, Best Start and the Koori Education Centre in order to tackle education, health and social issues.

Earlier I mentioned family values and the concern I and others have about narrow interpretations of what constitutes a family or family values. I believe family values cannot be defined on the basis of religious principles alone; rather, family values are also impacted upon and defined by cultural and historical traditions and practices. I spoke of the contribution that multiculturalism has made to this country. Beyond language, food and culture lies a great tradition of family values that many Australians, and indeed governments and policymakers, can learn from. I think it is important that we learn from the family traditions of multicultural, multifaith Australia. I think we should learn from the values of the extended family and how collective living, and the responsibility of caring for each other beyond the nuclear family, can be of benefit to a society that it is all too focused on the individual.

At a time when relationships break down so quickly and catastrophically, and with the youth suicide rate climbing to a level that is unacceptable, I think that political parties such as Family First, and even the government, have a lot to learn from the family values of other faiths and culturesâbecause family values, as defined by many people, are not the monopoly of particular Christian denominations. These lessons could be taken from the homesâmulticultural and multifaithâof Australian families, and especially from the family values of our newer communities and our emerging Muslim community. Many lessons could be learnt from the honest and hard-working multifaith families living in Meadow Heights and Dallas in my electorate and elsewhere across the country. If we want to look at how the family can bring some sense to this chaotic and insecure world we live in, let us look a little further into our own neighbours' backyards. Let us learn from them and listen to what they have to say.

In closing I would like again to thank the people of Calwell for giving me the opportunity to serve them in this parliament for a second term. I want to thank my colleagues, my friends and my own family for their assistance and the support that they have given me. I am very proud to represent the people of Calwell and I hope that I will be able to serve them well in the next three years. I take this opportunity also to welcome the new members to this parliament. I was a new member in the last term; I know that you face many challenges. It is a great learning curve but it is a great honour to serve people in this parliamentâso welcome. For my part, I look forward to the challenges ahead for me and my electorate.

talk.start.para: âI would like to associate myself with the remarks of the member for Calwell in this address-in-reply, particularly with regard to the family values that are common to all Australians, be they black, white or any other colour, whatever their background and wherever they come from. Like me, the member for Calwell represents a seat that has a diverse community. Being someone who comes from a regional area with a very high migrant background, I can identify with her and with her compassion for the community that she serves. We would all be well served if we took note of the address that has just been given to this House and invested in our communities the way that she has.

speech.para: My second remark with regard to the last speaker's address is that I was complimented by her in her welcome to new members. This is the third time that I have been a new member to this House. Unlike the member for Calwell, I have never been able to string two consecutive periods of representation together. She said she had been re-elected to this House and thanked the people of Calwell. The Leader of the Opposition said yesterday that if he had his way he would not mind having the Prime Minister's record rather than his own. I say to the member for Calwell that I would not mind your record instead of the record I am about to present to this House.

Much has happened since members began to speak in the debate on the address-in-reply to the Governor-General's speech. Later on I would particularly like to speak about the tsunami, the bushfires and the difficulties that the Australian community and the world community have faced and those that they have faced as one. I stand here today as a marginal seat member of this parliament, the member for McMillan for the second time, after an amazing victory over a very strong opponent from the Labor Party named Christian Zahra, who ran an excellent campaign and was highly regarded by the community. I wish him all the best in his future activities, as he represented the constituency of McMillan, particularly in the time from when I was defeated until I came back into this House, with distinction, energy and, in particular, youthfulness and determination.

I am not a hater of the opposition. I am not a hater of the Labor Party. In fact, I am someone who believes that we all have a contribution to make whichever party we come from. We all have a position and we all come from different backgrounds and, whatever the issues that we have to face as parliamentarians in this place as representatives of our community, we should always hold our opposition colleagues, our ministers and the people that work in this house in the highest regard for two reasons. One is that it is a very hard road to become a federal member of parliament. There is not one person here who has arrived on an easy train. The second is that we owe it to the broader community of Australiaâwe owe it to the nationâthat we pay respect to one another so that they can then take that lead and respect one another in the broader community. In saying that, I mean that we can draw out the best from our parliamentary colleagues and the best from the people who work in this house, whatever the role that they play, whether it is the young person who is delivering newspapers to federal members' offices at half past six in the morning, the Clerk of the House or those representatives who make this house, this place of democracy, work.

After those few words I wish to indulge myself for just one moment and recognise that I did not get into the seat of McMillan on my own. I had supporting my campaign a man named Neville Goodwin, who came in with determination, desire and energy; Ken Smith MLA, the state member for the seat of Bass in Victoria; of course my family; Victorian senator Judith Troeth, who worked the electorate as a patron senator for six years of blood, sweat and tears until she came home with me victorious; and a group of young girlsâCara, Priscilla and Julie-Anneâwho called themselves the A Team because they were the back-up, the information and research people and those who supplied the energy. They were the ones that supported me daily. They got up early in the morning; they were with me. I refer to the amazing band of Liberals in the seat of McMillan who decided to never give up and to keep on going and gave me another opportunity, another chance. I refer to Russ Street, who came into the campaign very early on and followed me right through to the finish on the night. I have paid tribute to Christian Zahra. I did that because, having been in so many campaigns, I know when somebody runs a good campaign and I know when someone is good at what they do. I know what I was up against when I took on this enormous task of trying to win backâas I noteâthis redistributed seat. Former member Barry Simon lost his seat of McMillan when it was redistributed and Korumburra was taken out of it. He lost it to Barry Cunningham. I think redistributions play a greater role in what happens in seats across Australia than the brilliance of members and their activities as candidates can ever attest. I know that, in the pitching and throwing that happens in politics in Australia, a redistribution can make all the difference.

Our campaign was very low key, and I thank all the people whom I have just named. They stuck together very closely. They were a very small team, but a very important team. Having lost four federal election campaigns and won three since 1983, and having more than 20 years of political activity, even I am amazed to be back hereâ

talk.start.para: âLots of scars.

âLots of scarsâknowing I have taken three seats from Labor but having been defeated by Labor four times in the past. What we tried to do seemed impossible. I think I am only one of four members to be returned to this House three times. Can I speak out my future in that I will not let this seat be wrested from me at the next election.

speech.para: I have mentioned the redistribution, and you have to understand that this seat now takes in Leongatha and Korumburra. It goes all the way down to beautiful Wilsons Promontory, to Wonthaggi and to Inverloch. My seat goes from the snow to the sea, from Mount Baw Baw all the way through to the ocean. As every member in this House will say, it is one of the most beautiful electorates that you could ever drive through. Members, you should take any opportunity to come to beautiful Gippsland and see our beautiful green hills, even at this time of year. We have had some lovely, refreshing rain. It has not been accepted by everybody with such glee, but it certainly has in our area. It is the most magnificent part of the world, and I feel honoured, blessed and openly thrilled to be the member for McMillan.

I do feel new. Even though I have been to this House three times beforeâI tried to get here in 1984 and 1987 but did not succeedâI feel new and fresh. I am sending a message out to other people that (1) you should never give up, but you have heard that before, and (2) it does not matter what age you are; it is how you think and the opportunities that you can grab that matter. To young people who would like to have a future as a federal or a state parliamentarian, I say take the chance when it comes. Never say: `I'm too young. I'm too old. I'm too tall. I'm too short. I haven't got enough hair,' or `I don't look good enough.' Forget that. If the opportunity arises and you have a heart to serve the people, come on down because this is the place for you to be.

There were issues in our campaign that made a difference. South Gippsland is a most beautiful area. Let me take you on a quick drive and swing you out of Melbourne until you get past the suburbs and into the Strzelecki Ranges and over towards Wilsons Prom, into that beautiful and pristine area where you come over the Foster hills and the whole vista of Wilsons Prom is spread out before you, with the beautiful ocean and the crystal clear waters. If the wind turbine companies have their way, as you look down that vista you will see row after row after row of wind turbines. The people in south Gippsland have said, `No, we don't want to change.' Without mentioning names, there are former Labor and Liberal politicians, including senators, living down there and they are all of one accord. It is a pristine communityâa glorious place.

One of the members in the chamber now is from Tasmania. I visited that state because someone said it is Australia's best kept secret, and I did not know it until I went down there for a week and needed three weeks. It is so beautiful. You have to remember that south Gippsland is the closest thing there is to Tasmania. I am in the most south-easterly seat on the mainland. The rocks that are under me that have been there for thousands of years before we came along are the same rocks that are under Tasmania. It is the same string of mountains. So we are related by rocks, by beautiful hills and by pristine countryside.

People travel the world to find places just as I have described to you. It is a matter of sincere passion when I say to you that I am not going to sacrifice the beautiful coastline of Gippsland on the altar of renewable energy. In fact, I would be distraught if Iâafter all this time and after all the workâbecame the member responsible for the destruction of that area for the next 75 years by the placement of wind turbines on the coast. I know there are people on all sides of politics who are opposed to wind turbines in that area. There are plenty of places in Australia where people want turbines, but generally the community in south Gippsland has said, `We don't want them here. We don't want them on the access road to the promontory. We don't want them spread across Bald Hills. We don't want them spread across the Dollar Hills. We don't want them close to our coastline.'

If you went to any city people, say, in Victoria, and said, `Here's your pristine Brighton Beach,' or in Coogee and said, `We're just going to put up a few little wind turbines on Coogee Beach,' there would be an absolute uproar. Or the same would happen if someone wanted to put a row of wind turbines just outside Parliament House here so that we could run some power into the placeâat the moment, we cannot even build a proper fence around it, but that is another issue for another time. I am pleading with the Greens, some of whomânamed hereâthink that we should be selling wind turbines better because they are such beautiful things. Would this lady, who is a Green from somewhere, want them? You are going to say, `Not in my backyardâthis is a nimby issue.' This is not a nimby issue. It is not an issue of substanceâsuch as the Pakenham bypass, interest rates, the lowest unemployment in 10 years, but there is still more to be done in the seat of McMillan. This is a burning issue for people. The way things are going, it may take five minutes to erect these wind turbinesâthey said they can be put up very quicklyâbut they will be there for 25 years. So it could take a generation to put them up, a generation that puts up with them and a generation to pull them down.

When I started this exercise, I thought, `This is a pretty clean, green way to produce power.' I have moved completely away from that, not from becoming a candidate for that seat but from learning what wind turbines are all about. On further investigation I have found that they are not as efficient or effective and that they disrupt the power source. There is a real problem with them. I am going to be one of those membersâI am sorry, members who are gathered here todayâwho will talk and talk about wind turbines until I stop them from ruining the Gippsland coastline, until I can go back to the people there and say, `I represented you reasonably and fairly. Look, there are no wind turbines on the Gippsland coastline. It is there for your children.'

The immediate concern is the declining land values because of wind turbines being located next door. The issue is splitting communities because those who are going to benefit from wind turbines want them and those who are going to have their life and amenity depleted by wind turbines do not want them.

Without talking about noise, without talking about the amenity of the area, without talking about the visual and landscape aspects, without talking about the planning aspects, without talking about being railroaded by state governments, without talking about subsidies for wind turbines which, without the subsidies, would not even be going up, the simple message I want to send today is thisâand my staff will be furious because I have not stuck to the notes they gave me for my address to the House todayâI know that the heart of the people is to save that pristine area for future generations.

I am excited and proud to identify with the government, the opposition and the people of Australia in our response to the events of Boxing Day last year, and I know that all members of this House support every effort the government put in. I am sure that every member of this House was enamoured, amazed and taken aback by the generosity of the Australian people in their efforts on behalf of people who have had their lives destroyedâthe many hundreds of thousands who were killed. I must leave this message with you: my fear on Boxing Day night and the next day was that we were going to be faced with thousands of Australians killed. I do identify with those who have lostâand there have been manyâbut how blessed is this nation that we lost so few when we could have lost so many, and that we were in some way protected? It has just amazed me every time I have seen the footage of the families that have lost and the stories of the miraculous escapes. The Australian people and the people in my electorate have raised so much money and thrown their heart and soul at the devastation that has happened after the tsunami.

I am proud this day to be a resident of that part of Victoria which is connected to Tasmania by rock. I want to protect the pristine community. I am proud today to be a new member in this House and to participate in the address-in-reply to the Governor-General's speech. I am proud today to say that I am part of a government that has responded in this way to the needs of those who are least able to care for themselves at this most difficult time. I am also proud to say, in response to the nine deaths in another bushfire in South Australia, that we were able to respond quickly. This nation has now trained its organisations, public servants and authorities to respond quickly. The first people into Aceh were Australians at all levels. Mr Deputy Speaker, I thank you for the opportunity to bring this to the attention of the House today.

talk.start.para: âIt seems a long time ago that we gathered in the Senate to hear the Governor-General deliver his speech on the opening of parliament. It is a shame that we are stuck in the Main Committee room responding to the Governor-General's speech in this address-in-reply debate.
âIt's a good committee room.

âI know; it is nice and relaxing. It is great to be back here for the fifth time as the federal member for Franklin. It is something of a record. The Labor Party only ever won four elections in a row in Franklin, and that was way back in the 1940s when Mr Frost was the federal member for Franklin. Winning the seat in 2004 meant I was lucky enough to win five in a row, and so set the bar a little higher. I, like all other members, would like to thank all the people who worked tirelessly on the campaign. I have always advocated that, once you are re-elected, you start on the next campaign and you structure your three years as the federal member so that the people you look after are catered forâtheir every whim and demand are usually looked after as best as you can by you and your wonderful staffâand when the 33 days of madness comes along you are not swept up by all the excitement, you do not pour thousands of letters into the post office and then wonder why people are disillusioned with you. I have never intended, in the five campaigns that I have contested, to spend a dray load of money (a) because I do not have it and (b) the punters are not stupid, as I have said. With all the stuff that is stuck in letterboxes in a normal week, let alone what is put in there during the election campaign, why would they bother to read it? A grassroots campaign has always been my strategy, and it has been successful so far in five terms.

speech.para: I would like to pay my compliments to Henry Finnis, my Liberal Party opponent. Henry was a commanding officer in the Navy in Tasmania for three years and then came back here to Canberra, worked in the bureaucracy in the Navy and then was convinced to come down and try his luck against me in 2004. Henry, to his credit, ran a very creditable campaignâa very clean, policy driven campaignâbut he was unsuccessful. Over that period of 33 daysâit was actually 42 days with the extra week we hadâHenry and I got to know each other really well, and we have maintained that friendship since 9 October.

Five terms in this place is pretty good, I guess, but the frustrating thing is that I am on the other side where you cannot really do much and the bags of money are not necessarily thrown in your direction.

talk.start.para: âTasmania got a lot.

âThe funny thing is that it is always thrown at Bass, because Bass has always been a marginal seat and, for a little country town of about 60,000 or 70,000 people, more infrastructure resource money would be spent on it than any other comparable town in Australia. Unfortunately, the state Liberal and Labor parties do exactly the same. Braddon, Bass and northern Lyons are where government is decidedânot in Denison and Franklinâand that is where all the money goes. That is where all the good roads are. That is where we have a plethora of hospitals and people are looked after and pork-barrelled beyond compare.

speech.para: I have set myself a couple of things to try to sort out in my fifth term. One is the treatment of veterans. We have only three of the First World War Diggers left. What worries me is that, with so few left, we have not really learnt how to look after our veterans. In 1994 we took a whole lot of veterans back to Europe, and then I was privileged in 1995, on the 80th anniversary, to go over with a representative of each of the states and territories and Norfolk Island. That special part of our history was recognised, but the Diggers were suddenly gone. The same thing is happening with our Second World War guys. Most of them now are in their 80s. Their numbers are depleting by dozens virtually every day.

Some of our DVA officers really worry me. They seem to me to be happy to thwart and frustrate the veterans. I will give you an example. When a veteran wants to go to visit the doctor they have to go through some paperwork so that they can get a taxi refund and DVA does not think they are rorting the system. Each of us here has a Cabcharge card. We are accountable. Our Cabcharge account comes in every month, and we have to sign off to say we have done the right thing and we have not rorted the system. I know of instances where veterans in their 90s have forgotten to remind the doctor to put the date on a formâand when the form goes in it comes back. The veteran has to then go back to the doctor to fill out another form or to get the first form signed or dated. Why not give all these Second World War guys a bloody cabcharge? You can monitor it. They call the taxi, swipe their card, sign the form, go to the doctor and do the reverse on the way back. Are we just keeping the DVA people happy and shuffling paper?

I went to my local DVA office in Hobart, and said, `How many thousands of bits of paper do you send back to the veterans, who then go back to get it date stamped or signed by the doctor, most of whom are racing around like headless chooks?' and they said, `Thousands of them.' God knows how many of these forms, around Australia, are going backwards and forwards and costing more money when there is a simple solution. We are not talking about a lot of people. Give them a Cabcharge card each. It could easily be monitored by the department, and all the paperwork is gone. We are supposed to have a paperless society, for God's sake. Something as simple as that would relieve all the tension. I say to the DVA: your job there is to look after the veterans, not thwart them and frustrate them. Many of them have gone through being either a POW in Japan or a POW in Germany. And there is another issue. We have never given those guys or their families $25,000. I can tell you for sure that a lot of the trauma that they went through in Germany was just as bad as the punishment, in lots of cases, under the Japanese. We gave the 16 Korean POWs their $25,000âbut `stick it up your jumper' to the ones who were in Europe. They have some terrible stories to tell. I say to the Minister for Veterans' Affairs: have a look at some of the DVA offices and think about a Cabcharge card.

While we are talking about DVA, it is the 90th anniversary of Gallipoli this yearâa really special time. It is special to me because my dad was there as a young 18-year-old with the 7th Battalion. He managed to survive that and then go over to Franceâand on 19 July 1916 he was one of the 5,335 who got absolutely hammered at Fromelle. He came home an invalid at 19. I would like to think that some of us could go over there. As many of us who do want to go and who can pay our way could have some arrangement as Australian government representatives. I know the minister is going to go, the PM will go, Kim Beazley will probably go and the shadow defence minister will go; but I think we as a parliament ought to make a symbolic pilgrimageâas many of us as possible. We are not going to be here. Parliament is not going to be sitting. The government, through the Minister for Veterans' Affairs and the Minister for Defence, should say, `We are going to charter a couple of Qantas planes, and all those who want to go will pay their way.' We have thousands of frequent flyer points, travel entitlements and study leave. Let us organise something rather than suddenly seeing in the Sydney Morning Herald, the Age or the Australian that a little select group of people are going over there and no-one else is involved. Let us open it up to each and every one of us to go over, because there are only three of the First World War guys left. Let us make this, the 90th anniversary, very special.

Honourable members would know that we had a few hassles in Tassie: we lost a couple of seats. We lost Sid Sidebottom, the member for Braddon, and also Michelle O'Byrne, the member for Bass. We had a bit of a bunfight about the forests and some of us had some rather nasty things to say about our state Premier. You would be happy to know that we have kissed and made up. We kissed and made up over the tsunami appealâstrange times, and strange times bring people together. I would like to put on the public record that the whole forest issue in Tasmania needs to be sorted out once and for all. It is interesting to note that the Prime Minister went over and spoke to the cheering timber workers, saying, `I'm going to sort the problem out. I promise you 170,000 hectares will be locked away. You're not going to lose your jobs and everything will be fine.' He said he would send Senator Ian Macdonald or one of the other senators down to sort the mess out and it would all be done before Christmas. Christmas has come and gone and nothing has been sorted out.

talk.start.para: âSo did the tsunami and so did everything else.

âI know. The honourable member opposite says a whole lot of things, but we have had several visits from the minister responsible, the senator, and nothing has changed. I would say to the people of Tasmania: I think you have been conned. You have been shown the old sleight of hand card trick. The sad thing about the whole forest debate is that it has been going on for far too long. We have been gazing at our navels, we almost know the name of every tree in Tasmania, and Tasmanians are sick and tired of the whole issue. Let us put it aside and get on with some of the other issues that are just as important.

speech.para: One of the things that I would like to mention is the issue of Indigenous health. The Australian Medical Association came out and made statements about how terrible it all was. It almost seems like a yearly event. I was lucky enough to be on the House committee that did a report into Indigenous health called Health is life. It was an excellent report. People extolled it as the blueprint to solve Indigenous health. The government responded almost four or five years ago, but one wonders whether anybody has the backbone to really get involved with the states and territories to ensure that their various health, education and housing ministers and also the local government authorities are putting the money where it should be spent. Today we had a bit of a debate about some of the money that is thrown around at election time. Some of it seems to be highly desirable; other parts of it seem to be a waste of time, energy and effort in an attempt to purchase a seat. Indigenous health can be resolved and it can be sorted out, but someone has to grasp the nettle and say, `We are going to do it,' because if you wander around Australia you see that it is in an appalling state of affairs.

Another issue is substance abuse. We are seeing in our newspapers almost daily the effect of cannabis on the mental health of so many of our young people and also people generally across our society. Once again, the then House of Representatives Standing Committee on Family and Community Affairs put out, in August 2003, an excellent report called Roadtorecovery. I am sad to say that the government has not responded to the heaps and heaps of recommendations. Some of the states are taking this into their own hands, and I would like to compliment the Victorian government for its introduction of random drug testing. That had a few bugs to start with, but that is now accepted to be the first and the best way of trying to catch those who are partaking of such substances. To its credit, the government of Tasmania has decided to follow. But why do we still have to have this railroad gauge mentality? Why can't we have a national approach to these issues? Why can't we say that we are going to do this nationally, rather than each state coming along and saying, `We'll try it,' and then we do it? For goodness sake, Victoria led the way with random breath tests, 0.05 and seat belts and all the rest of the states were drawn kicking and screaming along to do it.

We need a national approach. We are a national parliament. If it was up to me I would get rid of all the states and have a national approach, a regional approach. Let's hear some of this stuff being expounded up here. I do not give a toss whether it is a Liberal or a Labor federal government, as long as someone gets off their whatsit and does some of these things. For God's sake, we have a national weights system. Do we have a national time system? No. If you are the Queensland Premier or the Western Australian Premier or the Tasmanian Premier you have your own time over summer. For God's sake, China has got one time zone, a national time zone: Beijing time. We have got all these issues and we are pussyfooting around. Let's do something as a national parliament to solve some of these issues. I know they might sound peripheral and airy-fairy but, for God's sake, some of them really impact on people in our community.

Another issue I would like to speak about briefly is the issue of carers. This is another group of people who are unsung, who are saving our governmentsânation, state and localâmillions and millions of dollars. Do they get any real recognition? Occasionally they do, and we have National Carers Day and we all go and pay tribute to them. But when you talk to carers you should ask them about some of the Centrelink hassles. For God's sake, we need to start resolving some of these and ironing out some of the issues for people who are carers. They are operating on a shoestring and having to fight Centrelink. The bureaucracy has gone mad, for goodness sake. Let's really recognise them by giving them what they really deserve.

Finally, in my last minute and 43 seconds, I want to talk about the issue of child care. As an ex-teacher I say to the child-care industry: `We undervalue you. We underpay you. You are in most cases providing the first foundation stone for our young people. We do not have a national registration or a national training regime. We do not pay you a decent wage.' For goodness sake, let's look at that issue. In the next three years, those opposite and we must work together with our state colleagues to ensure that we have a national framework. Community based child care and for-profit child care can work together, but they need to be paid properly and they need to have training. And we need to get away from early childhood teachers in the state system saying: `You're worthless. We're the first teachers, and you're just doing the babysitting and the mickey mouse stuff.' It is a total educative process.

As I said, it is great to be back for my fifth term. It is great to see many of my friends on the other side whom I love and admire and respect. Hopefully the 150 of us can work together in this wonderful place to ensure that once this three-year term is over we can look back and say, `We've made a difference.'

talk.start.para: âI will start my contribution to the address-in-reply debate by expressing my great honour and gratitude to the people of Gilmour for their confidence, friendship and guidance in returning me as a member. I am grateful for the opportunity and for being permitted to continue representing them in this House. I would also like to thank Martin Laverty and David Smith and all my campaign team for their trust and confidence in me. Now the work really starts. Among the first of our campaign promises was that this government would introduce institutions for excellence in trade skills. Already expressions of interest for 24 regional areas have been called for throughout Australia. The Illawarra is one of those regions, and as the Shoalhaven is part of the Illawarra I can assure residents that the Shoalhaven City Council and industry have already lodged an expression of interest.

speech.para: The Shoalhaven has many unique advantages to offer and a great opportunity to bring social and economic benefits to a region that the New South Wales Carr government is obviously leaving behind. I see two specialty areas that would be ideal in developing a synergistic component to complement our local industrial base. Those areas are the composite industryâfibreglass, carbon fibre, Kevlar and so onâand electrical engineering and avionics. Members may be aware that Nowra has a naval base, HMAS Albatross, supporting naval air operations. It was once the headquarters of the Fleet Air Arm and so has a long and illustrious tradition in supporting military avionics.

Nowra also has a vibrant boatbuilding industry which will complement trade training facilities when established. The boatbuilding industry has a strong export focus and many of the international racing yachts manufactured in this country and exported to Asia and Europe are manufactured in Nowra. The synergy between the aviation industry and the boatbuilding industry with regard to composites would provide a firm foundation for a curriculum to be offered. This curriculum would also support the automotive industry, which, in recent times, as all of us would realise, has been increasingly orientated towards composite materials both in the original equipment and in the repair automotive sectors.

The defence industry capability around Nowra has grown in recent years. Many of the international defence companies are represented in Nowra, thanks to the Howard government fostering the defence industry and to the foresight of Shoalhaven City Council to encourage those industries to be established in our electorate. For years those in the industry and business sector have been discussing with Shoalhaven City Council the problem of skills shortages and the amount of headhunting that exists. It is a well-known trend that the Australian defence department trains its people well and industry is not backward in poaching this expertise at the expense of the Australian taxpayer. I should add here that as a former business employer I am fully committed to seeing employers made responsible for the training of their employees so that all can share in the benefits.

Shoalhaven City Council is one of the first councils to put their money where their mouth is by putting on additional trainers and apprentices, and I commend it for that. Within the Shoalhaven, over 500 employers currently participate in a vocational education program with local high schools. In addressing some of the skills shortages in this aviation industry, one local registered training organisation, Aerospace Training Services, has developed a course approved by the New South Wales Board of Studies as part of the higher school certificate program. It offers this to local students in both the Shoalhaven and the Wollongong areas and is undertaken at the Australian Aviation Museum located at HMAS Albatross. This is just one example that is addressing our dire skills shortages.

Discussions have already ensued between Shoalhaven City Council and the University of Wollongong, who have a campus in West Nowra whose creation was made possible by this federal government. All are very keen about the prospect of such a facility being available in the Shoalhaven, as the present education precinct would auger well for a technical college, and commencing next year a medical schoolâagain, fully funded by the government. We have a TAFE college with in excess of 4,000 students and there is the recently announced Sealab, now known as the Shoalhaven Marine and Freshwater Centre. All are located in the university precinct. So, Mr Deputy Speaker, you can see why we would like to add a technical college to the site to work in conjunction with our high schools. A meeting has been called to gather all our expertise to present a united approach. This brings me to another promise made by me that I would investigate the possibility of training for nurses, especially in aged care and how that could interact with our medical school. I will be discussing this with the university, the Minister for Health and Ageing and the Minister for Education, Science and Training.

Where to from here? As far as the electorate of Gilmore is concerned, I can report a genuine atmosphere of confidence. Even those who may not have voted for us realise that Australia and Gilmore are doing pretty well. It really came home to me last week when some of the training network providers claimed they had difficulty in filling places for Work for the Dole as people were actually working. Today people seem to be more satisfied with their lot, and there is a distinct absence of apprehension about the future. I am heartened by the many positive statements people have expressed to me recently, suggesting they have faith in the direction in which we are going.

The Shoalhaven, Kiama and the Southern Highlands have been rediscovered. People want to live, work and play here. Yet one of the greatest obstacles to encouraging growth was the lack of job opportunities and the absence of comprehensive and modern services. This is changing with more and more commercial enterprises setting up shop, creating employment opportunities for young families.

Without a doubt, the most significant project we have going is the construction of main road 92 or the Shoalhaven Highway from Nowra to Canberra. The benefits that this link to the economic centres of south-east Australia will bring to the region are enormous. Such a link will have the effect of redistributing traffic flows of freight so that, instead of bypassing the South Coast, they will be able to add yet another economic centre to their routes. Yet after announcing $34 million worth of funding as far back as 1998, six years ago, progress remains slow. The state government continue to drag their heels seemingly with disinterest at cultivating this new economic hub. Rather, their emphasis has been on preserving the status quo, discouraging growth through inaction and hesitation six years after the deal was made.

So many opportunities have been lost. No wonder that people lose faith. What should have been done was to build the road together with the eastern gas pipeline and the Telstra fibre optic cable. Now of courseâyou guessed itâcables et cetera have to be moved at a huge cost to the taxpayer. However, being the eternal optimist, I am pleased to report that the work will be commencing in 2005. It is almost as if there is a reluctance on the part of the state governmentâbut for reasons best known to them. As if to emphasise this reluctance to open the South Coast to economic benefits, the state government continues to avoid confronting the need to upgrade the Princes Highway, despite the appalling record of road deaths over recent months.

My colleague in the state seat of South Coast, Shelley Hancock, is also conscious of the surge in demand and has called on the state government to accelerate the investigation of a third bridge crossing over the Shoalhaven River. The present crossing represents a traffic bottleneck where, if a major incident blocked the existing crossing, road traffic would have to be diverted through Goulburn. In this day and age, people have greater expectations of service and, clearly, the existing infrastructure is well overdue for a makeover.

As enthusiastic as I might be about opening road links, I know and appreciate how important it is to find the right balance. I also appreciate that it is not wise to assume that everything will remain constant and that there exists a need to hedge for the future. That is why I have been enthusiastically pursuing new innovations that will contribute towards a more diverse economic and social culture. Health is becoming more focused in importance each day as our population grows in Gilmore. More and more the community is doing the work of the state government.

A linear accelerator is required for our increasing number of patients having to travel to Wollongong for treatmentâand I use the word `travel' loosely, for you can forget about the trains; you need a car. Until you have been caught in such a situation, it is difficult to imagine the plight of my constituents who rely on this external health service. That is why I will fight tooth and nail to see an MRI licence being granted for the Shoalhaven. Once again, our people have to go to Wollongong for this, as that is the only service licensed in the Illawarra. Shoalhaven has one but it is not licensed and therefore not claimable through Medicare. I am in constant contact with the minister on this matter and anxiously await his decision. Yet again the public have rallied for an oncology unit for the Milton-Ulladulla area hospital and are still waiting for support from the state government, as they are waiting for a linear accelerator.

In 1996, when the government came into power, Gilmore's aged care services were well below the quota. All licences went to the Illawarra, Wollongong and Shellharbour with Kiama and the Shoalhaven not on the radar. I am pleased to be able to report that since then 1,600 extra beds and aged care packages have been delivered. That is not to say we do not need moreâwe certainly do. We are hopeful of further announcements to be made. Each of our aged care facilities are first class with excellent staff who really care for our elderly.

With respect to youth, where do I start? There are always the positive aspects which rarely get mentioned, such as our Defence cadets, our citizen cadets, our recent young people's first aid training course, our talented musicians, our young playwrights and artistsâand the list goes on and on. But, as ever, the media concentrates on the negatives, and we have not missed out. There is no doubt that all governments, parents and schools have a responsibility towards lowering our road carnage. This government has announced it will be supporting the notion that young drivers should be taught skills to enable them to survive the carnage of our roadways, and the Princes Highway is certainly a separate issue to be addressed.

Many of the drivers involved are in the high-risk bracket. They are predominantly male in the 17 to 25 year age group and we have a large percentage of young people in Gilmore. They are not always the victims, but this demographic looms large in many vehicle accidents. Even before the concept of compulsory driver training for that age group was raised, we had started the process to have such a facility in our electorate, both in Nowra and Ulladulla. Yet the New South Wales government withdrew funding recently for one such program, which is hardly surprising given their record. I am on the record as stating that schools have a role to play in the education of would-be drivers, starting by educating them at primary school, certainly with the rules of the road, a sense of respect for others, awareness and respect for the law and setting the right examples in behaviour.

Whilst still on the subject of young people, I raise the opposite, so to speak, and that is the role of grandparents. In recent years, I have been dismayed at the increase in grandparents taking responsibility for their children's children through sheer necessity, social problems, family break-ups or health or medical reasons. These are wonderful, caring people and they seem to have been forgotten by governments in the past. It is heartbreaking to see grandparents in their 60s and 70s having to take on the responsibility for young children and sometimes three or four in their own family. But they do it without complaint. I would like to thank our former minister, Larry Anthony, for recognising this and creating legislation that will assist these people to lead a financially improved life. I fully acknowledge that a lot more needs to be done and I will work actively towards those changes.

Without a doubt, family law, child support and child custody is the hardest area to solve in my electorate. It is heart-rending to see parents destroy each other by using their children for their own agendas. There has to be a fairer way of dealing with these issues. Allied to that, this year I have given a further commitment to try and work towards improving the delivery of mental health and depression services. As one who travels extensively throughout the electorate, I cannot but see the areas of concern.

It is far easier for me to concentrate and actively work towards infrastructure and roads, but it is also incumbent upon me to act and to understand the needs of those with that insidious disease that comes to us through no fault of our own and is so common in today's society. It never ceases to amaze me just how many people are affected by it and how people work to overcome it or, worse still, try to hide it and still lead some semblance of normal life. It is true that there are not enough professional people to deal with this growing problem. The state government does little to recognise it, and if you try to find an establishment where you can get such help there is a waiting list of weeks and months. It is a sad indictment that desperate families have begged to have their child put in jail because they feel that there they would at least get proper treatment. This is not something I am prepared live with. I will actively pursue all levels of government in lifting their role to assist. Another group we will be working for, together with pollies from both sides of the political fence, is our Parkinson's support group, by trying with determination to have them acknowledged on a federal level.

Tourism and small business are significant contributors to commerce in Gilmore, and it is no secret why so many visitors flock to Gilmore to enjoy our lifestyle. From mountains to the sea, we have it allâfrom luxury accommodation to a tent by the beach; from large shopping centres to the village general store. My background has been in tourism and hospitality for many years and, as such, I could wax lyrical about the exciting and challenging opportunities on offer to us. Yet we have not succeeded in putting together a project to gain advantage from the many federal tourism grants available. I intend to address that by working energetically towards formulating a suitable approach, together with the tourism officers from Wingecarribee Shire, Shoalhaven and Kiama, with particular emphasis on the off-peak seasons.

Finally, the completion of our fast-growing university campus at Moss Vale is in sight. It was this government that again recognised the needs of the Shoalhaven and Southern Highlands ever-growing young population and of the need to provide a decent place for tertiary education. With this continued growth has come the need to broaden our horizons and harness the ever-growing cultural, musical and artistic talents on offer. Minister Kemp is well aware of our special icon Bundanon, having visited Gilmore on numerous occasions. Time is now well overdue for a performing, multi-use cultural centre both in the Shoalhaven and Kiama. In a city of about 95,000 such a centre is of necessity to promote our wealth of talent. Council needs assistance to build the facility. The Shoalhaven has an annual growth rate of over two per cent, but council's rate is being stymied through the fact that 65 per cent of the Shoalhaven is either Crown land or National Parks and Wildlife Service reserve. The community has prepared a strong case to support an arts centre, but it needs funding to get the ball rolling. My role will be to help the community find the means to get the project up, an item high on my agenda for this term.

Last but not least I turn to the environment. There is no doubt that Gilmore is an icon in regard to its natural beauty, in beach, estuaries, lakes and rivers, mountains and dams. The Shoalhaven and Wingecarribee supply much of their water to Sydneyâa very sensitive topic, I might add. The first, a very large effluent scheme, was instituted by Shoalhaven City Council, whereby the historical effluent discharge to the ocean was minimised by piping effluent outfall to 16 large farming properties. It is proving a real blessing during drought. Kiama municipality in Gilmore is looking at options to provide the same. I intend to assist with identifying possible sources of environmental funding for this and many other necessary environmental projects. Green Corp has been highly successful, both from the point of view of ridding our land of bitou bush, repairing sand dunes and bush regeneration. It has also been very successful in assisting some 3,000 young people in our electorate to learn skills, both in environmental studies and work ethics. Almost half of these young people have gone on to gain full-time employment.

This right of reply has allowed me to document our forward plan for Gilmore, one that I will vigorously pursue. I would like to publicly thank the three local government councils in Gilmore for their cooperative support, those being the Shoalhaven City Council, Wingecarribee Shire Council and Kiama Municipal Council. It is an honour and a pleasure to work with them in getting the job done in Gilmore.

talk.start.para: âLast year, I had the pleasure of being involved in two elections, one in Australia and one in the United States. Despite all the commentary to the contrary throughout the year and indeed during both elections, neither were going to be line-ball elections. In the respective prevailing economic conditions in both countries there was simply no way Labor, the Democrats or John Kerry could win. However, it was absolutely fascinating to observe both academic and political commentary in both countries at first-hand. Most was and proved to be totally inaccurate and often inane.

speech.para: Political commentary in both countries has deteriorated yet again into a weak, pale laxative of largely synthesised nonsense bereft of proper analysis. Too many political academics and journalists appear to act out of a fear that they seem shaken by a recognition that they may have wasted their careers by not engaging in and observing the lives of people around them. That applies to some politicians too, but fewer than most people would think. More importantly, these people in the media and in academia seem to become wholly and totally intimidated at the prospect of an economic, cultural and communications revolution commencing and leaving them behind as irrelevant.

Since the end of World War II, there have been only five changes of government in 60 years. The 1949 election, which saw the re-emergence of Robert Menzies, was largely reported as an election won on petrol pricing and nationalisation of the banks. It was not. Both were factors, of course, but very minor factors. Labor lost because the economy was out of control, with interest rates rising, inflation rising and unemployment rising. The next change happened in 1972, the election which saw Gough Whitlam elected as Prime Minister of Australia. This was largely reported as a strategic masterpiece of campaigning with the `It's time' campaign. Wrong. In fact, the result was an underachievement.
