Labor won by only eight seats; it should have won by 16 to 25. There was a vast gap between the campaign and what actually happened on the ground. But again the economy was out of control with rising interest rates, rising inflation and rising unemployment.

The next change was in 1975. This election was largely reported as the Gough Whitlam dismissal election. Wrong. The economy was out of control with rising inflation, rising interest rates and rising unemployment. The next election in 1983 was largely reported as the Hawke rising star ascendancy. Wrong again. The economy was out of control, with rising interest rates, rising inflation and rising unemployment. Members opposite will remember they were all above 10 per centâthe trifecta of doom for any government. In 1996, the next change, the election was largely reported as the Keating downfall. Wrong again. The economy was out of control with rising interest ratesâthey went from 10 per cent to 10Â½ per cent. Inflation went from 1.2 per cent to 3.7 per cent, and even though the employment measurement mechanism changed everybody knew that unemployment was higher, although the figure was supposedly lower.

There are only three other elections of note. The 1961 election was fascinating. Interest rates went up, inflation went down and unemployment remained the same. Menzies, the incumbent, won by the narrowest marginâone seat. I remember it well. My father lost a week's wages to his father because, even though they both supported Labor, my grandfather was sure that Menzies would hang on by the barest margin, and he did. He has been correct every since. In 1990, interest rates rose from 15Â½ per cent to 17 per cent. Inflation, however, fell from 9.4 per cent to 8.6 per cent and unemployment fell from 7.8 per cent to 6.1 per cent. The incumbent, Hawke, won. It was never in doubt.

In 1993 we had the unlosable electionâso called by so many commentators. What a nonsense! In 1993 unemployment was 10.9 per cent, but interest rates fell from 17 per cent to 10 per cent and inflation fell from 8.6 per cent to 1.2 per cent. Keating was never in any danger whatsoever. Hewson had no hope whatsoever. And 49 of the 51 members of the political press gallery got it spectacularly wrong. Only two got it right: Amanda Buckley and Laura Tingle. They are slow learners that lot, bereft of analytic skills, but we will keep it quiet; they get angry when you remind them. As United States Democratic Party Speaker Sam Rayburn said after Franklin D. Roosevelt's landslide 1936 win:

quote.para: When you get too big a majority, you're immediately in trouble.

speech.para: From 1975 onwards, Malcolm Fraser had effective control of the Senate; he blew it. Howard will have control from 1 July this year. There are but two basic options: control the economy, stop throwing money at undeserving groups and use the revenue to build the nation's skills, infrastructure and competitiveness; or blow the economy, as Howard did under Malcolm Fraser. If Howard controls the economy, there needs to be a balance between the public and private good. That prospect looks pretty poor, given the massive increase in subsidies to private health and private education in recent years and the continuing ratcheting up of subsidies. If Howard controls the economy, his government will need to invest in infrastructure to improve efficiencies in the economy and deliberately acquit high-skill, high-pay job dividends for the expenditure.

With the exception of the Alice Springs-Darwin railwayâwhich, by the way, the government got right despite all the barking criticism of many in the eastern statesâand, obviously, increased defence expenditure, there appears little evidence that Howard will increase infrastructure expenditure, AusLink included. If Howard controls the economy, he will need to balance his responses to the capital markets and not be intimidated by them, as so many of our state governments appear to be. If Howard is to control the economy, he will need to deliberately upgrade education and training to give the Australia of the future a highly skilled and competitive labour force. He won't. He never has and he never will. In the longer term, this inattention to building the nation's infrastructure and building the nation's skills base will lead to higher inflation and higher interest rates, and it will lead inevitably to the loss of government.

Immediately after the election, Senator Nick Minchin raised the issue of voluntary voting. The sycophants of the Minister for Health and Ageing, Tony Abbott, raised the issue of abortion. Both issues were raised in the context that they would divide the Australian community. Senator Minchin wants to diminish community participation in elections; that is clear to everyone. His methodology is divisive and he knows it. So too the abortion debate. If government members seriously wanted to do something positive, the topic would not be abortion; it would have been the prevention of unwanted pregnancies, as the member for Moore apparently stated in the coalition party room yesterday. This topic includes all good people of goodwill. The topic of abortion drags every lunatic in Australia into one room. Last year, to his credit, the Prime Minister dropped both of these issuesâor so we thought. Abortion, in all its demented divisiveness, is now back, and the Prime Minister thinks it is deserving of debate.

What about voluntary voting? What about all those other divisive issues taking attention away from the main game: keeping the economy under control? Your guess is as good as mine, but just remember Democratic Party Speaker Sam Rayburn's words in 1936:

quote.para: When you get too big a majority, you're immediately in trouble.

speech.para: The elections in the United States and Australia, so similar in so many ways, lead us to ask some pertinent questions. What sort of country is Australia becoming? Is Australia becoming a country with a line between church and state that is inviolate? Is Australia becoming a country where religion trumps science? Is Australia becoming a country where leaders mobilise deep moral energies to divide us from each other and the world? Is Australia becoming a country that interferes with the rights of women to control their bodies? Is Australia becoming a country that intrudes into people's sexual preferences? Is Australia becoming a country where religious energy is used in politics to promote division and intolerance, and is that energy really on God's agenda? These are important questions.

I have always had the view, one that I note is shared by the Prime Minister and the Leader of the Opposition, that your religious viewpoint ought to be private. In fact, one of the great strengths of the Australian democracy is that that belief is a basic tenet of our nation. People seem to forget that the overwhelming majority of religions in the world are not democraticânever have been and never will be. Nor are countries democratic when religions control the nation. Those points have no impact whatsoever on the right of all Australians to believe in and practice whatever faith they choose, but people do not have the right to interfere in the political process and to push their own particular morality on the rest of the population.

Good governments should insulate the Australian community from the economic shocks of interest rates, inflation and unemployment. Good governments should build on the skills base of the nation and invest in the necessary infrastructure to ensure our competitiveness into the future. And good governments should protect and insulate the Australian community from the loopy minorities that raise their heads from time to time. The current alliance with the fundamentalist religious Right is a case in point. It will, as it always does, end in tears, unnecessary anger and division and an overinflated sense of importance, taking the community backwards and wasting precious human energies.

The government is showing signs of losing control of the economy. Inflation is creeping up already. It always does when you fail to invest in infrastructure and a proper skills base. The same applies to rising interest rates. The current account deficit is fast approaching seven per cent, not the six per cent that has been quoted in the papers over the last couple of years. Personal debt in Australia is skyrocketing. The stock market is overvalued, as is the housing market. The economy as it is currently structured in Australia is simply not sustainable, and a judgment day and a shift correction is fast approaching. It has always been thus and it will prove to be the case yet again, catching out the greedy and those in debtâthe rich and the poorâjust as did past corrections in the 1890s, the thirties, the sixties, the eighties and so on. Corrections do not discriminate in favour of the forces of good or of evil in our community, more is the pity. The most vulnerable are always the worst affected. In the next few years those who have eliminated debt will be the only people in this country who will have the chance to ride out the massive correction when it arrives.

The Prime Minister is fast heading in the same direction he did when he was Treasurer to Malcolm Fraser. Control of the Senate did not help Malcolm Fraser; he wasted every opportunity that was presented to him. It may, similarly, not help John Winston Howard. In the next few years under the Howard government, Australians can look forward to rising interest rates on massive mortgages. A rise in the rate of just one per cent on mortgages of sometimes $200,000, $300,000 or $400,000 is a huge impost on families each month. Under the Howard government Australians can look forward to rising inflationâalready happeningâand lower wages. There is government activity already pushing in that area, too.

Under the Howard government Australians can look forward to rising unemployment and underemployment. In fact, it is this issue of underemployment that will become the real problem, more so than it is today. All of us are confronted on a daily basis by the number of people who come into our offices wanting to work 30 or more hours a week but who only have 10 or 15 hours a week or a fortnight and cannot get any more. In the meantime, when corrective economic action could have been taken, we will have a divided Australia talking up the merits or demerits of abortion, voluntary voting, the religious Right, private education and private healthâin fact, any topic whatsoever that divides the Australian populous and takes us further from addressing the real problems and the challenges facing this country.

The world is changing dramatically. Hundreds of millions of peopleâat least 300 million in countries like China, India and Indonesiaâin the next five years will assume higher skills and financial status. They will demand, as is their right, more manufactured goods, infrastructure expenditure and accommodation needs, and this is going to put enormous pressure on the price of fuel and resourcesâoil in particular. The American economyâthe biggest economy in the world, 25 per cent of the world's economyâsaved so often in the past by the spending patterns of US consumers, is I believe much more fragile than most people appreciate or realise. A withdrawal of investment from the US economy by the remainder of the world would have disastrous consequences, and for Australia too. The salient point to make is what I have described as probable and likely, not the opposite.

When individuals, groups or governments put their heads in the sand and play side games, as we are seeing at the moment, they usually get their rears kicked and their heads crunched. Dealing with side issues while ignoring the main game seems to be an increasing activity of the Howard government and its frontbench and backbench. Mind you, it has company in the world, with other countries doing exactly the same in their attempt to direct attention from the real problems of the nation. Mr Mahathir in Malaysia was, of course, an expert at this, and he often directed his anger at Australia when in fact he had problems in his own country. But I love this little example in North Korea. Do you know that in North Korea they are currently conducting a campaign against long hair? Probably facial hair too. In fact, North Korean state television warned that growing hair consumed a great deal of nutrition and could starve the brain.

talk.start.para: âIs that your problem?

âThe latter commentâstarving the brainâcould equally apply to some of the actions of members of the coalition in recent months, including the member opposite. The real test, I suppose, is will it infectâ

âNo, you, Mr Slipper; it would never apply to Downer, but certainly to youâalways to you. The real test, I suppose, is: will it infect the Prime Minister and the Treasurer? Time will tell, but I think the Democrat Speaker Sam Rayburn's words will come back to haunt this government. They will have the next three years as this economy in this country unravels, and they will not have the courage to do anything about it.

speech.para: In the last two minutes perhaps I can say thank you to some people who helped me in the last election: my staff, my family, my campaign committee and my branch members. In South Australia I am very fortunate in that I have perhaps the most active branch. Unlike a lot of FECs, we meet every month. We have a good time, and we have a good group of people. In our FEC, unlike some, you can say whatever you like. You can disagree with the federal member; you can disagree with anybody. You can actually participate, and you are encouraged to participate. That loyalty that those members give me is a great honour and a great privilege. I hope in the next three years that I will make an impact for those people both in my seat of Port Adelaide and in the areas that I care deeply aboutâemployment, education, infrastructure and control of the economy.

I do not want to see Australians get hurt by a government's inaction, which happens from time to time and begins when a government goes out. The sad part that we often do not acknowledge is that, in the meantime, millions of people have been very badly hurt in the process. When governments lose, as they always do, many people are harmedânot just the politicians. It is usually the community that is harmed very badly. The new government always has the very difficult challenge of getting things back on a level again. To those people in Port Adelaide, there are some issues coming up that I hope to speak on from time to time, including the AusLink proposals. Hopefully those issues will become important, and I will be able to expound on those at a later date.

talk.start.para: âAs the member for Hughes, it is a privilege and an honour to be able to add my name to that of my colleagues and members of this House in responding to the address of His Excellency the Governor-General at the opening of the 41st Parliament of Australia. His Excellency clearly articulated for us the steady progress of the government's economic reforms, the increased resilience of our national economy and our enviable position in the world as one of the stronger performing nations. His Excellency also profiled several of the many issues that will challenge the 41st Parliament. I would like to speak to some of those challenges and add a few thoughts of my own. I want to speak about the nature of the current conflict in which we find ourselves, which we call the war against terrorism, of the continuing violence against Aboriginal women and children, and of the contradiction in public policy terms between an ageing population and the depopulation of unborn children in Australia.

speech.para: The war against terrorism is the name for the current conflict which engages the focus of our national security. For today's Australians, it is the challenge of our generation. It is fair to say that the vast majority of Australians reject ideas, political movements, events or incidents which appear to deny the most basic human rights to our fellow Australians, most especially when such ideas, political movements, events or incidents are also seen as totalitarian in nature. Totalitarianism can be explained as a regime in which the state or government controls nearly every aspect of the individual's life. According to Wikipedia, totalitarian governments do not tolerate activities by individuals or groups that are not directed at the regime's goals. Such regimes maintain themselves in power through any or all of the following: secret police, propaganda disseminated through the media, active exclusion of any open criticism of the regime and the use of violence and terror tactics. Internal and external threats are created to foster unity of the population through fear.

The term has been used to describe nationalist, imperialist, fascist or communist regimes. However, a common element is that such a regime is in direct conflict with the `free world' as we understand it. Such governments, regimes or movements that can be labelled totalitarian are marked by extreme brutality to its opponents. The ruling ideology demands that every aspect of an individual's life is subordinate to that of the regime; and this includes education, occupation, income, recreation and religion, even including family life and relationships.

Further, it is not a Left or Right issue. Stalin from the Left and Hitler from the Right were bitter enemies, but both ran totalitarian-like regimes. Their place on the political spectrum mattered not one whit to their citizenry, who existed in a state of terror and fear. Nor, it seems, is such a regime an aberration of Western civilisation. For example, Stalin, Mussolini, Hitler and Franco were later joined by Mao Zedong, Idi Amin, Pol Pot and Saddam Hussein, to name a few from Eastern traditions. Like today's Islamic radicals, and their soul brothers the Islamic terrorists, they all believed in the total state, the total doctrine and the total adherence of their populations to the movement.

These are some of the points that Paul Berman makes in his book published last year entitled Terror and Liberalism. He suggests that the philosophical foundations of today's Islamic suicide bomber have been drawn from the same pathological Western ideas that led to Stalin and Hitler. Berman points out that the only way in which Islamic terrorists differ from the totalitarianism of Western civilization is that the Islamic terrorists have been passed through an Islamic prismâa radical militant Islamic prismâand consequently the current war of terror against the West and its values is being waged through an extreme, religious Islamic world view.

The irony is that the philosophical roots of today's Islamic terrorist can be traced back to the anarchy of Lenin's totalitarianism that had developed into indiscriminate violence and mass terror. The terrorists imported these feral Western views, acquired in Western Europe, back to the Middle East and incorporated them into a new form of militant Islam that Berman terms Islamism. The policy implication in all this is that as a community we need to understand the nature of what we are fighting against when we speak of the war against terrorism. Our Australian Muslim and non-Muslim communities need to see that we are not simply fighting terrorism as some kind of opaque, confusing political movement.
The former US Secretary of the Navy and current member of the Kean Commission investigating the September 11 bombings, John Lehman, in his address to the US Naval Institute on 31 March 2003, said:

quote.para: We are currently in a war, but it is not a war on terrorism. In fact, that has been a great confusion, and the sooner we drop that term, the better. This would be like President Franklin Roosevelt saying in World War II âwe are engaged in a war against kamikazes and blitzkriegâ. Like them, terrorism is a method, a tool, a weapon that has been used against us.

speech.para: He goes on to speak of `the emergence of a trans-national enemy driven by religious fervour and fanaticism' for which the US government was simply not prepared. He says:

quote.para: Our enemy is not terrorism. Our enemy is violent, Islamic fundamentalism. None of our government institutions was set up with receptors, or even vocabulary, to deal with this. So we left ourselves completely vulnerable to a concerted attack.

speech.para: Because Australia is a liberal democracy, with a considerable emphasis on individual freedoms and personal liberty, we will always be an anathema to such a religious fundamentalist movement that is totalitarian in nature. We are a living example of what it considers to be so terribly wrong. Only when we understand the totalitarian character of this radical religious phenomenon can we take appropriate steps to counter and repel its intolerance and aggression. We have to call it what it is; we have to understand its nature to allow us to develop an appropriate defence.

To secure our future in this increasingly uncertain world, we must no longer be tolerant of the intolerant. Clearly articulating the nature of the challenge encourages policies to implement appropriate government strategies and, far more importantly, to garner wider community understanding and support. As Australians, both Muslim and non-Muslim, we are against all those who would seek to derail, especially violently derail, our democratic institutions, our Australian values of a fair go for all, our religious and political freedoms and our tolerant, easy-going way of life.

In some ways, many Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander women live in fear of abuse in a kind of de facto totalitarian state that is marked by violence and isolation in remote communities in the very heartland of this democratic nation of ours. In June 2000, I spoke in this House about a war zone in Australia today. I was speaking in response to the report of the Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Women's Taskforce on Violence, chaired by Professor Bonnie Robertson from Queensland.

In the light of that report, I said that in some Indigenous communities violence and sexual abuse against women and children had reached a crisis point. While the source of this violence could be traced to the impact of history, with the consequences of dispossession, marginalisation, unemployment, alcoholism and poor education, it mattered little to the innocent women and children who were being bashed, raped, mutilated and murdered on an appallingly large scale. The Robertson report showed that many women, children and the elderly led a life that was a continuum of frequent mayhem and violence and that the women and children in particular were being deliberately ignored by those who had a duty to protect them.

In his address to this parliament, the Governor-General referred to the need to address family violence in Indigenous communities. I know that the government has made a determined effort to remedy the appalling state of affairs to which Professor Robertson drew attention. For example, the Family Violence Prevention Legal Services program will come on stream from March this year, with a total of 26 units operating Australiawide within the next four years. A further $22.7 million over four years has been committed by our government, and the units will be located predominately in rural and remote areas of high need.

However, despite this and other measures that have been implemented, it appears that the situation of women in rural and remote Indigenous communities has even worsened since the year 2000. According to Professor Robertson, as reported in the Weekend Australian newspaper in January this year, the problem is increasing. Professor Robertson says that we need to be addressing the causes rather than the consequences of family violence and identifies a growing sense of frustration all around. Others suggest that we should immediately address the consequences. Ideally, it should be both. But, when we come to a serious accident, first aid should be applied while we wait for the ambulance. So too with this problem. We should be tackling the immediate consequences while calling for the resources to deal with the causes.

I would like to see federal and state governments, the law enforcement agencies and particularly the courts emulate the British government's actions of enforcing the law against the sexual abuse of women and children on Pitcairn Island. The Pitcairn Island abuse occurred some years ago. If only Australian women in Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander communities could get the justice that the women of Pitcairn have at last received. The key to doing this is the protection of women and children from reprisals if they do come forward to seek the justice that is due to them.

As a first step in providing such protection, there is a great need to provide more safe houses in isolated and remote communities, where women and children can find sanctuary from imminent danger. There also needs to be in place a dedicated transport arrangement to enable them to escape the immediate danger in their community and find longer term safety elsewhere. If non-Indigenous women have a need for and ready access to these facilities, then so too should Indigenous women in remote communities. Indigenous women have to have good cause to feel safe enough to come forward and to seek help and support. If this does not happenâand if the last five years are anything to go byâthen in another five years time we will still be pouring tens of millions of dollars into a problem that remains a national shame.

One of the longstanding problems of Indigenous affairs is that the majority of rural, Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander women have been marginalisedânot only in the governing of their own communities but also in exercising influence over the policies of successive governments. I believe there has been a watershed change to this problem, with the government's decision last year to close ATSIC and all that it represented; with the establishment of the National Indigenous Council, headed by magistrate Sue Gordon; and with the appointment of members to the NIC who, so far, appear to have a positive inclination to seeking solutions. It is long overdue and a welcome step in the right directionâtowards destroying a total denial of their basic human right to live without fear and violence. This is a kind of cultural totalitarian way of life, if you like, wrought by circumstances of social breakdown, cultural dilution and marginalisation that is marked by rural isolation: a lack of individual rights and a powerlessness that has fed on our past indifference.

Australia is a wealthy country, a land of great opportunity andâfor most of usâa land of great personal freedoms and expression. It is time that these Australian women shared in our freedom and prosperity. We must empower them by seeking their direction on their needs and ensuring that their requests are delivered. I look forward to the full implementation of the new legislation and to some positive outcomes from the new council that will impact in a meaningful way on the tragic lives of these Australian women and children.

I now refer to recent interest in and call for a debate on abortion, raised by those who are uncomfortable with the high number of abortions and the reports of women suffering from post abortion trauma, and who have recognised that some scientific and technological developments over the last decade are raising legitimate questions about abortion that previously did not exist.

The issue of the high number of abortions each yearâwhatever that high number isâis also relevant to our future population profile, which in turn has implications for our future prosperity. Australia has a birth rate of 1.7 per woman, which is below the population replacement level of 2.1 births per woman. Australia's welfare system was developed when the proportion of our over 65 years of age population was much lower than it is today. This is of serious concern to those who would ensure our economic sustainability and our future prosperity.

To this end, long-term government policy has spent millions of dollars on our immigration program and more recent policy has aimed at providing a $3,000 contribution to assist new mothers with their babies. Excluding medical terminations, if most of the 70,000 or more abortions of choice in Australia each year were not performed, this would have a significant and beneficial impact on the demographic and economic outlook for Australia. On the one hand there is hand wringing about our critically low birth rate while on the other hand there is the government subsidy of abortion of choice. This represents a conflict in public policy, to say the least.

Abortion is not an academic issue for me. As a young mother with three children under three, I was presented with serious medical reasons for not continuing with a fourth, unexpected pregnancy. I know the darkness of that deep emotional abyss. I exercised my free-will choice, but I continued with the pregnancy. I support the free-will choice of all women to make their own decision between an abortion and a baby. It is not for men or governments to take that free-will choice away.

Australia is a free, liberal democracy. We have a birthright to make our own decisions on such personal matters because we each have to live with the consequences of those decisions. Butâwith the exception of medical terminations, and stepping aside from the deep emotional aspects of this subjectâwe can clinically observe in abortions of choice, at the very least, a lifestyle choice and, at the very worst, the most brutal form of contraception.

When one appreciates that contraceptives are readily accessible and relatively inexpensive todayâand if the figures of between 70,000 and 95,000 abortions annually in Australia are anywhere near correctâand allows for a percentage of preventative measures that may fail, that still leaves a lot of women and men who are not taking responsibility for their sexual activity. So one could well ask: why should the Australian taxpayer? In this scenario, such abortions of choice are a service of choice and should, appropriately, be self-funded by the user.

From my inquiries it appears that abortion clinics charge around $500 for an abortion. The mother contributes around $180 and presents her Medicare card. The balance of $27.2 millionâthat figure, of course, is annualisedâis paid for by the Australian taxpayer. However, any reform of Medicare funding for an abortion should at least require that independent, factual information and alternatives are provided to the woman when taxpayer dollars are spent. In this way the taxpayer can be assured that such funding is truly being spent on a woman's health needs and on giving her an informed choice of all her options.

I make this point because I have a group of women in my electorate who are in a desperate situation, not of their choice or making, and they are struggling. They are struggling to bring up special needs children or support special needs young adults, and the resources from governments have been drying up progressively over many years. Many of these women are struggling alone because the fathers could not cope and walked away and left them with the job. Many do not get sufficient respite. Many have surrendered career opportunities. Many are lonely. Many live below the poverty line. Such is the life of a carer today. All of these women are acutely aware of a great unmet need for services, for education, for occupational training, for accommodation, for respite, for educational services for their family membersâand I could go on. When they gather the strength to approach governments they are always told there is no funding available for them. Yet we do have funding for those who freely choose to avail themselves of an abortion when many of them could also freely choose to take other preventative measures.

As I said before, I leave the choice about an abortion to the free will of the pregnant woman. But her free-will choice should be an informed free-will choice and should be based upon up-to-date information. She should also have the widest possible range of alternatives for her consideration when she makes that choice. Medical science knows so much more today about the development of the foetus than it did 10 years ago. A foetus can no longer be dismissed as a disposable piece of human tissue. Modern technology is increasingly informing the layperson that the human foetus has its own genetic identity and its own cerebral activity. It has an independent heartbeat, an independent circulatory system. A human foetus can grab and hold on to the finger of an operating surgeon. Another development is that medical science is helping premature babies to survive at an earlier stage.

I do support the efforts of Senators Boswell and Santoro to seek comprehensive data and up-to-date information on the number of abortions and on any negative psychological or other detrimental health outcomes that have been experienced by women after an abortion, so that governments can offer appropriate support services. It is of some concern to learn of an increase in post-abortion depression amongst women who have been traumatised by the experience of an abortion. Anecdotal evidence from consulting psychologists indicates that some women are not getting the appropriate counselling before they undergo such an operation. It is clear that greater and credible research to this special area of woman's health is imperative. Such research and data is not only necessary to inform governments in the provision of appropriate support services but also to inform and empower a woman in making her own choice.

The issues I have raised today are very current issues which are of concern to most Australians. They touch on our national security, our responsibility to our Indigenous sisters and their children, the quirkiness of our population policy and the special plight of those exceptional Australians who care for family members with special needs. As the Governor-General said:

quote.para: ... Australia stands on the threshold of a new era of national achievement. With renewed energy and purpose, the government rededicates itself to the great ideals of the Australian nation and to the service of the Australian people.

speech.para: His Excellency concluded his address by saying that our nation is a leading example of democratic freedom, institutional stability and economic wellbeing. For those of us here, it is our job to keep it that way and to use our best endeavours to ensure that such values are shared equally with all the people of Australia.

talk.start.para: âFirstly, I want to welcome you, Mr Deputy Speaker McMullan, on your accession to the Speaker's panel. I trust that you will perform in that capacity in the same illustrious way you have in every other capacity in this parliament.
âWhy don't you bring him back into a frontbench position? He is one of the best you have got.

âI have never demurred about that. And the member for Fraser well knows that it was my view on the Friday when he was given the nod by the previous leader of the opposition as shadow Treasurer that I thought it was great that a level of professionalism would be brought back to that position. However, that was not to be. That is past history, but the future may hold other things for both of us.

speech.para: Today I will speak in a somewhat unusual way. Normally I speak off-the-cuff but today, in my speech in the address-in-reply debate, I am going to refer to notes. I hope to mount an argument which will give the lie not only to what the Prime Minister has been putting about in question timeâin particular, yesterday's question timeâbut also to what he has been putting about after the election, in the address-in-reply debate and in the election campaign. The fundamental context of my speech is the fact that the government won the election. It did so, in good part, because of the arguments it put in regard to interest rates. The government felt it had a convincing caseâand certainly many people in the community thought soâcompared to Labor's.

Even since being elected to the Speaker's panel, I have often interjected in question time during the Prime Minister's arguments that this coalition government's performanceâand the performance of all coalition governmentsâin relation to the economic indicators for inflation, unemployment and interest rates has always been better than Labor's. I am here to give the lie to that today. As you would well know, Mr Deputy Speaker McMullan, from your past experience in the Hawke-Keating government, that is simply not true; it is incorrect to argue that. The Prime Minister does it, though, day after day. Of course, he has form on a number of matters, but he also has the signal distinction of being the only Treasurer in the more than 100-year history of the Commonwealth Parliament of Australia who has achieved the trifecta of double-digit unemployment, a double-digit interest rate and a double-digit inflation rate. Noone else has had those three indicators go so badly. Other people have had recessions. There was the 198283 recession, responsibility for which we lay at the very door of the then Treasurer, John Howard, the member for Bennelong. He is the person who was responsible for running Australia's economy at that time.

Everyone here should remember and have imprinted on their memory the depth and extent of that recession and the amount of time we took to dig ourselves out of that during the Hawke-Keating period. But they should also have imprinted on their memory the three figures pegged up on boards around Australia in January 1983. Unemployment was at 10.1 per cent. Who was the Treasurer? John Howard, the member for Bennelong. Inflation was at 11 per cent. Who was the Treasurer? The member for Bennelong. And then there is the housing loan interest rateâa key issue not only in the last election but also yesterday in question time when the Prime Minister again averred that the coalition has always been better than the Labor Party on interest rates and would always have lower interest rates. He also argued in the propaganda campaign put out during the election campaign that, over a period of 30 years, interest rates have always risen to more than 10 per cent under Labor. In January 1983 the coalition was in power and had been in power since December 1975. Malcolm Fraser was Prime Minister and John Howard, the member for Bennelong, was Treasurer; he had taken over from the late Phillip Lynch. The interest rate was 13.5 per cent. Under the coalition, the average for that year was 13.1 per cent.

The Prime Minister argued only yesterday that Labor had always had higher interest rates. What is the comparator? In the Parliamentary Library, which is at least non-partisan in regard to this, there is a very interesting comparison. Let us remember that interest rates under the Hawke government went to 17 per cent at their highest point. Under the Keating government, they went to 12 per cent at their highest point. John Howard, as Treasurer, achieved 13.5 per cent. But what did they achieve over the life of the governmentâ

talk.start.para: âIt is a simple comparison. The Whitlam government, parodied by this Prime Minister and hacked to pieces by ministers from this government, averaged a housing interest rate of 9.16 per cent. Over its two terms, the three years it was in powerâharried from one end of the Commonwealth to the other by a coalition baying for its blood and doing everything they could to try to stop it from governingâthat government achieved an average interest rate of 9.16 per cent.

speech.para: What was the interest rate under the Fraser government in toto? It was 10.66 per cent. Is it true, as the Prime Minister averred yesterday, that under Labor interest rates are always higher than they are under a coalition government? The answer is no, that is not the case. What was it, though, if you take just John Howard's period as Treasurer? It was a failed, miserable record in so many regards. What was the interest rate? It was 10.94 per cent. That is just under 11 per cent as an average across his total period as Treasurer.

We will be honest enough to put the comparatives in over the period of the Hawke-Keating government and say that over the life of the government the interest rate was 12.84 per cent. I can readily and strongly argue that there is a conditioning situation and a larger context there. We, coming into government, came in at the end of a period where the economy had been poleaxed by Treasurer John Howard and where the country had been driven into deep recession. In part, this was because of the madness of Prime Minister Fraser, who thought there was going to be a massive resources boom and talked it up through 1980 and 1981. Instead, we had a massive increase in unemployment and fundamental structural problems in the economy that had not been addressed for a number of years and we ended up with an average rate of 12.84 per cent over the life of the government.

But we were also shackled by something else that is extremely noteworthy. If you look at the current account deficit for the period of January-February it is 4.7 per cent of GDP. That is a significant weight on the government's operations. If you look at John Howard's history, in February 1983 there was 10.7 per cent unemployment, up 0.6 of one per cent; there was 11 per cent inflation; and housing interest rates were at 12Â½ per cent. That was a trifecta of the very worst economic indicators you could have, with a current account deficit of 4.7 per cent of GDP.

There was something else that we need to remark on and to underline that conditioned how the Hawke-Keating government, particularly in its early years, dealt with the economy and the problems of trying to restructure it. The member for Fraser well remembers, as do I, that in the week before the 1983 election Treasurer John Howard was asked publicly what the deficit figure would be for the Commonwealth budget at that time. I think it was the Tuesday before the election when he was first asked that. He demurred significantly, but eventually coughed up a figure of $4.6 billion as the deficit in prospect on the advice that he had been given. On the Friday before the electionâone single day before the March 1983 election which brought Bob Hawke and the Labor Party to powerâTreasurer John Howard, the member for Bennelong, was forced to concede that the $4.6 billion figure he had uttered was not correct. He corrected the record and he said it was closer to $6 billion. Mr Deputy Speaker McMullan, you know and I know that when he uttered the $4.6 billion figure and the $6 billion figure he did not tell the truth, because the reality was that the advice that he got from Treasury was that the deficit looming for the federal budget was $9.6 billion in March 1983 figures. That is a significant amount of weight, you would think, to take onâthat budget deficit for one single year. Given all those other economic indicators which were so bad and which no Treasurer before had ever racked upâthree double-digit figuresâthe impact of that deficit on the economy and on the management of the economy was significant.

What is that $9.6 billion in today's dollars? That $9.6 billion figure has been thrown around in past elections. Something close to that was said just a couple of elections ago by Treasurer Costello. If we actually look at the impact of what that would be in today's dollars, that $9.6 billion would in fact be $35 billion. That would be $35,000 million added to the deficit that the Commonwealth faced in just one simple year. So when the Hawke-Keating government came into power in March 1983 and opened the books, what did they find? What the member for Bennelong said on Tuesdayâa $4.6 billion deficitâwas false. What he said on Fridayâ`It was not $4.6 billion; it was closer to $6 billion'âwas knowingly false. That $9.6 billion in those dollars is equivalent to $35 billion now.

Getting up and over that economic hurdle, attempting to restructure an economy that was effectively a basket case, having to deal just three short years later with the cumulative effect and then the one-off effect of a situation where Australia faced a decline in its terms of trade over a 30-year period of one half of a per cent to one per cent per year to, within the period of one month, having a 25 per cent fall in Australia's terms of tradeâthese were significant and, indeed, unexampled problems facing any treasurer and any government. But manfully and properly, Treasurer Keating, Prime Minister Hawke and the Labor ministry that the member for Fraser was a part of stuck to the job, saw it through and refashioned, under the impetus of what happened in 1986, the economy.

So dramatically did they refashion Australia's economic infrastructure, substructure and indeed superstructureâto borrow a series of phrases from someone who is buried in Highgate cemetery in Londonâand so significantly did they change the way in which things are done here that the breaking of the back of inflation in 1990-91, and the low inflationary period that has been in evidence since then, is the key reason why the figures for the affordability of housing or affordability of interest rates for the Howard prime ministership and the Howard government from March 1996 are comparatively good. Certainly they are comparatively good compared to those of Treasurer Howard, a disaster in so many respects and a fundamental failure.

The member for Bennelong could build on the back of the structural work done by the Hawke-Keating government. He could not build on the back of his own work when he was Treasurer to Prime Minister Fraser. So in this situation we have got a very simple comparison. Even the Whitlam governmentâso badly spoken of by members of this governmentâhad a better record on housing interest rates than the member for Bennelong did as the Treasurer in the Fraser government. Indeed, if you look at the current Howard government from 1996 until now, there is the Whitlam government standing at 9.16 per cent and what is the average for interest rates under a Howard government operating in a completely changed economic environment building on the back of what had been achieved in our 13 years of government? It is 7.2 per centâstill relatively high and not all that far from the rest. But the key point is it has only been able to be achieved because the back of inflation was broken and a low interest rate regime and a low growth-low inflation rate regime was introduced into Australia, and we simply had not had those conditions for decades, since the early 1950s. So you can do a great deal if you simply ride on the back of that.

But there is a lot that is not just riding on the back of that. When we are dealing with comparators where you cannot trust what this Prime Minister will say in comparing his government's achievements with what he regards as deficits from former Labor governmentsâand I think I have just given the lie to what he said in the parliament yesterday and what he argued during the election campaignâif you look at some other indicators you could argue that having a look at interest rates over the life of a parliament is not really the best way to do it because you might not take into account a whole series of factors: when people came to government, what the business cycles were, what the general economic cycles were and what the major movements were worldwide.

If, however, instead of looking at pure interest rates you looked at home loan affordability as another measure and did a comparison in that regard, you would find something quite different, and that has been done. The Real Estate Institute of Australia and AMP Banking did that and they came up with an average home loan affordability ratio under Hawke and Keating of 39.6. With this figure the higher the number, the better you are doing. You would imagine, given the coalition's argument, that they would have an extremely high number and that they would have well outperformed the Hawke and Keating governments in terms of home loan affordabilityâparticularly with a 7.2 per cent interest rate regime over the life of the government. The reality is that their number is 39.4. They have underperformed the Hawke-Keating governments throughout the whole cycle of the government in terms of home loan affordability.

When the Prime Minister says, `Interest rates under Hawke went up to 17 per cent,' under the member for Bennelong they went up to 13.5 per cent in January 1983. Take into account that in 1989, when those interest rates were running at 17 per cent, the average home loan was $66,700. Also take into account that just less than one year later the Hawke government was reelected for a fourth time, despite the fact that interest rates were so high, because actual home loan affordability was there. What people did not readily appreciateâ

talk.start.para: âI know you do not understand this and that it is really beyond you. You would not have understood the other fundamental point: that whatever the level of interest rates isâ13.5 per cent in January 1983 under Treasurer Howard or 17 per cent in 1989âthere is also another indicator you take into account and that is the level of inflation at that particular time. You end up doing a subtraction with a real interest rate, and the fundamental is the real interest rate that people are facing. We do that all the time. The Reserve Bank does it when it looks at home and housing affordability here and when it looks also at what the interest rate regime is here and what the settings for that should be and what the comparators are when you look at the key economy to drive this, the United States. We have always been in a position, in having to get money in from overseas, that we have set our interest rates higher than they have been in the United States because of the need to attract people and to have a higher set of interest rates to do so. In 1996, when Labor left office and housing interest rates were at 10Â½ per cent, the average housing loan was $99,100 and the repayments were $883 a month. In 2004, the average housing loan is $213,600. That is an average repayment of $1,523 at the current housing interest rate of 7.1 per cent.

speech.para: I said at the start that I would actually read this speech. I have not; I have spoken off-the-cuff again, so I suppose I have broken that promise. But the core point here is that in this speech I have given the lie to the Prime Minister's argument that housing interest rates are always better under the coalition than under Labor. It is actually the reverse, and even the Whitlam government beat him.

talk.start.para: âThis debate is a great opportunity to reflect on the achievements of the Howard government and to discuss our comprehensive agenda for our fourth term. Serving in this place has always been a great honour, but serving as part of the Howard government has been an absolute privilege. I was very fortunate to be part of the first wave, so to speak, having been elected by the people of Forde in 1996. The world and our nation have certainly faced many challenges since then. When I delivered my maiden speech in this place in April 1996 we were a nation suffering the aftershocks of the dreadful Port Arthur massacre. At that time the Prime Minister acted swiftly to introduce national gun control laws to help make our community a safer place.

speech.para: As the last parliament gathered, the world was still coming to terms with the events of September 11 and the implications for all free nations. Once again the Prime Minister acted decisively to ensure that we have a leading role in the worldwide effort to defend against and defeat terrorism. We have remained steadfast in our resolve to help create a safer, more stable future for Australians and the world. Our resolve was further strengthened by the tragic terrorist bombings in Bali in October 2002, in which so many of our fellow countrymen lost their lives. Our involvement in overthrowing Saddam Hussein has delivered democracy to the people of Iraq, and it continues to be an integral part of the war on terror. Once again our government have never wavered. While others were advocating a withdrawal, we were determined to stay there the full course. The tremendous turnout and the obvious excitement at the recent Iraq elections have vindicated our belief that freedom is worth fighting for.

Now, tragically, as this parliament is just beginning, our nation and the world are facing yet another challengeâthe most devastating natural disaster in our history. The tsunami which devastated entire coastal areas of Indonesia, Sri Lanka, India and parts of Africa and many, many islands in between has left an indelible mark on the world. The human cost in terms of lives lost is just staggering. The enormous task of rebuilding shattered communities seems almost insurmountable. Again, as the world came together to meet this challenge, Australia has been at the forefront by leading relief efforts and setting new benchmarks with our financial commitment. Once again our government, under the strong leadership of the Prime Minister, have acted decisively in the face of a very difficult challenge.

It is this sort of leadership that has won the respect and trust of the Australian people. As I did after the 2001 elections, I want to thank the Prime Minister for the great judgment and character he has shown over the past nine years. The Prime Minister has withstood enormous pressure and, at times, ridicule. He has always held strongly to what he believes in, and his desires to do what is in the national interest have always been evident in everything that he says. Anyone knows him behind the scenes, as the people on this side of the House in government do, would see that he is a genuine man who has it in his heart to make sure that he does the right thing by Australia. It is that tenacity and the fact that he remains true to his beliefs that has endeared him to Australians from all walks of life and has even won him begrudging respect from the left-wing media who irrationally dislike him.

I have been delighted to host many visits from the Prime Minister in my electorate over my time in parliament, and the feedback has always been hugely positive. I can say with certainty that they like him in the electorate of Forde. On behalf of the people of Forde, I thank the Prime Minister for his leadership of our nation, and I certainly look forward to welcoming him back to our local area in the course of this parliament. Today I also take this opportunity to reaffirm my commitment to the people of the Forde electorate. Having lived in our local area for 28 years and having worked closely with our community both before and after entering parliament, I have a deep commitment to our special place in south-east Queensland. My husband, David, and I have raised our eight children in Forde. They are now a very important part of our local communityâmembers of schools, P&Cs and sporting clubsâand our grandchildren are now growing up there and attending local schools. I remain motivated by my desire to seek a better deal for our region, to help local communities and small businesses reach their full potential and to ensure local residents have the best quality of life. That is the bottom line and the reason that I do this job.

While much has been achieved, there is still a lot more that I have to do. Unfortunately the state government have neglected many services within my region. They have understaffed the Logan Hospital. They have cut services at the Beaudesert Hospital. They have failed to match our funding increases for local state schools. They have failed to put in place truth in sentencing to deal with crime. They have failed to protect our children at risk. They have also failed to do anything about securing our future water supplies in Queensland. In contrast, our government have stepped up to the plate. We have established an after-hours clinic to reduce pressure on our emergency department at the Logan Hospital, which is a public hospital. We have increased funding for local state government schools. We have spent $30.2 million over the past three years in Forde just to improve facilities. We have introduced the Community Crime Prevention Program to give local communities the opportunity to work with police and to help reduce crime, and it is working. We have established the $2.1 billion Australian Water Fund to really tackle water supply and its usage issues.

The thing is that Labor have always spent a lot of time talking about health, education and the environment, but those words are never backed up by what they do in office at either the state or the federal level. That is the real difference between a government of action and an opposition just of words. We are hands-on and we remain accessible to the Australian people, while Labor squabble amongst themselves. Over the past nine years, many ministers have come to my electorate to talk with our local residents and to listen to their concerns and their ideas. It has been a hallmark of this government that we have never taken our position for granted. We have made a conscious decision to remain in touch and to take a hands-on approach rather than leave the decision making to public servants. We have not forgotten the lessons of Labor's 13 years in officeâhow out of touch they became with the Australian people and how they lost sight of the hopes and the aspirations of the battlers they had previously claimed to represent.

In contrast, the Howard government have kept faith with the mainstream Australians that we represent. I believe that the large class of `96 and their members have led the way to this approach. Collectively, we believe in getting out there, being part of the community and listening to and working with our local residents with a real community based approach to politics that Labor has either forgotten or abandoned. I am delighted that our approach has been backed up over the past three years by the class of 2001. Now we have this great class that have just entered. They are brimming with new ideas, enthusiasm and energy, and I am quite sure they are here for the long haul. I take this opportunity to congratulate and welcome our new members and wish each of them well. It certainly augurs well for our government that our members continue to come from a diverse range of real-world backgrounds: police, business, community service and, of course, academia.

It makes you wonder if Labor are really taking any notice, because it is very telling that once again in Werriwa Labor are looking at endorsing a former trade union official as their candidate. It seems abundantly clear that Labor have not yet learnt the lessons of the 1996 election, let alone 1998, 2001 or 2004. Deep down many Labor members still regard the last three election results as some sort of aberration, crediting the extent of the last loss to being largely due to the personal shortcomings of the former member for Werriwa. At least at the last election they paid lip-service to the need for fundamental change in the ALP and the member for Hotham then tried his best to get some sort of reform happening, but it was very marginal at its best. This time around there have been a few months of navel gazing and infighting, and this now has all been brushed aside amid calls for unity. The new leadership of the member for Brand proves again that he does not have the ticker to make these difficult decisions. Not one single member of Latham's frontbench has been replaced or changed.

The difference between the government and the Labor opposition is quite stark. The Australian public recognises them. Of course, the biggest difference at the last election was the issue of economic management. The coalition's track record of strong economic growth, low interest rates, low inflation and job growth in the uncertain international climate was well understood and well recognised by the Australian public. In contrast, Labor offered a cobbled together tax policy with figures that did not add up. They described the $600 per child parenting payment as `not real'. They proposed a change to health care that would have blown the budget.

Further, they had a history in oppositionâincluding during the first, long six years under the current Leader of the Oppositionâof opposing every tough decision the government made to bring about the economic conditions we all now enjoy. The Australian people are not silly: they looked at what was on offer and saw a very stark contrast between the government and the Labor oppositionâa contrast based not solely on what Labor had done nine years ago while in office but on what they were offering now. Of course, the track record of Labor in government remains very relevant throughout. What makes it especially relevant is that it appears Labor have not learnt from anything at all in the past. I was astounded to hear that the member for Brand, during one of his first interviews as the opposition leader, on the Sunday Sunrise program, declared, `We were very good at running the economy when we were in office.'

Clearly, either Labor are desperately trying to fool the Australian public by rewriting history or they truly believe it. They have not learnt a thing. And, to be honest, I do not know which is more frightening. Does the member for Brand truly believe that it was good to push interest rates to 17 per cent, to have unemployment up above 10 per cent and to run up more than $96 billion in debt, not to mention small business interest rates of 24 per cent? Who could really stay in business and who could really employ people under those conditions? Does he really think that that was good economic management to have budget after budget where he promised a surplus but ended up delivering a huge deficit? If he truly does, there is a really clear point of difference between us and them because we do not think that high interest rates, high unemployment, successive budget deficits and massive government debt constitute good economic management.

As one of the many Australians who were struggling to raise a family and who only kept the family home by taking out a huge second mortgage, I can tell the member for Brand that he is not going to get very far trying that line, as we remember what it was really like. Importantly, our kids who were growing up then and who now own their own homes which they are paying off also remember. As I said at the outset, today I reaffirm my very strong personal commitment to the people of Forde. I will continue to take a hands-on approach with my open days and community newsletters. I will be out there speaking with local residents and I will be down here knocking on ministerial doors to make sure that we get what is needed in our electorate.

I would like to take the time I have left in this speech to briefly thank the many people who helped ensure that I would be returned here today by keeping up their fight. Firstly, I thank the voters of Forde once again for their confidence in me. I was very humbled to get such a phenomenal swing, close to seven per cent, in my fourth term. After a redistribution I was expected to reduce my margin. When I first stood for the seat the margin was notionally 0.1 per cent Liberal and we have built that margin over the four elections to 13.7 per cent. It is a testament to the working relationship I have with my community, and I will continue to work hard to repay that trust. My electorate includes the rural townships of Boonah, Beaudesert, Rathdowney and the beautiful area of Tamborine Mountain and the Kooralbyn district, the growing semirural suburbs of Jimboomber and Logan Village and the suburban areas of Eagleby, Loganlea, Beenleigh and Bethania, fast-growing Gold Coast areas including Coomera, and of course the dozens of small towns and regions in between. Each area has its unique needs and challenges, and I will continue to work with local residents to meet those particular challenges.

I was extremely heartened by the many offers of help and the support I received throughout my campaign from local residents, some of whom are party supporters and many of whom are not. To my huge army of volunteers who worked on polling day manning 50 different boothsâonce again, too many people to mention; over 500 people came out to work on that dayâI thank each and every one of you. I am here because of your help and support. A very heartfelt thanks to you and to the campaign committee, especially Chairman John Wallerstein, who has been a rock over many years for my campaign. To my campaign director, Selma: you continue to amaze us. What a talent! You earned the respect of many. Once again, I was fortunate to have a fantastic group of office volunteers who helped my staff in many ways. To Jerry, John, Gwendolyn, Barry and Eve and to the others who have given their time throughout the years, I thank you most sincerely.

I also want to thank and acknowledge my staff, all of whom do a great job and who worked very long hours for me and continue to do so. Thanks for all the extra effort and thoughtfulness that you displayed during the campaign. I could not ask for better staff. For me to be standing here today is the result of a huge team effort, and I thank every member of my team. Of course, my closest team and greatest cheer squad is my own special family, and I would like to take the time to mention them also. I know it is getting to the point where I will need 20 minutes just to name them all, but I will give it a go. To Selma and Andrew, Kellie and Stuart, Bill and Tracey, Eddie and Sam, George and Kristy, Johllene and Nev, Talena and Heath: without you I would not be standing here today.

To my 14 beautiful grandchildren, whom I will not name: you make life worth while. My wonderful husband is my love and my never-ending supportâhe does all the work. Finally, I again express my pride at being part of the government and of this parliament. The challenging times we find ourselves in place a big responsibility on each of us. I know our government will continue to get on with the job of governing in the national interest and delivering a better future to all Australians. Once again, I welcome and congratulate the new members of this House, and I look forward to a productive and positive new parliament.

talk.start.para: âI want to start, in this address-in-reply debate, by thanking the people of Ballarat for putting their faith in me again for a second term. It is a pretty humbling experience to put yourself forward in the context of a federal election, and I really do thank them for their support but also pledge to them that I will not let them down. I will certainly continue to work as hard as I can to improve the circumstances for people in my district. People in my district are not wealthy. For the people in my district, the average household income is around $34,000 a yearâI wish it were $34,000 a week; it would be quite extraordinary to have an electorate of that sort of standing. As I said, it is quite a humbling experience to go before them and try and make sure that the policies we have in place are what are needed to make their circumstances better. I certainly think the last election showed that the people of Ballarat are awake to some of the messages that are coming from the Howard government and they have a pretty cynical attitude to some of the things that they are being told by this government.

speech.para: I particularly also want to thank my campaign team. I do not wish to name all of them individually because there are some other issues I want to talk about here. But I appreciate all of the efforts of the campaign team, my campaign director and my staff, who work incredibly hard and often under pretty tough and demanding circumstances. I also particularly appreciate all of the volunteersâall of those ALP members, supporters and their families and my own familyâthat do such incredible work getting out to the polling booths, stuffing envelopes and just making sure that life keeps ticking over and that I keep sane. Thank you.

This government has prided itself on its economic record over its term in government. Like all political parties it has attempted to claim credit for the elements of the economy that are going well and to shift blame for the elements of the economy that are not going so well. That is Marketing 101. But good economic growth does not just happen; it does not just appear out of thin air. You have to build it on a solid foundation and, once that foundation is set, you have to maintain it and manage it. The hidden story of the Howard government's economy is that it did not build the foundations of the good economy we are experiencing; Labor did. Only Labor was able to reach agreement between industry, the states and territories and the union movement to deregulate the Australian economy. We did not always get it right, but we had the courage, the foresight and the determination to build the foundations of the Australian economy that we are benefiting from now.

The other part of the economic story is that the Howard government has, in the last few years, begun to squander the economic legacy it was left and it has taken its eye off the ball in terms of where Australia's next round of economic growth will come fromâand that is a worrying trend. I want to take trade for example. Yesterday the trade minister challenged us to compare Labor's record on trade with the Howard government's record. We did, and it shows that, under Labor, exports grew by an annual rate of 8.1 per cent compared to 3.6 per cent under the Howard government. Under Labor, manufactured exports averaged an annual growth of 11.5 per cent for five years to 1996. Under the Howard government, they have averaged 3.2 per cent for the five years to 2003. Under Labor, services exports averaged an annual growth of 11.7 per cent for the years to 1996. Under the Howard government, services exports averaged a growth of only 4.8 per cent for the five years to 2003.

Under Labor, Australia's global share of trade peaked at 1.22 per cent in 1989. Under the Howard government, Australia's share of global trade has declined to 0.98 per cent in 2003. Under Labor, net exports consistently made a positive contribution to economic growth. Under the Howard government, net exports have made a negative contribution to economic growth for the past three years. The Howard government, rather than delivering sustained economic growth, has delivered the 38th trade deficit in a row. The government has been coasting along for nine years without a plan to tackle trade and current account deficits.
In the second of his series of so-called headland speeches in the leadup to the 1996 election, the then Leader of the Opposition, John Howard, said:

quote.para: The $2.9 billion current account deficit figure for May was not only bad news in itself but symbolised the utter failure of current policies to address the problem.

speech.para: Today, under the stewardship of John Howard and Peter Costello, the current account deficit has risen to $13.7 billion. Then it was $2.9 billion and the then opposition leader, John Howard, was saying, `bad news in itself but symbolises the utter failure of current policies to address the problem'. Today it is $13.7 billion. In that same headland speech the then Leader of the Opposition said:

quote.para: When I left office, net foreign debt stood at a manageable $23 billion. Today our foreign debt burden is crippling $167 billion. That's nearly $10,000 for every man, woman and child in Australia.

speech.para: Under the stewardship of this government and the same person who spoke those words in 1996, our foreign debt has risen to $406 billion. So, according to the preferred formula that the Prime Minister, the then Leader of the Opposition, used, it is well over $20,000 for every man, woman and child. Far from being strong on economic policy, the Howard government's performance smacks of laziness and complacency. The reality of the record of the Howard government is that it has produced record foreign debt; record current account deficits; record trade deficits; record household debt; record credit card debt; a record election spending spree, without the savings to fund it; a record low proportion of first home buyers in the market; and a record tax take as the highest taxing government in our history. The economic credentials of this government are yet another of the tales that it likes to tell about itself. The reality of the Howard government's economic laziness is being felt by families. They are paying record taxes, with what is the highest taxing government in our history, but they are receiving less by way of services and are under increasing debt.

Much of the growth in the economy has been driven by consumer spending and high levels of debt, and frankly it is just not sustainable. Retail figures released last week have shown that households are reining in their spending because many families have reached the limit of their spending and are trying to consolidate their budgets. The September quarter financial accounts revealed that household debt in Australia stands at a record $818 billion, and debt as a proportion of household income continues to rise. As a percentage of disposable household income, household debt is now a record high of 154.7 per cent, up from 85.5 per cent in March 1996. Household debt in Australia is among the highest in the developed world, which means even a small percentage increase in interest rates will create financial hardship for many families.

Some of the debts are a direct result of government policy. I, like many members of the House, have had numerous complaints about the family tax benefit system. Under the current system, many families each year have been slugged with debts or have had payments clawed back at tax time or they have not received the benefit of the payments they were told they would receive. The government's refusal to correct the family payment system, which cannot pay families the right amount when they need it, limits parents' ability to balance work and family. Increasing family payments for some families, without fixing the flaws in the system, has resulted in this money being clawed back at tax time or their not receiving the full benefit of the announcements.

On top of a family tax system that places people into debt, the government has also been increasing the amount of money people pay for services. The GST clearly increased the cost of basic goods and services but there have been additional rises. The so-called reforms to Medicare, which I do not think are sustainable in terms of the safety net, from the health budget's point of viewâbut we will live to see what happens in relation to thatâhave seen an increase in the amount people have to pay to see a doctor. The changes to the Pharmaceutical Benefits Scheme have seen people having to pay more for pharmaceuticals. The approval by the government to Telstra has seen the cost of line rentals on telephones skyrocket, and there is more. There is the cost for people of sending their kids to university, if they are lucky enough to find a place, the increased costs of child careâif, again, they are lucky enough to find a placeâthe cost of petrol, the cost of utilities that have now mostly been privatised and the cost of basic goods like food.

People are experiencing significant financial insecurity. The government has been moving strongly down the path of user paysâregardless of incomeâat the same time as increasing taxes. It is not just one small sector of the community; many sectors are finding it hard. Older people on fixed incomes, particularly those that do not own their own their homes, single people on low incomes struggling to pay debts and get ahead and families who, on top of all the issues mentioned previously, are trying to find the money to pay for their family tax benefit or child-care rebate debt are all finding it difficult under this government.

The great shame is that the Howard government is squandering the economic growth of the last 20 years and has eroded the foundations on which it was built. One of the issues we are going to hear a lot more about from industry and also from local councils, which are desperately concerned about what is happening to their future economic growth, is the skills crisis. There is a skills crisis in this country and it has happened during this government's watch. We live in a skilled and global economy. The Australian economy cannot grow and prosper as it has over the past 20 years without a skilled and dynamic work force. It is therefore alarming that, despite the Howard government's rhetoric on its good economic management, they are failing to provide Australia with its next generation of builders, carpenters, engineers, town planners, teachers and nurses.

Regional businesses, economies and families are feeling the effect of Australia's skills shortage right now. Regional Victoria has an even higher number of professions and industries experiencing a skills shortage than metropolitan areas. Regional economies have overcome many difficulties to survive and succeed in modern Australia. They have had to be more resourceful, dynamic and flexible to compete with many of the metropolitan businesses. Regional economies are often the first to feel the brunt of any economic reforms undertaken by governments.

One company in my district is having to bring in skilled boilermakers from China, as the local economy does not have the skills base to fill vacancies. DIMIA will be visiting my electorate shortly to meet with local businesses, to talk to them about how they could use temporary skilled work visas. This is at the same time as we have record levels of teenage unemployment in my community. There is something seriously wrong with a government that, during its nine-year watch, has allowed teenage unemployment rates to rise to the extent that they have and a skills shortage to exist. There is something seriously wrong with a government that has allowed an economy to emerge in regional and metropolitan Australia where that can happen.

Last month's skills vacancy index released by the Department of Employment and Workplace Relations buttresses the experiences in my electorate. We are experiencing a skills crisis in key sectors of our economy. In the 12 months ending January 2005, skilled vacancies in the professions are up 5.3 per cent, while in the vital information and communications technology sector vacancies are up 63.7 per cent over the same period.

Over the past 12 months, the professions worst affected by the Howard government's skills crisis include those in building and engineering and health, which is up 3.8 per cent; accountants and auditors; organisation and information technicians; and science professions. These are the very sectors of our economy that will drive economic growth in Australia and assure that we remain a competitive force in the global market.
