These are the very sectors where the jobs for the next generation of Australians will be and these are the jobs that will allow tomorrow's Australians to enjoy the lifestyle that many of us enjoy today.

The Howard government has been asleep and policy lazy on this key economic issue. The problem has not even begun to be fixed, when we see that teenage unemployment is at record levels and thousands of people are being turned away from TAFE and universities. The gap between teenage unemployment rates in regional Victoria and inner city Melbourne is widening for four out of five regional districts which are suffering from increases in unemployment. Opportunities for younger Australians are not being created, despite the well-known skills shortage in regional Victoria.

My own electorate of Ballarat is the worst affected region. The Barwon West district, which covers Geelong, Ballarat and right up to the South Australian border and also covers Warrnambool, recorded a teenage unemployment rate of 34 per cent, compared to just 4.8 per cent in inner city Melbourne. Such a divide is totally unacceptable and is not affordable if Australia wants to maintain its competitiveness in a global economy. It is not just the level of teenage unemployment that is concerning but the speed at which it is occurring. In the Barwon West district we have seen a 10 per cent increase in the space of only a few months. Regional labour markets are suffering a skills shortage, yet we have large numbers of teenagers turned away from TAFE each year. The government's proposal to fix this is totally inadequate for the size of the problem.

Australian technical colleges in 24 regions across this country are not going to fix this problem. In my own electorate, I would have to say that the idea of a technical college is too little, too late. The government has the opportunity to do something about this immediately and that is to put more money into the TAFE system, straight away. Most communities, in order to get these Australian technical colleges, need to go through the expression of interest process and also have to wait at least two years before they come on line.

Most communities that have been offered these Australian technical colleges are really grappling with what the government means by them. I know, having seen the Warrnambool proposal, that they have very clearly said, `We've already got the infrastructure in place for this thing. What we are going to do is set up a virtual college.' I do not know if that is quite what the government had in mind when it announced these Australian technical colleges but we will wait and see. I suspect they are pretty keen to open a building with `Warrnambool technical college' on the front.

But even more bizarre is the total lack of transparency about where these are located and on what basis they have been located. Bendigo and Geelong in Victoria are being targeted for an Australian technical college. Ballarat is not. Where is the transparency in terms of why you are putting these things in Bendigo and Geelong and not necessarily putting something like that in Ballarat or addressing the skills shortage there?

I know the Mayor of the City of Ballarat will be visiting Canberra tomorrow. He has been trying for some time to see Minister Hardgrave about this issue and about the skills shortage issue in particular. Ballarat has a different modelâit is not the Australian technical colleges model, because they do not think that is going to work and it certainly will not work in my electorateâthat they would like to put to the minister. They cannot even get an appointment. That is how much the minister is interested in assisting regional economies and trying to help with both the skills shortage and teenage unemployment.

In the remaining time I have in this debate I want to turn to some of the local projects that have a major impact on our local economy. I have talked before in this place on the AusLink bill about the Deer Park bypass. It is absolutely extraordinary that, in the context where you have a road that has the highest cost-benefit ratio of any road project not just in Victoria but in the country, so little progress has been made. A feasibility study has been done for the route of the road. It is sitting on a national highway, the second busiest freight route in the whole of this countryâthe Hume being the first. It is the major transport link between Melbourne and Adelaide. It takes all of those car components from western Victoria to Adelaide to the car industry there. It takes all the wine grapes and all of the other market and engineering components that are manufactured in Ballarat, to Melbourne and on to Adelaide. It is a major economic development issue in our district.

What we saw from the government during the election campaign was absolutely cynical politics. Ballarat was not a targeted seat during the last election. I hope that that is not the case at the next election. In terms of what the government promised and what it actually did in my seat, it did nothing. There were lots of promises during the election campaign and lots of hope. `We're going to fund the Deer Park bypass; it's a major economic issue; we know it's a priority.' The Treasurer was out there in 2001 saying it was the most important project in the whole of Victoriaâand what happened? We saw the Treasurer go down to Geelong to a project that was not even on the radar screen two years ago. Its cost-benefit ratio is nowhere near that of the project in my electorate. He went down to Geelong and announced full funding for that projectâand it is a Commonwealthstate shared project.

For the project in my electorate, one that sits on the national highway, we get $40 million for a $294 million project. It is not to start this year or next year but after the next federal election. The bill is going to pass the Senate. It will be 100 per cent responsibility for the Commonwealth. It was cynical politics and our community reacted extremely strongly to the inadequate promises made during that campaign.

What is talked about in relation to tolls is absolute hypocrisy. What is going to happen in terms of national highways and the Deer Park bypass in particular? My community is now faced with the prospect that, if it ever wants to get this project builtâwe have $40 million already promised in 200708 to start this project and cannot start until we know we have the money to finish itâit will have to go to the state government and to the private sector. We now have to ask our local councils to work together to find the huge shortfall that the Commonwealth has left, the huge responsibility it has dumped on us in relation to a national highway that used to be a 100 per cent responsibility of the Commonwealth. That means potentially that all of the communities along that national highway and every other national highway in this country will have to fund their projects via private partnerships, which will mean tolls. So it is total hypocrisy on the part of the government to be making statements about tolls. Communities, such as mine, along a national highway are now faced with the reality that the only way they can get their road maintained and funded is via tollsâand the government should be condemned for it. (Time expired)

talk.start.para: âI am very proud not only to be the member for Deakin for the fourth time, but once again to be a member of the Howard government. The result of the 9 October election was gratifying and a real testament to the hard work that this government has put in throughout the last nine years. This is the government's fourth term, and I am elated to be given the opportunity to once again represent my electorate. The people of Deakin are an intelligent, thought-provoking group with a high level of interest in matters of local, state and federal public policy. Let me say that with their thought-provoking intelligence the people of Deakin put me to the test on a regular basis, and I am proud to say that. I am here to represent them again and to do the best I can for those who voted for me and for those who wanted to see me out, but of course that is the nature of our democracy.

speech.para: As I made my way around the electorate to meet members of the community and discuss the issues that matter to them, it was clear that above all people seek the ability to engage at many different levels. People want the opportunity to engage with their families and their community in a meaningful and practical way. But they also want security, security of income and jobs, so they can raise their children without the fear so prevalent elsewhere in the globe. They recognised that the Howard government could deliver on those expectations and aspirations.

As expected with a slender margin and occupying a strategic outer suburban location, Deakin was a target for extensive campaigns from numerous interest groups and left-wing lobby groups. I must say the tactics directed towards the government and towards me personally were at times excessive. While I welcome hard-fought campaigns, I was sickened to hear that a prominent Melbourne newspaper opinion writer had the gall to propose placing caged children outside my electorate office in order to peddle her agenda against detention centres and to gain guaranteed publicity.

Sadly, some of these wacky ideas were not confined to interest groups. The alternative government, the ALP, also came up with its own listâbe it a job-destroying forest policy to appease the Greens or its Medicare Gold health care for the over 70s that would have surely bankrupted the health budget. The ALP's repetitive and simplistic attack on the health system was flawed, with little factual integrity. Indeed, the electorate did not think that Medicare was in need of saving and did not buy the propaganda that was put out by the Labor Party during the campaign.

There are of course pressing issues in health care and the Minister for Health and Ageing, the Hon. Tony Abbott, I believe, has been a breath of fresh air and a magnificent minister for health in the time that he has been in the job. He has been to the electorate to listen to the needs of general practitioners for after-hours clinics and to the need for a Medicare funded MRI facility. My electorate has been identified as an area that needs a Medicare funded MRI facility within its local public hospital. I am pleased that the local peak health organisation, Eastern Health, with my strong urging and support, has formally applied to have the service based at one of its local hospitals. I am confident, with the looming announcement of the successful tender, that the eastern suburbs will be a beneficiary of such an announcement, but we will have to wait and see.

The Australian public resoundingly rejected the social engineering principles expressed by the left-wing intelligentsia behind the ALP. I am pleased to see that some of those left-wing elements have been pushed aside in the most recent reshuffleâalthough of course we do not know how many more reshuffles there will be between now and the end of the year. I for one know that by and large my constituents are concerned about the issues that matter most to their livesânamely, keeping the household budget in check, having a real choice about where to send their kids to school, having a real choice of where and how to obtain medical services, knowing that they can afford their mortgage and knowing that there are job opportunities for them and their families. These are the things that concern them. These are the things that we addressed. These are the things that we have directed our policy attention to over the last nine years, and we will continue to do so in the next term.

In the lead-up to the election it was fascinating to view local small business men and women interact with the Prime Minister when he visited Deakin on various occasions. They raised myriad issues from import duties to taxation concessions, to GST and to industry partnerships. All of these issues attracted active and healthy debate. However, they were all dwarfed by the most unanimous support for reform of the unfair dismissal laws. The government's failed attempts to reform unfair dismissal laws for small business has been a thorn in the side of the government. Small business owners and operators were vocal in their opposition to Australia's draconian one size fits all approach to unfair dismissal. This is an area that must be addressed by the current parliament, and I am encouraged by the announcement by Minister Andrews of further reforms in the workplace relations area which will aim to do just that and more.

At present in Australia we are experiencing low unemployment ratesâthe lowest unemployment rate in a generation. However, successful economic indicators should not prompt a government to rest on its laurels. I was also encouraged by the Prime Minister's comments only this week regarding the establishment of national awards and changes to federal-state industrial relations. The current system of the Australian Industrial Relations Commission also needs to be addressed.

One thing that I will be pushing forward, and certainly making appeals for in this term, is for us to look at the entire Industrial Relations Commission set-up. It was established over 100 years ago when federal-state relationships were very prominent and it was feared that the place of the states would be under threat by a federal government. We are now entering our second century. The Industrial Relations Commission is over 100 years old. We should be looking to see whether or not the current Industrial Relations Commission meets the needs of a modern, vibrant Australia that needs continuing productivity and industrial relations reforms. As a start, one thing we could do is look at the British Low Pay Commission rather than the current system, which allows the Industrial Relations Commission to be the arbiter of salary and wage decisions.

Today we were fortunate to see the Victorian government finally apply the National Code of Practice for the Construction Industry and the Australian Government Implementation Guidelines. This is an important step forward and a positive way of tackling reform in the $46 billion construction industry. It is an industry that has too long been blighted by corruption and thuggish tactics.

Another issue that popped up regularly throughout the election, and which has continued due to the emphasis given to it by the minister since we have returned, is that of vocational education. Vocational education is an issue of huge importance, not only in the eastern suburbs of Melbourne but throughout Australia, in particular the growing skill shortages in traditional trades. We have seen communities, parents and industry warm to the government's pronouncements on addressing vocational education needs.

Over the last 8Â½ years there has been a 181 per cent increase in the number of new apprenticeships in Deakin. There are 1,900 more places available than there were in the dying days of the former Keating government. Growth in this sector does not occur by accident or by fortuitous circumstance. The government has worked hard and has invested heavily in new apprenticeships. In the 2003-04 year alone, over $7Â½ million worth of incentives were allocated to Deakin to assist businesses in taking on apprentices.

During the last term, the Prime Minister visited the Starr automotive workshop in Blackburn to launch the Victorian Employers Chamber of Commerce and Industry new apprenticeships centre. This centre was a magnificent achievement. However, it is glowingly evident how continually hard it is to entice school-age people into a trade. There are many factors behind this; the most significant is what I would term the `Macklineske' ideal of `higher education or else'. That has created a cultural bias against entering a blue-collar profession. A key heartland to tackle this cultural bias is within the secondary school system and in the living rooms of most suburban homes.

To help facilitate this, I believe Minister Nelson has come up with a number of great ideas. One which is very specific to my electorate is when he came to launch the Automotive and Manufacturing Skills Centre at the Ringwood Secondary College. I have spoken about this before. I am proud of this achievement. The new centre operates in partnership with the Eastern Industry Education Partnership and targets its auto skills training to the transitional years between early adolescence and the end of secondary school. I am proud of this achievement because it was a federal government response to a need which the state government, the Bracks Labor government, specifically turned its back onâbecause they actually were approached on it. They were approached to submit the project through ANTA, and they turned their back on it. I am pleased that the federal government, and in particular Minister Nelson, came through and saw the centre up and running. This centre is available to schools across the eastern region of Melbourne and does not discriminate between government and non-government school students.

One of the things that I was astounded by during the last election campaign is that in the case of the most marginal coalition seat in Victoriaâone which you would have thought the alternative government would have to winâMr Latham failed to actually step into it. The opposition leader failed to enter into the electorate of Deakin. And no wonder. They did not have a good news story to tell. When you have people like Mr Latham and his education spokesman Jenny Macklin proudly announcing that they are going to cut funding to non-government schools, those sorts of wacky ideas did not resonate in the electorate. Although Labor did not propose to cut the funding to any of the major non-government schools in Deakin, several were going to have their funds frozen. It was a timely warning to parents and teachers that the ALP does not believe in a balanced educational system and real choice for families.

The second initiative from the Minister for Education, Science and Training which has received a lot of attention is the Australian technical colleges, which will provide a natural progression in the area of vocational training. Engaging the local training and industry communities in vocational education is paramount in ensuring the cultural bias against the blue-collar trades is tackled. The solution does not lie with governments telling our young school leavers that there is a shift in emphasis to trades. It lies in providing students and industry with a meaningful role in the future of training.

Since that announcement we have had Minister Hardgrave release a discussion paper in Deakin last month and I have met with local peak training bodies to discuss a possible eastern suburbs consortia for a local college. Those discussions continued as early as eight o'clock this morning when there was a meeting called by the Ringwood Secondary College with the local TAFE colleges, other schools and industry as well. They met on the premises of AAA, the Australian automotive vehicle premises, to discuss establishing a consortia. While the eastern region of Melbourne has been identified as a key area of need, the necessity for a strong proposal in or near Deakin is high. I am not going to stand up and say it has to be within my electorate. I recognise that as long as it is in the eastern suburbs of Melbourne it is going to be of great benefit to young people.

One of the first pieces of legislation to pass this new parliament was a $33 billion package, the largest ever investment in education by a government in Australia. It represents an increase of $9.5 billion over the current fouryear agreement. The significance of this package is the direct funding of schools and students for the areas of capital works and tuition. It is a notion that really appeals to the local community. Schools in the area are excited by this prospect. No longer do they have to wait for some state bureaucrat to decide whether or not the torn carpet, leaking roof or run-down toilet facilities warrant upgrade and maintenance. No longer do they need to push for another lamington drive in order to pay for this nor does the principal need to continue to pray for mercy from the Bracks state minister for education to receive attention. That is the kind of dilemma that some of these schools have been facing. I am pleased to see that this package has been welcomed in the electorate and I certainly will be pushing to see that the schools in the area that do need upgrades and capital works put their hands up and receive funding for much needed projects.

In the time that I have left I want to touch on an issue which has been dear to the hearts of most MPs of the eastern suburbs and which members on the other side are probably sick and tired of hearing us talk aboutâthat is, the Scoresby Freeway. One cannot ignore the message that voters sent to the Labor Party about their deceitful backflip on tolls on the Scoresby Freeway. This was clearly the most emotive issue throughout the Deakin election campaign and it demonstrated that the ALP, at both the state and the federal level, simply cannot be trusted to represent the interests of our area. I was amazed to consistently hear the ALP simply dismiss the backflip as a state issue. I imagine this is also one of the reasons why Mark Latham, the then Leader of the Opposition, failed to come to the electorate of Deakin for the entire election campaign. He knew that if he crossed Middleborough Road, if he came down the Eastern Freeway and down Springvale Road, he would have been ambushed by a very irate community that felt they had been deceived by the state, and deceived by his announcement very early on in the election campaign. He did not even have the guts to make the announcement of the federal ALP's backflip in the electorate. He made the announcement in a radio studio. One of the opposition leader's first campaign announcements was to remove that $445 million. Quite simply, the ALP and their supporters that they bussed in for the campaign did not understand the issues that matter to this part of the world that I represent.

It is interesting to read today that the Victorian Minister for Transport, Peter Batchelor, is accusing the federal government of blackmailing the Bracks government through bilateral AusLink funding. Central to his argument is the need to honour the contract signed with the successful tollway consortium, ConnectEast. This is certainly a tall order from the only state transport minister in Australia to break a written, signed agreement between a state and the Commonwealth.

I observe with interest that the AusLink (National Land Transport) Bill 2004 recently passed through the lower house. As I have already highlighted in this speech, the issues of roads and transport are key in Deakin. While the Bracks Labor government has backflipped on Scoresby, there are other prominent road issues in the eastern suburbs. In my electorate we have one of the worst traffic black spots in the entire state of Victoriaâthat is, the intersection of Springvale and Whitehorse roads in Nunawading, where there is a level crossing only 100 metres away. The need for action on this intersection is pressing. Not only is it the junction of two of the state's busiest roads, Springvale and Whitehorse roads, but also it has a level crossing and is going to be a feeder road for getting off and on the Eastern Freeway-Scoresby Freeway interchange.

There has already been a lot of money poured into that intersection by the federal and state governments, but there is an urgent need to address the problem in a more sustainable way. It is one of Melbourne's major north-south thoroughfares, which is used by approximately 125,000 vehicles per day. The level crossing services the two main eastern railway lines and accounts for 250 passenger trains a day. Springvale Road and the railway line clearly need to be separated. To their credit, the local Whitehorse City Council has recognised the importance of this and has conducted a feasibility study of grade separation of the site.

In light of the clear problem in the study undertaken by the council, the federal government has taken a lead role in addressing this issue by committing to sit down with the council, VicRoads and the state government to pursue how this intersection can be fixed. The council study came up with seven recommendations, ranging from additional traffic lanes to a large-scale undergrounding of Springvale Road. I welcome the upcoming meetingâwhich will take place in the next two weeksâbetween the council, officers from the Department of Transport and Regional Services and me to discuss the options for the site. I call on the Bracks government to get behind the project with funding of its own. It is absurd for the state Labor government and the state representative for Mitcham to consider any other local crossing ahead of Springvale Road.

There are a number of other projects in the Deakin electorate which I could talk about and no doubt there will be opportunities in the House to do so, but I want to end by paying tribute to the hundreds of community groups in Deakin for their tireless work in assisting the welfare of others. Whether their work be in local youth welfare, with the elderly, in the environment or in other valuable areas, these people do good work for our local community and make our life so much better. The recent Australia Day celebrations afforded me the privilege of honouring many of these local heroes with the Deakin Community Australia Day awards. I am pleased to have made those awards. I am pleased to once again be a member of the government. (Time expired)

talk.start.para: âWhen I came into the House the member for Deakin was into one of his attacks on conciliation and arbitration in this country without any real understanding of the significant history or constitutional requirements. I do not think the member for Deakin likes working people very much. Most of us, like a lot of people, get pretty sick of that side of the House constantly attacking one side of the argument in industrial relations. The government is not going about this debate with fairness. It is a one-sided debate. I think the honourable member for Deakin has got a considerable amount to learn to have any understanding of fairness in the workplace.

speech.para: In my speech in the address-in-reply debate tonight, I must first thank the people of Lyons who gave me the opportunity to continue my work for them. I give my commitment that I will continue to put their interests first in my deliberations in this parliament, in the House of Representatives. We live in tremendously turbulent times with the world changing after the tsunami. Even if people have not had family involved in that, the feeling of anxiety and grief that has rocked the world has certainly touched all our lives. We have had our Labor leader fall sick in the middle of all this and, because so much else was happening, the fact did not sink into our consciousness until it became a major problem. Mark Latham felt he could not continue because of health issues and stood down.

I was very critical of Mark during the election campaign because of the way he rewrote the forestry policy without consultation and without reference to anyone in the industry. It cost us two seats in Tasmania and we lost the trust of many people in rural Tasmania. But many other parts of the policy had been carefully developed and could have been a healthy new direction, so I was disappointed that we did not have the option to work together again to change and improve our policies. I am sad for Mark that he had to stand down in the circumstances in which he did but I understand that his health and family must come first. I hope he finds his place in a different environment where he can still continue to contribute.

Now we again have Kim as our leader. It is a new start for the Labor Party to rebuild people's trust and confidence. At this stage Kim is giving us a great feeling of stability and strength while we really start to sort ourselves out. It is another challenge that we face in the year of the rooster, the year of new horizons, and I know my colleagues and I will be working hard to ensure there are lots of good ideas going out to our communities, to give them a chance to choose a better alternative to the current government. So during this year I will be talking to my communities around Lyons and asking them to continue their good work in advising me of what is wrong with this government's policy and how it is affecting them on the ground. This I will bring to the parliament. It will involve asking a few questions with their help, attempting to find answers to those important questions that will enhance this country, our work force, our seniors, our veterans and of course our young people.

During the election a number of very expensive promises were made by the government in its bid to retain office. I would now like to remind my colleagues opposite that, having made those promises, they are duty bound to keep them. Let us start with forestry. The federal government has now committed itself to a sum of $51 million in Tasmania over four years towards preserving some old-growth forest. There has been a lot of discussion about this, but still we have no idea where the money will be spent and how it will be distributed. So that is one thing I will be following with great interest. I do not believe we should lock up anything more. But there are areas that would benefit by having more funds spent on them to ensure their values are properly preserved.

The Bass Highway was promised $15 million to fund the upgrade at Sisters Hills. I would like to point out that my erstwhile colleague Sid Sidebottom got a commitment out of the opposition in 1996, 1998, 2001 and 2004 for funds to be committed to this projectâand they were, without any strings attached. Now we have a situation where the federal government has copycatted and begrudgingly committed the $15 million but on the condition that the state government put in a contribution. This road is and should be part of the federal roads system and thus it should be funded under the federal roads budget without recourse to the state, which has the responsibility of course for all the other roads. What we have here is some petty politicking that is just going to delay the inevitable. In the meantime, the northwest coast people have to cross their arms, sit on the side and watch this silly endplay. On this, I say, `Get on with the job; no more procrastination; let's sort this road out now,' so I will be watching this with great interest.

While we are on the northwest there are a couple of little projects that have been raised by my friend Sid, who was always pestering the bean counters in the party for funds. The projects were the rhododendron gardens and, of course, the Axeman's Hall of Fame. The latter used to be in my electorate until the boundaries changed. I also fought for that to be funded and I am looking forward to seeing this important Tasmanian feature finalised. These are the sorts of projects that should be given high priority as they add to Tasmania's interest and prosperity.

I have been keeping my eye on the Bass electorate too. Our new member for Bass should be so busy handing out cheques that he will not even have time to attend parliament. If we are to believe all the money that was promised there, millions of dollars will flow into Bass. Talk about buying a seat. The budget purse had a hole in the bottom when it came to Bass. One of the promises was for a technical trades college. It appears there is to be an alternative TAFE that is propped up by industry. It seems a pity that there are no funds for existing training establishments but, according to a press release from the Minister for Education, Science and Training, he wants them to be run and managed a bit like non-government schools in that we do not want a centralised education bureaucracy to run them. This assumes that someone else will be picking up the tab for the administration, a favourite trick of this government: fund projects but let some other poor group pick up the expensive bitâadministration, wages, safety issues, insurance et ceteraâand just take the glory for the project.

This is typical of this government and can be seen in the Work for the Dole schemes and many other so-called community and privatised schemes. I am disgusted that this can be called fair and equitable when the many hopeful groups get slogged for those costs and therefore either go out of existence or have to find some other way of delivering the training side. The government would be better off funding the existing organisations and not worrying about the political correctness of privatisation. It does not do anyone or anything any good except the political rhetoric. Funding is needed in the VET area urgently and I can only hope that some of our enterprising teachers can use this program.

Then we have the $600,000 promise to establish regional business and development supportâwhich is fine. This seems to be bankrolling two new positions and perhaps even developing a new export hubâwhich is not a bad idea. This might possibly help put some more funding into our freight needs out of the state, something that has been lacking for some time. The state has done the lion's share of this, so it is about time that the federal government put in and had a go at it.

Then there was some money for the setting up of the pulp millâa mere $5 millionâeven though it may not be needed for the mill itself but rather for the infrastructure around it. I am not quite sure what is factored into this promise. Then, of course, there is the $3 million for the river bank improvements in Launceston, $1 million each for the swimming pools in Burnie and Devonport and $4 million for the Elphin Sport Centre, all adding up to a tidy sum in Bass and Braddon. These funds will be keenly awaited, and I will be waiting with great interest to hear their announcement throughout this year.

What about the $3 million promised for roads between Bridport and Scottsdale, Nunamara and Targaâjust a snip to keep the road lobby at bay. These roads need money, so let's get on with it and get them sorted out. The Minister for Defence announced that the future of the Scottsdale Defence Research Centre was secure. I do not think it was under threat from us, so it must have been from the other side. But I am glad that these jobs are secure and I will keep an eye out to make sure that they do not disappear when the chooks start coming home to roost.

Now let us have a look at what was promised in my own electorate of Lyons. I am afraid the Liberal candidate has disappeared into thin airâit is a bit like where he came fromâbut they made these promises. Now I am chasing them up to provide this money and I am going to follow it right down until it is spent in my electorate. Firstly, there was the recycled $7 million for cleaning up the King River on the west coast. The old mine was dumping tailings straight into the river. This one has been around for a while and I was looking forward to work starting on the King, because there are many businesses in Strahan that would benefit from this clean-up. They said it would go ahead immediately. I have not seen anything yet, and I was only over there on Australia Day for celebrations at the miners' picnic. I rode the Apt Railway overâthe first miners' train for 42 years to go to the picnic. It was good to relive that old tradition. I guess the government must have gone on holiday, because they have not started that work on the King River yet, but it was promised to start immediately.

We were also promised $100,000 for the Lyell districts war memorial hall, which would be an added bonus for Queenstown if it comes off. I look forward to that coming in. They also promised $15,000 for a skate park in Queenstown. The kids will be pleased to see that. I have been meeting with them on and off over the last couple of years to help them choose an area and start a bit of fundraising so that they have something to contribute and are a part of it, as I have done in many communities around the Lyons electorate. So the kids will be waiting and looking forward to that. I talked to a few the other dayâthey are looking forward to getting their skate park. I do not think they will see the Liberal candidate again, but I am sure that one of the other government members or the minister will turn up with the skate park funding.

Then there was $1.7 million for the Trail of the Tin Dragon, going from Bass, running into Lyons and picking up the old tin trail where a lot of the Chinese who came to Tasmania in the 1800s mined for tin. And a great joss house which sits in the museum in Launceston could be returned to the north-east in some sort of displayâit would certainly build into our tourist attractions in that part of the state, where the state government is putting in a lot of effort and a lot of infrastructure. I look forward to seeing this happen and I look forward to the $15,000 which has been promised for the feasibility study. The sting in the tail, of course, is that, if the study does not recommend that it go ahead, the $1.7 million will not be forthcoming. So there are some weasel words in that to be sorted out, but I will certainly be raising that again.

What else was there? I remember a little article in the Examiner newspaper on 5 October entitled `Funds to rain on Hagley School'. A bit like rain, this is all that happened. This little pocket of gold was to shore up Senator Barnett's old school at Hagley to do up the accommodation for visiting schoolchildren and to build an interpretation centre to promote the deeper understanding of sustainable agriculture. That is good stuff and I support it. It is interesting how these little things work. I am not deriding the school; it is a very good school, providing a great service to the community. There are many that could do with these sorts of funds to help them develop additional resources. I hope Senator Barnett does not stop at this one. I will be watching and reminding him of his commitment.

I note there was an interesting selection of projects in the south. New Norfolk features quite heavily in the promises too. We can add those local figures to the list of national promises of which Tasmania is a beneficiary. I would say there are a lot of projects coming to Tasmania as a result of the Liberals' election commitments. But we will not see any additional help for our hospitals. We are not putting funds into getting more doctors and specialists trained in our universities. We are having universities put up their fees again to get the courses on, and working people are still trying to work out whether they can afford private health insurance or to register their car. Much of this money, although welcome in itself, is not dealing with the huge number of problems faced by Tasmanians every day. What about the one call zone for Telstra? What about decent reception statewide for the ABC and SBS? What about access to the mobile phone system and broadband technology? The only thing we are hearing about at the moment, of course, is that Telstra is to be sold.

It is time to do the sums and actually start doing what a federal government is supposed to be doing, such as getting on with delivering a national bushfire strategy. We just had the COAG report dropped by the Prime Minister. A heck of a lot of issues came out of the bushfire inquiry, of which I was the deputy chair, after the disaster in Canberra. We still have not got a national strategy in place, and we are just about through the end of this year's bushfire seasonâa great neglect by this federal government. We have got to sort out our departmental information systems so that people with mental health problems will not get lost in the system, and we have got to deal with the health and education problems that exist in this country.

My commitment for this term is to watch the promises made and make sure that they are kept, to continue my rounds of the Lyons electorate to ensure that everybody who has a problem can get access to me in my office, to let people know what is available through the federal government assistance programs for their communities and to make sure that the government meets its commitments made at the last election.

talk.start.para: âWe had an election late last year and I was privileged to be returned for the fourth time as the member for Herbert. I very much appreciate the vote of confidence that I received from members of my electorate. During the election campaign, I certainly was able to promise a number of very important programs for the seat of Herbert, and I am going to deliverânot like the former speaker. I do not know what his position is, but I am certainly going to deliver.

speech.para: Let me run through the major commitments that I made. We are going to have an Australian technical college in Townsville, and I would like to report to the parliament tonight that I think we are going to have the first in Australia. I have had tremendous support from the local authority, the City of Thuringowa, who have taken the lead role in making sure that all the community comes together and puts in a bid that is going to succeed. We are certainly very hopeful of being able to start in the beginning of 2006, in 12 months time. There are some processes to go through between now and then, but I have great confidence in the groups that are involved in the consortium that is being put together.

I thank Mayor Les Tyrell for his and his council's commitment to making the Australian technical college happen. It is very important. With the skills shortages in the north, particularly in the mining and construction industries, we desperately need more people trained. I thank the principals of the local high schools who have also very enthusiastically embraced the concept of an Australian technical college because they want to see a pathway that is school to work through skills training. I think we are going to get a great outcome.

Another commitment that I am going to deliver on is the tropical science research precinct at James Cook University. You can say that pretty quickly, but what does it mean? It means that within 10 years James Cook University will be one of the top five tropical universities in the world. That is where we are going as a result of the commitment that I have made to the electorate, and I am very proud of that. Part of the tropical science research precinct will be what are now the reef and rainforest CRCs. They are likely to take on a new name when their current funding runs out, but they will continue. The precinct will include the CSIRO, the Australian Institute of Marine Science and of course James Cook University.

On top of that, just to show that I have been working very hard, we are going to have the first new veterinary science undergraduate degree in any Australian university in years. But like the television commercial, there is more: there will also be a tropical agricultural science degree. That will all link in with the medical precinct at James Cook University, particularly vet science. You understand, Mr Deputy Speaker Scott, the shortage of vets in regional Australia and the threat of diseases that are coming in down the cape. We need to be on guard for Australia. Biosecurity issues are very significant, and we need local vets trained to look after those sorts of issues. We are going a step further forward with this particular degree by looking at zoonosisâthe transfer of diseases in animals to diseases in humans. That will link into the medical school. So the foresight and vision that are there will certainly set up James Cook University to be a very significant university in the years ahead.

With respect to another of our election commitments, I am proud to say that I have secured almost $6 million for the Great Green Way project. Townsville to Cairns is a tourism region in Australia that should not be missed. The philosophy of this program is not just to get tourists to Cairns, Townsville or somewhere in between but to get tourists to experience the region. Cairns has some significant attributes that Townsville would like to be part of, and of course Townsville has significant attributes that Cairns would like to be part of. Under the Great Green Way project, which is the linkage between Townsville and Cairns, we will be able to share our tourists and that is very important for both ends of the region.

There are some very significant tourist attractions in North Queensland, and of course the major tourist attraction is the weather. Townsville has 300 days of sunshine every year, but there is a negative: it does not rain, so Townsville can be brown from time to time. But that is fine. The dry tropics are an experience.

Cairns is the reverse, with the rainforest and the wet tropics. We have the World Heritage area in the rainforest and the World Heritage area in the Great Barrier Reef Marine Park. Those two World Heritage areas meet and you can stand in two World Heritage areas at the same time. We have got it in North Queensland! We have some very significant other attractions such as the Undara lava tubes, the longest lava tubes in the world, sitting north-west of Townsville, south-west of Cairns. They are an awe-inspiring experience. This $6 million program will be money wisely spent by the tourism and development bodies in the north and will bring great benefits to the region.

But there is more. Mr Deputy Speaker Scott, you will also understand this: I have secured a commitment from the Department of Defence to continue on immediately with the stage 4 upgrade of Lavarack Barracks. You have been to Lavarack Barracks on many occasions. You know that the barracks, which were built in the 1960s, need to be refurbished. We are currently doing stage 3. Stage 4 will be another $175 million pumped into the Townsville economy in the refurbishment of, principally, 4 Field Regiment and also 3 Combat Engineer Regiment, Lavarack Barracks. To have that kind of money circulating in the economy will mean pretty full employment and prosperity for the people of Australia's largest tropical city.

There is more. I had a look at what was needed for road projects in the region and how, by spending Commonwealth money, we could best improve traffic flow through the region. To the surprise and delight of many, I secured $40 million for the completion of the Townsville ring-road. When the existing Douglas arterial road is finished and opened at the end of Marchâin about seven weeksâthat will make a mighty change to the traffic flows in the city and bring great convenience to the residents of the Upper Ross. This new Townsville ring-road project will connect the end of the Douglas arterial road through to the northern Bruce Highway and will open up the access roads from the north into the university, the hospital and Lavarack Barracks and the reverse. That is an absolutely great result.

I would like to pay a tribute to the men and women of Australia's Defence Force based in Townsville. In the break when the parliament was up, we had several deployments overseas. We saw Alpha Company of the 1st Battalion, Royal Australian Regiment deploy in 18 hours, from being on Christmas holidays to being on the ground in the Solomons in response to the death of Adam Dunning in Honiara. I guess it shocked people who did not want to obey the law in Honiara when they saw 100 soldiers from the 1st Battalion arrive within 18 hours of that event.

Those people are the most professional people, the most dedicated people. I farewelled them. I saw the families. It was two days before Christmas, but the wives said to me, `Look, it's my husband's job. I understand. He goes with our best wishes. We'll have Christmas when he comes back,' and they did. I was privileged not only to farewell the 1st Battalion soldiers but also to welcome them home again. I was also privileged to welcome home soldiers who came back from Iraq, as I was to farewell 11 Brigade who went to the Solomons and 11 Brigade who went on another exercise that we do not talk about for security reasons. It was a magic experience to be there. Mr Deputy Speaker, I seek to continue my comments when the debate is resumed.
Leave granted; debate adjourned.

talk.start.para: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Communications, Information Technology and the Arts, in writing, on 17 November 2004:

question.para: (1) Has the Minister seen the article by Ian Royall titled âTelstra late fee faces legal fightâ in the Herald-Sun on 25 November 2003 which reported that Telstra had announced that in March 2004 the penalty for the late payment of bills would rise from $5.50 to $11 for bills of $130 or more.

(2) Has the Minister seen the article by Kirsty Needham titled âPush to lift electricity late feesâ in The Sydney Morning Herald on 8 December 2003 which reported comments by the Chair of the Australian Consumers Association, Mr Chris Field, to the effect that the Telstra late-payment fee might be unlawful and that companies can only charge a fee that represents the actual cost to them of the consumer's default, rather than an amount that would be construed as a penalty.
(3) Can the Minister confirm that Telstra has recently doubled its late-payment fee for bills exceeding $130; if so, from what date was the increase applied; if not, why not.

(4) Does Telstra's late-payment fee increase correspond to a doubling in the real cost of managing late-paying customers; if so, what evidence has Telstra provided to confirm the increased cost; if not, what part of the late-payment fee represents a penalty for late payment.

(5) Will the Minister ensure that any part of the late-payment fee above the actual cost of managing late-paying customers is (a) not charged in future bills, and (b) refunded to those customers who have already paid late-payment penalties; if so, when; if not, why not.
(6) Will the Minister ensure that Telstra gives its customers at least three weeks notice of the due date for bill payments; if not, why not.
(7) Will the Minister ensure that Telstra does not charge late-payment fees that exceed the cost of managing late-paying customers; if not, why not.

talker.name: McGauran, Peter, MP
Mr McGauran
talker.role: Minister for Citizenship and Multicultural Affairs

talk.start.para: âThe Minister for Communications, Information Technology and the Arts has provided the following answer to the honourable member's question:

answer.para: (1) and (2) I am aware of these newspaper articles.
(3) Telstra has advised that the $11 late-payment fee was introduced for bills exceeding $130 issued from 6 March 2004, and that the previous fee was $5.50.

(4) and (5) Telstra has advised that the increase in the late-payment fee was introduced because one in three customers paid their Telstra bill after the due date, generating administrative costs of $75 million each year for Telstra through costs of reminder bills and other follow-up steps.
Telstra advised that the late-payment fee does not fully recoup the cost of managing late-paying customers, even after the increase.
(6) The notice given of the due date for bill payment is a commercial matter for Telstra to determine, within the constraints imposed by relevant legislation.
(7) See answer to parts (4) and (5).

talk.start.para: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Communications, Information Technology and the Arts, in writing, on 17 November 2004:

question.para: (1) Has the Minister seen the article titled âMinister signals `no' to a fourth free-to-air TV Networkâ by Jason Koutsoukis in The Age on 2 August 2004.
(2) Can the Minister explain why there is not a great need for a fourth television network.
(3) Can the Minister explain how the niche markets being talked about are largely being fulfilled through the Foxtel (pay TV) network.

(4) Can the Minister confirm that (a) less than 20% of the potential television market subscribes to Foxtel, (b) more than 80% of television viewers rely on free-to-air television, and (c) most cannot afford to pay between $60 to $100 per month subscription for pay television.

talker.name: McGauran, Peter, MP
Mr McGauran
talker.role: Minister for Citizenship and Multicultural Affairs

talk.start.para: âThe Minister for Communications, Information Technology and the Arts has provided the following answer to the honourable member's question:

answer.para: (1) Yes.

(2) The Government considers that the current arrangements for the three existing commercial television licences appear to be working well in providing quality free-to-air television to the Australian public. In accordance with statutory requirements, the Government has commenced a review of matters relating to the end of the moratorium on the allocation of new commercial television broadcasting licences, which concludes on 31 December 2006. The question of whether any further commercial television licence should be issued after 2006 will be one for the government of the day.

(3) A large and diverse range of content is offered by subscription television providers, including Foxtel. Foxtel promotes its digital subscription service as providing over 130 channels and services. It would be reasonable to assume that a broad range of niche markets and interests would be catered for with such a large number of channels and services.

(4) (a) to (c) The Australian Subscription Television and Radio Association (ASTRA) reports that approximately 1.6 million homes are now subscribing to subscription television in Australia. This represents approximately 21.3% of households with television. An alternative way of calculating the share of the television market is as a percentage of population. ASTRA estimates, based on an estimated average of 3.4 residents in a typical subscription television home, that the penetration rate in Australia for subscription television is 26.1%.

Therefore, between 73% and 79% of television viewers rely on free-to-air television alone. Monthly subscription fees can be as low as $44.95 (the price listed for Austar's basic digital package). The amount which any household has available for discretionary expenditure is a matter for the household.

question.para: (1) How many Job Network providers are currently operating in the Wollongong and Southern Suburbs NSW Employment Service Area and what are their names and addresses.
(2) How many job seekers are currently registered with (a) each Job Network provider, and (b) each office of each provider in the Wollongong and Southern Suburbs NSW Employment Service Area.

(3) For the year (a) 2000, (b) 2001, (c) 2002, (d) 2003, and (e) 2004 in (i) Australia, and (ii) the Wollongong and Southern Suburbs NSW Employment Service Area, how many Newstart or Youth Allowance recipients were placed into jobs through assistance from Job Network providers.

(4) For the year (a) 2000, (b) 2001, (c) 2002, (d) 2003, and (e) 2004 how many long-term unemployed people (i) in total; and (ii) as a proportion of all unemployed people, participated in intensive assistance in the Wollongong and Southern Suburbs NSW Employment Service Area.

(5) For the year (a) 2000, (b) 2001, (c) 2002, (d) 2003, and (e) 2004 how many of the people who have participated in intensive assistance have participated on (i) one occasion, (ii) two occasions, (iii) three occasions, and (iv) more than three occasions in the Wollongong and Southern Suburbs NSW Employment Service Area.

(6) For the year (a) 2000, (b) 2001, (c) 2002, (d) 2003, and (e) 2004 how many job seekers who participated in intensive assistance found employment in the Wollongong and Southern Suburbs NSW Employment Service Area, and what proportion found (i) full-time, (ii) part-time, and (iii) casual employment.

(7) How many Work for the Dole providers are currently operating in the Wollongong and Southern Suburbs NSW Employment Service Area, what are their names and addresses and what programs do they offer.

(8) For the years (a) 2000, (b) 2001, (c) 2002, (d) 2003, and (e) 2004 how many of people who participated in a Work for the Dole program found employment in the Wollongong and Southern Suburbs NSW Employment Service Area.

(9) For the years (a) 2000, (b) 2001, (c) 2002, (d) 2003, and (e) 2004 what proportion of people who participated in a Work for the Dole program found (i) full-time, (ii) part-time, and (iii) casual employment in the Wollongong and Southern Suburbs NSW Employment Service Area following their placement.

(10) For the years (a) 2000, (b) 2001, (c) 2002, (d) 2003, and (e) 2004 how many people who participated in a Work for the Dole program were in (i) full-time, (ii) part-time, and (iii) casual employment in the Wollongong and Southern Suburbs NSW Employment Service Area three months after completing their placement.

talk.start.para: asked the Minister for Transport and Regional Services, in writing, on 1 December 2004:

question.para: (1) Is he aware of reports that Israel is planning to install `Flight Guard' on civilian aircraft to protect against shoulder-fired surface to air missiles.
(2) Is he aware that `Flight Guard' was recently tested and that the radar automatically spotted the Strella SA7 missile, launched flares, and that the missiles chased after the flares.
(3) Has he or his department evaluated this system for possible use in Australia; if so, what was the outcome; if not, why not.
(4) Is he able to say whether any commercial airlines in Australia have expressed interest in the system or evaluated it.
(5) Is the Government evaluating any other anti-missile systems for civilian aircraft and has it provided advice to Qantas on the installation of anti-missile systems.
(6) Is the Defence Science and Technology Organisation involved in research on anti-missile systems for Australian military or commercial aircraft.

talker.name: Anderson, John, MP
Mr Anderson
talker.role: Minister for Transport and Regional Services

talk.start.para: âThe answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

answer.para: (1) Yes.
(2) I am aware that Israel has been testing the `Flight Guard' missile countermeasures system, for planned use on certain of its civil aircraft fleet.
(3) No. Assessment of such equipment is a commercial decision for the airlines based on their respective risk assessment.
(6) This question should be directed to my colleague, the Minister for Defence.

talk.start.para: asked the Minister for Health and Ageing, in writing, on 2 December 2004:

question.para: (1) What sum did the Minister's department spend during 2003-2004 on outsourced (a) barristers, and (b) solicitors (including private firms, the Australian Government Solicitor and any others).
(2) What sum did the Minister's department spend on internal legal services.
(3) What is the projected expenditure on legal services for 2004-2005 for the Minister's department.

talker.name: Abbott, Tony, MP
Mr Abbott
talker.role: Minister for Health and Ageing

talk.start.para: âThe answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

answer.para: (1) The Department spent $424,564 GST exclusive on outsourced barristers, $3,797,569 GST exclusive on outsourced solicitors and $134,848 GST exclusive on barristers and solicitors disbursement fees during 2003-2004. It should be noted that these amounts cannot be directly compared to the response to House of Representatives Question on Notice 3184 of March 2004, in which the same question was asked relating to amounts expended in 2002-2003. Since the earlier response the Department has improved its methodology for calculating amounts in keeping with the requirements of a recent survey by the Australian National Audit Office (ANAO) of Commonwealth legal arrangements and in accordance with the recommendation by the Attorney-General's Department for calculating legal expenditure.

(2) The Department spent $6,367,698 on internal legal services during 2003-2004. It should be noted that this amount cannot be directly compared to the response to question 3184 of March 2004, in which a similar question was asked relating to amounts expended in 2002-03. Since the earlier response the Department has improved its methodology for calculating amounts, as outlined in question (1).

(3) The Department's projected expenditure on internal and external legal services for the 2004-2005 financial year is $11,410,630. It should be noted that this amount cannot be directly compared to the response to question 3184 of March 2004, in which the same question was asked relating to projected expenditure for 2003-04. Since the earlier response the Department has improved its methodology for projecting expenditure, in line with answers to questions (1) and (2).

Amounts outlined in response to questions (1), (2) and (3) include the amount of $284,212 for barristers and solicitors, $1,166,136 on internal legal services and $1,361,182 for projected expenditure on legal services for 2004-2005 by the Therapeutic Goods Administration (TGA). It should be noted that the TGA recovers its costs from fees and charges to industry.

Additionally, questions (1) and (2) include amounts for the Commonwealth Rehabilitation Services Australia (CRS Australia). From October 2004, CRS Australia moved to the newly formed Department of Human Services. For this reason, a projection for 2004-05 on internal and external legal services for CRS Australia has not been included.

This amount includes fees and disbursements. The department does not separately record the amount spent on barristers. Barristers are generally engaged through firms of solicitors and their work is included as part of the overall invoices submitted by those firms. To provide a separate figure for the cost of barristers during the 2003-2004 financial year would involve an unreasonable diversion of the department's resources.

(2) My department spent $1,632,847.94 (GST exclusive) on internal legal services during the 2003-2004 financial year. This amount includes payments for overheads related to internal legal services. The answer given to the honourable member's previous question on notice on the amount spent by my department on internal legal services in the 2002-2003 financial year did not include amounts relating to indirect costs or overheads involved in the provision of the internal legal services. These overheads are included in the calculation of the amount spent by my department on internal legal services in the 2003-2004 financial year.

(3) My department's projected expenditure on external and internal legal services for the 2004-2005 financial year is $6,548,329.20 (GST exclusive). The calculation of this amount takes into account fees and disbursements paid to external barristers and solicitors and all indirect costs or overheads. The amount compares to a total external and internal legal services spend in the 2003-2004 financial year of $6,729,532.06.

talk.start.para: asked the Attorney-General, in writing, on 9 December 2004:

question.para: (1) Is he aware of media reports that the International Committee of the Red Cross (ICRC) has presented a report to the Government of the United States of America stating that the treatment of prisoners at Guantanamo Bay has been âtantamount to tortureâ and has he seen a copy of the ICRC Report.
(2) Has he or another Minister requested a copy from the ICRC or the United States of America; if so, what was the response.

(3) Has the Government engaged in any discussions and/or correspondence with the United States over the content of the ICRC Report; if so, what was the substance of the discussions and/or correspondence.

(4) Is the Government aware, either from the ICRC or from any other source, of allegations of mistreatment of detainees at Guantanamo Bay, including Mr David Hicks and Mr Mamdouh Habib; if so, (a) what were the allegations, (b) what was their source, (c) what actions has the Government taken to investigate the veracity of the claims, and (d) when were each of the actions to investigate taken.

(5) In respect of the Government's earlier advice that it was aware of previous complaints about the treatment of detainees in Guantanamo Bay and that it had asked the United States to investigate, (a) what follow-up action has the Australian Government taken on this investigation, (b) when does he expect a response from the United States, and (c) is the Government satisfied that the timeframe is acceptable.

(6) Is it his understanding that the United States reserves the right to use as evidence, during the Military Commission trials, admissions and statements of Guantanamo Bay detainees made while under torture, or under the threat of torture; if so, (a) is it the Government's understanding that the United States reserves the right to use evidence obtained from the accused under torture in the trials of Australian citizens Mr Hicks and Mr Habib, and (b) what is the Australian Government's position on whether evidence obtained by torture should be admissible in military commission trials in other circumstances.

(7) Is the use of evidence obtained by torture contrary to Article 15 of the International Convention against Torture and Other Cruel, Inhuman or Degrading Treatment or Punishment to which both Australia and the United States are signatories.

(8) In respect of his reference to the Rules of Procedure and Evidence for the International Criminal Tribunals for Yugoslavia and for Rwanda in his media release dated 6 December 2004 to justify his view that evidence obtained by torture can be used in international tribunals, can he advise of any case or any tribunal where (a) such a finding has been made, and (b) such evidence has been used.

(9) Can he say under what circumstances torture is deemed to be of such probative value that it overcomes Article 15 of the International Convention against Torture and Other Cruel, Inhuman or Degrading Treatment or Punishment.
(10) What is the latest information or estimate on when Mr Hicks' military commission hearing will (a) commence, and (b) be completed.
(11) What is the latest information on when or if Mr Habib will be charged and tried under a military commission.

talker.name: Ruddock, Philip, MP
Mr Ruddock
talker.role: Attorney-General

talk.start.para: âThe answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

answer.para: (1) I am aware of the media reports but I have not seen a copy of the ICRC report.

(2) The Government has not requested a copy of the ICRC report. The Government's previous requests for access to ICRC reports were refused by both the United States and the ICRC on the grounds of confidentiality. We have previously asked the US to take any reports into account in its investigations into the treatment of Mr Hicks and Mr Habib and would expect this report to be taken into account as well.

(3) During conversations with Australian officials, members of the United States administration have flatly rejected the ICRC claim that the treatment of Guantanamo Bay detainees is tantamount to torture describing it as inaccurate and disingenuous.
(4) The Government is aware of allegations that Mr Hicks and Mr Habib have been subject to abuse while in the custody of the United States.

(a) The allegations are that Mr Hicks was beaten by United States military personnel after his capture and during interrogation in Afghanistan. It is also alleged that Mr Habib was tortured while in Egyptian custody and subjected to physical abuse while in United States custody.

(b) The allegations have come from several sources, including Mr Hicks and Mr Habib, their lawyers, former United Kingdom detainees, and non-Government organisations such as the ICRC and Human Rights Watch.

(c) A comprehensive investigation into allegations of mistreatment while in United States custody is being conducted by the United States Naval Criminal Investigation Service. An investigation of records held by the United States Department of Defense was concluded in August 2004. That investigation did not reveal any information to support the allegations.
(d) See the answer to (c).

(5) As part of a concluded investigation ordered by the United States Deputy Secretary of Defense Wolfowitz, an examination of medical records and other documents concerning the detention of both men has revealed no information to support the abuse allegations. The Naval Criminal Investigative Service (NCIS) is currently conducting an independent investigation. The findings of this investigation are pending.

(a) In relation to the investigation that has already concluded, no follow-up action was required. The Government will wait for the report of the NCIS investigation before deciding whether further action is necessary.
(b) The investigation ordered by Secretary of Defense Rumsfeld was concluded in August 2004. The NCIS investigation should be concluded in the near future.

(c) The NCIS investigation is intended to be comprehensive. For example, interviews have been conducted with detainees and with United States military personnel, some of whom are not located in the United States. Given the comprehensive nature of the investigation, we are satisfied that the timeframe is acceptable.

(6) Questions about the position of the United States on a particular issue are matters for the United States. In relation to paragraph (b), the `other circumstances' referred to in the question are not clear. However, Australia will abide by its obligations under Article 15 of the Convention Against Torture and Other Cruel, Inhuman or Degrading Treatment or Punishment.

(7) Article 15 of the Convention Against Torture and Other Cruel, Inhuman or Degrading Treatment or Punishment speaks for itself. In relation to the United States, the reservations and statements made by it on ratification would be of relevance. Those reservations and statements are as follows:
`I. The Senate's advice and consent is subject to the following reservations:

(1) That the United States considers itself bound by the obligation under article 16 to prevent `cruel, inhuman or degrading treatment or punishment', only insofar as the term `cruel, inhuman or degrading treatment or punishment' means the cruel, unusual and inhumane treatment or punishment prohibited by the Fifth, Eighth, and/or Fourteenth Amendments to the Constitution of the United States.

(2) That pursuant to article 30 (2) the United States declares that it does not consider itself bound by Article 30 (1), but reserves the right specifically to agree to follow this or any other procedure for arbitration in a particular case.
II. The Senate's advice and consent is subject to the following understandings, which shall apply to the obligations of the United States under this Convention:

(1) (a) That with reference to article 1, the United States understands that, in order to constitute torture, an act must be specifically intended to inflict severe physical or mental pain or suffering and that mental pain or suffering refers to prolonged mental harm caused by or resulting from (1) the intentional infliction or threatened infliction of severe physical pain or suffering; (2) the administration or application, or threatened administration or application, of mind altering substances or other procedures calculated to disrupt profoundly the senses or the personality; (3) the threat of imminent death; or (4) the threat that another person will imminently be subjected to death, severe physical pain or suffering, or the administration or application of mind altering substances or other procedures calculated to disrupt profoundly the senses or personality.
(b) That the United States understands that the definition of torture in article 1 is intended to apply only to acts directed against persons in the offender's custody or physical control.

(c) That with reference to article 1 of the Convention, the United States understands that `sanctions' includes judicially-imposed sanctions and other enforcement actions authorized by United States law or by judicial interpretation of such law. Nonetheless, the United States understands that a State Party could not through its domestic sanctions defeat the object and purpose of the Convention to prohibit torture.

(d) That with reference to article 1 of the Convention, the United States understands that the term `acquiescence' requires that the public official, prior to the activity constituting torture, have awareness of such activity and thereafter breach his legal responsibility to intervene to prevent such activity.
(e) That with reference to article 1 of the Convention, the Unites States understands that non-compliance with applicable legal procedural standards does not per se constitute torture.

(2) That the United States understands the phrase, `where there are substantial grounds for believing that he would be in danger of being subjected to torture,' as used in article 3 of the Convention, to mean `if it is more likely than not that he would be tortured.'

(3) That it is the understanding of the United States that article 14 requires a State Party to provide a private right of action for damages only for acts of torture committed in territory under the jurisdiction of that State Party.

(4) That the United States understands that international law does not prohibit the death penalty, and does not consider this Convention to restrict or prohibit the United States from applying the death penalty consistent with the Fifth, Eighth and/or Fourteenth Amendments to the Constitution of the United States, including any constitutional period of confinement prior to the imposition of the death penalty.

(5) That the United States understands that this Convention shall be implemented by the United States Government to the extent that it exercises legislative and judicial jurisdiction over the matters covered by the Convention and otherwise by the state and local governments. Accordingly, in implementing articles 10-14 and 16, the United States Government shall take measures appropriate to the Federal system to the end that the competent authorities of the constituent units of the United States of America may take appropriate measures for the fulfilment of the Convention.
III. The Senate's advice and consent is subject to the following declarations:
(1) That the United States declares that the provisions of articles 1 through 16 of the Convention are not self-executing.'

(8) The reference in my media release dated 6 December 2004 to the Rules of Procedure and Evidence for the International Criminal Tribunals for the former Yugoslavia and Rwanda was simply a statement of fact.
(9) The interpretation of article 15 of the Convention Against Torture and Other Cruel, Inhuman or Degrading Treatment or Punishment is a matter for courts, tribunals and like institutions.

(10) As a result of the United States District Court decision in Hamdan v Rumsfeld, further proceedings in Mr Hicks' case have been postponed until 15 March 2005. It is not possible to predict how long the trial will last once it begins.

(11) On 6 January 2005 United States authorities informed the Government that they would not charge Mr Habib. In that circumstance, the Government asked for Mr Habib to be returned to Australia. On 28 January 2005, Mr Habib arrived in Sydney on a flight chartered by the Australian Government.
